DOC.HEAD: Woman Sheds 710 Pounds Through Surgery, Diet
DOC.TEXT: A woman who has dropped 710 pounds in three years is still losing weight through a combination of surgery, diet and exercise. ``I am happy now. Alive, that's how I feel,'' said Rosemarie Carnemolla, who has slimmed down to 250 pounds. Carnemolla, who lives in Union Vale about 50 miles north of New York City, had surgery in 1987 to reduce the size of her stomach. After 18 months on a liquid diet, she began a diet of three meals a day with a lot of fruit, vegetables and fish. Since her surgery, the 5-foot-4-inch Carnemolla has seen her 115-inch waist shrink to 44 inches. Her feet, once a size 12EEE, are now a size seven. ``I can buy clothes right off the rack. They're big, but it's still something. I can go out, work, take a walk,'' said Carnemolla, who had been a binge eater since childhood. Her weight will drop by 25 pounds next month when doctors operate again to cut off excess skin, she said. Meanwhile, through diet and exercise, her weight continues to drop. Carnemolla's goal is to get down to 140 pounds. She swims, bowls, walks and goes to Weight Watchers every week. Inspiration has come from diet expert Richard Simmons. Carnemolla and Simmons talk on the telephone several times a week and they have appeared on TV shows together. Carnemolla said the more weight she drops, the harder it gets to lose more. ``Last week, I only lost a pound and a half,'' she said. ``That's all right. It's a pound and a half less than the week before.''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: No green-tinted swine will lead Paddy's parade, because of objections that pig lovers made. Plans were all set for St. Patrick's big deal until animal activists started to squeal. A full-blooded Irishman _ a sight to be seen! _ planned to carry, dear Colleen, a pig dyed bright green. But Grand Marshal James Monahan, who will lead the parade, got grief for the ham-handed plans he had laid. The humane society had 30 complaints: Dyed pigs are no tribute to dead Irish saints. The porker might suffer emotional shock if paraded by Monahan block after block. So Monahan said he'd instead buy a stuffed one _ perhaps a toy pig will be almost as much fun.

Next time, how about a little coffee with the Cremora. State health officials were called in last weekend when a white powder coated cars and homes in this northern South Carolina community. But officials from the Department of Health and Environmental Control said there was nothing to worry about. ``It's just Cremora,'' said Joe Faris Jr. Borden Inc. manufactures powdered coffee creamer, and occasionally, air vent driers inside the plant become clogged, sending clouds of Cremora drifting through the vents on the company's roof. Faris said Borden's occasional accidents cause ``aesthetic'' problems. But to the people who live and work near the plant, the white powder is a source of aggravation. The coffee creamer mixes with dirt and pollen and settles in a grimy layer over siding and windows, residents complain. When moistened by morning dew, it hardens like concrete on car windows. Grace Dover, whose home is just a few yards from Borden's back door, said she has stood on her back porch and watched the creamer ``fall just like snowflakes.'' On Saturday, she said, the ``stacks out yonder were belching like a volcano.'' Borden's plant manager, Don Seltz, did not return telephone calls seeking comment.

DOC.HEAD: Sexy or Sporty Looks Displayed for Winter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: With hooker styles at Angelo Tarlazzi and wild lampshade hoop skirts at Thierry Mugler, some fashion shows failed to resemble their purpose _ ready-to-wear. But with all the craziness in Thursday's shows for next winter, there existed quiet and sporty moments at houses like Cerruti, Castelbajac and even Comme des Garcons. Japanese Rei Kawakubo at Comme des Garcons concentrated on drawstring-parka looks and bubbly silhouettes. Coupled with minis or long skirts, the bunchy parkas or anoraks were often in black, white or lame, with the drawstrings all over the place. Kawakubo's new discovery was ``bonded'' or unwoven fabrics with a light, shimmery quality, sometimes crimped, or in gray with a mosaic or snakeskin quality. They looked appealing in shades of brown, gold or caramel or spring colors like robin's-egg blue. And some iridescent velvety fabrics were striking for dressier moments. Shapeless tunics, dangling extra sleeves and bunching in odd places were the usual Kawakubo trademarks that appeal to her many fans in Japan. Yohji Yamamoto went in for red and black in a big way and offered fun if somewhat complicated styles in bicolored outfits with petal-like skirts under cute fake fur wraps. He also used curvy bell shapes to advantage in longer-skirted models, with quilted skirts and sleeves paired with fitted bodices. The bubbly skirts and tops gave it all a ``modern-medieval'' look. In sexier ready-to-wear, Angelo Tarlazzi showed a lot of provocative skin-tight knit minis in hot colors or navy, some with draping and buttons at the skirt with hems way up to high thigh. Topped with loose little jackets and worn with long satin shirts, these looked reasonably wearable by the younger set. His late-day clothes in stretch satins and crepes featuring quilted satin hearts on derrieres and busts and his draped sizzling satin body-hugging numbers were tarty in an echo of what Ungaro did several seasons ago. They looked zingy on the runway but couldn't be safely worn by polite society. Jean-Charles de Castelbajac had some great ideas in the sporty line, starting with his huge mohair tartan overcoats topping tiny bright minis and tights all in his preferred primary colors. Bright new mohair and ribbon-woven fabrics mixed with quilted leather made for interesting jackets topping leather shorts with colorful tights. A witty feature was the rolled window-blind panels on coats worn over shortie kilts. There were rafts of duffel coats, full shorts bunched at the waist and some striking burnoose coats with hoods. Unforgettable were the vast trapeze coats in plaid on the outside and white fake fur linings turned out to make cape collars. ``This special double-faced plaid fabric especially made in southwest France is basically what the old French concierges' bedroom slippers are made of,'' said Castelbajac. Nino Cerruti kept his show relatively quiet with soft and loose hooded duster coats over narrow jersey pants, and some good dark windowpane plaids _ in blazers over lean draped asymmetrical skirts or jumpsuits with full pants. In the late-day line he stuck to things like pants in shades of bronze Lurex split up and flapping to show the whole leg, and a raft of sexy black ``tuxedo'' outfits, some with shorts, others with long skirts and backless. Thierry Mugler ended the day with several shows so crowded with waiting journalists and buyers there were near-riots. His main theme as usual was slightly kinky sex. This time he flaunted it with lots of black vinyl tight pants or tiny minis with flared hems and neon colors in late-day dresses. The ``ball gowns'' had lampshade hoop skirts, cut very high up front. Aside from some beautifully fitted long jackets and ankle-length coats with full skirts, there wasn't much to wear on the street. One spectactor remarked, ``Those hoops would be hard to fit into a taxi.''

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts from Hostage Statement
With PM-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Kidnappers holding three Americans threatened to kill them if the U.S. government did not meet unspecified demands. What follows are excerpts from the statement Thursday by the group that calls itself Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. The handwritten statement in Arabic, translated by The Associated Press, said: ``The Organization of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine denounces media reports about humanitarian moves to free the hostages and close this case. ``It asks the authors of these moves not to interfere in this matter because we are holding agents and spies against our people and they will be executed if the American administration fails to meet our demands. ... ``We did not carry out the death sentences because we are waiting for the appropriate time. ... ``We have laid down the trap and are eagerly waiting for the promised American adventure to free them (hostages) by force. ``We announce that there is no solution for and no deal about this issue except within the framework of exchanges. ``Humanitarian efforts should move in the correct, useful and meaningful directions. ... ``Our people shall not stand handcuffed in front of this conspiracy. We shall not at all suffice ourselves by watching but shall begin taking the adequate measures to prevent the arrival of the Soviets. ... ``All airports facilitating the transport as well as airlines, their jetliners and offices, will be direct targets for us. This is a warning and a threat.''

DOC.HEAD: March 17 is Just Another Day in `Irish County' USA
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: March 17 is just another day in Lafayette County, Fla., the nation's most Irish county. The county seat is named Mayo, but there will be no St. Patrick's Day parade, no green line painted down Main Street, no green beer at the Hideaway Tavern, no St. Pat's Day cards at West's Drugs, no corned beef and cabbage at the Mayo Cafe. No shamrocks, not even a leprechaun. Faith n' begorra, y'all! A few folks will wear the green, but only because ``they heard about it on television,'' according to Emmett Howell, a local historian. Residents, in fact, were surprised to learn that in the last U.S. census 17.7 percent of Lafayette's 4,035 residents declared Irish ancestry, the highest percentage of any county in the United States. They weren't the only ones. ``I was shocked, until I found out what happened there,'' said James Allen, a California State University professor who spent seven years studying the census data. In their eight-pound demographic atlas, ``We the People,'' Allen and fellow geographer Eugene Turner explain that Lafayette's Irish descend not from Roman Catholics who left Ireland after the famine in the middle of the 19th century, but from Protestants who migrated from northern Ireland years earlier. These immigrants traced their own roots back to Scotland, which their ancestors left in the 1600s to colonize northeastern Ireland. But many moved on to America, where they led the first wave of trans-Appalachian settlement. Most of the counties with the highest percentage of Irish ancestry in the 1980 census were in rural and small-town sections of the Southeast, the area where the Scotch-Irish settled and which now has more than a third of the American Irish. Smith, Miss., is the nation's third most Irish county, and Houston, Tenn. its fifth. Numbers two and four are Norfolk and Suffolk counties in and around Boston, whose Irish are typically Catholic and more likely to have descended from post-famine immigrants. The Scotch-Irish, whose descendants account for about half of the 40 million Americans of Irish descent, ``have retained a sense, albeit a weak one, of an Irish heritage,'' according to Allen. Mayo shares its name with the famously bleak county in western Ireland, but the town actually was named after a Confederate officer. With only two traffic lights _ one a mere blinking caution signal _ and a population around 1,000, Mayo would be hard pressed to celebrate St. Pat's Day in style, even if it wanted to. Which it doesn't. At West Drugs, Harriet West said she used to stock St. Patrick's Day cards, but it wasn't worth her while. ``Didn't sell more'n one or two,' she explained this week. At the Mayo Cafe, Thelma Driver said there would be no corned beef and cabbage on the menu because St. Pat's ``is not a real big deal here.'' Asked if she knew anyone who was Irish, she said, ``No one's said they were Irish.'' She paused and added: ``My husband's part Irish.'' If there was any real Irish spirit in town, surely it would be found at an establishment called the Hideaway Tavern run by a man named Sullivan. ``Is WHAT a big day?'' Lewin Sullivan asked during a telephone interview. St. Patrick's Day. ``Not particularly,'' he said, drawing the word out in his panhandle drawl. ``Most of 'em don't ever think of it.'' Well, you're Irish, right? ``I figure I must be, from the name, but how much, I don't know.'' It seemed there could be no less Irish place than the most Irish county in America ... other than one of the least Irish counties in America. In Morgan County, Utah, only about 32 of 4,917 residents claimed Irish ancestry 10 years ago. People there, mostly Mormons of English descent, are as unexcited about St. Patrick's Day as Lafayette residents. ``I've never heard anyone boast of being Irish,'' said Linda Smith, secretary of the county historical society. ``It just isn't discussed.'' Morgan City, a community of 2,000 just northeast of Salt Lake City, is as bleak as Mayo: no green line down Commercial Street, no corned beef at the Spring Chicken Inn. Jeff London, chairman of the Board of Commissioners, flipped through the telephone book looking for Irish surnames, and came up only with an O'Driscoll. Exiled children of Erin, however, can take heart: On Saturday the Country Cafe will have green beer on tap and Irish decorations, ``like four-leaf clovers,'' said manager Beverly Dahlquist. Sure you're a fine colleen, Beverly, but a shamrock has three leaves.

DOC.HEAD: `Irish Up' Over Offensive Cards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Irish County
DOC.TEXT: Angry Irish-American groups are calling for a withholdin' of the green _ cash, that is _ from a Chicago-based card company they accuse of printing offensive St. Patrick's Day cards. Several organizations and individuals want a boycott of Recycled Paper Products, whose March 17 offerings included cards that show a drunkard inside a bottle marked ``Irish Whiskey,'' and a naked woman with a shamrock across her buttocks. ``I'm all for the First Amendment, but this stuff goes way over the top,'' said Niall O'Dowd, publisher of the weekly newspaper Irish Voice. ``I don't mind some of the things _ they're done in reasonable fun _ but this ...'' The newspaper encouraged its readers to call or write in protest to Recycled. An Irish radio personality, the Ancient Order of Hibernians and other Irish groups called for a boycott of the company and stores selling the cards. The company said it was aware of the complaints and might remove some of the cards before next year, but such talk failed to appease angry Irish-Americans. ``I was totally revolted, just revolted beyond belief,'' after seeing some of the cards, said Adrian Flannelly, whose radio show claims 1.2 million New York City-area listeners each weekend. While greeting cards may seem like a small thing, the money they make could raise Irish eyebrows. St. Patrick's Day is the ninth most popular holiday for exchanging cards and the industry estimates that 20 million go back and forth. Recycled is well aware of this; executive secretary Karen Thompson says her company is just catering to the marketplace. ``We have different types because people want different types. ... At no time did we want to offend anybody or pick on any groups.'' But such talk didn't calm Nick Murphy, one of 250,000 members of the Ancient Order of Hibernians. ``On St. Patrick's Day, we're all supposed to be drunk, and that's all we do,'' said Murphy, past president of the Hibernians. ``A lot of people look upon St. Patrick's Day as a religious holiday.'' It's not the first time the company has been attacked for its St. Patrick's Day cards. Last year, the National Ethnic Coalition of Organizations awarded Recycled Paper Products a ``Golden Pit'' award for a card illustrated with a vomiting bishop. That card has since been discontinued, said Ms. Thompson. The Irish groups hope the same happens to the rest of the offending cards. ``We'll definitely be using the airwaves to make sure nobody buys anything from these people,'' said Flannelly.

DOC.HEAD: Series Of Anti-Semitic Incidents Worry South African Jews
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The emergence of neo-Nazi groups and black leader Nelson Mandela's embrace of Yasser Arafat have frightened South Africa's Jews, who fear the country may be facing a wave of anti-Semitism. South African Jewish leaders are concerned South Africa's tense political situation is giving neo-Nazi and other anti-Semitic groups more opportunity to operate and increase their support. The South African government has expressed concern over a recent rash of incidents. ``These extremist acts of desecration have no place in a civilized society,'' Foreign Minister Pik Botha said in a statement. Swastika flags and anti-Jewish slogans have become prominent at extreme right-wing rallies. An Israeli flag was burned at a right-wing meeting in Pretoria in February and vandals left a severed pig head and a swastika on a synagogue door in Johannesburg in March. Members of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement wear khaki uniforms and insignia reminiscent of the stormtroopers of Nazi Germany. Anti-Semitic slogans and placards are becoming more common at the group's meetings. South Africa's Jewish community also was shocked when Mandela embraced Palestine Liberation Organization leader Arafat in Zambia. Mandela said his African National Congress and the PLO were allied ``freedom fighters.'' Told his action had worried South African Jews, Mandela said it was ``too bad,'' according to local press reports. Gerald Leissner, chairman of the South African Jewish Board of Deputies, said the anti-Semitic incidents were worrying. ``We would like to live in a society in which there is no racial hatred. Unfortunately, it seems these incidents are becoming more frequent,'' he said. The right wing has been gaining strength in South Africa because of fears among some whites over the government's plan to end white-minority rule and share political power with blacks. While the main right-wing parties publicly denounce anti-Semitism, some of their supporters have openly paraded with swastika flags. More extreme rightist groups are attracting support and neo-Nazi groups are starting to operate in the open, according to Jewish leaders. Aleck Goldberg, national executive director of the South African Jewish Board of Deputies, the main Jewish leadership, said the wave of anti-Semitic incidents had frightened many South African Jews. ``The Nazis are crawling out of the woodwork,'' he said in an interview. ``Up until now they've been underground. They haven't come forward in the past.'' Goldberg said Nazi groups were claiming that Jews are part of a racial conspiracy to end white-minority rule. Jews were being singled out because many are prominent liberals who have fought against apartheid, he said. The Nazi groups appear small with no more than a few hundred supporters, but Jewish leaders want the government to take action to ensure they do not become a serious threat. ``We would hope because of the inflamatory nature of what they're doing that the authorities will take strong action against them,'' Goldberg said. The Jewish community also was worried about that black nationalist groups might be anti-Semitic. Jewish leaders did not see Mandela as anti-Semitic, but were worried about the ANC's ties with the PLO, Goldberg said. ``There is concern because Arafat is regarded as a menace,'' he said. South Africa and Israel had close ties for many years because of the international isolation both nations faced. Israel has cut support for South Africa in recent years, including economic and weapons assistance, because of U.S. pressure to isolate Pretoria because of its white-minority rule. South Africa's Jewish community still had close ties with Israel and wanted South Africa to remain a friend of Israel whatever the ideological complexion of any future government, Goldberg said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Baker Ventures Into New Area
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III is about to venture into his first round of on-site African diplomacy, a task that draws less attention than the Arab-Israeli dispute in the Middle East but can be as complicated. After a 25-hour flight, Baker's aging U.S. Air Force jet will land Monday in Namibia, the newly independent former South African colony, and he and other world figures will attend ceremonies for the new nation. That's the easy part. The United States, during the Reagan administration, played a leading role in the establishment of Namibia and is prepared to provide $7.8 million in aid next year to help the new country get on its feet. As the U.S. representative, Baker can take pride in his country's help in ending a long and difficult guerrilla war. But once the ceremonies are over, Baker may feel as if he is still trying to bring Israelis and Palestinians together. That effort went into suspension this week amid an Israeli government crisis over Baker's formula for negotiations. It could be months before the United States resumes its mediator role. In Africa, though, Baker will be instantly hip-deep in the struggle over apartheid. He has invited black activist Nelson Mandela to meet with him in Windhoek, the Namibian capital. And he has made arrangements for talks in Cape Town with President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa as well as black opponents of racial separation. Mandela, who was freed by de Klerk last month after spending 27 years in prison, is demanding that the Bush administration cut its diplomatic ties to South Africa and stiffen economic sanctions. But State Department policymakers would rather keep the current sanctions and use relations with Pretoria, such as Baker's five-hour visit to Cape Town next Thursday, as leverage to steer de Klerk into accelerating change. De Klerk's freeing of Mandela from prison and the legalization of the African National Congress were viewed as positive, even courageous steps by the Bush administration. But a 3{-year state of emergency still exists and there are up to 300 political prisoners whose release is a prerequisite to lifting U.S. sanctions. President Bush, in the euphoria over Mandela's release, invited de Klerk to the White House. But Baker is likely to do a diplomatic soft-shoe away from the subject. He is under pressure from American critics of apartheid to hold out for the dismantling of racial segregation first. Randall Robinson, executive director of the black lobbying group TransAfrica, says ``the Oval Office carries with it a special meaning,'' and that de Klerk has not earned that recognition. So Baker will be walking a tightrope as he tries to nudge South Africa toward more reform. Baker also may try some mediation between rival parties in Angola. He has invited President Jose Eduardo dos Santos to see him in Windhoek and Jonas Savimbi, the leader of the U.S.-backed UNITA rebel movement, in Zaire at the end of the week. The United States has no relations with the Angolan government and provides an estimated $45 million to $50 million a year in covert aid to Savimbi's guerrillas. The 14-year war settled into a stalemate after government forces captured part of Mavinga, a Savimbi stronghold in southeast Angola, in late December. Diplomacy sometimes operates most effectively in a stalemate. A negotiated settlement appears more attractive when neither side can gain the upper hand. Savimbi has ties to South Africa and is a favorite of conservative members of Congress. Dos Santos has the support of Cuban troops, but about half of the 50,000 who were in the country have withdrawn under the agreement that produced independence for Namibia. The rest are supposed to leave by next year. The United States is alone among major Western countries in not recognizing the Angolan government. Despite ties to the Soviet Union and Cuba and its Marxist trappings, the country is developing a private economy and exports about 75 percent of its oil to the United States through two American oil companies, Chevron and Conoco. Last year, Dos Santos accepted an invitation from 36 members of Congress to visit the United States. But he wanted to be received as a head of state, which is impossible because of the lack of U.S.-Angolan diplomatic relations. So Baker will have to try some fancy footwork on Angola, too, while looking for openings to promote a peaceful solution.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid covers U.S. diplomacy for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Burmese Drug Lord Indictment Revealed
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials say they've been unable to figure out how to seize Khun Sa, the admitted opium warlord of Burma now facing federal drug-trafficking charges. A 10-count indictment returned in December against Khun Sa was unsealed Thursday as Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced the charges. The charges stem from the largest heroin seizure in history _ 1,086 kilograms seized in February 1988 in Bangkok, Thailand, before they were to be shipped to New York. Khun Sa is ``probably the largest heroin producer in the world,'' said Ed Heath, who until recently headed the Drug Enforcement Administration's heroin desk. The Burmese government has been unable to apprehend Khun Sa after years of fighting his private army. Khun Sa also is charged with importing or attempting to import more than 3,500 pounds of heroin into New York between September 1986 and February 1988, according to the indictment returned in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn, N.Y. The indictment was kept sealed for several months while the DEA ``explored every option that we could to determine if it was feasible to apprehend Khun Sa,'' DEA spokesman Frank Shults said Thursday. ``We thought that by watching his travel, it might be possible to apprehend him in another country,'' Shults said. ``We explored all those other possibilities, and it was determined that that was not a feasible approach, so the indictment was unsealed now.'' The indictment was revealed just weeks after the State Department announced a substantial increase in worldwide production of opium, from which heroin is derived. The worldwide total, the department said, was 4,209 metric tons last year, up from 2,433 to 3,308 tons in 1988. In Burma alone, opium production increased to 2,625 tons last year, up from 770 to 1,100 tons in 1988. DEA Administrator Jack Lawn said the current U.S. consumption of heroin is just over 5 metric tons a year. It takes 10 tons of opium to make 1 ton of heroin. Lawn estimated that up to 45 percent of the heroin consumed in the United States comes from the Burmese section of the Golden Triangle _ an area of Southeast Asia where Thailand, Burma and Laos meet. Khun Sa is reputed to control as much as 90 percent of the heroin from Burma. The DEA believes Khun Sa has been targeting Americans as customers of his drug business for decades, Lawn said. ``We believe that Khun Sa was predominantly responsible for the flow of heroin to our military forces in Vietnam and in Thailand during R&R (rest and relaxation) as a means of retaliating against the U.S. forces for the damages they wrought during the war itself,'' Lawn said. Thornburgh denounced Khun Sa as the ``Prince of Death'' and sought to play down the difficulties of bringing him to trial in the United States. Khun Sa leads the private Shan United Army, a force estimated at 4,000 to 16,000 guerrillas who have been battling the Burmese government since 1958, when it broke a promise to allow the Shan state to secede. U.S.-Burmese relations have been strained since U.S. aid was cut off two years ago following several massacres and the installation of a military government. But Thornburgh said the two governments were united in their desire to apprehend Khun Sa and added, ``He may be subject to delivery by his own forces, if someone decides to betray him.'' Khun Sa has offered repeatedly to abandon the drug trade if the United States would pay him millions of dollars a year for six to eight years to buy out the opium crops. Such an annual fee has been reported recently as ranging from $100 million to $300 million. The U.S. government has rejected such offers. ``The last thing to do is to pay the extortionist,'' Lawn said.

DOC.HEAD: `English Masada' Remembered on Its 800th Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: A ram's horn sounded and a cantor's melancholy psalms went out from the mound where, 800 years ago today, the Jews of York committed mass suicide to escape an anti-Semitic mob. It is sometimes called ``The English Masada,'' this most infamous incident of Jew-hatred in British history. Like the Jews who killed themselves on the desert fortress of Masada rather than fall slaves to Rome, the memory of York Jewry's fate has survived through the ages, still strong enough eight centuries later to draw several hundred Jews and a handful of Christians to a memorial service Thursday at the place where it happened. The service opened a four-day program of lectures, concerts and exhibitions organized by Jewish and Christian groups and the city of York to commemorate the slaughter of March 16, 1190. No one knows exactly how many died, but historians reckon the death toll was about 150. The story was told in compelling detail by William of Newburgh, a contemporary historian who lived near the northeast England city. Anti-Jewish feeling grew in England with the religious fervor of the Crusades, the attempt by European Christians to win control of the Holy Land from the Moslems. By March 1190, York was close to exploding. Egged on by the local noblemen who thought they could clear their debts to Jewish moneylenders by killing them, a mob set out to hunt down the Jews. The Jews fled to a castle, where they were entitled to royal protection. The mob surrounded the fortress. The constable went out of the castle, perhaps to reason with the crowd. When he returned, the frightened Jews would not let him back in. He called in the sheriff, who ordered the door broken down. The mob read this to mean royal assent to a pogrom, while the Jews assumed all hope was lost. Rabbi Yomtob of Joigny turned to his people and, according to William's account, told them: ``We ought to prefer a glorious death to an infamous life ... for if we should fall into the hands of the enemy, we should die according to their pleasure, and amidst their mockery. Therefore, let us willingly and devoutly, with our own hands, render up to Him that life which the Creator gave to us...'' First to act was a man named Josce, who killed his wife and children. Yomtob then killed him. Then each head of family killed his loved ones, and was in turn killed by Yomtob. Yomtob died last. Those who chose not to die accepted the mob's offer of life if they accepted baptism. But when they came out, they too were killed. Finally, the mob broke into York Minster, where the documents of their debts were kept, and burned the papers in the vestry. Although the monarch of the time, King Richard the Lion-Heart, was furious and sent a senior official to mete out punishment, the perpetrators were never caught. And although Jews continued to live in York, many came to believe it was an accursed city. That sentiment persists, as reflected in lines by the northern English poet Jon Silkin: ``The event has the frigid persistence of a growth in the flesh ... a gross tumor and a sense of such growth haunting the flesh of York.'' Today fewer than two dozen Jews live in York, and they are used to the surprised reactions they get from other Jews. Ben Sugar, a retired economics lecturer who has lived in York since the 1930s, says many Jews believe a rabbinical edict forbids them to live here. ``It's a myth that has developed over the generations,'' he said in an interview. After lunch at a York hotel and a lecture on the massacre, the Jews walked through town to the bleak mound in the middle of a car park and up a flight of steep stairs. They crowded into the circular stone Clifford's Tower, built long after the massacre, to listen to services conducted by Anglican Archbishop of York John Habgood and Rabbi Norman Solomon from Birmingham. Psalms were read, the cantor sang the dirge ``El Malei Rachamim'' (God full of Mercy), and the crowd recited ``Kaddish,'' the prayer for the dead. ``On this mound ... occurred one of the most atrocious events in medieval history,'' said the Rev. Geoffrey Hunter, the Anglican chairman of the commemoration committee. Hunter blamed it on mob violence, greedy noblemen, and ``the church's tragic and sad record in not only countenancing anti-Semitism, but so often indeed fostering it.'' ``May perpetrators and victims come together in forgiveness and in hope,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Loss of Amazon Rain Forest Would Change Regional Climate
DOC.TEXT: Removing the tropical rain forest from the Amazon River basin of South America would change forever the climate of that region and could affect the global weather, a new study says. Once the trees are felled, said Jagadish Shukla, a professor of meteorology at the University of Maryland, the famed dense jungle forest along the Amazon River will be gone forever. ``You will never be able to regenerate the forests once you have cut them,'' said Shukla, the co-author of a study appearing today in the journal Science. Shukla said wiping out the Amazon River forest probably also would affect the worldwide climate because it would change the temperature of waters near the mouth of the river and perhaps disrupt weather patterns affected by those waters. The scientist said a computer model of the effects of deforestation along the Amazon River shows that rainfall would decline by more than 26 percent, the average area temperature would rise and evaporated moisture in the Amazon basin atmosphere would decline by 30 percent. Loss of the trees would not turn the area into a desert, although Shukla noted in an interview, ``We were tempted to say that, but we didn't go that far.'' The Amazon basin gets about 97 inches of rainfall a year. Killing the tropical forest, he said, would reduce the annual rainfall by about 25 inches. Once this new, drier pattern is established, the loss of the Amazon basin forest would be irreversible, Shukla said. Global climate also could be affected, he said. The Amazon River dumps huge amounts of fresh water into the Atlantic Ocean, which affects the delicate distribution of heat in the ocean and in the atmosphere. By reducing the amount of rainfall over the Amazon Basin, Shukla said, the amount of water carried to the Atlantic also would be reduced. ``There would be tremendous changes in the chemistry and ecology of the oceans,'' he said. ``It is very likely that there will be very significant global effects on the climate.'' It is not known precisely how the world's weather might change, however, he said. Shukla and two colleagues at Maryland's Center for Ocean-Land-Atmosphere Interactions created a computer program that tests the effects of Amazon deforestation. The computer model enables the scientists to make the complex calculations necessary to predict what would happen if the Amazon's trees were gone. The Amazon rain forest is the largest forest in the world and is being destroyed at what Shukla called ``a devastatingly fast rate.'' About 14,000 square miles of forest are cleared annually and about 12 percent of the forest already is gone. Most of the clearing is by slash-and-burn farmers who replace the trees with crops and pasture. ``If deforestation were to continue at this rate, most of the Amazonian tropical forests would disappear in 50 to 100 years,'' Shukla wrote. He said clearing the forest affects the regional climate in three ways: removing the trees causes sunlight to heat up the soil surface; loss of the trees significantly lowers the rate at which water is evaporated into the atmosphere; and loss of the trees disrupts the wind patterns that carry moist air over South America from the oceans. About half of the Amazon basin rainfall comes from water that has evaporated from the vegetation of the forest. Once the forest is gone, Shukla said, it would close off this source of water vapor for the rain clouds. Shukla said there weren't enough weather records in the area to determine if the climate has already been changed by the 12 percent of the trees that have been removed. However, studies have shown that soil temperatures increased in the cleared areas and that forest fires are more intense in periods of reduced rainfall. ``What is the critical size beyond which the climate changes and we can't recover the forest? We simply don't know,'' Shukla said. ``Our study is limited to the total deforestation.'' The study was co-authored by Carlos Nobre and Piers Sellers, also of the University of Maryland at College Park. Science is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan, inspired by the tearing down of the Berlin Wall and talks on reunification of East and West Germany, will make a trip to Berlin in coming months, his aide said. ``He has followed the events with great interest and he hopes to visit Berlin soon,'' spokesman Mark Weinberg said Thursday. No date was set. Weinberg said Reagan wasn't making the trip on behalf of any particular party or candidate in coming elections.

Heavy metal rock star Ozzy Osbourne says he's not into Satanism or drugs. He just wants to have fun. ``All I really do is have Halloween every night I'm on stage,'' Osbourne said in an interview scheduled to air today on Channel One, the Whittle Communications news and information program for teen-agers that began broadcasting into schools March 5. In a sermon earlier this month, Roman Catholic Cardinal John J. O'Connor said that heavy-metal music spiked with satanic lyrics created an atmosphere conducive to devil worship and demonic possession. Osbourne said it wasn't so. ``There's no demonic message or anything freaky about it, it's just a bit of fun for the night and why not?'' The rock star also said he condemns drug use. ``It's bad because you're living in a total fantasy world,'' he said. ``When you think you're right, you're wrong and when you think you're wrong, you can't make the right decision. I'm under psychiatric help for what drugs have done to me and it's a sad existence.''

Actress Morgan Fairchild says she was abducted years ago while visiting New York City for the first time, but has since learned how to keep out of trouble by learning ``that New York walk'' and talking tough. Fairchild, 40, said in an interview to be aired on ``The Joan Rivers Show'' on Monday that she was abducted after traveling from Dallas to Manhattan to visit her sister. She was 20. She said she was walking in Manhattan during the daytime when two men forced her into a waiting cab. Fairchild said she screamed, but passers-by laughed. ``I guess they thought I was one of the kidnappers' hookers or something,'' she said. She said she was terrified as they drove around New York. ``They kept telling me all these horrible things they were going to do to my body.'' The actress said she started making jokes. ``Finally, one of them looked at the other and said, `You know what? She's funny. Let's let her go.' And they did.'' Fairchild said she now knows when in New York not to set ``yourself up to be a victim. You have that New York walk and say things like, `You touch me and I will kill you.'''

``Today'' co-host Bryant Gumbel said after his memo that castigated Willard Scott and others on the show became public, he couldn't get hold of the weatherman for a while. When he did, he said they cried. Gumbel broke his yearlong public silence on the topic in an interview with ``Today'' alumna Barbara Walters. The interview will be shown today for Walters' ``20-20'' series on ABC. Gumbel, who has been on the ``Today'' since 1982, said there have been days he's thought of leaving, but ``I still like the job.'' Since former co-host Jane Pauley departed at the end of December, once No. 1 ``Today'' has been trailing ABC's ``Good Morning America'' in the ratings. Gumbel, whose caustic memo to Marty Ryan, then executive producer of ``Today,'' created a stir when it was leaked to a newspaper last year, told Walters he likes Scott and that they have a good relationship. In the memo, Gumbel said Scott ``holds the show hostage to his assortment of whims, wishes, birthdays and bad taste,'' that movie reviewer Gene Shalit's reviews ``are often late and his interviews aren't very good,'' and that consumer reporter David Horowitz is ``a walking cliche.'' Gumbel told Walters that when he finally reached Scott on the telephone, ``we shed a lot of tears.''

John F. Kennedy Jr. and the City University of New York announced a program to further educate and train those who work with the mentally and developmentally disabled. The program is for workers in low-paying jobs ``simply because educational programs do not exist which would allow them to advance in their careers and enhance their income,'' the school said in a statement. The initiative will be financed funded by the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation. The first 10 Kennedy Fellows were named Thursday. ``Workers who care for retarded people share with their clients the same right to achieve their fullest potential,'' Kennedy said. As things stand, however, ``the high turnover of staff disrupts the trusting relationship that develops between client and staff,'' said Kennedy, a lawyer in the Manhattan district attorney's office.

Sammy Davis Jr., who's recuperating from recurring throat cancer, canceled an engagement at a Lake Tahoe casino, a spokeswoman said. Davis was scheduled to appear at Harrah's Tahoe April 4-8, but withdrew because of illness, the casino said Thursday. The entertainer was released from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles on Tuesday, and his publicist, Susan Reynolds, said he went to his home there to recover. The 64-year-old singer-dancer, who most recently appeared in the 1989 movie ``Tap,'' underwent chemotherapy during his recent hospitalization.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Army Helicopter Crashes in South Korea
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Army helicopter crashed after hitting a power line during the annual U.S.-South Korea joint training exercise, Team Spirit, but no one was hurt, the 2nd U.S. Infantry Division reported today. Officials said the OH-58 observation helicopter was carrying only two pilots when it crashed Thursday night near Changhowon, 37 miles south of Seoul. They said both pilots were wearing night vision enhancement equipment. The helicopter, belonging to A Company, lst Battalion, 2nd Aviation, was destroyed, they added. The 2nd Division also reported that Spec. John G. Dement, 27, of Ovett, Miss., assigned to Headquarters Company, lst Battalion, 72nd Armor, died after being found unconscious in a ditch March 7. They said Dement underwent surgery for a ruptured blood vessel in his head but died Tuesday. No further details were given. The United States and South Korea began the two-week Team Spirit military exercises Tuesday. About 19,000 U.S. troops joined the 43,000 American soldiers stationed in South Korea for the exercises. An OH-58 helicopter was one of two Army copters that crashed Feb. 21 on training flights in Panama. Nine people were killed in the crashes, which happened during a thunderstorm.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Told Keating He Had Regulators `Right Where You Want Them'
DOC.TEXT: An attorney's assurance that thrift owner Charles H. Keating Jr. had federal regulators ``right where you want them'' in 1988 is being cited as new evidence that he exerted undue influence. The letter strongly suggests ``the fix was in'' for the owner of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, said Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, the House Banking Committee chairman who released it Thursday. Margery Waxman, an attorney with Sidley & Austin in Washington, telecopied the letter to Keating on May 10, 1988, to prepare him for a meeting with officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. ``You have the board right where you want them and you should be able to reach an agreement ... which will completely satisfy you,'' she said. Waxman added that she had successfully ``put pressure on'' M. Danny Wall, then chairman of the bank board and chief regulator of thrift institutions. Banking panel aides refused to say how they obtained the letter. Wall, who quit earlier this month after harsh congressional criticism of his handling of Lincoln, said he had never met with Waxman concerning Keating. Her letter was ``a lawyer trying to justify a fee,'' he said. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, which succeeded the bank board as S&L regulator, said the letter ``was riddled with errors and false conclusions.'' Waxman's law firm denied in a statement that it applied political pressure to the bank board or its employees. It said the only pressure it exerted was advising the bank board that Keating was considering filing a lawsuit. ``The letter indicates what has been generally understood for some time. That is there were intensive negotiations going on at the time with regard to a memo of understanding between Lincoln and the bank board,'' said Leonard Bickwit, a Washington attorney representing Keating's holding company, American Continental Corp. Keating is chairman of American Continental, owner of Irvine, Calif.-based Lincoln. The thrift was seized by regulators last April and is expected to require the nation's costliest S&L bailout at about $2 billion. At the time Waxman wrote, Keating was fighting federal efforts to rein in his institution. Bank board examiners based in San Francisco had recommended that the government take over Lincoln, and Keating had appealed to authorities in Washington. ``As you know, I have put pressure on Wall to work toward meeting your demands and he has so instructed his staff,'' Waxman wrote. ``They all know the Wednesday meeting is crucial to their future. If they mess up this time, it is all over.'' Wall, however, said, ``I would not under any circumstances threaten anybody with their job. That is not my character. That is not my way of doing business.'' The letter was written five days after a divided bank board decided to move the Lincoln case from the jurisdiction of its San Francisco office to Washington and on the same day Wall had a telephone conversation with Keating. Waxman outlined what she expected to be the result of the meeting, including a new examination of Lincoln and memorandum of understanding between the institution and regulators, which was executed five days later. ``San Francisco is finished,'' she assured Keating. ``There is no going back to San Francisco and nothing can be done to follow up their exam.'' In the new exam, she said, ``nothing will be done ... that you are not aware of in advance.'' Also, she told Keating that bank board personnel ``will not be able to enforce any violation (of the memorandum of understanding) ... without going to the board first. ... This will give you two bites at the apple _ before the board and in court if necessary.'' Gonzalez, the House Banking Committee chairman, said the letter ``tracks with amazing accuracy the actions taken by the board _ actions which were interpreted publicly as clamping down on Lincoln.'' ``In reality, as the letter carefully explains, the actions were to be shams designed not to punish but to allow Keating an escape route,'' he said. Rep. Jim Leach of Iowa, a Republican member of the banking panel, said, ``It's clear from the law firm's memo ... that Keating had undue and unprecedented influence on the board. ... This memo would appear to put Wall at the center point of directing in a powerful, if not coercive, way his employees to abide by his decision to go easy on Lincoln.''

DOC.HEAD: Rural Development Bill Sidetracked by Killer Amendment
DOC.TEXT: Reluctance by the House to change the distribution system for federal rural development money has temporarily sidetracked a bill designed to give new life to decaying villages and towns. Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza said an amendment approved Thursday by the House killed ``the heart of the bill as it exists now.'' But he said, ``We can regroup.'' ``The debate was inaccurate in many instances,'' de la Garza said. ``The inaccuracies have to be corrected.'' He said the members of the House are ``still committed to rural development.'' He said the bill's supporters would take some time to educate colleagues before seeking a final vote. The House Agriculture subcommittee on rural development, led by chairman Glenn English, D-Okla., and ranking Republican Tom Coleman of Missouri, spent nearly two years working on the legislation. Hearings were held throughout the country and in Washington to determine the needs of residents of areas where consolidation of farms has caused small businesses to suffer and population to decline. However, the big problem lawmakers faced was a lack of money to infuse into these dying communities. Their answer was to pool three existing funds: water and sewer, which contains about $500 million to $600 million this year; business and industry development, about $100 million; and community facilities, about $100 million. The states could decide their own needs, spending all of their allocation from the three funds on one area if necessary. But Rep. Charles Rose, D-N.C., contended the provision gave too much power to the agriculture secretary and offered an amendment that froze the three funds, prohibiting pooling. Under the original legislation, state review panels would set priorities on projects, but the Agriculture Department would have the final say on use of the money. Rose said that if his amendment were not adopted, the agriculture secretary would have ``unprecedent, uncontrollable authority to transfer money without input from Congress.'' Rep. Jamie Whitten, D-Miss., chairman of the House Appropriations Committee and well known for his power over agriculture programs, did not speak during the floor debate but said earlier that pooling was ``a serious step backward'' that his panel would ``write provisions to avoid'' if necessary. Rep. Robin Tallon, D-S.C., said the bill's provision constituted a ``modified block grant proposal. This scares me because traditionally block grants have died a slow, withering death.'' After an hour of debate, the House approved Rose's amendment, 204-193. English said the system that Rose's amendment preserves has shown ``tremendous inequity'' among the states. He said that if a state doesn't use all of its share of water and sewer money, for example, the funds go back to the federal government and become available to any other states that apply for it. English said the aggressiveness of the local Farmers Home Administration directors has had a lot to do with how much of the money a state gets. ``There are some FmHa directors who philosophically don't like these programs, so they spend very little of it (the available money),'' English said after the vote. De la Garza said time has been set aside next week for further action on the bill, but did not say whether sponsors would try again that soon or take more time to try to persuade members to change their opinions.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Battle Cools As Lawmakers Avoid It
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: This was going to be the year that the abortion battle ran head-on into the state legislatures _ the irresistible force meeting the immovable object. So far, the immovable object is winning. Of more than 150 abortion-related bills introduced in legislatures so far this year, just one has been signed into law. Dozens more have been killed or are dying a slow death in legislative committees. After all the predictions of sweeping changes following last year's Supreme Court ruling in Missouri's Webster case, after all the demonstrations and counterdemonstrations and teeth-gnashing _ what happened? ``The issue is so hot, so controversial in many states that legislators just don't want to deal with it in an election year,'' said Kate Michelman, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, a Washington-based lobbying group. ``They want this issue to go away. They wish they could escape it.'' Spokeswoman Nancy Myers of the National Right to Life Committee, the largest anti-abortion lobbying group, agreed. She added, however, that legislative timidity has nothing to do with the Supreme Court decision in Missouri's Webster case last July. The case allowed states to limit access to serivces without removing the federal right to abortion. ``Politicians would just as soon avoid the issue, and that was no different before Webster. It's always been that way,'' she said. Abortion, explained Ohio Senate President Stanley Aronoff, is ``a no-win issue'' in an election year. For that reason, there is almost no chance that Ohio will pass an abortion bill this year, although two have been introduced. The story is similar elsewhere. Oklahoma legislators rejected 10 abortion bills in a single day last month, leaving just one bill _ and it isn't expected to pass. In Missouri, 11 bills have been introduced; none is expected to pass. Nine have been introduced in New York; all are expected to die. In Iowa, three bills have been killed; two others are given little chance. ``The problem is, this issue is so emotional,'' said Iowa state Rep. Jane Svoboda. ``There is no opportunity for the two sides to reach any kind of compromise. In the meantime, everybody suffers and everybody loses. ``I really wonder about the national course we're on,'' she added. ``This is not a black and white issue.'' That's not to say that battles have been avoided in every state. Abortion has been a major issue this year in Michigan, South Carolina, Minnesota and Idaho. It would have been in Pennsylvania, except that legislators there passed the most sweeping abortion restrictions in the nation late last year. The Michigan Legislature approved a measure requiring minors to get a parent's consent, or a judge's waiver, before an abortion. Gov. James Blanchard vetoed it, leading anti-abortion groups to launch a petition drive to take the issue to voters. South Carolina Gov. Carroll Campbell signed a similar bill _ the one abortion bill that has made it into law. Nine other bills in South Carolina have remained stuck in committees. Idaho has been the biggest battleground lately, and may represent the best opportunity for anti-abortion forces to get the Supreme Court to reconsider Roe vs. Wade, the 1973 ruling that forced states to legalize abortion. An Idaho bill would outlaw abortion as a form of birth control, allowing it only in cases of rape, incest, ``profound and irremediable'' fetal disabilities or to preserve the mother's health. A state House committee voted Wednesday to postpone action on the bill until today so it can hear from more experts on the constitutional issues involved in the bill. Ms. Myers said the National Right to Life Committee is ``cautiously optimistic'' about prospects for the bill, which she said would ``surely'' be challenged in court if passed. Ms. Michelman of the Abortion Rights Action League agreed, saying, ``We may lose there.'' She said the Idaho legislation ``is designed to chip away at Roe, or overturn Roe completely.'' Not all legislation has been proposed by abortion foes. Slightly more than 25 bills this year have been supported by the abortion-rights' side. But abortion rights advocates have fared no better than their opposition. Their best shot may be in New Hampshire, where the House of Representatives passed a bill repealing pre-Roe laws that outlawed abortion and ensuring the unrestricted right to an abortion through the 24th week of pregnancy. Even if that bill passes the Senate, Gov. Judd Gregg is expected to veto it. Few bills across the nation will reach the governor's desk. Ms. Michelman credits the high mortality rate to the Webster ruling, which she said ``awakened the sleeping giant'' of the abortion-rights movement. Ms. Myers, not surprisingly, sees it differently. She said the anti-abortion movement never expected easy sledding after the ruling. ``We're not expecting a whole lot of legislation to pass this year,'' she said. ``There's a lot of legislation out there ... but legislation takes a long time, and we're in it for the long haul.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Abortion Legislation, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a state-by-state breakdown of abortion legislation so far this year, excluding states in which no abortion bills have been proposed: ALABAMA: Bill to regulate abortion clinics and require women to undergo pre-abortion counseling passed House, pending in Senate. Two other bills given little chance of passage. ALASKA: Bills pending to prohibit gender selection abortions, require fetal tissue exams before abortion; both expected to die in committee. ARIZONA: Nine bills pending; prospects uncertain. They include informed consent, spousal notification; bans on gender selection, abortion as birth control, use of public funds; providing funding for abortion alternatives; regulating abortion clinics; outlawing abortions except to save life of mother. CONNECTICUT: Five anti-abortion bills pending, including ban on gender selection; parental and spousal notification; requiring doctors to test ``viability'' of fetus after 20 weeks; informed consent. One pro-choice bill to strike down unenforced law making abortion illegal. Prospects uncertain; compromise possible. DELAWARE: One bill requiring parental or family court consent for minors seeking abortion; expected to die in committee. FLORIDA: Legislature not in session until April 3. Senate committee has endorsed bill to make abortion clinic records available to state. Bills pending to stiffen penalties for blocking clinic entrances; study clinic regulation. GEORGIA: Four abortion bills postponed until next year. HAWAII: Two bills died in committee. One required parental notification; other appropriated money for women to carry babies to term. IDAHO: Two bills passed House and sent to Senate; both expected to pass. One outlaws abortion as form of birth control; other repeals ``trigger'' law making abortion illegal if Roe vs. Wade is overturned. Ten other abortion bills died. ILLINOIS: Two bills, one requiring viability tests after 20 weeks, barring use of public employees or facilities; other allowing state health insurance to pay for abortions. Passage considered difficult for both. INDIANA: Bills requiring informed consent and banning use of public facilities were passed by House, defeated by Senate. Viability testing bill died in committee. IOWA: House defeated bills to gather abortion statistics; prohibit abortions at University of Iowa hospital. Three other bills expected to die. KANSAS: Parental notification bill passed House, sent to Senate; has governor's support but expected to be amended. Three other bills pending, given little chance of passage. KENTUCKY: Bills pending to require doctor to determine viability of fetus; prohibit abortions ``for reasons of convenience.'' Prospects uncertain. MARYLAND: Four anti-abortion bills and one pro-choice bill pending. The former forbid abortions for gender selection or birth control; require abortions to be performed in hospitals; allow them only in cases of rape, incest, deformity or when the mother's health is at stake; require parental consent for minors. None expected to pass. The latter protects right to abortion if Roe vs. Wade overturned. Prospects uncertain. MASSACHUSETTS: Pro-choice bills would prohibit state from interfering in reproductive decisions, wipe out century-old ``Crimes Against Chastity'' laws. Anti-abortion bills require spousal notification; set fetal viability at 20 weeks, instead of 24; ban counselors from advising minors to have abortions in other states. Prospects uncertain, but Gov. Michael Dukakis would likely veto anti-abortion bills. MICHIGAN: Parental consent bill passed by Legislature and vetoed by Gov. James Blanchard. Anti-abortion forces now preparing petition drive to put the measure before voters. Other abortions measures expected to die in committee. MINNESOTA: More than a dozen bills introduced. The most attention has been given to bills that would ban abortion except in cases of rape, incest, deformity or to save the health of the mother; ban abortion after the 23rd week, with some exceptions; ban most abortions after 20 weeks. Prospects uncertain. MISSISSIPPI: Bill to license abortion clinics passed Senate and is pending in House. Prospects uncertain. Two other anti-abortion bills killed. MISSOURI: Eleven bills introduced; none expected to pass. Only one to receive a hearing so far would add right to privacy to state Constitution, preventing state from intervening in abortions. NEBRASKA: Bills pending to require parental notification and informed consent. Neither expected to pass this session. NEW HAMPSHIRE: House killed bills declaring life begins at conception, prohibiting use of public funds. House passed a third bill that establishes right to abortion through the 24th week. Some pro-choice measure is expected to pass Senate, but probably would be vetoed. NEW JERSEY: Bill pending to require parental notification for minors, with some exceptions. NEW YORK: Nine bills introduced; none likely to pass. They include parental consent, ban on medicaid funding, ban on abortions after in vitro fertilization and ban on state collecting information about abortion patients. OHIO: Bills introduced to prohibit abortions after 24th week, require informed consent. Neither expected to pass. OKLAHOMA: A House committee killed 10 abortion bills in February, leaving only one parental notification bill before the Legislature. It is considered likely to pass Senate, unlikely to pass House. PENNSYLVANIA: About a dozen abortion-related bills pending, but none considered likely to pass. They include pro-choice measures to assure a woman's right to an abortion and restore public funding for abortions. RHODE ISLAND: Bills pending to strengthen ban on public funds, strengthen a parental notification law; also to require spousal notification, define a fetus as a person in wrongful death cases and prohibit investment of state funds in companies making ``abortion pills.'' Pro-choice package would repeal funding and insurance bans, overturn existing spousal notification law, prohibit discrimination in the use of public facilities and block government interference in woman's right to decide. Prospects uncertain. SOUTH CAROLINA: Parental consent bill signed by Gov. Carroll Campbell on Feb. 28. Nine other bills considered unlikely to pass. TENNESSEE: Bill to repeal insurance requirement for abortion clinics was killed, but attorney general later said requirement was illegal. Bill prohibiting abortion for birth control was withdrawn. Gov. Ned McWherter's appropriation bill includes ban on state funding of abortion. Prospects uncertain. UTAH: Two anti-abortion measures withdrawn, replaced by non-binding resolution declaring Legislature's opposition to abortion. VERMONT: Five anti-abortion bills introduced, including four parental notification bills and one state funding ban. None expected to pass. VIRGINIA: Bills introduced to ban abortions for sex selection, require a patient's informed consent and require parental notification for minors. Parental notification the only bill to survive an initial committee vote; it passed House of Delegates and died in Senate. WASHINGTON: Senate killed two pro-choice measures to stiffen penalties for protesters who block access to clinics and create programs to combat teen pregnancy. WEST VIRGINIA: Several bills introduced, all died in committee. They included spousal notification, informed consent and ban on state funding. House and Senate amended budget to ban state-funded abortions for poor women. WISCONSIN: Parental consent bill passed Assembly, is pending in Senate; unlikely to be approved. Assembly defeated bill to abolish old abortion penalties that are no longer enforced. WYOMING: Bill to repeal parental notification law was turned down before introduction.

DOC.HEAD: Grandmother Tries to Hold Family Together After Series of Shooting Deaths
LaserPhoto BX9
DOC.TEXT: When Willie Mae Newberry moved to Boston's inner city in 1968 after a lifetime spent in a small Georgia town, she was hoping for a better life. Instead, she's seen her family devastated by violent crime. Since 1987, two of her daughters and a son-in-law have been gunned down. Another son died mysteriously in Boston in 1974. The day after her daughter, Delores, 33, was shot to death this week, Newberry, 65, sat in a corner of her living room, staring at a flickering TV screen. She was surrounded by the grandchildren she must now raise on her own. ``It's something you can't describe,'' she said about the violence that has caused Boston's murder rate to soar. ``Some of them can cope with it and some of them can't.'' Newberry showed no emotion as she gazed out her apartment window. Her grandson Shariff, 15, sat to one side; her granddaughter Shahera, 10, on the other. The children's mother, Delores Newberry Gandy, was fatally shot Tuesday night while wielding a pitchfork trying to protect her children from suspected gang members who were trying to set fire to her apartment. Their father, Percy Gandy, was shot to death in a Roxbury housing project last summer. Mrs. Gandy was the mother of five children ranging in age from 18 months to 17 years and the grandmother of two infants. ``It's hard to explain,'' Shariff said about his feelings for his mother. He fingered a pencil and stared at the TV. ``She used to take us places and stuff. She watched out for us.'' His sister did not want to talk. She slumped in an armchair, playing with an infant toy. But Willie Mae Newberry said she's become almost hardened to the violence. She didn't even flinch, she said, when a nurse from the hospital called the other night and said her daughter was dead. She didn't crack when she had to go down to the hospital to identify her body. ``It don't make me angry, I have to accept it,'' said Newberry. ``Any mother misses her child but she's gone and she ain't going to come back and I don't let it get next to me. But I don't know what we're going to do about that violence out there.'' Thirty-two people have been murdered in Boston this year, up from 21 during the same period last year. On Thursday, city and state officials called for a crackdown on inner city drugs and violence. Newberry gave birth to 10 children but only six are alive. One daughter died of diphtheria at 9 months old when the family lived in Cordele, Ga. Newberry and her husband, James, moved to Boston in 1968 in the hope of finding more work and a better life. Six years later, Newberry discovered her son, James Jr., dead in his apartment. She said she does not know what killed him. In 1987, Willie Ann Newberry was shot to death by her boyfriend. Her two children live with Willie Mae Newberry. But the grandmother remained stoic as she recited her family's grim history. ``It's the will of the Lord,'' she said. ``He's the one who lifts me up and keeps me going.'' Most of the time, Newberry lives a quiet life. She likes to walk to the park, watch TV and play with her grandchildren. ``She's a very strong person,'' said Carrie Haygood, 35, one of the friends gathered in Newberry's apartment Thursday. ``She sits there taking it and keeping it together. People are dying out there and her kids are dying and she keeps it together. I thank the Lord I don't have kids.''

DOC.HEAD: Divisiveness of Abortion Issue Apparent at House Hearing
DOC.TEXT: The deep political and emotional disagreement over abortion divided a congressional panel as it opened hearings into recent state restrictions on a woman's right to end her pregnancy. The chairman of the House panel, Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., drew opposition Thursday when he refused to allow an anti-abortion witness to show videotapes of a fetus inside the womb. Edwards is a sponsor of a bill that would write broad guarantees of abortion rights into federal law. An anti-abortion member, Rep. James F. Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., challenged Edwards' ruling and, after losing on a party-line vote, walked out of the meeting. He denounced ``this charade'' and accused majority Democrats of ``gagging the witness.'' Edwards' Judiciary subcommittee on civil and constitutional rights held its first hearing on the so-called ``freedom of choice'' bill with a look at the effect of a Missouri law restricting abortions. The Supreme Court upheld that law in a ruling last year that energized the political debate on abortion. Appearing on a panel of abortion-rights supporters, a Missouri woman and a physician testified that the restrictions have left some women unable to obtain safe abortions even when they face life-threatening complications. Maralee Dinsdale of Carrollton, Mo., described three difficult and unsuccessful pregnancies, including a third last year when tests revealed she carried an anencephalic baby _ a fetus that had not developed a skull or brain and would not live long if brought to term and delivered. ``I was denied a needed medical procedure that could save my life,'' she said. She said she also had a history of bleeding and other complications, and decided to have an abortion. Because of the Missouri law, she said, her doctor was denied permission to perform the abortion at the two hospitals where he practiced and referred her to a clinic _ not a hospital _ in neighboring Kansas. There, Mrs. Dinsdale said, she suffered heavy bleeding and other complications after the abortion and was rushed to a hospital 20 miles away, where she recovered. ``I was emotionally drained and scared to death, but I felt I had no choice,'' she said. ``No hospital would help me, my doctor had more or less abandoned me, and I truly felt it would endanger my life more by carrying the baby to term _ in a sense, for nothing.'' The Missouri law prohibits abortions from being performed at public hospitals, bans tax dollars from being spent for ``encouraging or counseling'' women to have abortions and requires doctors to determine when possible whether a fetus of 20 or more weeks is capable of surviving outside the womb. Mrs. Dinsdale said she was denied an abortion at private hospitals, even though the Missouri law bans them only at public institutions. Dr. Howard I. Schwartz, a Kansas City, Mo., obstetrician and gynecologist, said that because of the law both private and public hospitals often refer women seeking abortions elsewhere _ even when the fetus has major abnormalities, or the woman suffers diseases that could be life-threatening if she remains pregnant. The subcommittee's dispute arose when a second panel of witnesses, all abortion opponents, testified. Sharleen R. Richard, a radiologic technologist from Michigan, wanted to show examples of a new sonograph technology providing high-quality images of the fetus at an early stage of pregnancy. ``I have personally seen many women change their mind after they see that little baby in the womb,'' she said. But Edwards said the subcommittee had ``a general rule'' against showing videotapes. Sensenbrenner protested the panel had no such rule and invited Mrs. Richard to turn on her videotape machine and television. When she moved to do so, Edwards ruled her out of order. The subcommittee plans more hearings, although sponsors have not decided whether to seek a vote on the bill. Similar hearings are scheduled in the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: State, City and Federal Law Enforcement Meet to Combat Crime
With PM-Family of Violence, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Every city police officer will receive a list bearing the names of 105 hard-core, violent gang members with outstanding warrants against them under a new attack on urban crime proposed by Mayor Raymond Flynn. Jolted by the recent crime wave that has pushed the city's murder rate 50 percent higher than the same period last year, more than two dozen state, city and federal officials joined Flynn's call for a crackdown on inner city drugs and violence at a hastily called summit Thursday afternoon. Flynn organized the meeting following the rash of violence Tuesday night that left three dead and several other people wounded. Thirty-two people have been murdered in Boston this year, up from 21 during the same period last year. The mayor proposed a program to combat violence centered on a plan to find and arrest gang members who have defaulted on court appearances. He also recommended eliminating loopholes in a law mandating a one-year sentence for criminals in possession of illegal weapons, reducing delays in bringing to trial those accused of drug crimes or violent crimes, expanding prison space and offering drug treatment on demand. Gov. Michael Dukakis, who also attended the meeting, suggested the appointment of a task force including one federal representative to meet daily to close in on gang members. Flynn's plan was prompted in part by a report issued by the Boston Bar Association Thursday that said the state criminal justice system lacks the resources to fight the war on drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,616.44, down 55.20 points or 0.17 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: An Astrologer's Influence: Three Versions
With PM-Reagans' Astrologer
DOC.TEXT: Astrologer Joan Quigley says she didn't intend to write a book about her influence in Ronald Reagan's presidency _ until she read what Nancy Reagan said about it. ``It reads like fiction and much of it is evasive,'' she wrote in her new book about Nancy's book. ``What she has left out would fill a book.'' ``No political decision was ever made based on it,'' Mrs. Reagan said in ``My Turn'' of Mrs. Quigley's readings of the moon, the sun and the planets. ``Through Nancy, I had a direct line to the president,'' said Ms. Quigley in her memoirs, ``What Does Joan Say?'' Said Donald Regan, the fired presidential aide who first revealed in his memoirs, ``For the Record,'' that Mrs. Reagan was consulting an astrologer: ``Virtually every major move and decision the Reagans made during my time as White House chief of staff was cleared in advance with a woman in San Francisco who drew up horoscopes to make certain that the planets were in a favorable alignment for the enterprise.'' Here are excepts from the three books on the question of Ms. Quigley's role:
DONALD REGAN:

``Nancy Reagan seemed to have absolute faith in the clairvoyant powers of this woman, who had predicted that `something' bad was going to happen to the president shortly before he was wounded in an assassination attempt in 1981. ...'' ``There was no choice but to humor the first lady in this matter. But the president's schedule is the single most potent tool in the White House, because it determines what the most powerful man in the world is going to do and when he is going to do it. By humoring Mrs. Reagan we gave her this tool _ or more accurately, gave it to an unknown woman in San Francisco who believed that the Zodiac controls events and human behavior and that she could read the secrets of the future in the movements of the planets.''
NANCY REAGAN:

``My relationship with Joan Quigley began as a crutch, one of several ways I tried to alleviate my anxiety about Ronnie (after the March 30, 1981, attempt on his life). Within a year or two, it had become a habit, something I relied on a little less but didn't see the need to change. ... ``I want to state one thing again, and unequivocally: Joan's recommendations had nothing to do with policy or politics _ ever. Her advice was confined to timing _ to Ronnie's schedule, and to what days were good or bad, especially with regard to his out-of-town trips.''
JOAN QUIGLEY:

``Through Nancy, I had a direct line to the president. That the astrological work I did for both Reagans affected the top level of government is now a matter of history. ... ``I was responsible for timing all press conferences, most speeches, the State of the Union addresses, the takeoffs and landings of Air Force One. I picked the time of Ronald Reagan's debate with (Jimmy) Carter and the two debates with Walter Mondale; all extended trips abroad as well as the shorter trips and one-day excursions, the announcement that Reagan would run for a second term, briefings for all the summits except Moscow, although I selected the time to begin the Moscow trip. ``I timed congressional arm-twisting, the second inaugural oath of office, the announcement of Anthony Kennedy's Supreme Court nomination. ...'' ```Ronnie's `Evil Empire' attitude has to go before he can meet with Mikhail Gorbachev at Geneva,' I told her. `Gorbachev's Aquarian planet is in such harmony with Ronnie's, you'll see,' I said. `They'll share a vision. What's more, when Ronnie and Gorbachev meet, they'll get along famously, better than you can imagine if _ and this is a very big if _ Ronnie goes to Geneva with the proper attitude.' ```I know you are right,' Nancy said. `But it won't be easy to change Ronnie. First, I'll have to persuade him. You know as well as I do how he feels about Russian leaders. I'll have to make him realize what you say about Gorbachev is true.'''

DOC.HEAD: In Grafton, Even the Schools are Closed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Guy Linda Moyer is cq in 10th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: Some folks in this hard-luck railroad town don't think much of the walkout by West Virginia's teachers. ``People around here can't really relate to the supposed plight of a person making $22,000 a year. ... If you're making that much, you're well above the average person around here. And that's for nine months work,'' said Thomas M. Mason, owner of a local remodeling business. This mountain town of about 6,000, about 110 miles southeast of Pittsburgh, has seen Union and Confederate raiders fighting over its once vital rail hub. But the railroad jobs are all but gone, shuttered businesses line Main Street and coal does little to spark a sputtering economy. Now Grafton's schools, the town's largest employer, are idle. Teachers here were among the first to walk out a week ago, when thousands of West Virginia's educators struck over the state's refusal to grant pay raises. Only South Dakota and Arkansas pay teachers less than West Virginia, according to the National Education Association. Teachers in 47 of the state's 55 counties remained on strike Thursday despite threats by state officials that they would be fired if they don't return to work. Mason said he doesn't think Taylor County's 205 teachers have much to complain about in an area where unemployment reached 11 percent two months ago and the average salary was $8,650 in 1987. ``Some might think they're doing pretty good,'' Mason said. Annual salaries in the district range from $16,109 for a starting teacher with a bachelor's degree to $29,123 for a teacher with 20 years' experience, a master's degree plus 30 additional credits, according to the West Virginia Education Association. Enrollment in the district has dropped 23 percent since 1980. ``The average man on the street is going to have a blue-collar job around here,'' said Guy Linda Moyer, a speech pathologist for the school district. ``This strike is about people who have invested thousands of dollars in an education in order to get their jobs. ``We have different aspirations and goals than they have,'' Ms. Moyer said. ``That's not to say ours are any better. Just different.'' ``The people are pretty much divided,'' said L.N.
