Thorp, 68, as he sopped up a breakfast of biscuits and gravy at a local diner. ``There's a lot of people who are against the strike and anything they think is going to cost them even 10 cents more on their tax bill. But I think there's more people for the teachers than against them,'' said Thorp, who retired from CSX Corp. after 40 years as a freight car inspector. Television game shows and afternoons at the playground have replaced reading, writing and arithmetic for Debra Lyons' 7-year-old twins. ``They're driving me crazy, right up the wall. Aren't they ever going to go back to school? I've had it,'' Mrs. Lyons said as she separated her roughhousing first-graders, Jason and Jessica. Some enterprising pupils are making a few dollars during the strike. Seventh-grader Andi Peters, 13, is earning $15 a day watching two children. ``I'm going on a trip to the Virgin Islands this summer and this will help pay for it,'' she said. ``It's fun, but I wish the teachers would go back. They're taking our education away. They should find another way to get what they want.'' In Charleston, 115 miles southwest, the focus of the strike moved from the governor's office and picket lines to the courts as state officials sought judges' orders to force teachers back to work. Schoolchildren were off Thursday and today after state School Superintendent Hank Marockie called a statewide ``cooling off period'' in the strike.

DOC.HEAD: Astrologer Claims Influence Over Reagan
DOC.TEXT: An astrologer claims she was responsible for revising Ronald Reagan's attitude toward the Soviet Union and timing everything from press conferences to the former president's cancer surgery. ``Ronnie's `evil empire' attitude has to go before he can meet with Mikhail Gorbachev at Geneva,'' Joan Quigley, Nancy Reagan's astrologer for seven years, claims to have advised the former first lady. ``Gorbachev's Aquarian planet is in such harmony with Ronnie's, you'll see ... They'll share a vision.'' Ms. Quigley also claims in a new book released Thursday that she changed Mrs. Reagan's image, encouraging her to stop talking about fashion and devote herself to the anti-drug campaign. She said in an interview Wednesday that former White House chief of staff Donald Regan's book, ``For the Record,'' which disclosed Mrs. Reagan's consultations with an astrologer, ``was the first part of the trilogy and Nancy's book (``My Turn'') tried to sweep it all under the carpet.'' In her book, Ms. Quigley says ``My Turn'' ``reads like fiction and much of it is evasive.'' Mrs. Reagan wrote that while Ms. Quigley was ``helpful and comforting ... a kind of therapist,'' she had influence solely on Reagan's schedule. Asked for a comment on Quigley's book, a spokesman for the Reagans in Los Angeles, Mark Weinberg, said: ``We will not have anything to add to what is in Mrs. Reagan's book.'' Ms. Quigley said in her new book that she had a direct line to the former president through his wife. ``I was responsible for timing all press conferences, most speeches, the State of the Union Addresses, the takeoffs and landings of Air Force One,'' she wrote in ``What Does Joan Say?'' ``I timed congressional arm-twisting, the second inaugural oath of office, the announcement of Anthony Kennedy's Supreme Court nomination. I delayed President Reagan's operation for cancer from July 10, 1985, to July 13, and chose the time for Nancy's mastectomy.'' Ms. Quigley said that before Reagan's first summit with Soviet leader Gorbachev, she worked three hours to persuade Mrs. Reagan that her husband could trust him. She said she ``battled her to the mat'' to get Reagan's view of Gorbachev changed. ``Gorbachev's chart leads me to believe that he is different'' from past Soviet leaders, Ms. Quigley said she told Mrs. Reagan. ``The placement of his ruler, Mercury, in the tenth house of power and position convinces me that Gorbachev came to power not only because he had been favored by powerful older men, but also because of his high degree of intelligence.'' After working for free for the Reagans during the first presidential campaign, Quigley said she agreed in 1981 to help Mrs. Reagan improve her public image and was paid each month through a friend. Quigley writes that she advised Mrs. Reagan to focus on her two pet programs _ drug rehabilitation and foster grandparents _ and to play down all her privileged social connections. At the end of the tutoring, though, when Mrs. Reagan couldn't give a reporter an example of something she had found particularly touching in the course of her anti-drug work, Quigley concludes: ``My pupil was a consummate actress, but I couldn't help feeling that while she had worked hard and studied diligently, she had never really understood the reason for taking the course.''

DOC.HEAD: President Says Some Economic Signs `Worry Me'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he remains generally optimistic about the U.S. economy, but there are some signs ``that worry me.'' Among other problems, the nation's bulging deficit is making it impossible to give new democracies in Eastern Europe and Central America the aid they deserve, Bush said. ``I sometimes wish as president that there were more funds readily available _ read that less of a deficit,'' he told a group of newspaper executives on Thursday. ``There's a great deal that we have to do to keep this expansion going,'' Bush said. ``The economy at this moment isn't as robust as I'd like to see it.'' He asserted that congressional approval of his proposals for a lower capital gains tax and educational reforms would help make the nation more competitive aboard. ``If we're successful, then we're going to have not a peace dividend but a growth dividend,'' Bush told members of the National Newspaper Association. The president rejected the notion that America was in decline. ``We still have the highest standard of living in the world,'' he said. ... So I am not that pessimistic, and yet I don't want to stand here with some Pollyannnish attitude about the economy. There are some signs that worry me.'' Economic growth as measured by the gross national product slumped to an anemic 0.9 percent in the final three months of 1989 and many economists also are projecting a slow first quarter of 1990. American manufacturing has been in the doldrums for months. Appearing before the congressional Joint Economic Committee on Thursday, White House budget director Richard Darman said the economy's poor performance in the final quarter of 1989 would add $6.2 billion to the projected budget deficit for next year. The added red ink would be in the $12 billion to $15 billion range if the economy rebounds only gradually, he said. Before the new economic performance figures became available, the administration had estimated that the shortfall for fiscal 1991 _ which begins next Oct. 1 _ would be $100.5 billion. Bush, in a speech earlier Thursday to the National Association of Manufacturers, said: ``Our economy is not perfect and I don't want to paint an unrealistic picture.'' But he added that democratic upheavals in the world present the opportunity for U.S. companies to capture new markets. Changes in Eastern Europe and Central America ``mark the triumph not only of free ideas but also of free markets,'' he said. On other subjects in his meeting with newspaper executives, Bush: _Praised Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a ``reasonable man'' and said he was not concerned because Gorbachev's powers have been strengthened by the Soviet parliament. He said there was ``much less of a danger today'' from the Kremlin than in the past. _Expressed irritation with American volunteers in Nicaragua, who he said were intent on keeping the outgoing leftist government in power. ``Now they're picketing ... in front of the U.S. Embassy because in their view the wrong people won the election.'' _Said that last week's speculation that an American hostage in Lebanon might be released ``frankly confused me'' because there are no negotiations going on involving the U.S. government. ``I wish I could tell you that there was a serious, immediate effort that would pay off, but that isn't the case,'' he said. _Expressed opposition to suggestions that U.S. aid be cut to Israel and Egypt to make money available for emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. ``I don't want to suggest cutting to good friends,'' the president said, adding that he would like greater flexibility to disburse foreign aid. Bush was not asked about a fire that caused extensive damage at a Libyan plant the United States suspects of making chemical weapons. However, he answered with a firm ``no'' earlier Thursday when asked at a picture-taking session in the Capitol if there was any U.S. involvement in the Libyan fire. Administration officials said the plant had been knocked out of commission by a serious fire. ``We don't have any idea who did it,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher; Stocks Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing Nikkei, dollar
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose slightly against the Japanese yen in Tokyo Friday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell moderately. The dollar ended the week at 152.50 yen, up 0.03 yen from Thursday's close of 152.47 yen. After opening at 152.25 yen, the U.S. currency ranged between 152.20 yen and 152.63 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 55.20 points, or 0.17 percent, closing the week at 32,616.44. The index gained 319.51 points Thursday. Currency dealers said market sentiment for the dollar remained bullish. ``Trading was relatively quiet as prospects for a hike in the official discount rate have faded away, at least for now,'' said Shinji Tanaka, a dealer with Mitsui Bank. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno, returning from a nine-day European trip, told a news conference Thursday there was no change in the central bank's stance of monitoring the effects of its last rate hike. There had been speculation in the market that Japan's central bank might raise its discount rate by as much as 1 percentage point from the current 4.25 percent, in effect since last December, to stop the yen's downswing. The discount rate, the interest rate charged on loans by the central bank to commercial banks, has a strong effect on other interest rates. Higher interest rates tend to discourage stock traders. The benchmark No. 119 government bond price rose to 86.67 points as of 3 p.m. (1 a.m. EST), up from Thursday's close at 86.33. The yield fell 0.070 percentage points to 7.205 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Considers Helping Panama Rebuild
DOC.TEXT: A Peace Corps official says the agency may send volunteers to Panama to help that country rebuild from the December U.S. invasion and nearly three years of economic sanctions. ``Discussions are going on'' with the Panama government, Jody Olsen, chief of staff for the agency, said Thursday night. ``We are assessing ... the possibility of sending in a few volunteers'' to work in rural areas with other aid specialists as part of an overall Panama aid package, she said. A Peace Corps team will visit Panama next week to study logistics of how many volunteers could be used, where they might work and what they might do, said Olsen. The Bush administration has asked Congress for $500 million in aid for Panama this fiscal year and $300 million for Nicaragua, two countries in Central America making the transition to democracy. The December U.S. invasion that overthrew Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in Panama was succeeded by the U.S.-backed administration of Guillermo Endara, which has expressed interest in Peace Corps volunteers. But the Sandinista government defeated in the Feb. 25 elections is not scheduled to leave office under april 25, and Ms. Olsen said it was ``too early'' to tell whether Nicaragua would seek Peace Corps detachments. Olsen was responding to questions about a remark made by President Bush earlier in the day when asked if he would send Peace Corps teams to see that aid gets to the poor villagers of those countries. ``Yes,'' Bush answered. ``I'm strongly in favor of the Peace Corps. I've talked to our Peace Corps director. It's not _ you know, it's not quite right there.'' The president then complained about Americans who have gone to Nicaragua ``allegedly to help the people of Nicaragua,'' and ``now they're picketing ... in front of the U.S. embassy because in their view the wrong people won the election.'' ``They ought to stay down there if they're acting in this philanthropic way and try to help as the Peace Corps does,'' the president said. His remarks never returned to plans for the Peace Corps. Dennis Marker, director of a church-based group known as Witness for Peace, said Bush apparently was talking about his organization. ``We have had U.S. citizens demonstrating in front of the embassy since 1983,'' Marker said. ``The reason people are demonstrating is not because of who won the election. We are demonstrating against continued U.S. interference in Nicaragua.''

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Tuberculosis Rate Still Falling _ But Very Slowly, Due to AIDS
DOC.TEXT: A steady decline in tuberculosis has all but stopped amid the continuing threat of TB for the AIDS-infected, federal health researchers say. In 1988, the last year for which complete statistics are available, 22,436 U.S. tuberculosis cases were reported, down 0.4 percent from 1987, the national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. That slight drop compares with an average annual decrease of 6.7 percent from 1981 to 1984. One reason for the slowing of progress in wiping out TB is ``the increasing occurrence of TB in persons infected with ... HIV,'' the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome, the CDC said. AIDS leaves the body susceptible to a number of serious illnesses, including TB, and studies have found that about 4 percent of AIDS patients also are listed as TB patients. If the 6.7 percent average annual decline had kept up through the late 1980s, an estimated 14,768 fewer TB cases would have been expected during 1985-1988, the CDC said in its weekly report. Tuberculosis was down 8.7 percent among whites in 1988, as compared with 1985, but up 9.1 percent among blacks and 17.6 percent among Hispanics _ two groups with proportionately higher rates of AIDS cases. In 1988, 7,720 new tuberculosis cases were reported in whites, compared with 8,280 in blacks and 3,637 in Hispanics. The TB rate among blacks was 28.3 per 100,000, compared with 18.3 for Hispanics and 4.1 for whites. Another 2,371 TB cases were reported among Asians and Pacific Islanders in the United States, for a rate of 36.3 per 100,000. The CDC estimates that 10 million Americans are infected with the bacteria that cause tuberculosis, an infection of the lungs. The vast majority will never become ill. But the number of new cases is only part of the toll from tuberculosis, the CDC said. In 1987, more than 115,000 Americans were under TB treatment: 20,000 new patients plus 95,000 people labeled high-risk and on preventive therapy. Tuberculosis, which is curable in most cases with drug treatment, killed 1,755 Americans in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: In Policy Shift, Gov't Turns Again To Destroying Coca Fields
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Teams of workers armed with gas-powered weed cutters are destroying clandestine plots of coca seedlings, reflecting a policy change by Peru following the drug summit in Colombia last month. Peruvian police and U.S. anti-drug agents are supervising the small-scale operations in the coca-rich Upper Huallaga Valley, targeting isolated fields of young plants before they can be transplanted to larger areas. The move to destroy the coca fields marks a renewal of a government policy suspended more than a year ago. An alarming increase in acres planted has prompted the government to renew the eradication program, according to U.S. Embassy spokesman Gene Bigler. ``(The Peruvian government) has asked us for our support in eradication, and, of course, we're delighted,'' Bigler said. President Alan Garcia had temporarily halted joint anti-drug operations and threatened to boycott the February drug meeting with President Bush and the leaders of Colombia and Bolivia because of the U.S. invasion of Panama in December. He later attended. The eradication teams operate out of the U.S.-built base at Santa Lucia, 265 miles northeast of Lima in the Upper Huallaga Valley, the world's richest source of coca leaf. About 350 eradication workers are stationed in the area along with about 120 Peruvian police and 30 to 40 U.S. drug agents, contracted American helicopter pilots and mechanics. Ten UH-1 helicopters on loan from the State Department ferry the workers from the base to clandestine seedling plots, hidden under the dense jungle canopy throughout the valley. Despite a drastic drop in price over the last six months for Peruvian coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine, Peruvians continue to move into the valley hoping to get rich off the cocaine trade. ``They're cutting down all the trees,'' said Gen. Juan Zarate, head of Peru's drug police, from the back seat of a Huey helicopter cutting through the heavy jungle air 500 feet above the valley floor. Zarate pointed out new coca plantations carved out of the jungle hillsides, creating a haphazard patchwork of emerald hues up and down the valley. ``There's going to be so much environmental damage,'' he said. Zarate was taking reporters to visit a herbicide test site, where government scientists were studying the environmental effects of applying the herbicide Spike to illegal coca fields. Spike is one of a number of eradication methods under study. U.S. officials favor its use, saying testing so far indicate it does not cause ecological damage. But the Peruvian government has said more tests need to be done before it would consider using the chemical. The Cartagena Accord signed during the summit by President Bush, Garcia and the presidents of Bolivia and Colombia, linked eradication to development aid and the opening of U.S. markets to crops such as coffee, cocoa and palm oil to give the coca growers alternative means of support. However, the Bush administration has said it is reluctant to fund development projects with Peru's 3,000 percent inflation and a growing leftist insurgency by Maoist Shining Path guerrillas, who operate freely in much of the valley. Since September, the police have conducted raids against airstrips and jungle laboratories used by smugglers to transform the leaves into a semi-refined paste and ship it to Colombia, where it is made into cocaine. The police have destroyed about 125 labs since September, according to an embassy official. But despite interdiction efforts in Peru and Colombia, where authorities have confiscated hundreds of airplanes used by the smugglers, a recent U.S. government report says the number of acres planted in coca in the Andean nations grew by 12 percent last year. More than 250,000 people are involved in growing and processing the drug in Peru, bringing more than $1 billion a year into the country, according to U.S. and Peruvian government estimates. The government estimates that coca grows on half a million acres in Peru, with 60 percent of it in the Huallaga Valley. As the helicopter swooped over a small ridge, Zarate looked down on a woman and child standing next to a thatched hut with their latest coca harvest drying in the sun nearby. ``What we need is to give these people something else to do so they stop moving in here,'' the general said.

DOC.HEAD: Little Rock Case Prompts Infant Formula Warning
DOC.TEXT: Babies should not be given soy-based beverages other than infant formulas as their only source of nutrition, the Food and Drug Administration warns. The FDA said Thursday that the soy-based drinks, sometimes called ``soy milk,'' do not have the nutrients needed for infants. A 5-month-old baby girl whose parents bought the product in a health food store was in critical condition at Arkansas Children's Hospital in Little Rock because of malnourishment, the agency said in a statement. It did not identify the girl or her parents. The statement said the parents mistakenly believed a soy beverage sold in a health food store could be used as infant formula, and had fed it to their daughter almost since birth. Soy beverages analyzed by the Little Rock hospital were found to be lacking in calcium, niacin and vitamins D, E and C, the agency said. The FDA said children and adults can drink the soy beverages as long as they are part of an otherwise balanced diet. There are soy-based infant formulas that are ``complete and appropriate,'' and these formulas are not involved in Thursday's warning, the agency said.
DOC.HEAD: Michigan Real Estate Exec Picked for S&L Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has selected a Michigan real estate executive to serve on the board overseeing the savings and loan bailout. Robert C. Larson, chief executive officer of the Taubman Company in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was named Thursday to one of two vacant seats on the five-member Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who heads the board, said he expects the White House to announce the fifth member next week. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and Housing Secretary Jack Kemp also are members. The board sets policy and controls the purse strings of the bailout agency created last August. Congressional Democrats have complained that Bush waited until after most of the bailout policies were in place before naming the public members of the board, who were supposed to balance the influence of the government officials. Brady said the appointments were slow because the administration was looking for people experienced in real estate disposal. That complicated clearance checks for possible conflicts of interest, he said.
DOC.HEAD: No Lodging Deduction When Doctor's Care Not at Hand
DOC.TEXT: Lodging expenses for health-related travel are tax-deductible only if they are needed to obtain a physician's care, the U.S. Tax Court has ruled. Merely traveling on a doctor's recommendation to a more favorable climate to alleviate a specific ailment is not enough to justify a deduction, the court held. Instead, the travel must be essential to care provided by a doctor in a hospital or similar facility. The ruling earlier this week was the first time the court had considered a 1984 law that in certain situations allows lodging costs to be included in deductible medical expenses. The court case involved Earlene Polyak of Trenton, Mich., who suffered from chronic heart, artery and lung problems. Following her doctors' advice, she began spending winters in Florida, living in a travel trailer while her husband stayed at their home in Michigan. Her physicians did not refer Mrs. Polyak to any doctors in Florida, and she visited a doctor only twice during her five months there. She and her husband claimed a medical deduction for $1,426 they spent to rent a campground lot for the trailer but were turned down by the Internal Revenue Service. The new law was written to benefit people who must travel away from home because specialized care is not available locally or, in the case of some chemotherapy treatment for cancer, for example, may be obtained on an outpatient basis at a considerably lower cost.

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong to Send Vietnamese Refugees To Philippine Camp
DOC.TEXT: Hong Kong will move a group of Vietnamese boat people to a holding center in the Philippines to help ease congestion at camps in the British colony, a government official said today. Britain and the Philippines agreed on the relocating the Vietnamese under an international plan financed by Britain and other countries, said Mike Hanson, Hong Kong refugee coordinator. He said Britain has pledged $4.87 million to the plan. ``We hope the first small group can go by the end of this month,'' Hanson said. The plan is a new effort to relieve congestion in the squalid refugee camps in the British colony, where clashes have broken out with authorities and between rival groups of Vietnamese. In December, Hong Kong forcibly returned 51 Vietnamese to their Communist homeland under a plan that provoked sharp criticism from the United States and human rights organizations. The program was then put on hold. The Philippine camp at Morong, about 50 miles west of Manila, is operated by the U.N. High Commission for Refugees for Vietnamese for boat people who have been classified as refugees and have been accepted for resettlement in third countries. There are about 55,000 Vietnamese boat people in Hong Kong, and authorities fear their numbers will increase this summer when Vietnamese have normally fled their Communist homeland for other countries. Of the Vietnamese in Hong Kong, about 44,000 arrived after June 1988, when Hong Kong began to classify arriving boat people as illegal immigrants unless they can prove they face political persecution in Vietnam. Those classified as illegal immigrants can be repatriated back to Vietnam. The remaining 11,000 Vietnamese in Hong Kong arrived either before the cutoff date or have classified as genuine refugees entitled to resettlement in other countries. A Hong Kong government spokeswomen said refugees at the camp in the Philippines will be given vocational and language training to help them settle in their new countries.

DOC.HEAD: It's Been a Bad Flu Season; Vaccine Levels Among Old Probably Under 50
DOC.TEXT: The 1989-90 flu season could turn out to be the worst in five years, the national Centers for Disease Control says. And the dominant strain is one that hits especially hard against older people, who probably are not vaccinated, according to a CDC report Thursday. The CDC said the winter flu season has been marked by a flu type especially troublesome for older people: the type researchers know as A-H3N2. In the average influenza season, the flu kills about 20,000 Americans. But in 1984-85, the last year in which A-H3N2 was so predominant, about 57,000 people died. ``This year looks to me like the worst year since '84-85,'' said Dr. Walter Gunn, a CDC flu specialist. The U.S. flu season, which peaked in late January and early February, featured almost exclusively a Type A-H3N2 flu strain dubbed the ``Shanghai flu'' _ one of three components in the current flu vaccine, recommended for people older than 65 or patients with ailments such as diabetes or kidney disease. The recommended flu vaccine is up to 75 percent effective in preventing complications and death from flu in older people, the CDC said in its weekly report. But a survey of Medicare beneficiaries found that only 43 percent had received flu vaccinations for the 1988-89 winter flu season, the CDC reported Thursday. Nine out of 10 who weren't vaccinated fell into the older-or-ill group for whom shots are recommended. ``We still have quite a ways to go'' in immunizing Americans against influenza, said the CDC's Dr. Mary Ann Sprauer. The most commonly cited reason for not being vaccinated: 54 percent ``considered themselves healthy and not in need of vaccination,'' the Atlanta-based agency reported. Thirty percent cited concerns about side effects from the vaccine, and 30 percent were concerned about illness associated with the shots. The CDC stressed that the Medicare survey is not a representative national sample and may not reflect the nation's older population. But the findings among Medicare participants were somewhat more encouraging than previous surveys showing the vaccination rate among people over 65 to be 23 to 32 percent. ``We took a little heart in the fact that it seemed to be a little higher,'' Sprauer said. ``But the national goal, for the nation in 1990, was 60 percent (among those recommended for the vaccine). We'd like to see it up there around 60 or 70 percent, if not higher.''

DOC.HEAD: Students Excused From Final Exams For Excellence in Aiding Education
DOC.TEXT: High school seniors won't have to take the dreaded final exams this year, all because they got an A for effort in combating cuts in the state's education budget. At the student council's request, the school committee voted Wednesday to exempt the Class of 1990 from the annual year-end tests. Committee members said the seniors have proven their academic mettle by combating budget cuts and fighting for funds during a rally this week at the Statehouse. ``Children have to worry about things we never had to worry about when we were students,'' committee member Nancy Rubenstein said. ``They have to worry about fighting for education. ``They deserve it.'' Not everyone agreed. ``I recognize that this is an outstanding class, but I think this would be one more example of weakening academics,'' Superintendent John Maloney said. As for the students, they were ``totally shocked'' that the committee agreed to their proposal. Said class president Susan Slater: ``I can't wait to tell the kids at school.''

DOC.HEAD: Young Transplant Recipient Homeward Bound
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's first and longest surviving recipient of a heart-liver transplant, was cleared to go home after nearly a month of hospital care, her mother said. ``She's doing fine. She had her last checkup today,'' Susie Purcell said Thursday from a Ronald McDonald House near Children's Hospital, where 12-year-old Stormie was operated on twice in two days. Stormie and her mother, who live in the Fort Worth, Texas, suburb of White Settlement, were scheduled to return home today. Stormie arrived in Pittsburgh Feb. 19, nearly six years to the day after her historic first transplant. Ten hours of surgery were needed Feb. 20 to replace Stormie's first donor liver, which was damaged by hepatitis caused by an unknown virus. Doctors operated for nine hours the next day to stop internal bleeding. Stormie's donor heart has remained healthy, doctors said. The girl's first transplant, on Valentine's Day 1984, was needed because a disease left her with cholesterol levels 10 times greater than normal.

DOC.HEAD: Two Mutiny Leaders Escape From Military Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Two officers who took part in December's coup attempt escaped from a military hospital where they were recuperating from wounds suffered during the mutiny, a military spokesman said today. Authorities learned about the escape early today after the two officers were unaccounted for during a roll call of patients at the V. Luna General Hospital, said Lt. Col. Renato Maligaya. Marine Capt. Ariel Querubin and Army 1st Lt. Gener del Rosario may have escaped during the night, the spokesman said. Maligaya said the two suffered gunshot wounds during fighting at the suburban Camp Aguinaldo military headquarters during the Dec. 1-9 attempt to topple President Corazon Aquino. The fighting left 113 people dead. A search for the escapees was under way, Maligaya said. On Thursday, intelligence agents captured an army explosives expert who admitted participating in the December failed coup against President Corazon Aquino. Maj. Wilhelm Doromal, a former explosives instructor at the Philippine Military Academy, said in a television interview that he joined the coup attempt because of alleged army corrpution. More than 1,900 renegade soldiers and officers have been taken into custody since the December coup attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Man Loses Down Payment for Refusing to Buy Haunted House
DOC.TEXT: Tales of ghosts may have scared a Wall Street bond trader out of a deal for an 18-rVictorian house, but they can't get him his down payment back, a judge has ruled. State Supreme Court Justce Edward Lehner said Thursday that 63-year-old Helen Ackley was under no legal obligation to tmbovsky, 37, about the ghosts she believes go bump in the night in her home. ``It is clearin New York the doctrine of caveat emptor (let the buyer beware) still holds sway in real estate transactions,'' Lehner said. Stambovsky, who contends the ghost stories harmed the house's property valw things differently. ``We were victims of smic fraud,'' Stambovsky said. Lehner ruledt Stambovsky, in trying to get out of a $650,000s contract, was in default and not entitled to trn of his $32,500 down payment. Stambovskye and his then pregnant wife, Patrice Soriero, he house at first but became nervous about shariome with ghosts. Ackley said she told the buyers about the ghosts, but they laughed it ofmbovsky's lawyers, William Stein, said no mentiade of the ghosts until after the contract was signed in August 1989 for the home in Nyack, a town about 20 miles north of New York City. Ackley said the ghosts are a young Revolutionary-era naval lieutenant in his early 20s, a young woman about the same age, and a man in his 60s. She wrote about them in the May 1977 Reader's Digest in an article titled ``Our Hauntede on the Hudson.'' The ghosts can be heard g down the stairs in the morning and going backe evening, Ackley said. She said that when her four grown cn were young, the ghosts would up in the morning. That's all well and good, but what if the ghosts only like the Ackley family, Soriero said. ``They might not like it if she moves,'' she said. Once she sells the house, Ackley said, she plans to move to Orlando. She noted that ghosts usually get attached either to a particular person or a specificplace and she doesn't know what kind of ghosts she has. ``If they want to come with me, I'd be glad to hav them,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: $8 Billion Atom Smasher Gets Government Approval
DOC.TEXT: The government has given final approval to the $8 billion atom-smasher expected to shed new light on the sub-atomic particles that are the universe's fundamental building blocks. The Energy Department on Thursday approved the siting of the 54-mile ring, W. Henson Moore, deputy secretary of energy, told a gathering of more than 600 representatives from government, industry and science who will build the superconducting super collider. The announcement allows Texas to begin a land-buying binge outside of Dallas with some of the $1 billion it pledged in a successful effort to lure the project, and enables scientists to begin planning construction that could take a decade. ``Start your engines and start your land buying,'' Moore said. The Bush administration decided to support changes that would make the super collider more effective and more expensive, bringing the price tag up from the original estimate of $5.9 billion. ``The unanimous position was to go with the best science,'' Moore said. Morton Meyerson, head of the Texas National Research Laboratory Commission, said his agency, armed with a $250 million bond issue, is ready to move now that the site plan finally has been approved. ``The big flag goes down,'' Meyerson said. ``Now we begin land acquisition, and that's the toughest, hardest most intense project we have _ the one that will affect the most people.'' Hundreds of individual land purchases will have to be negotiated in rural Ellis County outside of Dallas, he said. The ring will be built underground and is intended by its backers to be the world's premier high-energy physics laboratory. It will hurl streams of protons, guided by powerful electromagnets, through the ring at almost the speed of light until they smash together and break up into even smaller particles. Critics of the super collider have complained it will absorb too much of the nation's scientific funding. Backers say it will increase interest in science. John Toll, president of the 77-university association contracted by the U.S. government to operate the super collider, said the knowledge generated by the super collider will be shared with schools and industries around the world. He also said the project's mammoth size has already aroused curiosity that he hopes will lead more students into scientific careers. The project is expected to spend $370 million annually when completed. It will create 2,500 permanent jobs and 4,500 temporary construction jobs. Congress approved $225 million in the current fiscal year for startup costs, and the Bush administration _ which has indicated it will spend up to $8 billion on the super collider _ is asking for $318 million for the upcoming year.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Fail to Recommend Breast X-Rays Often Enough, Specialists Say
DOC.TEXT: Almost one-third of the 44,000 women expected to die of breast cancer this year could be saved if more doctors urged their patients to have mammograms, a cancer specialist says. ``The whole point of mammography is you can find the breast cancer two years before you can feel it,'' Cori Vanchieri, director of the National Cancer Institute's early detection education program, said Thursday. ``Scientists say if women got mammograms as often as they should, we would see a 30 percent reduction in the (breast cancer) death rate,'' she said. Only 19 percent of U.S. women are regularly screened for breast cancer, said Dr. Sandra Swain of the Lombardi Cancer Center at Georgetown University. The cancer specialists were in New Orleans for the American College of Radiology's 24th National Conference on Breast Cancer, where findings from numerous studies on breast cancer are being presented this week. Mammography _ X-ray examination of the breasts _ is a widely accepted and often recommended method of early detection, according to the American Cancer Society. The society recommends a mammogram for women between the ages of 35 and 39, mammograms combined with a physician's examination every one or two years for women between 40 and 49, and annual mammograms and exams for women over 50. But doctors are not recommending mammograms for their patients with regularity, Ms. Vanchieri said. In 1989, 37 percent of doctors surveyed said they were referring women for screening based on the Cancer Society's guidelines. That's up from 11 percent in 1984 but still inadequate, she said. Doctor referral seemed to be the most important factor for getting women to have the checkups, according to a recent study, Ms. Vanchieri said. ``Eighty percent said they would have gone if a doctor told them to,'' she said. Early screening could improve cancer detection rates by 50 percent, said Dr. Daniel Kopans, an associate professor of radiology at Harvard University and director of breast imaging at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. ``Doctors to a certain extent are at fault for not recommending screening,'' he said. They give a number of reasons for not recommending X-ray screening, including cost, dispute over the beginning age and frequency for testing, and a lack of information, Kopans said. ``Believe it or not, a lot of physicians are just not aware of the value of mammography,'' Kopans said. A mammogram costs about $100, but screening is not covered by all insurance companies, Ms. Vanchieri said. Twenty-six states have laws requiring insurance coverage for such checkups, she said. ``The big issue for them (doctors) is whether patients can afford it,'' Ms. Vanchieri said. ``But women say cost is not a primary concern for them.'' Medical groups are working with radiologists and insurance companies to increase coverage and reduce expenses, Ms. Vanchieri said.

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. President Sees Hope for Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter today said chances seem better than ever for the release of foreign hostages in Lebanon and that President Hafez Assad repeated vows to help win their freedom. Carter made the comments to a news conference in the Syrian capital on the fifth anniversary of the kidnapping in west Beirut of American reporter Terry Anderson, the longest-held of the 18 Westerners missing in Lebanon. ``My own conviction is that more opportunities exist now for his release than ever before,'' Carter said. He spoke shortly before he left Syria for Jordan, the third leg of a tour that carried him earlier to Egypt and will later take him to Israel. Carter said he did not know if there were any secret U.S. dealings on the matter, but noted ``there are statements being made from Tehran that to me are encouraging. ``I think now there's a growing desire on the part of the Iranian government and the U.S. government to work out the problems between us,'' he said. ``There's no doubt that Iran has influence on those holding the hostages, although not complete control.'' Recent newspaper articles in Iran had suggested the hostages should be freed. Sheik Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah, spiritual guide of Lebanon's Hezbollah, or Party of God, said in a sermon last month that a humanitarian means of freeing the hostages must be found. Carter said the Saudi Arabian-brokered Taif accords for peace in Lebanon were ``a very constructive factor in the release of the hostaeveral powerful factions in Lebanon. ``When it's no longer necessary for Lebanon to be fragmented, with different militia groups jealously guarding their weapons and their prerogatives, then I think it's very likely the hostages will be released,'' Carter said. The tour, sponsored by the Cater Center of Emory University in Atlanta, is his fourth visit to the region since he left office in 1981. Carter said he discussed the hostage issue during a meeting of several hours with Assad on Thursday. He said Assad and other Syrian officials ``are using their good offices, they have assured me, in every way possible to both locate the hostages and convince those who might be holding them they should be protected and released.'' Although Syria has about 40,000 troops in Lebanon under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate, it has little influence with the Iranian-allied groups believed to be holding the hostages. Carter said he supported the right of Soviet Jews to emigrate freely to Israel, a position at odds with that of Syria, but said he agreed with President Bush that they should note allowed to settle in the occupied West Bank, Gaza Strip, Golan Heights or east Jerusalem, territories captured in the 1967 Middle East war.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Resigns To Give Roh Free Hand To Reorganize Government
DOC.TEXT: The Cabinet resigned today to give President Roh Tae-woo a free hand to reorganize the government following the merger of his party with two of the three main opposition groups. Government officials said Roh is expected to announce a new Cabinet on Saturday after consultations with his two fellow governing party leaders _ Kim Young-sam and Kim Jong-pil. A Cabinet change has long been anticipated after Roh merged his governing party with two centrist opposition groups, led by the two Kims, to form a giant conservative party last month. Government officials have indicated a sweeping Cabinet change would be needed to inject ``fresh air'' into national politics following the merger. They had said a change could be made after the National Assembly ended a special session today. Local newspapers, quoting unidentified government sources, reported the reorganization would probably affect nearly two-thirds of the 22-member Cabinet. The national news agency, Yonhap, said with up to 18 posts likely to be affected, the change would be the largest since Roh took office in the spring of 1988. The previous shakeup in December 1988 affected 16 posts. Almost all newspapers reported Roh would retain Kang Young-hoon as prime minister but replace Deputy Premier-Economic Planning Minister Cho Soon and most of other economic members. Cho and his economic team have been criticized for a series of policy failures that aggravated land speculation, increased inflation and slowed exports. Exports in the first two months of this year decreased 2.5 percent to $8.7 billion from a year ago. Roh, a former army general, was elected president in December 1987 following a split of two opposition parties. He replaced Chun Doo-hwan, who called the vote following mass demonstrations to demand democratic reforms and an end to autocratic rule.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers: Rare Blood Disorder May Not Be Due to Contamination
DOC.TEXT: A rare blood disorder linked to the recalled dietary supplement L-tryptophan may be due to a natural chemical breakdown in the body rather than contamination, researchers said. The over-the-counter health-food supplement used to treat sleeplessness, depression and other problems was pulled from store shelves last year after hundreds of people using it fell ill of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. No contaminant has been found, and natural chemical processes in the body during the breakdown of L-tryptophan could be behind the painful blood disorder, said the researchers at Georgetown University Medical Center. ``Arguing against the contamination theory is that in spite of the fact that people have been searching (for the contaminant), it hasn't been identified,'' said Dr. Paul Katz, chief rheumatologist at Georgetown. ``Also, the L-tryptophan implicated has been traced to three different manufacturers,'' he said Thursday from Washington. ``That argues a little bit against there being a common-source contaminant.'' L-tryptophan is an amino acid _ a building block of protein _ found in many foods. Fourteen people who took L-tryptophan have died in recent months and more than 1,200 others have fallen ill with eosinophilia-myalgia, which in milder cases causes aches, rashes and fever. A study of the problem by the Georgetown researchers was published in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. Katz and his colleagues believe L-tryptophan supplements under certain conditions contribute to a build-up of serotonin, a naturally occurring substance that helps nerves communicate with each other in the brain. Abnormally high levels of serotonin have been shown or suggested as factors in disorders similar to eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, the researchers said. Serotonin is a byproduct of the breakdown of L-tryptophan. Katz said: ``When you get away from the contamination theory, which is still the leading theory, people who develop this (syndrome) may have some intrinsic abnormality of L-tryptophan metabolism.'' The blood disorder may have occurred often in the past and diagnosed as something else, Katz said. ``The number of people who have gotten this (syndrome) is relatively small compared to the number of people who take it (L-tryptophan),'' Katz said, adding he could not estimate how many people have taken L-tryptophan supplements sold for years over the counter. The Food and Drug Administration on Nov. 17 requested a voluntary recall of L-tryptophan supplements and five days later extended the recall to include a ban on imports. FDA spokesman Chris Lecos said Thurday that federal researchers have analyzed hundreds of L-tryptophan samples, including some from people who fell ill, and ``have failed to identify a specific chemical or microbial contaminant responsible for the outbreak.'' He added, however, that the research didn't change the agency's advice against taking L-tryptophan.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Who would have ever thought in their wildest nightmares that this would last so long?'' _ Peggy Say, sister of Terry Anderson, the Associated Press' chief Middle East correspondent who is marking his fifth anniversary as a hostage.

``I am still a Communist.'' _ Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, hours after his inauguration to a strengthened presidency, in response to a question at a news conference on how his politics differed from those of a Social Democrat.

``Ronnie's `evil empire' attitude has to go before he can meet with Mikhail Gorbachev at Geneva. Gorbachev's Aquarian planet is in such harmony with Ronnie's, you'll see. ... They'll share a vision.'' _ Joan Quigley, Nancy Reagan's astrologer for seven years, on what she claims to have advised the former first lady before the first Reagan-Gorbachev summit.

DOC.HEAD: In Bid for Reading, Principal Agrees to Dress as a Woman
DOC.TEXT: John Branson dressed for success with a wig, bra and a little red number to reward pupils who doubled a reading goal at his elementary school. Branson, principal of Anthony Wayne Elementary School in this southwest Ohio town, initially offered to come to school in a Hawaiian shirt and shorts if his 300 students could read 3,000 books during last week's Right-To-Read Week. But the kids had another idea. We'll read the books, they said, if you dress as a woman and sit on the roof for everyone to see. The students ended up reading 6,669 books, so Branson put on a dress Thursday and moved his telephone to the roof of a one-story wing of the school. Sporting a shoulder-length brown wig, a straw hat, and a red dress over ``a 38B cup stuffed bra,'' Branson spent all day at the makeshift post. ``All during the week, they were just reading like you wouldn't believe,'' he said. ``The kids did a super job during Right-To-Read Week.''

DOC.HEAD: Rapper, `Spy' Magazine Series Potential New Shows for NBC
DOC.TEXT: NBC, heading for its fifth consecutive season as first in the prime-time ratings, is considering a new comedy series featuring rap singer Fresh Prince and a show based on the satirical magazine Spy. ``We're number one and we intend to stay there,'' NBC Entertainment president Brandon Tartikoff said Thursday. The fall schedules for NBC and its rivals won't be set and announced until May, but Tartikoff unveiled his development roster to whip up advertisers' enthusiasm for potential projects. CBS and ABC held similar sessions Wednesday. NBC's list of prime-time hopefuls, some of which will get a spring and summer tryout, include a Quincy Jones comedy series with the rap-music star, a comedy based on the ``Archie'' comic strip and a new version of the gothic soap opera ``Dark Shadows.'' Also on the list of prospects are two comedy specials. One, ``The Jackie Bison Show,'' would be a cartoon spoof of show business and star the first bison ever to host its own TV show. The other, a TV version of the satirical magazine Spy, will get its first on-air shot April 18. The theme will be ``How to Be Famous.'' Tartikoff, who spoke to advertising representatives at NBC offices in Burbank, told reporters afterward he thought that two of NBC's top money-earners, Bill Cosby and Johnny Carson, would be back next season. The Burbank meeting was shown at NBC offices in New York on a closed-circuit line. NBC is renegotiating a contract that would return the hit ``The Cosby Show'' for a seventh season, Tartikoff said. He didn't elaborate on what the renegotiations involved. Talks also are under way with Carson, host of the ``Tonight'' show since October 1962. ``We fully expect that Johnny will be back,'' Tartikoff said. NBC, which earlier renewed ``Dear John,'' said it was renewing five other series _ ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' ``Empty Nest,'' ``Midnight Caller,'' ``Quantum Leap'' and ``In the Heat of the Night.'' In earlier presentations in Los Angeles, third-place CBS said it had 23 series pilots under consideration, while ABC's roster of hopefuls showed 13 comedies, 15 hourlong dramas and two half-hour dramas. Under consideration at NBC are 13 dramas, 17 comedies and nine miniseries. The CBS comedy pilots include ``Sunday Dinner'' from producer Norman Lear, whose sometimes controversial sitcoms were mainstays of CBS in the 1970s, and ``Steel Magnolias,'' a small-screen version of the hit movie of the same name. ABC's possible series include Stephen Bochco's one-hour ``Cop Rock,'' which juxtaposes music and crime-fighting, and a sitcom, ``Dr. Ruth's House,'' starring the veteran dispenser of sex advice, Dr. Ruth Westheimer.

DOC.HEAD: Blizzard in Minnesota, North Dakota
DOC.TEXT: While much of the East enjoyed more balmy weather today, parts of Minnesota and North Dakota shoveled out from a blizzard that hit overnight. Low pressure in northern Minnesota produced snow and strong gusty winds across much of the northern Plains region and the Upper Mississippi Valley Thursday night and this morning. Snowfall totals in northwestern Minnesota were up to 9 inches at Detroit Lakes on Thursday. Fargo, N.D., also reported 9 inches of new snow. At least 88 schools canceled classes today in Minnesota. Strong gusty winds plagued both states and parts of Colorado, creating hazardous driving conditions. Winds gusted to 62 mph at Chadron, Neb. Winds gusted to nearly 60 mph across Illinois on Thursday, cutting off electricity to thousands of homes, delaying traffic at Chicago's O'Hare Airport and killing one person. Eddie Reese, 30, of Chicago was killed after he was hit by part of the roof of the Christmas card factory where he worked. Showers and thunderstorms developed in the central Gulf Coast states Thursday, spawning at least three tornadoes. In the southern Mississippi town of Benndale, a twister damaged two mobile homes, injuring three people. In southwest Alabama, a tornado accompanied by heavy rains flipped two mobile homes and blew the roof off a house. No injuries were reported. In the six hours ending at 6 p.m., Mobile, Ala., was drenched with nearly 4 inches of rain. Flash flood watches were in effect today for northwestern Georgia, northern and western Alabama, middle and eastern Tennessee and parts of northwest Florida. Cooler air moved into the East early today, but temperatures were still expected to be in the 50s and 60s over much of the region. On Thursday, the heat wave broke records for the fourth consecutive day in some areas. Temperatures were in the 70s and 80s eastward from the Mississippi River. At least 47 cities reported new record high temperatures for the date, with some cities reporting their warmest readings on record for so early in the season. In Harrisburg, Pa., the high of 82 degrees marked the first time in more than 100 years of records that there had been four straight days of 80 degree weather in March. Other records: 84 degrees at Baltimore; 72 at Burlington, Vt.; 80 at Cleveland; 77 at New York City; 81 at Philadelphia; and 81 at Washington, D.C. Readings warmed into the 60s along the Pacific Coast and into the 70s and 80s in the Southwest deserts. The high for the nation Thursday was 89 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla. Other reports at 5 a.m. EST: _EAST: Albany, N.Y., 58 partly cloudy; Atlanta 63 rain; Boston 40 foggy; Buffalo 68 cloudy; Charleston, S.C., 71 partly cloudy; Chattanooga 64 rain; Cincinnati 53 rain; Cleveland 55 rain; Detroit 51 rain; Hatteras 68 fair; Jacksonville 70 partly cloudy; Key West 76 windy; Knoxville 62 rain; Macon 65 foggy; Miami 75 fair; New York 49 partly cloudy; Philadelphia 60 partly cloudy; Pittsburgh 65 partly cloudy; Portland, Maine, 37 drizzle; Richmond 66 cloudy; Tampa 72 fair; Washington, D.C., 64 cloudy. _CENTRAL: Birmingham 62 thunderstorms; Bismarck 31 freezing drizzle; Chicago 47 fair; Denver 32 partly cloudy; Des Moines 36 fair; Fort Worth 50 partly cloudy; Indianapolis 47 foggy; Kansas City 40 fair; Little Rock 47 fair; Louisville 51 rain; Memphis 45 cloudy; Nashville 53 rain; New Orleans 58 thunderstorms; North Platte 38 windy; Oklahoma City 46 fair; Omaha 39 fair; Rapid City 35 snow; St. Louis 47 fair; Minneapolis-St. Paul 34 windy; Sault Ste. Marie 38 partly cloudy; San Antonio 45 fair. _WEST: Albuquerque 33 fair; Anchorage 23 fair; Boise 30 fair; Casper 31 windy; Fairbanks 21 cloudy; Great Falls 24 fair; Honolulu 68 fair; Las Vegas 49 fair; Los Angeles 56 fair; Medford 45 cloudy; Pendleton 37 fair; Phoenix 53 fair; Portland, Ore., 43 fair; Reno 37 cloudy; Salt Lake City 31 fair; San Diego 55 fair; San Francisco 53 cloudy; Seattle 43 fair; Spokane 35 fair. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 23 fair; Montreal 36 foggy; Ottawa 36 foggy; Regina 30 windy; Toronto 45 foggy; Winnipeg 28 snow; Mexico City 55 fair; San Juan 71 partly cloudy.

DOC.HEAD: Hard-liners Begin Efforts to Remove Shamir As Party Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with attempt to remove Shamir from party post. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY7,8
DOC.TEXT: Hard-liners today launched efforts to overthrow caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir as leader of the right-wing Likud bloc after a parliamentary no-confidence vote toppled his governing coalition. The Yediot Ahronot daily said Shamir was considering retirement from political life following Thursday's defeat. Another newspaper, Maariv, quoted the premier as saying ``I see no reason to resign.'' Israel radio said Likud leaders met in Shamir's office this morning for a discussion of the party's future. Sahi Alnegbi, a Likud member of parliament, said on Israel radio: ``Mr. Shamir will have to resign eventually because he cannot form a narrow government.'' ``When the time comes, he will have to realize he has to pass the leadership to someone else.'' He said the likely candidates to succeed Shamir are former Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, Foreign Minister Moshe Arens and David Levy, the housing minister and deputy prime minister. Senior Shamir aides were not immediately available for comment. Labor Party leader Shimon Peres, meanwhile, launched contacts to form a new government, hoping to cash in on the support from a swing religious party that yielded the 60-55 victory against Shamir. It was the first time an Israeli premier was formally ousted by a no-confidence motion. Past prime ministers have resigned before a vote was held when they appeared sure of losing. Shamir remains caretaker prime minister until a new government is formed, a process that could take months. The dispute that brought down Shamir's government centered on U.S. proposals for Middle East peace that included involving east Jerusalem Arabs and Palestinians deported by Israel in peace talks. Labor supported the moves, but Likud objected that including east Jerusalem Arabs could call into question Israel's control of Jerusalem and deportees could indirectly involve the Palestine Liberation Organization in the process. Peres, a left-of-center politician and former premier, appeared to have the best chances of being asked to form a new government, Israeli reports said today. But the complexities of reconciling demands of the religious parties and his allies in left-wing factions could force Labor and Likud reluctantly into a broad-based government or bring about early national elections. According to Maariv and the Hadashot daily, Peres has offered the utra-Orthodox Shas Party the important Finance Ministry in a new government. Five of six Shas leaders helped Labor Thursday by being absent from voting. Another would-be Labor ally is the ultra-Orthodox Agudat Israel faction, which voted against Likud. Hadashot said this party may be assigned the Housing and Welfare ministries. The two religious parties hold a critical 11 seats in the 120-member Parliament, which when added to 15 held by Arab and left-wing factions, would give the 39-member Labor a majority of 65. Likud holds 40 seats. The threatened end of its 13-year dominance in government touched off new infighting in the fractious party, with supporters of Levy urging the removal of the 74-year-old Shamir as party chairman. ``The reality shows that as long as we don't unite around one person it will be fateful for Likud,'' Levy supporter and legislator Reuven Rivlin said on the radio. ``Today we have to unite around one person who can lead us to forming a government.'' Rivlin said Levy supporters met Thursday night after the vote but no decisions were made. Levy has been an ally of Sharon, the retired general who quit in February to protest the government's peace policies. Shamir supporter and Minister of Arab Affairs Ehud Olmert also hinted there was talk of Shamir stepping down. ``What is in the realm of the possible is difficult to predict,''Olmert said. ``Concerning Yitzhak Shamir, I think that's something he must decide and I think we will speak about it in the next couple of days.'' Peres told reporters he was confident Labor would lead the next government and would move toward peace. Palestinians have waged a 27-month-old uprising against Israeli rule of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 663 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the revolt. Forty-three Israelis also have been slain.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Rules in Favor of Lesbian Jail Inmate
DOC.TEXT: Jail officials cannot deny a female inmate visits with her lesbian lover merely because of her homosexuality, a federal judge ruled. The ruling from U.S. District Judge D. Brooks Smith came on a lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union on behalf of the prisoner, identified only as ``Jane Doe.'' The woman, in Blair County Prison since May, claimed she was denied visits with her lover even though jailhouse visits were permitted between heterosexual inmates and their spouses and lovers. Smith ruled Wednesday that the ban was unconstitutional. He cited a 1980 Pennsylvania Supreme Court decision that the state cannot control the conduct of consenting adults in private, Marion Damick, a spokeswoman for the ACLU's Pittsburgh chapter, said Thursday. All visits at the jail in Hollidaysburg take place in a room where prisoners and guests are separated by windows. The lawsuit named Warden Gary Sparks and the Blair County Prison Board as co-defendants. During testimony before Smith in December, Sparks defended the decision to prohibit the visits, saying a prisoner identified as a homosexual could become the target of assaults and abuse by other inmates. If the prison board files an appeal, visits between the inmate and her lover would not be permitted until an appeals court rules.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Rebels Claim 13,000 Government Casualties
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas in northern Ethiopia say they have killed, wounded or captured more than 13,000 government troops _ half of them since Sunday _ and damaged several aircraft and tanks during an offensive. It was impossible to independently verify Thursday's rebel claims, and the government rarely comments on such assertions. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front said in a clandestine radio broadcast that 6,500 of the casualties were inflicted between Sunday and Wednesday. The broadcast, monitored in Kenya's capital, said this week's fighting occurred southeast of Asmara, capital of Ethiopia's northernmost province, Eritrea. ``In earlier engagements in the past two weeks in different parts of the same front, 7,000 Dergue (government) soldiers have been put out of action and the Dergue has lost three burnt fighter planes, eight tanks and four anti-aircraft carrier vehicles,'' the broadcast said. The broadcast did not specify the type of aircraft destroyed, but Ethiopia's air force flies Soviet-made MiG-17s, 21s, and 23s. ``In the last 20 days the Dergue has lost more than 13,500 soldiers as dead, wounded and aptured,'' the broadcast said. The rebels, who have fought 28 years for independence for the former Italian colony of Eritrea, launched their current offensive last month, ending a de facto cease-fire. The Eritreans claim to have captured Ethiopia's only deep water Red Sea port, Massawa, and cut the road from the harbor to Asmara. President Mengistu Haile Mariam's government has not acknowledged that claim, but admits the port has been closed by fighting it says continues in and around the city. It has acknowledged many casualties but has not given a figure. The government is also fighting a second but smaller force, the Tigre People's Liberation Front. The Tigreans have been fighting for 14 yeears and virtually control Eritrea's southern neighbor, Tigre province. The Tigreans seek Mengistu's ouster and the establishment of a government patterned after that of Albania, the last hard-line Marxist state in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Caution Against Dangerous Elevator Game
DOC.TEXT: A dangerous game called ``elevator surfing,'' blamed in the death of a college freshman, has been a problem for years in high-rise buildings, officials say. Also called ``elevator action'' or ``piloting an elevator,'' the hazardous sport involves climbing atop elevator cars _ either through trapdoors in the roof or by jamming doors open _ and riding on the roofs. ``We've taken it terribly seriously. We've been fighting it for a long time,'' said Val Coleman, public information director for the New York City Housing Authority. Coleman worked on a recently released cautionary videotape on the issue called ``Children are Too Young to Die.'' There have been 10 deaths and more than 50 injuries reported in New York during the past five years, he said. At the Otis Elevator Co., the largest elevator manufacturer in the United States, officials have been concerned about the dangerous game for some time, said Michael Jordan-Reilly, spokesman for the Hartford, Conn.-based company. ``This is one of our major concerns,'' he said. Susan Beckett, a student at the University of Massachusetts, told the campus newspaper, The Collegian, that students ride atop elevators ``usually on the weekends when people are drunk.'' At Ms. Beckett's school, 18-year-old Joel Mangion of Newton was found dead Sunday at the bottom of an elevator shaft. Friends said he had been jumping from one car to another in the double shaft. About a year ago, a student suffered serious injuries after falling 30 feet in an elevator shaft, university officials said. In the early 1970s, a student died after riding in a chair tied to the bottom of an elevator car. Joseph Zannini, executive director of housing at the university, said he has heard of the game occasionally during his 25 years in college administration. ``There's so many unfortunate ways that young people sometimes lose their lives because they just don't think,'' he said. Jordan-Reilly said the problem has probably existed ``as long as there have been elevators and as long as there have been people who want to try something dangerous.'' In Bridgeport, Conn., police and firefighters spent two tense hours in January rescuing a 13-year-old girl who was wedged between an elevator car and the shaft after she slipped and fell off the roof of the car in a public housing shelter. Police said the girl and her sister were playing on top of the elevator. Donald A. Robinson, director of environmental health and safety for the Massachusetts school, said officials are looking for new ways to discourage elevator surfing. ``The message needs to be made very clear how elevators should be used and not misused and to really emphasize the obvious significant consequences,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle: `Revolution of Democracy' Has Won in Western Hemisphere
RETRANSMITTING to change dateline
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Quayle meets with Contra representatives 11 a.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle returned to Washington today after spending a week in South America, where he proclaimed the ``revolution of democracy has won'' in the hemisphere. Quayle on Thursday said the inaugural speech by the new Brazilian president, Fernando Collor de Mello, marked ``a fitting cap'' to the trip, during which he daily sang the praises of democracy. The vice president said Collor proclaimed that his ``first unswerving commitment as president of Brazil will be to democracy.'' Noting that elected governments now exist through all of South America, he said ``the revolution of democracy has won.'' Quayle today was reporting to President Bush on his trip. He also scheduled a meeting with representatives of the U.S.-backed Contra rebels, following his series of contacts with outgoing Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega during his trip. Quayle said he would talk to the Contra leaders ``about a way to advance peace,'' including the U.S. proposal to have the rebels move temporarily into enclaves in Nicaragua under the supervision of United Nations peacekeeping troops. ``They'll certainly know that I think it's time that they stop fighting,'' the vice president said. Quayle said Thursday that Ortega ``can do a lot'' to change activities that the Bush administration contends portend trouble for a peaceful transfer of power on April 25. Asked what concerns he expressed to Ortega during their 10-minute chat in Brasilia on Wednesday, Quayle said he did not want to ``get into a public debate on a lot of specifics.'' But he said that disarmament of Ortega's Sandinista militia is as important as disarming the Contras. How to demobilize the rebels has been a principal topic of negotiations leading to the inauguration of incoming president Violeta Chamorro. ``There are reports that many arms are being shipped out to the Sandinistas that are taking them to their homes and taking them to the hills ready to fight again at another time,'' Quayle said at a news conference before leaving Brazil. ``That would be a most unfortunate development in the transition. Daniel Ortega can do a lot to stop that.'' U.S. officials also claim the leftist Sandinistas are depleting Nicaragua's treasury before leaving power and turning over houses to Sandinista militants. Quayle and Ortega had met earlier in the week in Chile for two quick chats and a 90-minute lunch. Ortega promised a peaceful transfer of power. The two were among foreign leaders attending presidential inaugurations in Chile last Sunday and Brazil on Thursday. At Thursday's inauguration, several of the key regional players trying to bring peace to Nicaragua chatted before the ceremony. Costa Rican President Oscar Arias was seated next to Ortega. They talked at length to Venezuela President Carlos Andres Perez and Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, as well as to Argentinian President Carlos Menem, Peru's Alan Garcia and Rodrigo Borja of Bolivia. Quayle did not talk with them, entering the crowded hall shortly behind Cuban President Fidel Castro. Castro was surrounded by a clot of people pressing in to greet him. Quayle had to edge past the group to get to his front-row seat. He later took the opportunity to again criticize Castro as being isolated in a hemisphere of elected governments. ``Only one Latin leader came (to the inauguration) in a military uniform,'' Quayle told reporters. ``The rest of the Latin American leaders were there because the people voted for them.''

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Wires Residents' Health Monitoring Payment
DOC.TEXT: Neighbors of a government uranium processing plant who sued the Energy Department over fears of radioactive contamination received $16 million of a $78 million court settlement for medical monitoring. The federal agency wired the long-awaited payment Thursday to Central Trust Co., a Cincinnati bank. Neighbors of the Feed Materials Production Plant, about 18 miles northwest of Cincinnati, filed a $300 million lawsuit in 1985 against the plant's former operator, National Lead of Ohio Inc., and its parent company, NL Industries. The Energy Department, as the Fernald plant's owner and contract employer of National Lead, negotiated a settlement approved last September by U.S. District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel. The Energy Department was to have paid the full $78 million by last Oct. 15 but didn't, saying there was confusion over which of its budget accounts was to be used to provide the money. The residents went back to Spiegel and obtained an order to compel payment. The judge had certified the lawsuit as a class-action on behalf of 14,000 people living within five miles of the plant. The Energy Department agreed to provide a second installment of $20.5 million by the end of this year, said Stanley M. Chesley, a lawyer for the neighbors. The agency agreed to pay off the balance of the settlement, with interest, by the end of 1991, he said. ``This is a true first in American history,'' Chesley said. ``We're finally going to get the medical monitoring. The message is, the judicial system works.'' Uranium processing for the government's nuclear weapons program was halted last July at the 39-year-old plant. Medical tests are to start soon on neighbors who fear that exposure to years of radioactive emissions from the plant may have caused cancer or other ailments. Chesley said he knew of at least 1,000 requests filed by neighbors for medical monitoring, which is to be performed under supervision of court-appointed trustees. ``I think history has been made here, I really do,'' said Lisa Crawford, spokeswoman for Fernald Residents for Environmental Safety and Health, the neighbors' organization that filed the suit. ``We're just pleased that we were able to stick this out and work it through and get the settlement, even though it was five months late,'' she said. The settlement is to be administered by four Cincinnati banks and three court-appointed trustees. Later, trustees are to decide which of hundreds of property claims and claims over emotional distress are to be paid.

DOC.HEAD: Police Drag Opposition Leaders From Presidential Grounds
DOC.TEXT: Military police battled opposition leaders in the gardens of the presidential compound today, broke up a planned sit-in and dragged the politicians away. The officials of the Democratic Progressive Party had demanded to see President Lee Teng-hui, but presidential aides said Lee was in a meeting and could not meet them. Today's clash with police was the latest since Tuesday by opposition supporters, who have protested a proposal to strengthen the National Assembly. The opposition fears the assembly, dominated by aging right-wing Chinese Nationalists who have ruled Taiwan since 1949, will hinder democratic reforms. Chang Chun-hung, the opposition party's secretary-general, said the party wanted to meet Lee because they were concerned the assembly, Taiwan's electoral college, would pass the proposal to meet annually to review bills passed by the Legislative Yuan. The assembly now meets every six years, primarily to elect Taiwan's president. There are fears the proposed legislation will expand the National Assembly's powers and hinder future democratic reforms in Taiwan. On Thursday, the Legislative Yuan passed a resolution threatening to freeze approval of the National Assembly's budget if the proposed legislation is passed. Witnesses said the opposition leaders were angered when about 100 police surrounded them and forced them to leave the Presidential Office building through a side gate rather than the main gate. ``As citizens, we only wanted to leave decently from the front gate,'' said party chairman Huang Hsin-chien, 62. The opposition leaders then tried to stage a sit-in in the Presidential Office gardens but were eventually dragged away by police. The Democratic Progressive Party leaders told reporters they were kicked and clubbed by police. Police said they were the ones who were attacked, but neither group reported any serious injuries. The 752-seat National Assembly is dominated by elderly deputies, most of them members of the governing Nationalist Party, who were elected on the Chinese mainland before 1949 when the Nationalists lost a civil war and fled to Taiwan. The aged politicians have been frozen in office to support a Nationalist claim to be China's legitimate government. They have rejected demands they retire. All 11 Democratic Progressive Party deputies in the National Assembly have been barred from taking their seats since Tuesday for refusing to pledge allegiance to the Republic of China, the name under which the Nationalists founded their nation in 1911. They have instead pledged their allegiance to the people of Taiwan. The Democratic Progressive Party, Taiwan's main opposition group, was formed three years ago and most of its members are native Taiwanese. The party claims its 11 delegates have been barred to allow the aged lawmakers to ram through the controversial legislation and other bills, including one that would allow the aged assemblymen to decide on their retirement. The aged lawmakers also have been accused of using ``political blackmail'' over President Lee because they dominate the National Assembly, which will elect Taiwan's next president March 21. Lee, 67, is the sole candidate for the post, but he angered the aged assemblymen earlier by rejecting their choice of Chiang Wego, the sole surviving son of Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek, to be his running mate. Lee became the first native Taiwanese to head the Nationalist government in 1988 when he was elevated from the vice presidency following the death of President Chiang Ching-kuo.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Rules Out Economic Sanctions Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Britain's ambassador to Iraq, Labor lawmakers introduce sanctions measure, Iraq planning demonstration Saturday. Pickup 7th graf `Australia's foreign...' TRIMS from bottom.
DOC.TEXT: Britain's ambassador to Iraq returned to London today after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher recalled him to protest the Baghdad government's execution of a London-based reporter accused of spying. While the Thatcher government stopped short of imposing economic sanctions, opposition lawmakers called for sanctions and an arms embargo to protest the hanging of Farzad Bazoft, 31, who Iraq said was spying for Britain and Israel. Mrs. Thatcher recalled Ambassador Harold Walker and ordered the expulsion of six Iraqi military trainees from Britain. Walker arrived in London this morning and said relations with Iraq had suffered ``a terrible blow'' in the short-term but that the long-term damage ``depends more on the Iraqis than ourselves.'' The British government also announced a freeze on visits by government ministers to Iraq and canceled a trade mission. But it did not break diplomatic relations or impose economic sanctions on Iraq. Britain has nearly a $500 million trade surplus with Iraq. Britain's expulsion order against the Iraqi military trainees does not affect about 1,000 other Iraqi students in Britain. A group of opposition Labor Party lawmakers introduced a motion in the House of Commons calling on Britain and the European Community to impose economic sanctions and an arms embargo on Iraq ``until the respect for human rights in that country has reached an acceptable standard.'' Such motions allow lawmakers to go on record with an opinion. No vote will be taken on the proposal unless it is presented as legislation. Government-run newspapers in Iraq today reported that authorities plan a mass demonstration in Baghdad on Saturday to protest the British measures. ``Iraq will not bow to any form of pressure or extortion and will pay no attention to any measures taken by British authorities,'' one of the state-run newspapers, Al-Shaab, wrote. Australia's foreign minister, Gareth Evans, also called the hanging ``barbaric'' but today ruled out sanctions on Iraq. Western European governments, press and human rights groups also denounced Iraq. The United States said it regretted that pleas for clemency had gone unheeded. Bazoft, an Iranian-born reporter who worked for the weekly newspaper The Observer, was arrested while trying to check out reports of an explosion at a Iraqi military complex. Bazoft, who had lived in Britain since 1975, was convicted and sentenced by a military court Saturday after a closed trial. Bazoft's colleagues in London insisted he was not a spy, just an enthusiastic reporter going after a scoop. Arab governments kept silent on the execution. Even Jordan's King Hussein, who joined with the Palestine Liberation Organization in seeking clemency for Bazoft, would not condemn Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. In a development late Thursday night, the British domestic news agency Press Association quoted unidentified British government sources as saying Bazoft had served a jail term in Britain for robbery. The report quoted the sources as saying that Bazoft was convicted at the Crown Court at Northampton in central England in August 1981 of robbing a savings and loan office of $760. He was reported to have walked into the office with a fake bomb and threatened to blow up the building if he was not given cash.
