The Zulus, one of several black tribes in South Africa, come from the southeast part of the country. Most blacks in the Johannesburg area belong to other tribes. Elsewhere, a black man was killed in an exchange of gunfire with army troops in a township outside the port city of Durban, police added.

DOC.HEAD: Terry Anderson's Supporters Fast for Release, Peace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Other observances...' with one graf to UPDATE with those that have occurred.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BF1
DOC.TEXT: Friends and supporters from Terry Anderson's hometown fasted today to urge freedom for all Western hostages in Lebanon and for peace in the Middle East. ``Tonight we gather with our lighted candles and our paper cranes and we pray ... that these would be the words that could free the hostages,'' Sister Pauline M. Petruzzella told about 180 people who attended an interfaith service Thursday night in this Buffalo suburb, marking the start of the 24-hour fast. The Roman Catholic nun also offered a prayer for the hostage-takers of Lebanon, ``that they could be freed of their anger, their hurts, their frustration.'' The service and fast marked the fifth anniversary of Anderson's abduction in Beirut. The Associated Press' chief Middle East correspondent, who grew up in Batavia, 40 miles east of Buffalo, is the longest held of 18 Western hostages. Today is his 1,826th day in captivity. He is now 42. He has never seen his 4-year-old daughter. He may not know his father and brother died in 1986. In Orchard Park, 60 children, one for each month of his captivity, carried paper cranes, a traditional Japanese symbol of peace. Later in the service, the children held aloft pictures of Anderson and 11 other hostages as their names and dates of captivity were read. Among those attending the service from Batavia were Penny Anderson, Terry's sister-in-law; Carl Anderson, a cousin; and Anne Zickl, a Batavia resident who has never met Terry but has become a leader of local efforts to win his release. Other observances occurred today in New York City, Washington, D.C., Cyprus and Tokyo. In Lorain, Ohio, where Anderson was born, veterans fired a rifle salute, and three Anderson cousins tied a large yellow ribbon around the city's flagpole today. The Batavia group planned to break their fast at a service tonight. A separate service was planned in Orchard Park. The idea to fast 24 hours in support of the hostages was conceived by Buffalo Area Metropolitan Ministries and was adopted enthusiastically by Peggy Say, Anderson's sister and the leader of efforts to free the hostages. Say, who will fast as she attends ceremonies today in Washington, said in a letter read at the service here that foreign leaders with whom she met in a recent trip to the Middle East had been deeply moved by the idea of a fast. ``Never before had I been so warmly received everywhere with so many positive assurances of help,'' she wrote. The Rev. Francis X. ``Butch'' Mazur, a priest at the Orchard Park church, urged all who support the hostages to give up something of value for the day. ``It may mean abstaining from one of the three meals that you would have in the next 24 hours,'' Mazur said. ``For little kids, it may mean fasting from candy or soda pop. For others, it may mean fasting from television or coffee or caffeine.'' Fasting ``is a transformation of self, which leads to a transformation of society, which takes its shape from our lives,'' he said. Many in the congregation signed pledges to do just that. ``I hereby commit myself to one day of prayer and fasting for Terry's release and the release of all innocent human beings held hostage anywhere in the world,'' the pledges read.

DOC.HEAD: Post Office Travel, Bonuses Criticized
DOC.TEXT: Postmaster General Anthony Frank is defending post office spending on travel and bonuses in the face of criticism from a senator and a member of the commission that rules on postal rates. Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., took the Postal Service to task for sending officials to conferences in various parts of the country _ including Hawaii and Florida. And John Crutcher of the Postal Rate Commission told Washington newspapers he's upset that top post office managers received performance bonuses ranging from $3,000 to $11,000 in 1988. Just last week, the post office announced plans to seek an increase in postal rates, citing a fiscal outlook that could present the agency with its largest dollar loss ever in this year. The new rates, including a 30-cent first-class stamp, would take effect next year if approved by the independent Postal Rate Commission. Commission member John Crutcher complained to Washington newspapers about the bonuses paid to postal managers, saying: ``Surely some of them are so bad some should be fired instead of getting an award.'' ``Managers are awarded bonuses for superior performance. Those who achieve or exceed specific goals in numerous categories are compensated accordingly and those who don't are not,'' Frank responsed Thursday. Pryor, meanwhile, cited a General Accounting Office report that said the Postal Service spent more than $6 million last year on travel for administrators attending conferences. ``At a time when the Postal Service is crying about its fiscal crisis and threatening to reduce service unless it can raise postage rates, it's nothing short of an outrage to find it has been spending money this way,'' Pryor said in a statement. Frank said the meetings and conferences were ``necessary for the proper conduct of our business.'' ``Participants always spent more than eight hours a day in these meetings. Despite the sometimes exotic locations, room rates ranged from $63 to $98 dollars a day, but some meal costs appear high,'' Frank said in a statement. He did not elaborate on the meal costs, but added that ``there is room for improvement.'' The Postal Service, which no longer receives tax subsidies, was established as a semi-independent agency in 1971 and directed to operate like a private business.

DOC.HEAD: F-16 Crashes in Western Utah; Pilot Ejects
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force F-16A jet fighter crashed near the Utah-Nevada line today, and its pilot ejected and parachuted safely, authorities said. The $16 million aircraft went down on the western Utah Salt Flats about three miles east of here about 9:30 a.m. MST, said Tooele County Sheriff's Sgt. Joe Bradshaw. He said the only crewman, a Hill Air Force Base pilot whose identity was not immediately released, had been taken to Wendover Air Force Base for debriefing. Hill crews were dispatched to the wreckage, authorities said. Mitch Barker, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration in Seattle, said he understood the pilot ejected after the aircraft's engine failed. He said the F-16A was en route to Wendover from Hill Air Force Base in northern Utah at the time of the crash. Hill officials said the aircraft had undergone maintenance there and left at 8:55 a.m. on a test mission.

DOC.HEAD: Report Scores Rising Violence, Censorship Against Reporters
With AM-Condemned Journalist Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Latin American democracies proved the most dangerous places for journalists to work last year, according to a report released Friday. The 53 killings in 1989 included many murders ``where journalists were killed in retaliation for what they had written or to prevent what they were going to write,'' Sonia Goldenberg, executive director for the Committee to Protect Journalists, said Friday. The formal release of the report at a news conference came a day after Iraq hanged a London-based journalist it accused of spying. It came on the fifth anniversary of the day Terry Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped in Lebanon. The death toll last year was more than double the 1988 total of 26 dead, the committee reported. It called the slayings ``censorship by death.'' Goldenberg said expulsions, which she called another form of censorship, also doubled to 60. She said journalists were most frequently expelled from China, Ethiopia and Romania. The committee also counted 325 journalists arrested and 102 physically assaulted in 1989, figures it said were higher than the previous year. The report listed 16 countries as ``cases of concern'' because of their treatment of journalists. They included Lebanon, where three journalists including Anderson are being held hostage, and China, where editor Wei Jingsheng has been jailed 11 years. However, two-thirds of last year's killings occurred in Latin America, the committee said, including 14 in El Salvador, where a civil war is raging. There were 11 deaths in Colombia; five in Peru; two in Brazil; and one each in Ecuador and Guatemala. ``We are talking about democracies,'' Goldenberg said. She and others said journalists need to make sure the public knows about atrocities and the U.S. government feels pressure to ensure its foreign aid recipients observe human rights. The trend toward greater violence and censorship was broken by good news at year's end from the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe. Goldenberg cited the freeing of imprisoned journalists and new press freedoms in several countries. Alexandr Kramer, a Prague writer, said he was visiting the West to ``relearn his craft'' with several colleagues under a United States Information Agency program. He said many Czech journalists must learn how to break a long habit of self-censorship. ``We don't have many complaints in Czechoslovakia nowadays,'' Kramer said. ``There is a boom of new periodicals. Everyone can write what he thinks.'' Farzad Bazoft, who was reporting for The Observer of London, was hanged Thursday after the Iraqi government convicted him of spying. He had been investigating reports of mass deaths in an accident at a military complex. Goldenberg said his execution will be a top priority for the committee this year. ``If we don't raise a protest in the loudest terms, we are afraid that other countries might take this example, and we cannot allow this,'' she said. She did not disclose what steps the organization will take. Another group, Freedom House, has put the number of journalists killed last year at 73. The two monitors could not explain the difference but noted each uses its own sources of information and methods of confirmation. One journalist was killed in crossfire in the U.S. invasion of Panama. Although that seemed accidental and motives for some killings were unclear, most apparently were politically motivated or the work of organized crime, the committee said. It did not count killings that clearly were not work-related. The 16 countries cited by the committee as ``cases of concern'' are China, Colombia, Cuba, El Salvador, Iraq, Israel, Kenya, Lebanon, Liberia, Peru, Romania, Singapore, South Africa, the Soviet Union, Sri Lanka and Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Has No Plans to Resign Party Leadership Despite Defeat
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has no plans to step down as leader of the right-wing Likud bloc, despite his government's defeat in a parliamentary no-confidence vote, a Shamir aide said Friday. Shamir met with Likud's government ministers Friday. Housing Minister David Levy and Economics Minister Yitzhak Modai, who have been trying to engineer Shamir's ouster for months, did not attend the session. Labor leader Shimon Peres, Shamir's rival, said he hopes to form a new government with the backing of 70 members of the 120-seat Knesset, or parliament. Some Likud Parliament members suggested Friday Shamir would have to step down as party leader since several leaders of religious parties have accused him of breaking promises to support religious legislation. But asked if Shamir was thinking of resigning, Yossi Achimeir, director of the prime minister's office, replied, ``I didn't even hear a hint coming out of his mouth. He will continue to lead as long as the party wants it.'' Under Israeli law, President Chaim Herzog decides who should form the next government. He scheduled meetings Sunday with Labor and Likud leaders, but Israeli newspapers reported the 66-year-old Peres was the likely choice. Shamir, 74, whose government was Israel's first to be turned out in a no-confidence vote, remains caretaker prime minister until a new government is formed. That could take months. Both Labor and Likud already have begun wooing ultra-Orthodox religious parties that hold the balance of power. Achimeir conceded Likud's chances for leading a new government were ``not bright'' after five of the six Knesset member from the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party abstained in Thursday's vote, giving Labor its victory. He said he did not exclude a challenge to Shamir's leadership. ``I believe that Mr. Shamir will eventually decide to resign because he cannot form a narrow government as long as Agudat Israel opposes his leadership,'' said lawmaker Tzahi Hanegbi, referring to an ultra-Orthdox faction that backed Labor on Thursday. Hanegbi said possible replacements could be Levy, former Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, or Foreign Minister Moshe Arens. Sharon quit the Cabinet last month to protest the government's peace policies. Arens is a protege of Shamir and would be a compromise replacement. Opposition to Shamir was expected from Likud rebels such as Levy and Sharon, but even some of the prime minister's supporters raised the prospect of replacing him. ``Concerning Yitzhak Shamir, I think that's something he must decide and I think we will speak about it in the next couple of days,'' said Ehud Olmert, the government's Arab affairs adviser and formerly a staunch Shamir backer. The dispute between Likud and Labor was over Secretary of State James A. Baker III's plan for Israel to accept east Jerusalem Arabs and deported Palestinians in a delegation to talk peace with Israel. Shamir had argued that including them might threaten Israel's sovereignty over Jerusalem. Likud has 40 seats and Labor 39 in the Knesset. With the backing of the 11 Agudat and Shas lawmakers and 15 allies in left-wing and Arab parties, Labor could have a majority of 65. It was not immediately clear how Peres would attain the backing of 70 members. Thursday's vote was 60-55 against Shamir.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Rice Display Removed, Automakers Agree to Boost U.S. Purchases
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials removed a small amount of American rice from an international food exhibition near Tokyo on Friday at the request of the Japanese government, because the rice violated Japanese trade law, officials said. Also Friday, two Japanese automakers pledged to boost their purchases of American semiconductors after the U.S. commerce secretary took his appeal for more balanced trade directly to company executives. In an indication of the sensitive issue of Japan's trade surplus with the United States, a dispute broke out in the Cabinet over U.S. demands that Japan repeal a law that protects its small businesses. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu cut off debate, and it was unclear if the issue was resolved. One of the sponsors of the five-day food fair, Nobuo Ogawa, executive vice president of the Japan Management Association, said the American Trade Office ``recalled'' six types of U.S.-made rice displayed at the U.S. Rice Council's booth. Food Agency officials said the display violates the Food Control Law, which bans virtually all imports of rice for sale in Japan. Japanese rice is about four times more expensive than U.S. rice. But the country insists on self-sufficiency in rice, its staple food. ``We, as the organizers, were annoyed by the rice exhibit that is in conflict with the Japanese law,'' Ogawa said. A U.S. Embasssy spokesman said there had been no public sampling or tasting of the rice, which was ``displayed only to illustrate the different varieties of rice available in the United States.'' Officials at the Rice Council's booth and the American Trade Office were not available for comment despite repeated telephone calls. In 1988, both houses of Japan's Parliament unanimously adopted a non-binding resolution against opening the nation's rice market to foreign imports. It said rice production affects local communities, the preservation of land and Japanese culture. Aout 900 companies and groups from 41 countries are participating in the international food exhibition, ``Foodex,'' an annual event in Chiba state 21 miles east of Tokyo. U.S. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher spent four days in Tokyo to follow up on talks two weeks ago between President Bush and Kaifu in Palm Springs, Calif. Mosbacher received ``very positive'' responses to his direct appeal to executives from Toyota, Nissan, Honda, Matsushita, Sanyo, Sharp, Victor, and Sony to buy more U.S. semiconductors, U.S. officials said. The president of Honda Motor Co., Tadashi Kume, pledged his company would buy 10 percent of its semiconductors from the United States in 1991, said the assistant U.S. secretary for trade development, Michael Skarzynski. That would be an increase from 1 percent last year. Toyota Motor Corp.'s president, Shoichiro Toyoda, said his company would set a goal of buying 25 percent of its general-purpose semiconductors from American manufacturers, the officials said. Such high-volume general-purpose chips are generally less profitable than custom-made semiconductors. In a 1986 semiconductor agreement, Japan and the United States set a 20 percent goal for foreign chips in the Japanese market by June 1991. U.S. officials say the figure was a commitment by Japan, while Japanese officials say it was only a target. So far, Japanese firms have boosted their foreign chip procurement to 12.9 percent from 8.6 percent in 1986. Skarzynski said ``U.S. executives also have to do their part'' to work for a higher market share. In recent trade talks, the U.S. government demanded that Japan change aspects of its economy to help reduce its $49 billion trade surplus. The Cabinet dispute Friday indicated that a consensus within the government on trade issues has yet to be reached. The dispute, between the ministers of trade and home affairs, is over how to handle U.S. demands that Japan review legislation regulating large retail store openings. Under current law, Japan protects small businesses by limiting where large stores are built. U.S. officials say an increase in large stores would boost sales of imported goods because they generally stock more foreign products than small stores. Home Affairs Minister Keiwa Okuda criticized the trade minister, Kabun Muto, for proposing that the law only be modified. He told the Cabinet that Japan should eliminate the law, a Home Affairs Ministry official said. Kaifu cut short the discussion before Muto could respond, and the three met afterward, the official said. It was not clear whether the dispute was resolved. Cabinet disputes are seldom reported in the Japanese media, but this one was covered prominently by television news.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Envoy Says Gorbachev Is Opening Door To Dialogue
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's diplomatic representative to the United States said Friday that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has opened ``a little door'' that will lead to negotiations on the future of his homeland despite the Kremlin's rejection of independence. In an interview in the five-story mansion the Lithuanian legation has continued to occupy throughout the Soviet occupation of his homeland, Charge d'Affaires Stasyz Lozoraitis welcomed Gorbachev's call for ``a respectful dialogue with the people of Lithuania.'' ``This is already a little door he is opening,'' Lozoraitis said. ``It will take some time. It will take some pressure. But with the help of the respectful dialogue we will go on and we will try to convince Gorbachev.'' The veteran diplomat said he believed the resolution passed Thursday by the Soviet parliament invalidating Lithuania's declaration of independence would have little effect. ``We had expected a rather harsh reaction,'' he said. ``What is said publicly I don't think has a very great importance. Probably something else is going on, and probably Mr. Gorbachev will understand that there is no other way. We must sit down and negotiate.'' Lozoraitis said the negotiations should embrace the other Baltic republics, Latvia and Estonia, which also have maintained legations in the United States since their countries were swallowed up by Josef Stalin in 1940 as part of the Nazi-Soviet pact. ``Gorbachev has accepted the idea that the Baltic states have been illegally occupied, so the logical consequence should be that he accepts the idea of these three states separating themselves,'' he said. Lithuania declared its independence March 11 and immediately called for negotiations with Moscow, but Gorbachev said, ``We cannot talk about negotiations. You carry out negotiations with a foreign country.'' The United States has never recognized the forced annexation of the three republics, but has indicated it will not grant full diplomatic recognition to Lithuania unless negotiations with Moscow give it the attributes of a nation-state. ``It will be a tough negotiation,'' said Lazoraitis. ``Gorbachev mentioned mutual, respectful dialogue. All right, I hope the dialogue will really be respectful. We will not get violent. We will not get disrespectful. We have shown we are a peaceful people. When Gorbachev came to Lithuania, he could just walk in the streets and nobody did anything to him although we don't like him very much as long as he is in Lithuania, or his troops.''

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Win Praise for Helping To Shelter Wildlife
LaserPhoto CU1
DOC.TEXT: A colorful male pheasant darts into a cornfield and several hens leave the grassy roadside ditch to fly into the blue sky over Glenn Kingdon's farm, a model for wildlife preservation. ``Five years ago, you wouldn't see a pheasant nowhere,'' Kingdon said as he walked through rows of pine trees planted to protect the birds and rows of corn left to feed them. ``It's a lot different now.'' Now, he sees 75 to 100 pheasants on his 420-acre central Illinois farm 40 miles east of Peoria _ and it didn't happen by chance. Kingdon buys baby pheasants, raises and releases them to an environment that includes both shelter and food. In addition to planting trees and leaving a few rows of corn unharvested, he limits mowing of roadside ditches and fence rows. He was one of 168 people honored under Successful Farming magazine's ``Farming in the Flyways'' program for providing habitat for waterfowl and wildlife within their agricultural operations. These farmers have established wetlands, planted windbreaks, preserved virgin prairies and adopted other conservation practices _ sometimes at their own expense and sometimes with government financial help. ``Instead of mowing or burning, we preserve natural areas to provide nesting spots for birds and small wildlife,'' said Cherrie Anderson, who was among those honored. ``And, we plant sweetcorn and leave some sunflowers standing to feed deer, raccoons, birds, whatever comes.'' She and her husband, Bernard, of Warwick, N.D., farm 1,000 acres near Devil's Lake, and devote about 300 acres in ``little pieces here and there'' to geese and ducks and other wildlife. ``The main goal of Farming in the Flyways was to find out from farmers themselves what wildlife conservation practices and policies actually are working out on the land,'' said John Walter, conservation editor for the Des Moines-based magazine. The program was announced a year ago, and farmers were invited to send in descriptions of their conservation efforts. The magazine selected winners, and profiles of the farmers with the best ideas were published in the February issue. Two private conservation groups _ Ducks Unlimited Inc. and the National Fish & Wildlife Foundation _ and American Cyanamid, which makes farm chemicals, cooperated in the program to provide awards to the farmers. The top prize, an heirloom shotgun worth an estimated $7,000, was presented to Ray McCormick of Vincennes, Ind., who floods a 112-acre grain field in the fall for waterfowl and plants soybeans into standing wheat to encourage quail. ``It's one of the best examples of how to increase net return while conserving soil, water and wildlife,'' McCormick said. The ``wheat cover crop makes excellent nesting habitat, while helping control weeds and soil erosion.'' Rick Van Etten of a Long Grove-based conservation group called Ducks Unlimited said the flight index for waterfowl has dropped from 100 million birds in the mid-1970s to about 65 million, as land plowed for farming has replaced nesting areas for wildlife. Now, he said, some farmers are leading the effort to establish and protect wildlife habitat. Kingdon, who estimates he spends less than $1,000 a year on his pheasant program, said farmers need to change their practices if they want to preserve wildlife for their grandchildren to enjoy. ``We tore out all the fences, the tree breaks and we mowed the roadsides like front yards,'' he said. ``We brought this on ourselves.'' Mrs. Anderson said she and her husband have done ``common-sense things'' and hope other farmers will follow their example. ``It's nothing expensive _ we don't have the money for that,'' she said. ``Farming in the Flyways publicized practical ideas that anybody could use.''

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Officer Pleads Guilty to Weapons Export
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian military officer pleaded guilty Friday in federal court to charges that he attempted to export of weapons without a license. First Lt. Ricardo Petersson Bernal, 26, was arrested Sept. 28 when U.S. Customs Service agents found two semiautomatic rifles, a 9mm semiautomatic pistol, a 12-gauge shotgun, 1,000 rounds of ammunition and a smoke grenade in his luggage checked for an Avianca flight to Bogota, Colombia. Petersson said at an earlier hearing that he was taking the weapons to Colombia for people who wanted them for their own protection. A month before his arrest, the Colombian government started a nationwide attack on drug cartels, triggering widespread bombings, kidnappings and other violence by traffickers. Sentencing was not immediately scheduled. Petersson's attorney, Milton Hirsch, said that under sentencing guidelines his client probably would not get more than 10 months.

DOC.HEAD: Election at a Glance
With AM-Germany
DOC.TEXT: Here is a glance at what is involved in the East German elections Sunday.
WHAT'S AT STAKE: _400 seats in the national parliament, which will be elected for a four-year term. _The majority party, or a possible coalition to run the next government.

ELIGIBLE VOTERS AND RULES: _About 12.3 million voters will choose one of the 24 parties or alliances listed on the official ballot. _All East German citizens who have reached 18 years of age are eligible to vote. _No voting by mail is allowed. The election was moved up at short notice from May 6 to March 18, which did not leave enough time to work out the mail voting rules. _Ballots will be marked in polling booths to permit secrecy of voters.

ELECTION SUPERVISION: _A 30-member watchdog commission made up of members named by the various parties and groups competing in the election was appointed by the old parliament to oversee the balloting.

MAIN PARTIES OR ALLIANCES RUNNING: _Party of Democratic Socialism, for former Commmunist Party, which still claims about 650,000 members. Party chairman: Gregor Gysi. Top candidate: Premier Hans Modrow, head of East Germany's caretaker government. Latest polls predict it will get about 18 percent of the vote. _Social Democratic Party, with about 100,000 members and widespread grass-roots support. Headed by Ibrahim Boehme, who is also the party's top candidate. Latest forecast: about 33 percent of the vote. _Alliance for Germany, with about 230,000 members, is comprised of the Christian Democratic Union, headed by Lothar de Maiziere, Democratic Awakening, headed by Rainer Eppelmann, and German Social Union, headed by Hans-Wilhelm Ebeling. Eppelmann is considered favorite to be the top candidate for the alliance, which is expected to get about 30 percent of the vote. _Other parties, including the Alliance of Free Democrats, made up of the Liberal Democratic Party and Free Democrats; and Alliance 90, a leftist grouping of New Forum, Democracy Now and the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights, are expected to split the remaining vote.

WEST GERMAN INFLUENCE: _All major West German politicians have campaigned with speeches and appearances in East Germany, including Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who backs the conservative Alliance for Germany. _Key campaigner for East Germany's Social Democratic Party was former chancellor Willy Brandt, architect of West Germany's improved ties with the Soviet bloc starting in the late 1960s and highly popular in both Germanys. _Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, of the centrist Free Democrats in Bonn, made election rally appearances for the Alliance of Free Democrats.

ISSUES: _The main issue is unification with West Germany or whether East Germany should continue as a separate state. The Party of Democratic Socialism and small far-left parties and groups are against quick unity while saying they can foresee it happening eventually. _The Social Democrats, Alliance for Germany, and Alliance of Free Democrats want rapid unification.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls for Peace in Northern Ireland
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, issuing an appeal for peace in Northern Ireland on the eve of St. Patrick's Day, said Friday that there's ``no place for violence'' in that nation. The president made brief remarks on the continuing strife in Northern Ireland as he received a bowl of shamrocks from visiting Irish Deputy Prime Minister Brian Lenihan at a Rose Garden ceremony. ``There is one thing all of us here, all Americans, are united in, and that is our desire for peace and tranquility in Northern Ireland,'' Bush said. ``We can't forget the suffering and the tragedy that plagues St. Patrick's Island and there's no place for violence in creating a new future for Northern Ireland.'' Lenihan presented the shamrocks to Bush, telling him ``the shamrock itself, three leaves on one stem, is a symbol of unity _ the essential unity between the American and the Irish peoples that has been celebrated in this manner since the time of the first president of the United States, George Washington.'' Bush, wearing a bright green tie and a gray suit, reached into the bowl and scooped out a handful of shamrocks. He stuffed them into in his breast pocket like a handkerchief. First lady Barbara Bush, wearing a green dress, also attended the brief ceremony. ``Your children are making Ireland young again, creating hope and opportunity for the future, rebuilding a strong economuy and a peaceful existence,'' Bush told Lenihan. ``Here in the United States, 43 million Americans are of Irish ancestry and I expect many more wish that they were of Irish ancestry.'' While Bush's ancestry is decidedly not Irish, he proclaimed: ``Once you've had a glass of Guiness with a man in Ireland, as I have with Brian Lenihan, why, you're friends.'' Bush's ancestors were among a small group of English Protestant dissenters who lived in the Netherlands for more than a decade before setting sail for America in the early 17th century. It was Bush's second St. Patrick's day event in as many days. On Thursday, he joined 62 lawmakers in a St. Patrick's Day lunch in the House of Representatives sponsored by House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash.

DOC.HEAD: Genetic Testing May Determine Likelihood of Cancer Spread
DOC.TEXT: Genetic tests on women with breast cancer could determine the risk of recurrence for some patients, improving the chance of treating women generally thought to be safe, a researcher said Friday. Cancer specialists also report that the use of lumpectomy and radiation therapy appear to be promising alternatives to breast removal for a common form of early breast cancer. The scientists' findings are being presented this week at the American College of Radiology's 24th annual National Conference on Breast Cancer. Genetic, or DNA, tests are run on some women, usually those with large tumors, to reveal whether cells are dividing rapidly and the cancer is expected to spread, said Dr. Eva Rubin, chief of the mammography section at the University of Alabama in Birmingham. But a new study shows that similar genetic irregularities indicating aggressive cancer show up in large and small tumors, a finding that could signal doctors to begin additional treatment to fight recurrence, Rubin said. Currently, women with small cancerous breast tumors that have not spread to the lymph nodes have surgery or a lumpectomy with radiation therapy, Rubin said. Most do not receive follow-up chemotherapy or hormonal therapy. But 30 percent of those patients later die from recurring cancer, she said. The Birmingham test was designed to determine if DNA test results were different for larger tumors that can be felt, and non-palpable cancerous tumors, she said. ``Of the 21 palpable and 24 non-palpable cancers we reviewed, we found that DNA characteristics of small tumors are the same as larger tumors,'' Rubin said. A DNA test on tissue taken in a biopsy can show if the cells are rapidly dividing and if the DNA has more or fewer chromosomes than the normal 46. If the tumor is growing and the DNA test is abnormal, the patient's cancer is likely to be aggressive, Rubin said. The study does not mean that all patients with breast cancer should have the DNA test to find out whether the tumor is aggressive, Rubin said, adding that more research and tests are needed before recommendations are made. Yale University researchers, meanwhile, said they found that a lumpectomy _ removing a cancerous tumor and some surrounding tissue _ combined with radiation therapy can be a good alternative to a mastectomy. Traditionally, the treatment for early cancer limited to the ducts in the breast has been to remove the breast, said Dr. Bruce Haffty of Yale's department of therapeutic radiology. But a study of 58 patients at New Haven Hospital shows a high success rate using the less radical surgical procedure, he said. Only three of the patients had recurring cancer. The women studied had received treatment from two to 10 years earlier. The median follow-up time was four years after treatment. ``Though we feel it is highly unlikely we have compromised patients in using this more conservative treatment, we will need to follow them for 10 to 20 years,'' he said. If the cancer returns after a breast-saving lumpectomy is performed, a mastectomy could still be an option, Haffty said. Some physicians are reluctant to use the breast-saving treatment for early duct cancer, believing that the breast should be removed if there is any chance that the cancer could recur. The Yale study so far does not bear out this concern, Haffty said. ``A main message here is that it's important for women to be screened by mammography so these tumors can be picked up earlier, treated more conservatively and this will give the patient a much better prognosis,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Marcos Leaves Home in Exile to Attend Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with details from hearing. Picks up 6th graf, `Mrs. Marcos is...' SUBS final graf to add explanation of mourning period.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY26
DOC.TEXT: Former Philippines first lady Imelda Marcos clutched the arm of her lawyer as she walked stoically into a Manhattan courthouse today for a hearing about her racketeering trial, which begins next week. Mrs. Marcos, with her head held high, walked up the steps of U.S. District Court with attorney Gerald Spence. She did not speak to the crowd of photographers and reporters that lined the steps. Once inside the courtroom, Mrs. Marcos sat at the defense table with her lawyers. She wore a black dress with a black scarf around her neck and held a black lace handkerchief. At the hearing, also attended by her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, lawyers discussed with U.S. District Judge John Keenan procedures for jury selection starting Tuesday. Spence expressed concern about finding jurors who wouldn't have preconceived opinions about Mrs. Marcos. ``Mrs. Marcos and her late husband have received much unfavorable press,'' Spence said. ``She has been tried and convicted in the press.'' He asked that open-ended questions be posed to prospective jurors about what they have read about Mrs. Marcos and their attitudes about ``a reportedly wealthy, notorious world leader.'' Keenan did not agree to any of the specific questions proposed by Spence but assured him that he would conduct a through examination of prospective jurors. ``I want a fair and impartial jury,'' the judge said. Mrs. Marcos, 60, arrived at LaGuardia Airport on Thursday on a commercial flight from Honolulu, where she has lived since she and her late husband left the Philippines after a popular revolt in 1986. Mrs. Marcos is charged with racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. The indictment says she helped in the illegal transfer of more than $160 million allegedly embezzled from the Philippine treasury to buy Manhattan real estate. It also accuses her of defrauding $165 million from banking institutions to finance the properties. Khashoggi, who will be tried for mail fraud and obstruction of justice, is accused of helping the Marcoses hide their ownership in the properties through false documents. Ferdinand Marcos, who was the central figure in the October 1988 indictment, died Sept. 28 in exile in Hawaii. The traditional mourning period in the Philippines, in which widows wear black, is one year.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party: From All-Powerful To Political Outcast
DOC.TEXT: When 12-year-old Michael Thiel, son of a top Communist Party official, stood up for his father in school recently, he was beaten up by classmates who broke his glasses. It has been a long way down for the party that ruled East Germany like a fiefdom for 40 years until its leaders were toppled by a popular rebellion in the fall. ``There is a lot of hatred against the party, and the children pick it up from their parents,'' said Michael's father Frank, deputy chief of the Communist Party in Leipzig. The city is an anti-communist stronghold where the protests that led to the nationwide movement began. Nearly 2 million party faithful have fled the party since the uprising. The 600,000 who remain have renamed themselves the Party of Democratic Socialism and have frantically tried to convince voters before Sunday's election that they have moved from dogma to democracy. ``We no longer want to shape man in the image of socialism, we want to create a kind of socialism that man can live with,'' said the 38-year-old Thiel, a physics professor and party member for 20 years. But most East Germans have had enough after four decades of secret police terror, corruption, travel restrictions and empty store shelves. They are bitter about wasted lives in a drab society that squashed all individual ambitions. ``We don't trust the Communists anymore,'' said Andreas Orlik, a 28-year-old plumber from Leipzig. Orlik stood in a crowd of 300,000 in the main Karl Marx Square, cheering West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his promises of ``affluence for all'' in a united Germany. Orlik said he would vote conservative in hopes that a free-market economy will finally reward his hard work. ``For the past eight years I have lived in a damp apartment with crumbling walls, and they wouldn't even let me install a bathtub even though I'm a plumber,'' Orlik said. ``I worked overtime for three years to buy a 17-year-old car on the black market for 10,000 marks ($1,960).'' The average monthly salary is 1,100 marks, about $215. Such sentiments are shared by many East Germans. The most optimistic forecasts say the revamped Communist Party will gain only 18 percent of the vote Sunday. Party leaders are aware of their outcast status and acknowledged that they expect to be relegated to the political hinterlands. ``A Strong Opposition for the Disadvantaged,'' read one campaign poster in Leipzig. Thiel said the party's main objective in the new 400-Parliament would be to block a reunification plan under which East Germany would agree to adopt West Germany's constitution. Such a proposal is backed by the conservative Alliance for Germany, a likely coalition partner in a new government. ``We want to negotiate unification as a sovereign state, and not simply be swallowed up by the West Germans,'' said Thiel. Other leftist parties share this position, but even they have refused to negotiate with the Democratic Socialists on a possible alliance in Parliament. ``The PDS emerged from the Communist Party, and therefore the other parties keep their distance,'' said Thiel. He said his main reason for joining the Communists as a teen-ager was to ``belong.'' The party is not only being shunned in the political arena. Party members, accustomed to a privileged life under the old regime, now face widespread hostility and even violent attacks. Democratic Socialist volunteers have been beaten up, and windows of campaign headquarters have been smashed. ``Today, I can't tell anybody that I'm in the party,'' said Mathias Rulf, a Leipzig police officer patrolling in Karl Marx Square. He said he was one of just a few party members left in the once solidly communist police force. ``These are lawless times,'' muttered Rulf, in his 30's. He watched the Kohl supporters waving West German flags and streaming into the square for the rally. Party Chief Gregor Gysi has warned of a ``new intolerance,'' citing complaints by high school graduates that they are being barred from university because of party membership. In the past, party membership was a virtual prerequisite for admission to a university or job advancement. Amid this atmosphere of hostility, the Democratic Socialists are trying hard to show voters they are no longer a party run by dour and dogmatic septuagenarians. In a publicity stunt, the 42-year-old Gysi performed a parachute jump, the first in his life. He quipped afterward: ``You see from above, how beautiful this country is, and that there is no reason to just give it away.'' The party's slogans are upbeat by East German standards, borrowing freely from Western commercials. ``Don't worry - take Gysi,'' said one. Thiel claimed the changes are not just cosmetic. Most old-time functionaries have quit or been fired since the peaceful revolution to make room for rank-and-file members with new ideas, he said. But both Thiel and the party's top candidate in Leipzig, Dietmar Keller, were already functionaries under the old regime.

DOC.HEAD: Former Official Pleads Guilty to Bribery
DOC.TEXT: An administrator of humanitarian aid to the Nicaraguan rebels pleaded guilty Friday to taking $93,000 in bribes to help a New York businessman get $2.6 million in consulting contracts. Donald F. Enos could be sentenced to up to 30 years in prison and fined $279,000 for his guilty plea to two bribery counts in U.S. District Court in Alexandria, Va. Enos, deputy director of the Agency for International Development's task force on Central American aid, admitted taking the money since 1985 from George Kraus, owner of a New York-based consulting company, according to court documents. No charges have been filed against Kraus, although he agreed Feb. 12 to plead guilty to one count of bribery and cooperate with the government investigation, according to court documents. Kraus has not appeared in court to formally enter his guilty plea, said AID spokesman Jerry Lipson. Investigators videotaped Kraus handing Enos $2,000 in cash during a Feb. 15 meeting the two men had in Tegucigalpa, Honduras. During the discussion that was secretly recorded by AID investigators, the two men said the payment was part of a $33,000 bribe, according to court documents. In return for the bribe money, Enos arranged for Kraus International Co. to obtain $2.6 million worth of contracts from AID, court documents said. Those included a $600,000 management consulting contract for the provision of health care to the Nicaraguan Contras. Enos also admitted ``finagling'' the extension of a contract as part of an arrangement to split the resulting $30,000 profit with Kraus, according to the documents. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton scheduled sentencing for May 25. Enos, of Reston, Va., was director of AID's Office of Human Resources and Humanitarian Assistance from 1985-87. He then became deputy director of the agency's Task Force for Humanitarian Assistance for Central America. Enos agreed to cooperate with the government's continuing investigation. He was placed on administrative leave with pay from his $72,000-a-year job, AID said. The agency said it would take steps to dismiss Enos.

DOC.HEAD: California Supreme Court Refuses To Halt Execution
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court today rejected an appeal to halt an execution that would be the first carried out by California since 1967. Double murderer Robert Alton Harris, scheduled to be executed April 3, can renew his appeal in federal court in San Diego. The state Supreme Court unanimously denied a hearing on new evidence submitted by the defense about Harris' mental condition, including a psychologist's diagnosis of organic brain damage. The evidence also included a statement from Harris' brother, a key prosecution witness at his trial, that Harris did not plan to rob or kill his two victims. In papers filed with the court, Daniel Harris said his brother was in a dazed state the day he fatally shot two San Diego teen-agers, whose car he later used in a bank robbery. Defense lawyers also claimed Daniel Harris' confession about the July 1978 crime was coerced and should have been barred as evidence against his brother.

DOC.HEAD: Non-Profit Organizations Share Experiences From All Over The World
DOC.TEXT: It's perhaps the oldest cliche in the charity business: Give a man a fish, you feed him for a day; teach him to fish, and you feed him forever. But the cliche took on a certain poignancy when Nina Belyaeva, of the Soviet Union, used it Friday during a two-day international conference on non-profit groups. Belyaeva, one of 400 participants from around the world, was referring the new growth of the voluntary ``third sector'' in her homeland, where state economic power is diminishing and private industry encouraged. Belyaeva says her country's fledging grassroots organizations must acquire Western technical expertise in philanthropy _ how to raise funds, how to organize, how to network _ not necessarily Western grants. ``What our independent sector needs now is to learn how to fish,'' she said during a panel discussion that included representatives from non-profit sectors in West Germany, Argentina, Australia and Japan. ``All Eastern Europeans are saying that,'' said Virginia A. Hodgkinson, vice president of research for Independent Sector, a 10-year-old non-profit coalition of 650 corporate, foundation and voluntary organizations, which sponsored the conference. ``It makes a whole lot of sense,'' she said in an interview. ``If you suppress the voluntary sector, then only a certain few people develop those skills. So what is necessary is to share experiences and to have experiences.'' Even for U.S. groups, long used to writing grant applications and staging yearly fund-raising drives, contact with the world non-profit community ``is a very self-renewing experience for all of us,'' Hodgkinson said. The eighth annual conference brought in representatives from organizations such as the Girl Scouts, environmental activists, Bible studies societies and charitable arms of major corporations. Tadashi Yamamoto of the Japan Center for International Exchange told a panel of his efforts to involve Japanese corporations in the United States in philanthropic actions that go beyond public relations. When the other panelists were asked if they would welcome Japanese foundations operating in their countries, all answered yes. The panelists spoke of various frustrations in operating charities in their countries, including encouraging government tax deductions. ``In Argentina, there is a system of deductions for non-profit organizations,'' said Andres Thomapson, of the National Council of Scientific Research in Argentina. ``The trouble is, there isn't a tax system.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans to Join Observers at East German Elections
DOC.TEXT: The government of East Germany has invited international observers, including a team from the United States, to monitor the national elections this Sunday, the State Department announced on Friday. Margaret Tutwiler, the department's spokeswoman, said communist Premier Hans Modrow accepted a suggestion made in Prague last month by Secretary of State James A. Baker III to permit observers to watch the election for a new 400-seat parliament. ``We commend this initiative of the German Democratic Republic and hope other countries in the area holding elections in the next few months will follow suit,'' said Tutwiler. She said the observers will come from the 34 members of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which was founded to monitor compliance with the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki accords which settled Europe's borders. Special passes will be issued to observers by the East German government to facilitate access to polling sites across the country. The American observer team will consist of staff members at the U.S. Embassy and six members of Congress. They lawmakers are: Sen. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee; and Reps. John Bryant, D-Texas; Jack Buechner, R-Mo.; Bill Richardson, D-N.M.: James Sensenbrenner Jr., R-Wis.; and David Skaggs, D-Colo. About 12.3 million East Germans are eligible to vote in Sunday's elections.

DOC.HEAD: Precede HARTFORD
Striker Arrested in Shooting of Greyhound Bus
With PM-Greyhound Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with court appearance, add details and quotes. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: A striking bus driver was charged today with shooting a Greyhound bus after he was traced through a videotape of pickets, police said. Roger D. Cawtra, 44, of Stratford was ordered held on $100,000 bond after he appeared in Superior Court in West Hartford. He was arrested at his home at about 7:15 a.m. on charges of criminal mischief, reckless endangerment and unlawful discharge of a firearm in Monday's shooting on Interstate 84. His arrest was the first in more than a dozen shooting attacks on Greyhound buses nationwide since the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions struck March 2, said company spokesman George Gravely. ``I will not tolerate such acts,'' Judge Allen Smith said before setting bond. The judge barred Cawtra from being within a mile of any Greyhound bus terminals in Connecticut. Cawtra, who has driven for Greyhound for three years, has denied knowing anything about the shooting, according to a police affidavit. Cawtra was arrested in the shooting of a Greyhound bus Monday in Farmington as it headed to Hartford from New York. The luggage compartment was struck by a bullet fired from a passing vehicle. None of the 19 passengers was injured. ``If that projectile had hit the wheel of the bus, we could have had a tragedy,'' Smith said. ``When I heard of the incident, I was appalled. I detest strike violence.'' Cawtra was arrested after Carl F. Harris, who was driving the bus that was shot Monday, watched a videotape of picketing Greyhound workers, police said. Cawtra did not see his assailant's face, but recognized his size, build and car on the tape, and a .380-caliber casing was found on the floor of a car of the same model rented by Cawtra, police said. When police told him about the casing, Cawtra told them he was a gun dealer, the affidavit said. He turned over eight weapons to police, including three semiautomatics, four revolvers and one rifle. None of the weapons was .380-caliber, the affidavit said. Workers on the picket line at Hartford's Union Station Friday expressed disbelief that Cawtra had been arrested, saying they thought he was being used as a scapegoat. ``I just don't believe it,'' said Charles True, a Greyhound driver for 17 years who said he has known Cawtra for three. ``He is just going to be made a scapegoat to slow down the violence nationwide. I don't know any Greyhound employee who would do something like that.'' The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions represents 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 other workers.

DOC.HEAD: Terry Anderson's Fifth Year of Captivity Marked by Friends, Relatives
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Terry Anderson's family and friends somberly marked his fifth year as a captive in Lebanon today as President Bush pledged to pursue ``all legitimate opportunities'' to win the release of the hostages. ``I intend to keep open lines of communications with all parties, including Iran, who have influence over hostage takers,'' the president said in a letter to Peggy Say, Anderson's sister. Mrs. Say met privately with Bush and his wife at the White House, then addressed a ceremony across the street at Lafayette Park. Directing her remarks to the captors of her brother thousands of miles away, she said: ``You complain that your story has not been told and yet the man who would tell it has been chained to a basement wall for five years. ... ``I don't want to punish them. I don't want to hunt them down. I just want my brother back. But I'm not going to pay them for doing so,'' she said. Anderson, 42, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held of the American hostages in Lebanon. All told, 18 Westerners are believed to be captives there, including eight Americans. Speaking at the sun-splashed ceremony, Louis D. Boccardi, president and general manager of The Associated Press, said, ``At this point the greatest gift we can give him is to press on, to not falter, to find an honorable way to get the job done. If you know Terry, that's what he's thinking, too.'' Bush did not attend, but said in a radio interview that ``every day I'm president I have a heavy heart when I think of the hostages.'' In an interview with National Public Radio, Bush called Mrs. Say a ``courageous woman. ... She has suffered for five long years and I just got to thinking that Barbara and I would like to hold her hand and say, `Stay with it, you're courageous and we respect you.''' In comments earlier to reporters Bush declined to say he was optimistic that any hostages would be released soon. Others at the observance included Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y.; Dan Rather, CBS television anchorman; and the Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, a former hostage who spent time locked up with Anderson before his release in the summer of 1986. Rather described the gathering as one of ``remembrance and love.'' While many Americans feel powerless about helping the hostages, the ceremony was a symbol that ``we are doing at least a little something. ... We will not rest until the hostages are home,'' he said. In contrast with the day's spring-like weather, Anderson has been held ``in terrible isolation'' and has endured brutality, Rather said. Among other things he has not seen his daughter, who was born after he was captured. Bush told reporters earlier in the day he would do ``everything I can to get those hostages out of there.'' Bush, viewing cherry blossoms along the Tidal Basin with his wife, said the plight of the hostages ``concerns me every day I've alive.'' ``I don't want to get the hopes up through a lot of speculation and have them dashed down,'' the president said. ``I respect the families too much to do that.'' No Greater Love, a Washington-based humanitarian organization, sponsored today's ceremony, as it has other observances on behalf of the hostages. The outdoor Washington ceremony was one of several observances of the captvity suffered by Anderson and the other hostages. In New York, Anderson's friends and colleagues attended a Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. In Tokyo, the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan was holding a ceremony tonight to honor Anderson, who was assigned to the AP Tokyo bureau from January 1977 to August 1981. Members of the club were to raise symbolically empty glasses in a toast to Anderson, a salute that planners said also would be made at the National Press Club in Washington, D.C., and at the Association de la Presse International in Brussels. In Beirut, local television stations planned to show a videotape today of Anderson's 4-year-old daughter, Sulome, whom he has never seen. The child shows off her ballet dancing and delivers a message for her father and his captors, saying, ``I love you, Daddy, come home. Please come home.'' In his letter to Mrs. Say that decried Anderson's ``merciless imprisonment,'' Bush said he continued to seek the immediate, unconditional and safe release of the hostages. ``As a further signal of commitment to resolving this tragedy, I intend to keep open lines of communications with all parties, including Iran, who have influence over hostage takers. Please be assured that your government will take advantage of all legitimate opportunities to obtain the safe release of all of our hostages.'' Separately, Vice President Dan Quayle said recent stories suggesting the hostages might be freed were counterproductive. ``We hope and pray they will be released,'' Quayle told reporters in his office. ``I have no new information to shed.'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We don't have any breakthroughs we can report.'' Said Bush: ``I'm going to do everything I can to get those hostages out of there, sometimes privately, sometimes publicly.'' Bush said he had not discussed the hostages with former President Jimmy Carter, who recently met with officials in Syria to try to get the captives freed. The president called Carter's visit ``unofficial.'' In a letter published by seven Beirut newspapers, Sulome's mother, Madeleine Bassil, told Anderson that she and the girl also feel like hostages. ``We are in as much captivity, Terry, only our living space is bigger here and it's shared by millions,'' she said. Anderson was kidnapped on a street in Beirut on March 16, 1985, after playing an early-morning game of tennis. Since then, he has been held in windowless rooms in the slums of Beirut, according to other hostages. Sometimes he has been chained and blindfolded. During his five years as a hostage, Anderson's daughter has been born and his father and brother have died. ``Who would have ever thought in their wildest nightmares that this would last so long?'' asked Mrs. Say, who has traveled to the Middle East and Europe trying to free her brother.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Prepare For First Free Elections
DOC.TEXT: Political parties made their final campaign pitches Friday, two days before East Germans elect their first democratic parliament and complete the transition from 40 years of Communist rule to a democracy. Sunday's first free vote in East German history could also be the last as the two German states rush toward unification. Unification has been a central issue in the election, which was forced on the government by last fall's peaceful rebellion that ousted hard-line Communists, opened borders and led to the creation of opposition parties. The makeup of East Germany's new 400-seat parliament could decide the pace of unification. Some conservatives urge quick unification, while some leftists favor a more cautious approach. All major parties support unification. A nationwide survey published Friday suggested nearly half of all East Germans favor immediate unification, although a third of the electorate would prefer a slower joining of the two Germanys. The poll found that 84 percent favored unification in general, according to a survey conducted jointly by the Central Institute for Youth Research and the Institute for Market Research in Leipzig. The institutes did not say how many people were polled or list the survey's margin of error. About 12.3 million East Germans are eligible to vote Sunday, selecting from 24 parties and groupings. Parties include the Communists, independent groups and those allied with West German political parties. There's even the Beer Drinking Union, which wants better ventilation in beer halls, an end to closing hours and a lifting of strict drunken driving laws. They also don't want too much ``thin'' foreign beer. The Communists ruled East Germany with an iron fist after the country was founded in 1949 from the zone occupied by Soviet troops in World War II. But the Communist leadership collapsed in October under popular pressure and East Germany has been run since then by a broad coalition caretaker government headed by Premier Hans Modrow, a reform-minded Communist. The parliamentary election originally had been scheduled for May, but with state authority collapsing rapidly, the ballot date was moved up. Most political parties staged their final rallies across the country on Friday, following a recommendation by East Germany's election commission. But one or two parties planned rallies for Saturday as well. Dozens of television networks from throughout Europe have set up mobile satellite transmission stations in the parking lot in front of the Parliament building in East Berlin to prepare for election day. Campaign posters are all over East Berlin. One of them, put up by a coalition of conservative parties, proclaims, ``Never Again Socialism.'' East German TV, freed from strict Communist control, has given equal time to election spots by all parties and has interviewed the candidates. Most East German newspapers are backed by political parties and have supported their own candidates. According to recent polls, the front-runners are the leftist Social Democrats and the Alliance for Germany, a coalition of three conservative parties. The alliance has received campaign backing from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is a Christian Democrat. The Social Democrats also have help from West German politicians, who have taken to the road en masse to speak at election rallies. The Bonn government poured in $11.8 million to help major East German parties mount campaigns. The East German election is seen by many as a dress rehearsal for West German elections in December and West German politicians have worked hard to build up an East German base for the time when unification comes. Kohl on Friday called East Germany's elections a ``destiny vote'' on the road to German unification, and promised to protect East Germans from hardship during their nation's economic overhaul. But as Kohl assured East Germans, West German states demanded an immediate halt to special aid for East Germans resettling in the West. Ernst Albrecht, the governor of Lower Saxony, said any future East German resettler ``cannot expect that the states will keep a made bed ready for him.'' More than 130,000 East Germans have moved to West Germany this year alone, joining more than 340,000 who came last year. The exodus is bleeding East Germany's economy, and has seriously burdened West Germany's social security net and job and housing markets.

DOC.HEAD: Show Goes on for Recovering Broadway Star
DOC.TEXT: British actor Michael Ball has not fully recovered from recently diagnosed hepatitis but continues preparing for the Broadway opening of ``Aspects of Love,'' a new musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber. The show's producer, Biddy Hayward, told the Daily News that Ball had complained of tiredness about four weeks ago and saw a doctor. ``The diagnosis was that he was in the final recovery stages of what the doctors have referred to as hepatitis,'' Hayward said. Since the script has Ball bestowing a lot of on-stage kisses, the women of the cast took precautionary blood tests, which came back clean, Hayward said. The show begins previews at Monday at the Broadhurst Theater.

DOC.HEAD: Britain: Outrage at Execution Not Diminished By Robbery Conviction
DOC.TEXT: Britain said Friday its outrage at Iraq's hanging of a London-based journalist was not diminished by news of his robbery conviction, but some lawmakers said it raises questions about his background and whether he was a spy. ``The questions of any incidents in the past are irrelevant to the charges he faced in Iraq,'' said a Foreign Office spokesman. ``Our dismay at the execution has been made quite clear by the government and remains unchanged.'' Iraqi president Saddam Hussein ignored international appeals for clemency and ordered 31-year-old Farzad Bazoft hanged Thursday for spying for Britain and Israel. Britain recalled its ambassador to Iraq, ordered all six Iraqi military trainees out of Britain, and canceled ministerial visits. It did not break diplomatic relations or impose economic sanctions. In Iraq, weekend demonstrations were planned to protest the British measures, government-run newspapers said. The main demonstration will be Saturday outside the British Embassy in downtown Baghdad, the papers said. The ruling Baath Party called on its hundreds of thousands of members to participate. ``This poisoned campaign against Iraq cannot hide the dirtiest type of politicial hypocrisy to undermine Iraq's lawful and sound decision to hang Bazoft,'' the Baath newspaper Al-Thawra said. Condemnation was universal in the Iraqi press, with one newspaper going so far as to claim Britain was an ally of Iran during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war so that it could regain sovereignty over the region. Bazoft, a stateless Iranian, worked as a free-lance reporter for the weekly Observer newspaper and traveled on British papers. He said at his trial that his televised admission of spying was made under duress. He told a British diplomat shortly before his execution that he was just a journalist in search of a scoop when he went to the Al-Iskandaria military complex south of Baghdad in September to check reports of an explosion. Conservative Party lawmaker Rupert Allason, who writes on espionage, said it was ``highly likely'' Bazoft was a spy for Israel but ``highly unlikely'' he was working for British intelligence, in view of his criminal record. ``I think that Bazoft knew that the moment his criminal conviction became known to The Observer he would have been out on his ear. He probably capitalized on the time he was there and his background by offering himself to the Israelis,'' he said. Allason also claimed to reporters that Bazoft ``offered himself four times to the British police in recent months as an informer.'' Scotland Yard made no comment. Observer editor Donald Trelford said: ``If Mr. Allason has a single scrap of evidence that Farzad spied for anyone, let him produce it. If not, he should keep his fevered speculation for his books.'' The mass-circulation Sun newspaper reported the robbery conviction on its front page Friday, quoting unnamed security sources. Bazoft, then a student, was sentenced to 18 months in prison at the Crown Court at Northampton in central England in August 1981 for robbing a savings and loan office of $764. The prosecution said he walked into the office and threatened to blow up the building. He was carrying a fake bomb. The journalist's landlady, Penny Brain, said he robbed the money to pay his rent. ``He robbed the building ... in the morning, paid me what he owed me at lunchtime and shortly afterward the police took him away,'' she recalled. Freed after a year with remission for good behavior, Bazoft won an appeal against deportation on grounds his life would be in danger in Iran. Conservative lawmaker Anthony Beaumont-Dark said: ``There now arises an incredible story of mystery and enigma surrounding the background of this fellow.'' Beaumont-Dark said ``nothing alters the cruelty of the sentence carried out by this inhuman regime.'' But he said it was ``highly irresponsible'' of the Observer to send an Iranian-born journalist to Iraq on such a dangerous assignment. Meanwhile, five opposition Labor Party lawmakers urged Britain and the European Community to impose economic sanctions and an arms embargo on Iraq, saying it has one of the world's worst human rights records. British companies have lucrative contracts in Iraq, which is rebuilding following the Persian Gulf war with Iran. The Foreign Office said Friday that Bazoft sent a final message of apology to British nurse Daphne Parish, 53, who was sentenced to 15 years in prison for driving him to the military complex. Trelford said publication of the conviction and the allegation that he spied ``obviously helps the Iraqis justify their bestial act.'' Michael Mifsud, a journalist and friend of Bazoft, claimed on Independent Television News: ``Somebody, somewhere, is trying to tone down public reaction in his favor for the purposes of maintaining a degree of stability in the Iraq-U.K. situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Steinle Resigns as UPI President
DOC.TEXT: Paul Steinle, president of United Press International, has resigned to form a broadcast production company, UPI Chairman Earl W. Brian announced today. The announcement said Steinle will form Steinle Communications, which will provide program development and production services with emphasis on news and information programming. The company will serve media and videocassette markets, Steinle said. Brian said UPI Vice Chairman Joseph K. Taussig will assume the duties of president of the news service until a new president is selected. Steinle, 51, has directed restructuring of UPI operations since February 1988. He joined UPI management in 1983 after serving as president of Financial News Network and its subsidiary, Data Broadcasting Corp. UPI is owned by Infotechnology Inc., an information and communications company, which also owns Financial News Network.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Sequester Jury in Oil Spill Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with sequestration motion denied, other motions today. Picks up 5th graf, `Hazelwood responded...'.
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood's defense asked today to have the jury sequestered during deliberations because of the upcoming anniversary of the tanker's oil spill. ``This raises the fear of a mistrial if the jury is exposed to demonstrations outside the courthouse,'' Attorney Dick Madson told Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone. He added that jurors might be unable to avoid reading stories and seeing television coverage next week marking one year since the nation's largest oil spill. Johnstone said Alaska law provides that attorneys must ask for sequestration before a jury is sworn in ``unless good cause is shown.'' He said, ``You have not shown good cause, and I am going to deny your application.'' In a discussion about legal instructions to be given to the jury, the judge said he would tell the panel members they may not consider Hazelwood's alleged efforts to move his ship off a reef as evidence of recklessness. He said testimony has shown clearly that it was impossible for the ship to move and thus there was no risk under the law. He said, however, he would allow the prosecution to argue that Hazelwood's efforts in turning on the engines and moving the ship's rudder could be interpreted as evidence of his impairment by alcohol. Closing arguments to the jury were scheduled for Tuesday. Hazelwood's lawyers rested their case Thursday without calling him to testify in his criminal trial. Prosecutors also wrapped up Thursday, setting the stage for final arguments next week after six weeks of testimony over the grounding of Hazelwood's tanker on a charted reef in Prince William Sound. With jurors out of the courtroom, Johnstone questioned Hazelwood about whether he freely decided to give up his right to testify in his own behalf. Hazelwood responded ``yes'' several times, but offered no explanation. It had become apparent in recent days that Hazelwood's lawyers, confident of their case, preferred not to expose him to possibly long and grueling cross-examination. ``Capt. Hazelwood, you have a right to testify, and if you were to testify you would be subject to cross-examination,'' Johnstone said. ``Do you understand that right?'' Hazelwood, seated at the counsel table, answered ``Yes.'' ``Is it your desire at this time not to testify?'' asked the judge. ``Yes,'' Hazelwood responded. It was the most the pensive, balding skipper has said in public since his trial began. A defendant is never required to testify in his own behalf, and jurors are instructed to infer nothing from a decision against taking the stand. Hazelwood, 43, returned to Alaska from his home in Huntington, N.Y., to stand trial on charges stemming from the March 24 grounding of the Exxon Valdez, a 987-foot tanker which spilled nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into waters rich with fish and other marine life. Hazelwood is the only member of the ship's crew to face criminal charges. He is accused of a felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors _ reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted on all counts, he could be sentenced to 7\ years in prison and fined $61,000. Key issues addressed by 46 prosecution and 15 defense witnesses centered on whether Hazelwood was reckless before and after the grounding. They were questioned about whether the captain seemed drunk, whether he erred in leaving the ship's bridge in control of a third mate and whether he tried a dangerous maneuver to drive the stranded tanker off the reef. The latter claim appeared moot by the end of testimony through defense witnesses who testified the gigantic ship was immovable. Johnstone said he probably will instruct jurors they cannot consider as reckless an attempt to do something that was impossible _ move the ship. The last defense witnesses, a marine salvage master and a naval architect, agreed the ship was stuck firmly on Bligh Reef. The final prosecution witness was Robert Mackintire, captain of Texaco tanker The Brooklyn, which preceded the Exxon Valdez into Prince William Sound several hours before the grounding. Mackintire testified he always remained on the bridge while going through the sound, but on cross-examination added he did not consider it a particularly difficult area to navigate. Hazelwood was in his cabin and a third mate was at the helm when the Exxon Valdez ran aground.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Leaders to Begin Talks With Government Next Month
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leaders exiled for decades will return home for groundbreaking talks with the white minority government April 11, President F.W. de Klerk announced Friday. Nelson Mandela, scheduled to arrive in South Africa on Saturday after a five-nation tour, is expected to head the ANC delegation at the discussions. They are designed to remove obstacles to formal black-white negotiations on a new constitution. ``The meeting is structured to address those things which are perceived to be stumbling blocks ... toward negotiations,'' de Klerk told a Cape Town news conference after the announcement. He said some leaders of the ANC's military wing fear arrest upon return to South Africa, and that could be one of the obstacles discussed at the meeting. But de Klerk also said he hoped the ANC would drop its reference to continued ``armed struggle'' so all leaders could commit themselves to peaceful solutions. There was no immediate comment from the ANC, the main black group fighting the white government. The Zambia-based organization said last month it wanted to hold preliminary talks with de Klerk ``as soon as possible.'' At a rally in Stockholm, Sweden, Mandela repeated ANC conditions for formal negotiations with the South African government. The conditions include lifting of the state of emergency, freeing of all political prisoners, and repeal of repressive legislation. During Mandela's past week in Sweden, he and other ANC leaders held extensive strategy discussions with ANC President Oliver Tambo, who is recovering from a stroke in Stockholm. Mandela, 71, was elected deputy president of the ANC earlier this month during a visit to Zambia. The position makes him the effective leader of the organization while Tambo recuperates. The government has made clear that the ANC would be only one of several black-led organizations it would invite to formal talks on a new constitution. Among others are leaders of South Africa's 10 black homelands, such as Mangosuthu Buthelezi, political leader of the Zulus. De Klerk has met with many black leaders in South Africa, and he told reporters: ``It will not be my first meeting with the ANC. I've already met Mr. Mandela twice.'' The relatively conservative Buthelezi, a proponent of capitalism, has long been at odds with the ANC over its use of violence and support for economic sanctions against South Africa. ``De Klerk has, as state president, burnt the ruling National Party's bridges behind him,'' said Buthelezi, who arrived for a state visit in Lusaka, Zambia. ``Bold movements he has made into the new South Africa ... are irretrievable commitments to abandon apartheid and to establish a new and just social, economic and politcal order in South Africa,'' he said. De Klerk also said the government would spend $380 million more this year to eliminate backlogs in black housing and education, and purchase more land for settlement of blacks near the cities. An additional $760 million will form the basis of a trust fund to be administered by the private sector. It will be used to encourage donation from inside and outside South Africa to improve blacks' living conditions and their opportunities for advancement. The ANC was banned in 1960, and many ANC leaders will make their first trip to South Africa since going into exile three decades ago. The president legalized the ANC and more than 60 other organizations Feb. 2. Nine days later he freed Mandela, who had been imprisoned 27 years for helping launch the ANC sabotage campaign. De Klerk says he wants to negotiate a new constitution that will bring blacks into the national government, but allow whites to maintain veto power over major policy decisions. De Klerk opposes a one-person, one-vote system that the ANC and other leading anti-apartheid groups demand. The ANC announced last month it would not open formal talks on a new constitution until de Klerk lifts the state of emergency. De Klerk said Friday: ``I would hope the government's actions and the influence of the total leadership in South Africa, including the ANC, will bring about a situation which will enable us to lift the state of emergency as soon as possible.'' De Klerk and other Cabinet ministers said recently that some black leaders were not ready to negotiate and were instigating a wave of violence that has killed 300 blacks in the past six weeks. The violence is considered the worst since the mid-1980s, which led the government to declare the state of emergency in June 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Orders Briefs Filed in Flag-Burning Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Friday raised the possibility it will decide by early summer the constitutionality of a new law making it a crime to burn the American flag. The court partially granted a Bush administration request for speedy consideration of the law, ordering challengers of the law to file legal briefs by March 26. The justices will wait until they receive those briefs before taking any further action in a pair of administration appeals to overturn lower court rulings that the law unconstitutionally stifles free speech.
