The Justice Department on Tuesday asked the high court to expedite consideration of the politically charged issue and schedule oral arguments as early as April 25. While the department and President Bush have expressed doubts about the law's constitutionality, the administration filed legal papers urging the court to uphold the statute. The department urged the high court to overturn rulings by two judges, here and in Seattle, who declared the law unconstitutional. The judges ``overvalued ... the narrow category of expressive conduct at stake and undervalued the compelling governmental interest that lies at the core of the statute: the preservation of the flag as the unique symbol of our nation,'' the department said. Conviction under the law carries a maximum one-year jail sentence. The Justice Department acknowledged that Bush allowed the law to be enacted Oct. 28 without his signature because he questions its constitutionality and prefers a constitutional amendment to assure the same protection for the flag. Bush said he has ``serious doubts (the law) can withstand Supreme Court review'' and said ``a constitutional amendment is the only way to ensure that our flag is protected from desecration.'' David Cole, a lawyer representing the defendants in both flag cases, accused the administration of seeking expedited high court review so that flag burning will be an issue in this year's campaign for House, Senate and state legislative seats. He urged the court to schedule arguments in the case when it returns in October from its summer recess. ``This is a very important constitutional question. It shouldn't be subject to political considerations,'' Cole said. The Supreme Court, voting 5-4 in June, struck down a Texas law barring desecration or destruction of the flag. The court said burning the American flag as a form of political protest is protected by the Constitution's free speech guarantees. The high court's June ruling touched off a political firestorm and led to enactment of the new flag-protection law. Democratic leaders in Congress supported the law as an alternative to a constitutional amendment. The cases are U.S. vs. Eichman, 89-1433, and U.S. vs. Haggerty, 89-1434.

DOC.HEAD: Quick Breakthoughs Unlikely When Talks Begin
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When the white government and the African National Congress meet, they face three issues that could block the start of formal negotiations on a new constitution. They are: _ The state of emergency. The ANC wants it lifted. President F.W. de Klerk does too, but says he will not do so until violence in black areas subsides. More than 300 blacks have been killed in the past six weeks, most in factional fighting. _ Political prisoners. The ANC says several hundred members convicted of politically motivated violence must be freed. The government has refused, but has been speaking to the lawyers of the prisoners. Also, the government has been vague on status of ANC exiles suspected of violence. The exiles want guarantees they won't be prosecuted if they return. _ Violence. The ANC still endorses its guerrilla campaign, though it poses no threat to the government. The government says there's no justification for armed resistance now that the ANC is a legal organization. If agreement is reached on these obstacles, the government, the ANC and several other black and white groups would likely begin formal talks on a constitution that would grant political rights to the 28-million black majority. Other major issues include: _ Apartheid laws. All black groups insist legislation segregating schools, neighborhoods, hospitals and other facilities be abolished. The government has said there will be changes, but so far opposes a full repeal. _ Voting rights. Black groups want one-person, one-vote. The government has said that would replace white domination with black domination. Many whites want guarantees the rights of ``minority groups'' will be protected. De Klerk envisions a system that gives blacks voting rights, but allows whites to have veto power on major policy decisions. _ Land. Blacks account for more than 75 percent of South Africa's population but are restricted to 13 percent of the land. Black groups demand land redistribution.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Republican National Committee Chairman Lee Atwater says the discovery of his benign brain tumor caused him to tone down his pit-bull style of politicking. ``I can't imagine me getting back in a fighting mood ... I don't see how I'm ever going to be mean,'' Atwater said in an interview published in The State newspaper Friday. ``It's going to be hard for me to be as tough on people,'' said Atwater, known for his aggressive style of politics and the successful negative campaign he waged for President Bush in 1988. ``What I'm going to do is take a new approach to how I proceed, because politics is people. I've always loved people. But I have a better sense of humanity, a better sense of fellowship with people than I've ever had before,'' he said Thursday from his car telephone in Washington, D.C., on his way to the hospital for a daily radiation treatment. Atwater collapsed while delivering a speech last week. Doctors determined he had a non-malignant brain tumor. The 39-year-old South Carolina native is undergoing radiation treatments to shrink the olive-size growth. ``Forget money and power,'' Atwater said. ``I had no idea how wonderful people are. I wish I had known this before. What a way to have to find out.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moved on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: More than 70,000 Indonesians chanted ``We love you Ali,'' as former heavyweight champion Muhammad Ali spoke to them before and after Moslem Sabbath services Friday. Ali is in the country for a music and boxing extravaganza on Sunday. Former heavyweight champion Larry Holmes will meet James ``Quick'' Tillis in a six-round exhibition, and Tim Witherspoon fights Greg Gunnell in a scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout. The crowd waiting to see Ali grew so great that security people kept the former champion in the mosque for an hour after the service and finally hustled him out through a way to avoid the crowd. At one point, Ali was was guided to the podium to lead a chorus of Islam's confession of creed in an effort to calm the crowd. Sunday night's fights will be held in the Senayan Sports Palace, where Ali won a decision over Rudy Lubbers of the Netherlands in 1973. Lace and Kool and the Gang head the entertainment card.

Actress Delta Burke, whose weight gain was fodder for supermarket tabloids, says putting on extra pounds was her way of keeping people _ particularly men _ away. The star of television's ``Designing Woman'' says she was molested when she was 4 and nearly raped while in her late teens. As a result, she became ``absolutely terrified of men,'' she said in US magazine's April 2 edition. ``I remember thinking that any guy walking towards me was gonna attack me, he was gonna hurt me. And once I got older, I didn't date. I would kind of hide from that,'' Burke said. ``The weight was a buffer, because the attention I got when I was thinner was too much.'' Burke, who is married to ``Major Dad'' star Gerald McRaney, controlled her weight for a while by taking diet pills and amphetamines but began gaining pounds once she stopped. She's since started battling back by going on a strict no-fat diet and working out daily with a personal trainer.

Thousands of Nigerians cheered Britain's Prince Charles and his wife, Diana, as they made their way to Lagos' main teaching hospital to give it an incubator. Health Minister Professor Olikoye Ransome-Kuti showed the royal couple through a children's ward of Lagos University Teaching Hospital and told them about the many medical problems facing Africa's most populous nation. The incubator, part of Britain's $97.5 million 1990 aid package to Nigeria, will help fight one of the highest infant mortality rates in the world. Up to 90 of every 1,000 babies born in Lagos die and the deaths rise to 200 in 1,000 in rural areas. Charles, the heir to the British throne, and his wife also presented $1 million worth of medication to the hospital.

Ivana Trump has hired a Texas detective to work on her divorce from her billionaire husband, Donald, according to a published report. Clyde Wilson, a Houston private eye noted for investigating murder cases and financial frauds among Texas' upper crust, has been hired by Ivana's lawyers, according to Friday's editions of New York Newsday. One unidentified source told Newsday that Wilson was hired before news of the divorce became public. That source added that Donald's considerable clout in New York led them to hiring a detective agency outside the city. Wilson's agency is to gather evidence of any possible infidelity on Donald's part, as well as document Ivana's contributions to the growth of the Trump empire, the newspaper said. Wilson and Michael Kennedy, Ivana's lawyer, refused to confirm or deny that the private eye was working on the Trump divorce, Newsday said. Jay Goldberg, one of Trump's lawyers, said hiring a detective was like grasping at straws in view of the prenuptial deal. ``It's a feather trying to knock down a steel door,'' he said.

Queen Mother Elizabeth will celebrate St. Patrick's Day in Berlin on Saturday, presenting shamrocks to the Irish Guard under extremely tight security, a press spokeswoman said Friday. The 89-year-old mother of Queen Elizabeth II was scheduled to arrive in Berlin on Friday afternoon aboard a royal jet from London, said a press spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity. Security forces were expected to be on maximum alert Saturday when she planned to salute the Irish Guard at their traditional St. Patrick's Day parade. Afterward, she was to present shamrocks to the regiment, as she has since 1928 when she was Duchess of York, carrying on a tradition begun by Queen Alexandra, wife of King Edward VII. The visit concludes Sunday with a visit to the Light Infantry, of which she is Colonel in Chief, the spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Congressional Seats at Stake in Special Elections
DOC.TEXT: A candidate for a Bronx congressional seat lives in Queens. The front-runner in a Staten Island race is trying to fill her father's shoes _ or at least his congressional seat. There are plenty of quirks in the campaign for two vacant congressional seats in New York City's boroughs to be resolved in a special election Tuesday. But when the last vote is counted, no surprises are expected. Republicans will likely hold onto the 14th District seat, which covers Staten Island and a sliver of Brooklyn, and Democrats are predicted to keep the seat in the 18th District, covering the impoverished south Bronx. Gary Koops, spokesman for the National Republican Congressional Committee, admitted it would be tough to win the Bronx seat, a longtime Democratic stronghold. Democratic Assemblyman Jose Serrano is the favorite. It also doesn't help that the Republican candidate, a former Democrat, is considered an outsider _ literally. Simeon Golar lives in Queens, and though candidates are not required to live in the districts they seek to represent, ``that can be a factor'' for many voters, Koops said. Also on the ballot is Ismael Betancourt, running on the Independent Fusion and Right-to-Life Party lines. The seat became vacant when Rep. Robert Garcia was sentenced to three years in prison for extorting payoffs in the Wedtech scandal. In the Staten Island race, Democrats are not racing to stencil the name of their candidate, Robert Gigante, on the door of an office in the Capitol. ``I'm optimistic we have a good chance to make this a very close race,'' says Howard Schloss of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in Washington. But, he quickly added, ``that's not to say we're going to win.'' Gigante, 41, is an attorney and virtual unknown facing City Council member Susan Molinari, whose father resigned from Congress in the middle of his fifth term to become Staten Island borough president. Many say Guy V. Molinari quit Congress to open the way for his only child. His 31-year-old daughter got a boost both media- and money-wise when President Bush visited Staten Island for a fund-raising luncheon that put an extra $223,000 into her campaign coffer. Her father ran Bush's 1988 campaign in New York. Gigante, who is running a distant second despite a 2-to-1 Democratic registration edge, has trashed his opponent for ``looking like a little girl at the podium.'' ``If that's the best issue Gigante's got, then I hope he has a strong law practice,'' Koops said. Others running in the 14th District include Carl Grillo on the Liberal line and Right-to-Life candidate Barbara Bollaert. Analyst Charles Cook, whose Cook Political Report handicaps congressional races for corporations, trade and union groups, snored loudly when asked to give his opinion of the two races. He says he hasn't even looked at the Bronx race because ``I just assume Serrano is going to catch it.'' Serrano spokesman Carol Pasco said the Bronx Republican Committee chose Golar, a former family court judge and ex-city commissioner of housing and human rights, because he is black. ``I think the strategy is fairly obvious,'' he said. The 18th District population is evenly split between blacks and Hispanics. In Staten Island, Cook says, Gigante is ``every bit as effective a candidate'' as Molinari, but he ``doesn't have the necessary resources _ i.e. money and support _ to pull it off.'' Molinari is expected to raise about $400,000 for the special election; Gigante is likely to bring in about $225,000. Gov. Mario Cuomo and New York Mayor David Dinkins have endorsed Gigante but neither has actively campaigned with him. If elected, Molinari would be the youngest sitting member of Congress. She has been the only Republican on the 35-member City Council, the legislative body that governs New York, since her election in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Government Say Housing Starts Slow Down
With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Housing starts fell 7 percent in February but remained well above the level of the last 11 months of 1989, the government reported Friday. Analysts said the building pace cannot be sustained. New homes and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.48 million units in February, the Commerce Department said. That followed a 24.7 percent jump in the warmest January on record, the biggest increase since a 29.3 percent gain in July 1982 despite being revised down from a 29.6 percent advance first reported last month. Temperatures remained above normal in February and although housing starts fell from January's 1.59 million-unit level, they remained higher than those of any month last year except for the 1.66 million units started in January 1989. ``The pace of activity in January and February is higher than we can expect over the course of the year,'' said Thomas Holloway, senior economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association. ``We're probably borrowing a few starts from later in the year because of the warmer weather.'' The increase in new construction was based entirely in the single-family sector, which rose 5.1 percent to an annual rate of 1.17 million units. It was the highest level since a 1.19 million-unit rate in January 1989. ``The fact that single-family starts were up in February bodes well for activity in the coming months as (mortgage interest) rates head downward,'' said John A. Tuccillo, chief economist at the National Association of Realtors. Multifamily starts plummeted 35 percent to an annual rate of 266,000 after rising 40 percent the previous month. Analysts said the January pace resulted both from the weather and from builders' desire to get construction underway in advance of new regulations designed to make apartments more accessible to the handicapped. The new ``fair housing'' rules could add $3,000 to the cost of multifamily units, said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. David Berson, chief economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, said a high vacancy rate also contributed to the multifamily weakness. ``It's almost certain to remain weak until vacancy rates come down,'' Berson said. The Northeast posted the biggest gain in overall starts, up 24.4 percent to an annual rate of 219,000 units. It was followed by a 14.8 percent jump in the South to 604,000 units. Starts in the Midwest declined 29 percent to an annual rate of 271,000 units and in the West fell 24 percent to 383,000 units. Applications for building permits, a barometer of future housing activity, fell 25 percent after a 26.8 percent gain in January. The decline was the largest on record.

DOC.HEAD: President Decrees Emergency Economic Package
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello on Friday implemented a sweeping emergency package of economic reforms that include a price freeze, a new national currency, and jail terms for ``economic crimes.'' ``Brazilians want serious action now,'' said Collor de Mello as he announced his plans. The new president took office Thursday. He is Brazil's first popularly elected leader in 29 years. Brazil has the developing world's largest foreign debt, $114 billion. Inflation is 2,700 percent, and the budget deficit is $31 billion. Millions of people live on the street or in shantytowns. At the same time, the country has the world's eighth-largest economy and the Western world's third-biggest trade surplus. Collor de Mello took office saying he would try to correct these imbalances. The reform package takes effect immediately but must be approved by Congress within 30 days. If Congress fails to vote, Collor de Mello can reissue the measures for another 30 days. Under the emergency measures, prices will be frozen 30 days and wages controlled. Inflation for March is expected to total 85 percent but to help lower the rate, workers will get a raise for the month equal to February's inflation, which was 73 percent. On April 15, when the price freeze ends, wages and prices will be ``pre-fixed'' by a government-set amount. TV Globo, Brazil's largest commercial network, reported the salary and price hikes would be 40 percent in April and 20 percent in May. ``The violence of inflation and runaway prices has made indispensable directed parameters for prices and salaries,'' said Collor de Mello. Collor de Mello said the measures would result in the ``weakening of speculation and the strengthening of investment.'' The new conservative president also announced a new currency, the ``cruzeiro,'' which replaces the 14-month-old new cruzado. The ``cruzeiro'' is Brazil's fourth currency in as many years. Private economists said it would be created by lopping two zeros off the new cruzado, which is now worth about 2.5 cents. Collor de Mello declared a new law against ``economic abuses,'' such as withholding goods from the market, financial speculation and illegal price hikes. ``Who tries to cheat and fool the people will be jailed,'' he said, adding that store owners and managers found guilty of economic crimes will face five-year jail terms. The most contoversial part of Collor de Mello's annoucement centered around his promise to balance the budget deficit this year. Promised new measures included: _ Major new taxes on the wealthy and on financial gains from trading in stocks and gold. _ The suspension of $2.2 billion in annual federal subsidies to private enterprise, that go to everyone from exporters to the computer industry. _ An ``ambitious program'' of privatizations of state-owned companies. Brazil has 188 publicly owned firms. Many operate at a loss and they have total debts of about $62 billion. _ Stiff increases in public utility rates, such as electricity and telephone. _ Firings of large numbers of Brazil's 700,000 federal employees. ``This year's federal deficit will be zero ... There's no way to knock down inflation if the government spends more than it takes in,'' Collor de Mello said. Collor de Mello also said he wanted to integrate Brazil's economy into the world market, eliminate import restrictions and bring foreign capital to the country. ``We will modernize our economy and stimulate competition ... Free initiative is the only way to sustained and progressive growth'' he said. Collor de Mello signed laws Thursday that reduced the number of government ministries from 25 to 12 and ordered the sale of government-owned mansions and cars. Also decreed was the extinction of 24 federal agencies and companies, including the Brazilian Institute of Coffee, which controls all coffee trade, and the government's port authority, Portobras. Initial reactions to Collor de Mello's package were mixed. ``We've worked all our lives for reforms like a balanced budget. Halelujah!,'' said right-wing Senator Jarbas Passarinho of the Social Democracy Party. Union leaders were mostly negative. ``I'm still analyzing the package but my sensation is that workers have lost. If he wants to take on the banks, fine, but we've got nothing else to give,'' said Luis Antonio Medeiros, president of the powerful Sao Paulo-based Metalworkers Union. Medeiros supported Collor de Mello in last year's presidential campaign. Collor de Mello was inaugurated for a five-year term Thursday. He replaced Jose Sarney, who took office in an Electoral College vote set up by the right-wing military regime that ruled Brazil between 1964 and 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Jamaican Prime Minister to Meet With Bush
DOC.TEXT: Jamaican Prime Minister Michael Manley will meet with President Bush on May 3 during an official working visit to Washington, the White House announced Friday. Manley will be in Washington May 2-4, meeting with various administration officials. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush and Manley would discuss coordination of efforts against drug trafficking as well as political and economic developments in the Caribbean region.

DOC.HEAD: Tornadoes Near Record Last Year
DOC.TEXT: There were 840 tornadoes in the United States last year, the second highest total on record, the National Weather Service reported Friday. The record is 907 tornadoes, recorded in 1984. There were relatively few fatalities in 1989, however, the Weather Service said. There were 48 deaths attributed to twisters, well below the 83 fatalities in an average year. Alabama suffered the most 1989 deaths with 21, according to the report. There were 9 deaths in New York, 5 in North Carolina, 4 in Georgia, 3 in Florida, 2 each in Louisiana and South Carolina and 1 each in Tennessee and Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Communist Party Calls Fourth Party Congress
DOC.TEXT: Cuba's first Communist Party congress in four years will allow some debate but will not challenge the party's 31-year monopoly on power, the state news agency said. Prensa Latina said the announcement of the congress, to be held next year, was made by Defense Minister Raul Castro, the brother of Cuban President Fidel Castro. The report came Thursday, the same day Vice President Dan Quayle appealed to other countries to urge the Havana government to hold free elections. Castro repeatedly has rejected Western-style balloting and said his country has no need for Soviet-style reform _ despite pressure from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and a drop in Soviet aid. The party congress will be held in the first half of next year, the dispatch said, without giving the exact date. The report was monitored in Mexico City. The party said the meeting would not exhibit ``unreal eagerness of unanimity _ false, mechanical and formal.'' However, the party, which seized power in a 1959 revolution, made clear its intention to retain full control of the Caribbean island. ``Our Communist Party, the base of political organization in our society, is perfecting itself to better complete its work of historical transcendence that we are setting up today,'' it said. When the government announced in February that a party congress would be called, there was speculation that the move might signal a change in course for the hard-line Marxist government. Since then, however, Castro has said he intends to remain staunchly loyal to Marxist principles. Quayle and Castro, both in Brazil on Thursday for the inauguration of President Fernando Collor de Mello, stayed clear of each other but debated through the media. ``We have encouraged all people who have any contact with Fidel Castro to urge him to stop the war in El Salvador, to stop funding'' the well-organized guerilla movement,'' Quayle told a news conference Thursday. ``We also urge anyone who is in contact with Castro to ask him when he's going to have elections,'' said Quayle. Castro said Wednesday he saw no need for Western-style elections in Cuba. Congresses of the ruling Communist Party choose Cuba's leadership. ``We have our own type of election,'' he said in an interview with TV Globo, Brazil's largest network. ``It would take long to explain our (political) process.'' Castro has faced growing international criticism of his human rights policies and increasing pressure to reform. In three months he lost his two closest Caribbean allies _ Panama's Manuel Antonio Noriega, who was toppled in a U.S. invasion in December, and Nicaragua's leftist Sandinistas, who were defeated by a U.S.-backed opposition coalition in elections Feb. 25. As criticisms of Cuba have appeared in official Soviet media, Castro has called on Cubans to brace for possible cuts in the Soviets' $5 billion in yearly aid. U.S. sources said last year said there had been substantial reductions already, as evidenced in the marked decline in the purchase of sugar, which the Soviet Union buys from Cuba at prices substantially higher than world market levels as a form of subsidy.

DOC.HEAD: President of United Press International Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Paul Steinle resigned as president of United Press International Friday, a little more than two years after taking over day-to-day operation of the news service. UPI Chairman Earl W. Brian said Steinle, 51, is leaving to form a broadcast production company, Steinle Communications. He will serve as a consultant to UPI during the transition to new leadership, Brian said. Brian said Joseph K. Taussig, vice chairman of the news service, would assume the duties of president until a permanent successor is named. Steinle became president of UPI in February, 1988, at a time when the wire service, now 83 years old, had been losing $2 million a month. Before coming to UPI, he was president of Financial News Network. He will remain on the board of that organization and of UPI, Brian said. Both UPI and FNN are owned by Infotechnology Inc., an information and communications company. Brian said Steinle made ``vital contributions to restoring UPI's financial stability and employe morale'' and directed restructuring of UPI operations. During his tenure, a number of individual business units were created within the news service. Steinle said his new company will provide program development and production services, with emphasis on news and information programming, for media and videocasette markets. Brian said Infotech plans to invest in the company. In a farewell message to UPI employees, Steinle said that in the last two years the news agency ``has been restored to stability. Through team effort a valuable journalistic tradition has been preserved and strengthened.''

DOC.HEAD: White House Announces New Commerce Appointment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday announced his selection of Robert Marshall White of Edina, Minn., as under secretary of Commerce for technology. The post, which requires Senate confirmation, is a new one. Since 1986, White has served as chief technical officer and vice president for research for Control Data Corp. in Minneapolis. A native of Reading, Pa., White, 51, is a graduate of Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford University.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Registered in Gulf of California
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake shook the Baja California city of La Paz on Friday, rattling windows but apparently causing no injuries or damage, residents said. The Tacubaya seismological station in Mexico City said the quake measured 5.6 on the Richter scale and was centered about 75 miles northeast of La Paz. ``It moved the tables. Everything moved. The windows rattled. It felt like something was hitting the house,'' said Alfonso Sepulveda Valenzuela. ``We thought a car had hit a post.'' But Sepulveda and other residents said they saw no broken glass or other damage in downtown La Paz. The city is about 800 miles southeast of San Diego. Jose Alberto Cesena, private secretary to the mayor, said no one in his office felt the quake and he heard no reports of it from other residents or local news media. Gonzalo Carreno Avitia, a Red Cross employee in La Paz, said there were no calls about the quake. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one whole number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake measuring five on the scale can cause considerable damage and one of six, severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Cost Estimate for New Air-to-Air Missile Up 21 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Inflation and a revision in the Pentagon's cost-estimating system have pushed the price of the next generation of air-to-air missiles to more than $14 billion, Air Force officials told Congress on Friday. The new estimate is 21 percent higher than the previous calculation. Lt. Gen. Ronald W. Yates also told the House Armed Services procurement subcommittee that the Air Force has suspended delivery of the AMRAAM missile because of problems with some of the 140 missiles it has accepted for testing. ``Most of the discrepancies fall into the category of quality, workmanship-type issues or process changes at the contractors,'' Yates said. Raytheon and Hughes manufacture the missile. The AMRAAM, which has been in development since 1981, is considered a ``smart missile.'' The Pentagon envisions that a fighter pilot would use radar to detect enemy aircraft at long distances and fire the 12-foot missile. The AMRAAM would then use its own radar to hit the enemy missile. The program, however, has had problems with cost overruns. Yates said the original cap imposed by Congress on the program in 1984 was $7 billion, but that limit was later revised to $7.5 billion and then $7.7 billion. Adjusted for 1984 prices, the new estimate of $14.37 billion for the 24,335 missiles the Pentagon has planned to purchase would be $9.3 billion _ 21 percent more than the last estimate. The assistant Air Force secretary for acquisition, John J. Welch, said a fourth of the increased cost is due to higher prices for components and the rest stems from the Defense Department's change in its estimating methods. Yates also said that the Air Force is reexamining the total number of missiles it plans to buy in light of the diminshing Soviet threat. The Air Force is responsible for development and overseeing production of the AMRAAM, but the Navy plans to purchase it as well.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Will Try To Accelerate Integration In South Africa
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III, venturing into his first round of on-site African diplomacy, will urge South African President F.W. de Klerk next week to end a 3{-year state of emergency and to release all remaining political prisoners. As Baker's trip was announced Friday by the State Department, the de Klerk government said it would begin negotiations with Nelson Mandela and exiled leaders of the African National Congress on April 11. A senior U.S. official said Baker hopes to accelerate the negotiations, but ruled out demands by Mandela for stiffer U.S. sanctions against South Africa as a pressure tactic. ``It is time for us to encourage them, not punish them,'' the official said, referring to de Klerk's release of Mandela from prison last month and the president's willingness to negotiate with the black opposition. But the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Baker would urge de Klerk to end the state of emergency in South Africa and free political prisoners, estimated by his critics to number nearly 300. Baker will leave Sunday for Namibia, the newly independent former South African colony where the secretary and other world figures will attend ceremonies for the new nation. The United States, during the Reagan administration, played a leading role in the establishment of Namibia and is prepared to provide $7.8 million in aid next year. While at the celebration, Baker will meet with Mandela, whose demand for stiffer sanctions and a suspension of U.S. diplomatic relations with South Africa is being rejected as counterproductive. The Bush administration prefers dealing with Pretoria as a way to try to shape events in the racially segregated country, arguing that a cutoff and a tougher stance would limit U.S. leverage. In Namibia, Baker also will meet with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. Before leaving for Capetown to see de Klerk, Anglican Bishop Desmond Tutu and black opposition leaders, Baker will open talks with Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos in an effort to end his government's 14-year war with U.S.-armed guerrillas. The secretary will then see Jonas Savimbi, leader of the Unita rebels, who receive an estimated $45 million to $50 million in covert U.S. aid. The United States has no diplomatic relations with Angola, but a virtual stalemate in the war since December may improve prospects for a negotiated settlement and U.S. recognition. The United States is alone among major Western countries in not recognizing the Angolan government.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine Officer Convicted in Absentia For Murder of French Nuns
DOC.TEXT: An Argentine navy officer was convicted in absentia Friday for the abduction and murder of two French nuns killed in Argentina 12 years ago. French legal experts said it was the first time someone had been convicted of a crime outside of his own country after having been granted amnesty in his homeland. On trial was Capt. Alfredo Astiz, 40, commander of a warship in Argentina, and scheduled for promotion. Known to human rights groups as ``the angel of death,'' he was sentenced to life in prison after a hearing in a Paris criminal court that lasted less than four hours. The court, in a symbolic gesture, also ordered the sequestration of all of Astiz's property. Astiz in the past has denied any connection with the crime. Along with all other junior officers in Argentina, he was exempted in 1987 from prosecution for any human rights violations committed during the ``dirty war'' waged against leftists by a military junta. President Raul Alfonsin, seeking to consolidate civilian rule with conciliatory gestures, said only senior military commanders should be held accountable. The nuns' relatives and their lawyers do not expect Argentina to extradite Astiz. But they said a conviction might prompt other countries to recognize an international arrest warrant on Astiz. That could in effect make Astiz a prisoner of his own country. The bodies of the two Roman Catholic nuns, Alice Domon and Leonie Duquet, were found on a beach near Buenos Aires two months after they were abducted in December 1977. Astiz, who had been captain of a navy frigate, was assigned at the time to infiltrate organizations that had taken up the cause of victims of the junta's repression. According to papers filed in the French court, Astiz ordered the abduction of the nuns, who had befriended anti-government activists. He later was implicated by an activist who escaped custody. Lawyers representing the nuns' families say they hold Astiz responsible for torture the two women allegedly underwent shortly after abduction. In the courtroom Friday were two women who said they had belonged to an organization of mothers of the ``disappeared'' in Argentina. They wore the group's traditional white scarves. In 1978 Astiz served briefly with the Argentine Embassy in Paris under an assumed name. The nuns' families filed charges against Astiz in 1982, and an arrest warrant was issued. France unsuccessfully sought his extradition from Britain, where he was taken as a prisoner after his capture during the Falkland Islands war. He was indicted in Argentina for the January 1977 arrest and disappearance of Swedish teen-ager Dagmar Hagelin, but freed from prosecution in December 1986 by a federal court that invoked the statute of limitations. Alice Doman, 40 at the time of her death, was sent to Argentina in 1967. She worked for a time in a Buenos Aires shantytown and later in an impoverished northern village before returning to the capital in 1976. She was abducted while leaving a church following a meeting with parents of missing activists. Leonie Duquet, 61 at the time of her death, had worked in Argentina since shortly after World War II. Her brother, Eribert, is a Roman Catholic priest who was posted in San Francisco at the time of her abduction. Astiz is stationed at the Puerto Belgrano navy base, about 460 miles south of Buenos Aires on the south Atlantic. The base is Argentina's largest.

DOC.HEAD: Rostenkowski Plan Under Fire From Labor Group, Moyhnihan
DOC.TEXT: A plan to balance the budget by raising taxes and freezing Social Security benefits was attacked Friday by a labor-financed group as unfair to low- and middle-income Americans. The plan by Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, ``looks a lot like what (President) Bush campaigned on,'' said Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice. McIntyre, whose organization has produced some widely read analyses of the tax system, outlined what he said would be fairer way to reduce the deficit. The central element in McIntyre's plan would raise the top individual and corporate tax rates to 38 percent, up from 33 percent and 34 percent, respectively. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., also criticized Rostenkowski's plan Friday because it would continue to the use of surplus Social Security taxes to hide the real size of the overall federal deficit. ``This is not government money,'' Moynihan said. ``This money belongs to the contributors'' _ meaning the workers whose payroll taxes finance Social Security. Moynihan has proposed eliminating the surplus by cutting Social Security taxes. Moynihan also faulted Rostenkowski for calling on retirees to give up their scheduled Social Security cost-of-living increase in 1991. ``This is the first time I have heard such a proposal made from our (Democratic) side on a unilateral basis,'' Moynihan said. He said that although the freeze would be for only one year, the failure to pay the increase would permanently reduce retiree's benefits. Moynihan's staff calculated that in 1991, the freeze would cost a typical couple retiring this year at age 65 about $588. Over five years the loss would total $3,192. Citizens for Tax Justice says Rostenkowski's plan is flawed because ``it's asking the wrong people to pay'' for the deficit. The organization's substitute proposal would raise individual taxes by $139 billion over the next five years and corporate income taxes by $178 billion. Another $195 billion for deficit reduction would come from reducing the defense budget and $62 billion would be derived from cutting government interest payments. ``All but the richest 5 percent of American families'' would fare better compared with Rostenkowski's plan, McIntyre said. Rostenkowski would eliminate the lingering deficit by eliminating cost-of-living raises for Social Security beneficiaries and recipients of many other government programs. It would also raise income taxes on everybody who files a return, with an especially big boost on the richest 600,000 people, and raise taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, wine and beer. Bush has said there is room for discussion in Rostenkowski's plan but repeated his opposition to any tax increase.

DOC.HEAD: Nepal's King Says He Will Consider Democratic Reforms
DOC.TEXT: King Birendra said Friday he would consider political reforms in this Himalayan kingdom, but he ruled out the multiparty system that protesters have demanded. Police arrested about 150 people, including prominent writers and entertainers, in one of the largest mass arrests of demonstrators since the movement for a return to democracy was launched Feb. 18, witnesses said. Nepal's two-year experiment with Western-style democracy ended in 1961 when King Mahendra, Birendra's father, dismissed the government headed by the Nepali Congress party. The king accused the party of corruption and banned all political parties. The National Assembly now shares power with the monarch. Birendra, a 44-year-old Harvard graduate, spoke at a rally in the resort city of Pokhara, 85 miles northwest of Katmandu. His speech marked his first public comments on the month-long campaign of protests and strikes in Nepal. At least 12 people have died in the unrest. ``We have instituted reforms as called for by the changing needs of time,'' the king said in an address broadcast by state-owned radio. ``Taking into account the Nepalese aspirations, this process will continue.'' But he said there would be no change in the decree banning political parties. The king said the ban was upheld in a 1980 national referendum and ``our political tradition relies on the popular will.'' He lashed out at the protest movement and said there could be no solutions when ``there is irresponsible behavior and undignified acts disregarding the interest of the country and people.'' The Nepali Congress said Birendra's speech was ``politically most disappointing.'' ``Indications of reform ... in the royal address cannot solve the real problems of the nation,'' the party said in a statement. Under the current system, the king nominates one-fifth of the National Assembly's 140 members and wields considerable influence in the selection of top officials and the formulation and implementation of government policy. The rest of the assembly's members are elected on a non-party basis. Riot police broke up a silent protest Friday at Patan College on the outskirts of Katmandu. The protesters wore black cloth over their mouths to demonstrate their resentment of the government's efforts to silence their demands. They distributed statements accusing the government of arresting more than 50 writers and artists, in addition to other protesters, ``during the recent crackdown on innocent and unarmed people.'' Witnesses who spoke on condition of anonymity said some of the protesters were beaten as police dragged them away. Those arrested included a 79-year-old poet, a popular comedy duo and a partially paralyzed novelist, Parijat, who was helped to a police van by fellow demonstrators, the witnesses said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Names Boards to Oversee Funds for Poland, Hungary
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday put New York investment executive John P. Birkelund in charge of managing U.S. aid to Poland and named former deputy Secretary of State John Whitehead to a similar post for aid to Hungary. Birkelund, chief executive officer of Dillon, Read & Co., and Whitehead, who served in the Reagan administration, were named as chairmen of the boards of directors of the Polish-American and Hungarian-American Enterprise Funds, respectively. The funds were set up by Congress to oversee the investment of total of $300 million in private sector development in the two new Eastern European democracies. The funds can be used for loans, grants and investment in Polish and Hungarian corporations. Other members of the Polish-American Enterprise Fund board named Friday by Bush were AFL-CIO president Lane Kirkland; Zbigniew Brzezinski, of the Center for Strategic and International Studies; Charles Harper, chairman and chief executive officer of CONAGRA; and Nicholas Rey, managing director of Bear, Stearns and Co. Other members named to the Hungarian-American Enterprise Fund board were Daniel Burke, chief exective officer of Capital Cities-ABC; George Gould, vice chairman, Klingenstein Fields and Co.; Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International and Paul Marer of Indiana University. ``The president is extremely pleased with the high caliber and range of professional diversity of the individuals who have agreed to serve on the organizing boards of directors for the two funds,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Gives Lithuania Three Days to Start Returning
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Stands for Soviet-Politics listed on news advisory.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday gave the breakaway Lithuanian republic three days to start returning to the Soviet fold, but he did not say what the Kremlin would do if Lithuania refused. The republic's leader declared Moscow's views irrelevant. Lithuania announced plans to start setting up check points on its borders. The official Tass news agency distributed the text of a terse telegram from Gorbachev to Lithuania President Vytautas Landsbergis. It accompanied a copy of the Soviet Parliament's proclamation Thursday that Lithuania's declaration of independence was invalid. ``In a three-day period, inform about measures toward realizing this directive,'' said the telegram, signed ``President U.S.S.R. M. Gorbachev.'' Parliament elected Gorbachev to the presidency this week and gave him expanded powers. The prospect of Gorbachev assuming new authority allowing him to thwart moves toward independence drove the Baltic republic on Sunday to reclaim the sovereignty that existed between 1918 and 1940, when Stalin's army moved in. Gorbachev on Tuesday called the move ``illegal and invalid,'' but said Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and a commission would conduct talks with Lithuania. But he said they would not amount to negotiations. ``We cannot talk about negotiations. You carry out negotiations with foreign countries,'' Gorbachev said. At a news conference Thursday night, Gorbachev said he expected to carry out ``a respectful dialogue'' with Lithuania. The Soviet leader and his advisers have ruled out the use of force to bring Lithuania back into the union, but Gorbachev has demanded $34 billion in reparations for Soviet investment in factories and infrastructure and wants to discuss territorial questions. Many Lithuanians expect an economic boycott by Moscow. Gorbachev was told by parliament on Thursday, the day he formally was given his new powers, to work out the dispute with the republic. However, Tass quoted Landsbergis as telling the republic of 3.7 million people that Moscow had no right to tell it what to do. ``It is not a problem that they do not recognize us now,'' Tass quoted Landsbergis as saying on television. ``The time will come, and they will recognize us.'' He said talks with Moscow undoubtedly would take place, Tass reported. The Lithuanian Communist Party leader, Algirdas Brazauskas, who started the drive toward independence but lost the presidency to Landsbergis, also appeared on TV and joined in appealing for unity and calm, Tass said. The Lithuanian government renamed the government newspaper Soviet Lithuania to Echo of Lithuania, and approved plans to set up 37 border checkpoints in the near future as part of an effort to prevent uncontrolled export of commodities, the Soviet news agency said. Lithuania borders the Russian, Byelorussian and Latvian republics of the Soviet Union. It faces the Baltic Sea, but has no other land borders. When they declared independence Sunday, Lithuanian legislators also changed their homeland's name to the Republic of Lithuania and dropped the Soviet republic's emblem. Lithuania's decision was bitterly criticized by deputies from other republics. They approved the directive urging Gorbachev to ``ensure the defense of the legal rights of every person living on Lithuanian territory,'' as well as defending Soviet interests there. Admiral Vitaly Ivanov, commander of the Soviet Baltic Fleet, accused Lithuania leaders of ``betrayal of their own people and the people of the Soviet Union,'' and called the declaration of independence ``a stab in the back.''

DOC.HEAD: CDC Considering Ban on Many Lab Monkey Importations
DOC.TEXT: The national Centers for Disease Control is considering banning most U.S. primate importations after a rare, deadly virus turned up in monkeys in at least two laboratories, officials said. In a letter to about 200 primate importers in the United States, CDC Director William L. Roper warned, ``The health of your workers may be at risk.'' Ebola virus _ the deadliest virus known to man before the discovery of AIDS _ was spotted in this country in November in three monkeys at a Virginia products testing center. In January, an Ebola-related virus turned up in a monkey at a Pennsylvania lab. Now, in the wake of the initial reports, ``further active transmission in monkeys in quarantine has been demonstrated,'' Roper said in his letter. The warning was sent Thursday to primate importers, health officials and others. The additional transmission has occurred at the Virginia laboratory, Hazleton Research of Reston, officials said. At least 173 people in the United States have been in contact with monkeys, blood or tissue from infected lots, with one person showing Ebola antibodies, Roper said. About 10 percent of monkeys studied from different countries show signs of infection with filoviruses, the family including Ebola virus. The primates involved are cynomolgus monkeys, which account for about 75 percent of all primates brought to the United States, according to officials of the Atlanta-based CDC. About 16,000 cynomolgus monkeys were imported last year. ``These data indicate a definite risk, probably at a fairly low level, of human infection in the course of ordinary handling and management of monkeys,'' Roper said. ``CDC is considering imposing a temporary ban on the importation into the United States of cynomolgus monkeys,'' he said. Atlanta's Yerkes Regional Primate Center, one of the nation's leading primate research centers, has 38 cynomolgus monkeys, long-tailed macaques. But a ban would not affect the center too much, said spokeswoman Cathy Yarbrough. Large primate research centers such as Yerkes breed many of their own animals. The CDC last month issued new guidelines for workers involved in the handling of such primates, calling for 31-day quarantines, restricted access to animal holding areas in primate importation areas and protective clothing for all workers in direct animal contact. Those guidelines are now mandatory, effective immediately, Roper said.

DOC.HEAD: American Head of WHO's AIDS Unit Resigns in Protest
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Jonathan Mann, the American expert who has led the World Health Organization's battle against AIDS, announced Friday that he is resigning because of major differences with WHO's director-general. The announcement surprised Mann's co-workers in WHO's AIDS program. One British AIDS specialist called the resignation a ``major disaster.'' The organization's director-general, Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima of Japan, issued a statement saying he regretted the announcement ``which happened, without previous consultation, at a time when the organization is confronted with new challenges concerning the fight against AIDS.'' He declined further comment. Mann's letter of resignation indicated there had been disagreements between the two men ever since Nakajima took office in 1988. Nakajima succeeded Dr. Halfdan Mahler of Denmark. ``On the basis of my experiences during the last two years, I have now come to the conclusion that there is a great variance between our positions on a series of issues which I consider critical for the Global AIDS Strategy and the WHO Global Program on Aids,'' he said. The program seeks to control an epidemic that has spread to more than 150 countries since it was first identified in 1981. More than 220,000 cases were registered worldwide by the WHO last month. Mann estimates there will be 6 million cases by the year 2000. His letter of resignation and a memorandum he sent to his staff, both released to the media, did not explain the differences he had with Nakajima. However, the departure follows persistent rumors of low morale among the 4,500-staff of WHO. Many blamed the director-general's management style for the problem. Critics reportedly complained of autocratic methods and of sudden transfers without prior notice. The Netherland's mission to the United Nations, in a confidential letter quoted by Dutch newspapers this year, said work at the agency was deteriorating. Mann said his resignation was effective at the end of his term in June. Nakajima, 61, took office in 1988. Before that, he was in charge of WHO's Manila-based regional office for the Western Pacific. He held that job nine years. When his candidacy for the top executive post became known, there were reports critically assessing his work on his previous assignments. Mann, a public health official who grew up in Boston and attended Harvard, joined WHO in June 1986. The AIDS program then consisted of Mann and a secretary, with funds coming from the regular WHO budget. The program now has a staff of close to 200 and a special budget that has tripled in the past three years to $109 million. Mann, 42, has been traveling throughout the world to push a worldwide campaign to inform people of the dangers of AIDS and the methods of protection. WHO spokeswoman Therese Gastaut said that following the announcement of Mann's resignation, he and Nakajima had a ``cordial'' meeting and agreed there are ``no differences on the fundamental problems'' of the Global AIDS Strategy. It was not immediately possible to reconcile that statement with Mann's letter and memorandum. Gastaut said Nakajima could not be interviewed because he was leaving for Afghanistan on Friday night. Mann left word with his office that he was not prepared to talk to the media. In London, Dr. Tony Pinching, who works at one of Britain's leading AIDS treatment centers, said: ``The loss of Dr. Mann is a major disaster, but it goes beyond that, and I view this with very grave concern indeed. ``There are few people of his caliber around. He has directed the program with great vision and ability and will be very difficult to replace.'' The resignation symbolized a ``very serious breakdown within the WHO'' which must be resolved for the sake of the program, he said. The British government's chief medical officer, Sir Donald Acheson, said: ``I have a very high personal regard for Dr. Mann who has worked tirelessly with all countries to develop a global strategy to reduce the spread of HIV, (the AIDS virus), to provide appropriate care, and protect the rights and dignity of those affected.''

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Brotherhood Urges Armed Struggle Against Israel
DOC.TEXT: Moslem fundamentalists who hold the largest bloc in parliament on Friday urged Arab neighbors to drop peaceful efforts to end the Arab-Israeli dispute and instead take up military action against Israel. In a statement sent to The Associated Press, the Moslem Brotherhood organization also urged Arabs to destroy U.S. interests in the Middle East, and it threatened the Soviet Union. ``We call on all Arabs to drop the option of a peaceful settlement with Israel ... and seriously return to the military option which was dropped by Arabs in 1974,'' the statement said. ``We should prepare all the Arab nation, males and females, to become an armed popular army that will convert every inch of the Palestinian land to become a bursting volcano where Jews will be buried.'' The Brotherhood movement made similar demands during November's election campaign. Its members captured almost two dozen of the 80 seats in parliament _ far ahead of any rival faction but not enough to dominate legislation. The Brotherhood electoral strength has had no effect on King Hussein's moderate policy of Arab-Israeli peace, which is based on Israeli withdrawal from the territories it captured from Jordan, Egypt and Syria in the 1967 war. Roughly half of Jordan's 3.1 million residents come from Palestinian families driven out of their homeland by the wars that created Israel and expanded its control over the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The brotherhood statement responded to reports that hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews plan to immigrate to Israel this year.

DOC.HEAD: Victims of Child Labor Violations Urge Congress to Stiffen Penalties
DOC.TEXT: The car wash that illegally hired Matthew Garvey at age 13 was fined $400 after he lost a leg at the weekend job, the boy told Congress Friday as child labor victims called for stiffer penalties. Garvey, using a cane to help him walk with an artificial leg, told the House Government Operations subcommittee on employment and housing that he had landed the job easily and had not been asked for a work permit. Now 16, the Laurel, Md., boy said the accident occurred in 1987, when he was sitting on a dryer that pulled his leg into the machine and severed it. At the hearing, Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., called for mandatory six-month jail terms and fines of up to $100,000 for employers that repeatedly violate child labor laws. He also called for increasing the civil penalties for child labor violations from $1,000 to $10,000. Schumer said that from 1987 to 1989 there were 128,000 minors who were injured and an estimated 59 killed in the workplace. The 37 employers who were cited for violations relating to those cases were fined a total of $27,000, he said. ``The average penalty was a paltry $740 _ $740 for a child's life in the United States,'' Schumer said. Suzanne Boutros, of Plainfield, Ind., said she was unaware until after her 17-year-old's death delivering a pizza that it was illegal for youngsters to drive cars on their jobs. The $1,000 fine that the pizza shop was assessed was not enough, she said. ``The quickest way to get sombeody's attention is through their pocketbook,'' Ms. Boutros said. On Thursday, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole announced that a three-day sting operation had uncovered 7,000 minors employed in dangerous jobs or working long hours in violation of child labor laws. The companies are expected to face civil fines totaling $1.8 million, she said. The committee chairman, Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., called the operation a ``spectacular public relations extravaganza,'' but said it had probably heightened the public's awareness about child labor violations. Lantos noted that the General Accounting Office, Congress' investigative arm, has reported that the 1,000 federal labor law inspectors spend about 4 percent of their efforts on child labor investigations. He called that percentage ``ludicrously and pathetically inadequate.'' Mrs. Dole has said she is not yet convinced additional resources are needed but said she will consider legislative changes such as stiffer penalties. Schumer and Pease are drafting a bill that would increase the penalties and make other changes in the law, such as expanding the definition of child labor violations to include door-to-door sales. They expect to introduce the measure next month. Lantos said the panel will try to find out whether child labor violations have increased because of labor shortages or increased economic pressures on families.

DOC.HEAD: Grumman Becomes Fourth Defense Contractor to Plead Guilty in Documents Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Grumman Corp. pleaded guilty Friday to illegally obtaining secret Air Force budget documents and was ordered to pay $2.5 million in fines and penalties. Grumman's guilty plea in U.S. District Court in suburban Alexandria, Va. made it the fourth defense contractor since November to plea guilty to illegal trafficking of Pentagon documents. The company pleaded guilty to two counts of conveyance of government property without authority in U.S. District Court in Alexandria. The company admitted that it obtained the two secret Air Force program objective memoranda for 1983 and 1984 through its former employee Harry Kotellos. Kotellos, 53, a retired Air Force lieutenant colonel who joined Grumman in 1980, pleaded guilty last Monday to conspiracy. He faces a possible five-year prison term and a fine of up to $250,000. In a statement of facts filed by prosecutors, Grumman admitted that between 1978 and 1985 it illegally acquired a wide range of Defense Department budget documents, including five-year spending plans for Pentagon programs. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton, who accepted the guilty plea, ordered the company to pay $2.5 million in fines and civil penalties. In a statement, the Grumman said it ``deeply regrets that the company or any of its employees was involved in conduct that resulted in today's guilty plea.'' ``Grumman fully recognizes the importance of adhering scrupulously to proper security procedures, and the company deplores the involvement of any of its employees in the misuse of classified documents,'' the company said. Grumman said it has instituted procedures ``designed to prevent any reoccurence'' of the offense. Since November, three other contractors have entered guilty pleas and three other individuals have been convicted in the investigation code-named ``Operation Uncover,'' an investigation still under way. They were: _Boeing Co. Boeing paid fines and penalties of $5.2 million following its Nov. 13 guilty plea. Former Boeing employee Richard Lee Fowler was convicted Dec. 7 of 39 counts of conspiracy, conveyance without authority, mail fraud and conversion of government property. He received a two-year prison sentence. _RCA Corp., a subsidiary of General Electric Co. RCA pleaded guilty Feb. 5 and paid fines and restitution totaling $2.5 million. A current RCA executive, Ronald Stevens, and a former executive, Leonard Kampf, are awaiting sentencing on their guilty pleas to conveyance without authority. They each face possible sentence of 10 years in prison. _Hughes Aircraft Co., a subsidiary of General Motors Corp. Hughes entered a guilty plea March 9 and was ordered to pay $3.57 million in fines and penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Strike, Prime Minister Calls for Resignation of Cabinet Minister
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Salim Hoss on Friday called on the interior minister to resign over a shooting outside the Central Bank that occurred when police tried to arrest the bank's governor. Banks throughout Lebanon began a two-day strike to protest the arrest attempt. The Central Bank interrupted foreign exchange operations Thursday, a few minutes after a police patrol sent by Interior Minister Elias Khazen arrived at the bank with a warrant to arrest bank director Edmond Naim. Sources at the bank said the conflict began when Naim refused to allocate $1.5 million that Khazen had requested for printing one million new Lebanese passports. Naim, a Maronite Catholic, has been a virtual prisoner in the bank for two years due to fears for his safety. The bank is in Moslem west Beirut. Bank employees surrounded the police to prevent Naim's arrest Thursday. One employee was wounded when police shot in the air to try to disperse the group. The police left the building after bank guards began shooting in the air. Banks said they intend to strike until ``the instigators are brought to trial.'' A government spokesman quoted Hoss as saying that ``this aggression should not go unpunished. The person basically responsible for the attack should bare the responsibility.'' ``The natural way to achieve this is for the interior minister to resign,'' Hoss was quoted as telling President Elias Hrawi by telephone. Khazen and Naim are both Maronites, the Catholic community that has dominated Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. The bank is in Syrian-controlled Moslem west Beirut. Naim is one of the only Maronite officials to have an office on the Moslem side of the city. Khazen had negotiated a contract with a British company to print the Lebanese passports, but Naim had already received an offer from a Swedish firm to print the passports at half that cost. Khazen visited Naim late Thursday to apologize for the incident and said that ``the incident is over. Its consequences have been solved.'' But the independent an-Nahar newspaper said Naim has decided to sue the interior minister on charges of attempted murder and kidnapping. Justice Minister Nabih Berri said Friday the government will hold an extraordinary session to discuss the attemped arrest. The Lebanese pound, once the most solid currency in the Middle East, has been hit hard by the 15-year civil war, dropping in the past five years from five pounds per dollar to around 550. Until now the bank has been the only government institution to remain largely intact through the war.

DOC.HEAD: Blind Demonstrators Demand Pensions, Monopoly Over Professions
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of blind people demonstrated outside government headquarters Friday, waving their canes and demanding pensions, priority housing and control over industries where large numbers of the blind work. ``We demand...the right to work,'' said Ion Manea, a representative of the the Enterprise for the Blind. ``Up to now we've only made brushes and boxes and done massage and worked on the switchboard.'' ``Since we were trained to do this ... and we cannot do anything else, we ask the goverment to give us a monopoly over these professions,'' he said. Manea said his group was also demanding pensions for the blind and a priority in the allocation of government assigned apartments. The blind received few benefits under President Nicolae Ceausescu, who was overthrown in a bloody December revolution. But they were well treated compared to the mentally and physically handicapped, who were locked in state institutions under extremely poor conditions. The number of blind people in Romania's 23 million population was not available.

DOC.HEAD: Police Warn Motorists Against Using Back Roads
DOC.TEXT: A white motorist died Friday when black township residents, believing they were about to be attacked by a rival black group, stopped his car on a back road and hacked him to death, police said. Two black residents also apparently died of shock after hearing unfounded reports of the impending attack, they said. Police warned motorists against using the sideroads and old highways passing near black townships to avoid mobs who were stopping and stoning cars. More than 300 blacks have been killed in nationwide unrest over the past six weeks in some of the worst violence since the mid-1980s. Much of the violence has involved black-on-black fighting. Late Thursday, thousands of women and children in townships south of Johannesburg took refuge in hospitals, police stations and trade union offices after hearing rumors that Zulu migrant workers would attack, police said. Men remained at home, arming themselves and setting up roadblocks of huge stones on the highways south of Johannesburg. Mobs numbering in the hundreds stoned cars that failed to stop, police said. Police said the 40-year-old white man driving his luxury car past the black residential area of Sebokeng, south of Johannesburg, was killed when a crowd of blacks armed with pickaxes and machetes hacked him to death, police said. A 17-year-old white girl was injured when rioters hurled a garden fork through the back window of the car in which she was riding, piercing her forehead, according to relatives and police. The couple she was riding were injured by glass splinters as tin cans and rocks shattered the car windows, the independent South African Press Association reported. The Zulus, one of several black tribes in South Africa, come from the southeast part of the country. Most blacks in the Johannesburg area belong to other tribes. Meanwhile, police said a black policeman arrested in connection with the shooting death of a white riot squad officer was killed Friday while attempting to escape from his captors. Maj. Deon Terblanche, head of riot police in Pietermaritzburg, Natal Province, was found Wednesday slumped over the wheel of his unmarked car, parked beside a freeway. He had been shot several times at close range. A black constable and member of the riot police, Ray Ngcobo, was arrested Thursday in connection with the slaying. Ngcobo was expected to be brought to court Friday, but instead, police said he was taken by car to the scene of Terblanche's death. Ngcobo grabbed the pistol of one of the officers, who then shot him, police said. Elsewhere, a black man was killed in an exchange of gunfire with army troops in a township outside the port city of Durban, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Brathwaite Sworn in as Grenada's Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: Nicholas Brathwaite, who led a 13-month interim government after the U.S.-led invasion of Grenada in 1983, was sworn in as prime minister on Friday following an indecisive national election. British Governor General Sir Paul Scoon administered the oath of office to Brathwaite although his National Democratic Congress party wound up one seat short of a parliamentary majority in Tuesday's election. A party normally must have a parliamentary majority to form a government, but the governor-general has constitutional discretion to waive the requirement if he thinks enough legislative support exists to govern. The National Democratic Congress won seven of the 15 seats in the House of Representatives, Grenada's parliament. The Grenada United Labor Party of former Prime Minister Sir Eric Gairy came in second with four seats. Two seats each went to The National Party, led by Ben Jones, and the New National Party, led by former Cabinet minister Keith Mitchell. The deadlock was broken after Brathwaite reached a tentative deal with Jones Friday. Jones resigned earlier in the day as acting prime minister, a post he held since the death of Prime Minister Herbert Blaize in December. Brathwaite and Jones both said they held talks Thursday about a new government, but they gave conflicting versions of what emerged. Brathwaite said Jones agreed to become deputy prime minister in the new government; Jones' colleague, legislator Alleyne Walker, would become public works minister, and both would support Brathwaite in moving legislation through parliament. Jones said the deal offered by Brathwaite was not good enough and he was waiting to hear further from him. He denied assuring Brathwaite of support, saying: ``I told him clearly that I was not making any commitment on that.'' The mix-up could mean this tiny Caribbean island nation of 94,000 people may have to hold another election. Brathwaite, 64, headed an interim government after U.S. troops, joined by a small regional force, invaded Gerenada on Oct. 25, 1983, and toppled a ruling Marxist junta. He was president until the last election in December 1984. Grenada gained independence from Britain in 1974.

DOC.HEAD: A Look at Ceremonies Honoring Anderson
With AM-Hostages-Anderson Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Terry Anderson's friends and family on Friday somberly marked his fifth year as a captive in Lebanon. Here are some of the ceremonies:
DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON
DOC.TEXT: Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, met President and Mrs. Bush at the White House then addressed a ceremony across the street at Lafayette Park. Directing her remarks to her brother's captors, she said: ``You complain that your story has not been told and yet the man who would tell it has been chained to a basement wall for five years. ... ``I don't want to punish them. I don't want to hunt them down. I just want my brother back,'' she said. Others at the observance included Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y.; newsman Dan Rather, and the Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, a former hostage.
DOC.HEAD: PARIS
DOC.TEXT: Two former hostages in Lebanon, Jean-Paul Kauffmann and Roger Auque, put on blindfolds and chained themselves to a tree outside the Iranian Embassy. The two were silent during their demonstration, but said in a statement: ``We have taken this action so people know how Terry Anderson is living at this moment. He is chained. He wears a blindfold over his eyes. He must be silent. This is how we were. This is how he is today.'' The statement said the demonstration was not intended as a ``hostile action'' against Iran, but added: ``We know the role played by certain Iranian officials in our tragedy.''
DOC.HEAD: NICOSIA, CYPRUS
DOC.TEXT: Anderson's 4-year-old daughter, Sulome, and her mother, Madeleine Bassil, attended a prayer service led by the Rev. Alistair Wynn at Nicosia Community Church. With family, journalists, and friends watching, Sulome lit a candle beside a photograph of her father on the altar to, as Wynn put it, ``light Terry's darkness.'' ``Let us pray that this will be the last time we have to gather to pray for Terry's release,'' Wynn said. ``We hope that the next time we come together will be to celebrate his freedom.''
DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK
DOC.TEXT: Anderson's friends and colleagues attended a Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral near The Associated Press headquarters. The Rev. Anthony Dalla Villa, rector of the cathedral, said in his homily that Anderson has become ``more than a symbol. He is an instrument for our time. ... God uses Terry Anderson as an instrument to teach us something profound.''
DOC.HEAD: TOKYO
DOC.TEXT: The Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan honored Anderson, who was assigned to the AP Tokyo bureau from January 1977 to August 1981. Members of the club raised empty glasses in a symbolic salute.
DOC.HEAD: BATAVIA, N.Y.
DOC.TEXT: Yellow ribbons hung from trees, signs and telephone poles in Anderson's hometown as relatives, friends and strangers fasted and prayed for his release. A service in downtown Batavia was planned to climax a 24-hour fast that nearly 200 people started Thursday night. ``I hereby commit myself to one day of prayer and fasting for Terry's release and the release of all innocent human beings held hostage anywhere in the world,'' read pledges signed by the fasters.
DOC.HEAD: LORAIN, OHIO
DOC.TEXT: In the town where Anderson was born, 200 people held a rainy vigil as veterans fired a rifle salute and three of his cousins tied a large yellow ribbon around the city's flagpole. ``Terry's in the hands of some zealots who don't give a damn about humanitarian concerns,'' said Jack LaVriha, organizer of the Free Terry Anderson Committee. ``We must keep on praying and keep the faith. We must not give up hope.''
DOC.HEAD: WALTHAM, MASS.
DOC.TEXT: In their second annual American Hostage Day assembly, 400 students at South Middle School honored Anderson and his fellow hostages. Principal Paul A. Connolly told students and staff ``your thousands of letters and prayers for these men shows a compassion that is missing in our government and many of our fellow Americans.'' Other speakers included former hostage Jerry Levin and AP Special Correspondent George Esper. The ceremony was sponsored jointly by South Middle School and the Society of Professional Journalists chapter at Emerson College in Boston.
DOC.HEAD: FRANKFORT, KY.
DOC.TEXT: Kentucky legislators adopted resolutions denouncing the ``oppressors who have so cruelly deprived Terry Anderson, an American citizen, of his right to freedom,'' and saluted Peggy Say ``for her continuous effort toward restoring her brother's freedom.'' Say lives in Cadiz, Ky., and Anderson once worked as news editor in the AP's Louisville bureau.
DOC.HEAD: AMES, IOWA
DOC.TEXT: At Iowa State University, where Anderson received a journalism and political science degree in 1974, the campus carillon is to toll 60 times on Monday, once for each month he has been held captive.

DOC.HEAD: German Mine from World War II Sinks Trawler
DOC.TEXT: A French trawler rammed a submerged German mine left over from World War II and sank in the English Channel, maritime authorities said Friday. While the 8{-foot mine, packed with 1,650 pounds of explosives, failed to explode, the Maritime Prefecture in this northern port said the fishing trawler Pierre le Dieppois sank after its hull cracked open after striking by the mine. Two crewmen were slightly injured in the accident Wednesday and rescued by another trawler. Explosives experts from the navy minesweeper Cybele safely detonated the mine Thursday, the prefecture said.

DOC.HEAD: Disgraced East German Leader Admits Mistakes Were Made
With AM-Germany
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Erich Honecker admits he made mistakes during his 18 years of iron-fisted rule, but feels he should not become a scapegoat for everything that went wrong, a pastor's wife who gave him refuge said Friday. ``He told me that some mistakes were made, but that not everything (done by his government) was a complete failure,'' said Sigrid Holmer, who with her husband, Thomas, a Lutheran pastor, has taken in the ailing 77-year-old Honecker and his wife. Two days before the East German elections, Mrs. Holmer spoke in the living room of the two-story parish house where the disgraced Communist and his wife, Margot, have lived since Jan. 30. The Holmers provided a safe haven after no one else would take in the Honeckers, who only five months ago were cheered by millions of East Germans. Lutheran Church documents show that, among others, the army refused to let the Honeckers live at a military base, saying it could not guarantee their safety. Honecker, toppled by a popular revolution in October, faces trial on high treason charges, but was released after a two-day detention in prison in January because he suffers from kidney cancer. The Honeckers live in seclusion in the house, with graying stucco walls and a forest nearby. When Mrs. Holmer's 18-year-old son, Traugott, asked Honecker on Friday at the request of an Associated Press reporter whether he had a message for East Germans before the elections, Honecker responded that his lawyers had asked him to remain silent. ``When the lines of curiosity-seekers drive by every weekend, Honecker sometimes stands at the second-floor window and looks outside,'' the son said. Mrs. Holmer said the Honeckers closely follow East German political developments, reading several East and West German newspapers and watching television. They live in two rooms on the second floor, and Mrs. Honecker, 62, cooks their meals on a small stove, said Mrs. Holmer. She said the couple brought a couch and table from their former home in Wandlitz, a secluded luxury enclave near Berlin, but that the rest of the furniture was provided by the Holmers. Honecker remains indoors nearly all the time, only taking an occasional evening walk with the pastor. ``My husband looks around first if the coast is clear'' to make sure Honecker will not be accosted outdoors, she said. Mrs. Holmer said the family also received bomb threats after taking in the Honeckers. On Friday a coal truck driver passing by the house shouted ``Kill the guy!'' and then drove off. Honecker's former political cronies have abandoned him. Only his daughter, Sonja, and infant granddaughter, Viviane, visit occasionally, bringing food and other supplies from nearby Berlin. Mrs. Holmer described Honecker as a ``very considerate guest.'' At first, the Honeckers ate with the Holmer family downstairs. ``The first day, my husband told him that we usually say grace before dinner,'' Mrs. Holmer said. ``Mr. Honecker said `Of course, go right ahead.''' Under the Honecker regime, Christians could practice their religion, but were hindered when they wanted to study at a university or advance in their jobs.
