Mrs. Holmer said nine of her 10 children were unable to go to college because they refused to join the Communist Party's youth movement. The youngest, Kornelius, is 14 and will have a free choice. But Traugott, who gave his room to the Honeckers, had to become an apprentice carpenter because the road to higher education was blocked. He said he felt no bitterness toward Mrs. Honecker, who was education minister during his school years. ``She is a pretty nice lady, and we talk sometimes,'' said Traugott, a lanky teen-ager with unruly blond hair. Then he excused himself and sped off on his motorbike to put up campaign posters for the conservative Alliance for Germany in Lobetal, a village of 700 people about six miles northeast of Berlin. The Lutheran Church presence is particularly strong in Lobetal, which also contains homes for the retarded, elderly and handicapped. Drab, weathered homes line cobblestone streets. A pleasant woods surrounds most of the town. Mrs. Holmer, 58, said she took the hard times under the Communists in stride. ``Christians were never promised a pain-free life,'' she said. Asked why she took in the Honeckers, she said: ``We have a statue of Christ here, and underneath is the biblical inscription, `Come to me, all those who are tired and downtrodden.'''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Preliminary US-Philippine Base Talks Begin Next Month
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Friday the long-delayed talks on the future of the six U.S. military bases in the Philippines will begin next month. Cheney stressed, however, that ``we'll depart'' the Philippines if the talks do not result in an agreement acceptable to the United States. Anti-American sentiment has been running high in the Philippines on the base issue. During a two-week trip last month to Asia that included a stop in Manila, protestors burned figures of Cheney in effigy and he was snubbed by Philippine President Corazon Aquino. Mrs. Aquino expressed unhappiness over a $96 million cut Congress made in the Bush administration's request of $360 million to compensate the Philippines for the use of sites that include the two largest U.S. bases overseas _ Clark Air Base and Subic Naval Base. The leases for the six sites expire next year. Preliminary talks on the bases had been scheduled to start in last December, but were put off following the most recent coup attempt against the Aquino government. Cheney noted the divisiveness of the issue within the Philippines in discussing the bases Friday at the National Newspaper Association. ``The situation in the Philippines is a difficult one,'' he said. But despite the public tiff with Mrs. Aquino, Cheney praised her as a ``symbol of democracy'' because she helped topple the regime of Ferdinand Marcos and helped restore democracy. ``Our presence in the Philippines has been important to the U.S. ... We have an interest in continuing at Subic and Clark Air Force Base if we can,'' Cheney said. The secretary said he learned what a ``very sensitive issue'' the bases are for Filipinos during his Philippine visit, but he stressed ``there is a limit to what we can afford to pay in order to continue to use those facilities.'' ``And we will begin the negotiations next month. Hopefully, we'll be able to reach an agreement that will allow us to continue to use those facilities. But obviously, if the Filipinos do not want us there or if we're unable to conclude an acceptable agreement from our standpoint, we'll depart,'' Cheney said. A Pentagon official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a specific date for the talks has not been set, but that they were expected to begin in mid-April. The preliminary talks are expected to lay the groundwork for full-scale negotiations between representatives that will be appointed to handle the talks, another official said. ``We have to agree to negotiate. The Filipinos could decide not to negotiate. That's a possibility,'' the second official said. Cheney's visit to the Philippines came during a trip designed to reassess the U.S. military posture in the Pacific and to prepare a plan to reduce troops in the region by 10 percent in light of tight budgets and reduced international tensions. In his speech, Cheney said America would fall from superpower status if military spending were cut in half over the next decade, as proposed by some defense experts. ``When serious people propose cutting the defense budget by half over the next 10 years ... they are not talking just about simple budget shifts,'' Cheney said. ``They would give us the defense budget for a second-class power.'' Among the most prominent advocates of halving the defense budget over the coming decade is William Kaufmann, a former Pentagon official who recently said such large reductions could be achieved without harming the nation's security. The Bush administration is proposing to cut next year's defense budget by about 2 percent, after inflation, to $292 billion. Many in Congress are pressing for a bigger cut. ``I think the notion of America's inevitable decline is both wrong and dangerous,'' Cheney said. ``My sincere belief is that far from becoming less of a force in the world, America is going to be taking on greater global responsibilities in years ahead.''

DOC.HEAD: Mozambique Expels Portuguese Reporter Over News Account
DOC.TEXT: A Portuguese journalist working for LUSA news agency and the Voice of America was ordered to leave Mozambique on Friday because of a story he wrote, and the VOA said he departed for France. The government had ordered Antonoio Mateus out of this southeast African country, a former Portuguese possession, within 24 hours for writing a story it said damaged Mozambique's image and constituted ``active disinformation.'' Information Minister Teodato Hunguana also said the story, filed to LUSA, the Portuguese news agency, and the U.S.-based radio network ``has no basis in fact.'' But other government departments acknowledged that elements of the story were true. According to Hunguana, Mateus filed a story Monday saying military helicopters flew over the capital the previous Saturday and that on Monday special police units patrolled the city following ``rumors about the launching of a wave of protest against the cost of living.'' Hunguana said the story also mentioned the detention of ``12 unemployed people'' Monday. The Mozambican national news agency AIM quoted an official source as saying it is routine for air force helicopters to fly over the capital, and that the flights Saturday ``had nothing to do with the rumors referred to by LUSA.'' AIM said the detentions mentioned by Mateus did occur, but had nothing to do with the kind of operation he described. It said police made arrests after a gang of petty criminals stole goods from stallholders in an open market. Deputy VOA director Bob Coonrod told The Associated Press in Washington that Mozambican authorities were offended because Mateus refused to divulge the name of a senior police officer he quoted anonymously in his account. Coonrod said Mateus had been a part-time reporter for VOA for three years.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms, Record Highs, Floods And Snow
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rain fell across much of the Southeast on Friday, causing flooding in Florida and Georgia. In the Northeast, the record heat wave held on but blowing snow obscured parts of the upper Midwest. At midday, showers and thunderstorms extended from southern Louisiana across southern and central Mississippi, Alabama, the northwestern two-thirds of Georgia, western South Carolina, western North Carolina, eastern Tennessee, western Virginia, West Virginia, the Maryland Panhandle, southwestern through central Pennsylvania and eastern Ohio. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to noon included 3.6 inches at Milton, Fla.; 2.79 inches at Troy, Ala.; 2.4 inches at Fort Benning, Ga.; 1.93 inches at Anniston, Ala.; 1.86 inches at Columbus, Ga.; 1.72 inches at Pensacola, Fla.; 1.71 inches at Mobile, Ala.; 1.58 inches at New Orleans; 1.32 inches at Atlanta; 1.36 inches at Marietta, Ga.; 1.34 inches at Asheville, N.C.; and 1.03 inches at Bluefield, W.Va. That brought the total rainfall since noon Thursday to 10.63 inches at Mobile and 8.51 inches at Montgomery, Ala. Heavy rain closed schools and highways and sent rivers over their banks in northern Georgia. And as much as 5 more inches of rain was expected through Saturday as wet weather moves across the region from the Gulf of Mexico. Polk County, Ga., police ordered the evacuation of a trailer park on the edge of Cedartown, where 4.1 inches of rain fell. Authorities in Chattooga County reported 16 secondary roads closed by water and said they did not have enough warning signs to go around. A series of northern Georgia floods beginning Feb. 10 resulted in at least nine deaths. In southern Alabama, schools were closed in Mobile and highways and homes were flooded. Alabama state troopers in Crenshaw County temporarily closed U.S. Highway 29 between Brantley and Dozier after an earthen dam on a 3-acre private pond broke. Several homes were evacuated south of Foley because another dam burst on a private lake. No serious injuries were reported, but a Mobile police officer suffered a leg injury when his patrol car was washed off a highway into a utility pole. In the western Florida Panhandle, flooded roads also stranded motorists in stalled cars and violent wind caused minor property damage, authorities said. No injuries were reported. A child clinging to a bridge over a swollen creek was rescued in the Cantonment area about 10 miles north of Pensacola, said Lt. Keith Edmonson of the Cantonment Volunteer Fire Department. In Santa Rosa County, Fla., several roads were closed north of Milton and a tornado reportedly damaged several trees at Milton, but there were no injuries or damage to the building, said Peggy Cheshire, a Civil Defense assistant. Friday's record highs, according to the National Weather Service, were 78 at Atlantic City, N.J.; 76 at Baltimore; 65 at Binghamton, N.Y.; 68 at Buffalo, N.Y.; 78 at Burlington, Vt.; 82 at Newark, N.J.; 82 at New York; 71 at Rochester, N.Y.; 78 at Syracuse, N.Y.; 70 at Worcester, Mass.; and 79 at Windsor Locks, Conn. The heat wave began March 8, starting in Montana and Wyoming, then spread east and south, followed by cooler air. Another part of the nation also had warmer weather Friday _ Barrow, Alaska, posted a record high of 27. More seasonable weather dominated the upper Midwest, where snow fell over northwestern Iowa, eastern South Dakota, eastern North Dakota and northern Minnesota. Rain fell across eastern Nebraska and west-central through southwestern Iowa. Advisories of blowing and drifting snow were posted over northeastern North Dakota and west-central and northwestern Minnesota. Eight to 12 inches of snow fell across that region Thursday. Wind gusted to 62 mph at Chadron, Neb., 59 mph at Rapid City, S.D., and near 50 mph at Pierre, S.D., during the morning. Nebraska Gov. Kay Orr signed a request Friday that tornado-ravaged south-central Nebraska be declared a federal disaster area. Adj. Gen. Stanley Heng of the Nebraska National Guard, who also heads the state Civil Defense, said the overall damage could be over $10 million. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 24 at Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 87 at Avon Park, FlA. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 4 above zero at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Fitzwater: Libyan Plant Likely ``Out of Business''
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 7th graf, Defense Secretary, with Cheney comment on fire; picks up 7th graf pvs, The Bush
DOC.TEXT: White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Friday a suspected chemical weapons plant in Libya was most likely ``out of business'' as a result of this week's blaze. ``I don't think we can say for certain ... but we do think some very extensive and serious damage has been done,'' Fitzwater said. He said he would not speculate on whether sabotage caused the explosion and fire at the Rabta plant. ``We still do not have a conclusion of how it occured.'' Asked if the United States had been assured by Israel and West Germany that they were not responsible for the fire, Fitzwater would only say: ``I don't know who we've talked to about this.'' Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi had said his government is investigating to determine whether West German intelligence agents had anything to do with Wednesday's fire. Both Israel and West Germany have denied any responsiblity, as has the United States. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, asked during an appearance Friday at a National Newspaper Association conference about the fire, said, ``I'm inclined to attribute it more to Libyan incompetence than anything else.'' The Bush administration has said all along that the plant was producing poison gas, although Libya insists the factory was making pharmaceuticals. ``It seems likely that it's out of business, common sense would suggest that. But I don't think we can reach an absolute conclusion at this point,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen: Project Faces Tough Funding Battle
With AM-Super Collider, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Designers of the government's giant atom-smasher are finally preparing to buy land for the project, but the battle for funding has just begun, key backers told a scientists' meeting Friday. The struggle to wring the first of a projected $7.5 billion from the federal budget for the superconducting super collider will move to the House Science, Space and Technology Committee in two weeks. Committee chairman Robert A. Roe, D-N.J., urged scientists, educators and industry figures at the meeting here to lobby for the project in Texas, designed to study the particles that make up atoms. ``We can't build it alone,'' Roe said in a speech at the International Industrial Symposium on the Super Collider. ``We can't get the votes on the floor of the House alone.'' The collider, awarded to Texas after an intense struggle among several states, will consist of an underground loop 54 miles in diameter to be built south of Dallas. The precise location of the loop was revealed Thursday at the symposium. The collider would use powerful electromagnets to send streams of protons traveling at nearly the speed of light smashing into each other. The collisions would produce even smaller particles, leading to a better understanding of the nature of matter. Four other members of Congress at the conference joined Roe in urging a campaign of support. ``Make no mistake, this is not a done deal,'' said U.S. Rep. Jim Chapman, D-Texas. Of the $7.5 billion the committee is expected to recommend spending on the project over approximately 10 years, no more than $5 billion should come from the federal government, Roe said. Most estimates put the final price tag of the super collider at $8 billion. The remainder would come from Texas, foreign contributors, who could serve as contractors or research partners, and from innovative financing. One possibility, Roe said, would be to lease some of the buildings on the campus planned to house the collider's staff of 3,000 scientists and support workers. Critics say money spent on the super collider could be better used to meet concrete needs such as housing and improved education. But supporters point to benefits of the competing CERN particle physics project outside Geneva, Switzerland. Fourteen nations cooperate in that project, which is said to have brought better housing, improved the job market in the area and led to inventions. ``For every dollar we spend on (the collider) we'll at least bring back five dollars that wasn't there before,'' Roe said. CERN is a model, but could become a threat if the collider isn't built, some scientists say. ``It's important that you have good research opportunities for faculty so that we don't undergo a brain drain'' of U.S. scientists, said Marvin Gettner, particle physics professor at Northeastern University in Boston who has worked at the Swiss facility.

DOC.HEAD: `Let Them Go Free,' Students Sing
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: To the tune of ``America,'' 400 students on Friday sang out a plea for freedom for Terry Anderson and the other American hostages in Lebanon. In their second annual American Hostage Day assembly, the students at South Middle School sang: ``My country, can't you see ``Those losing liberty ``Please bring them home: ``We can't forget their plight, ``We want them in our sight, ``God using all your might ``Let them go free.'' The ceremony was sponsored jointly by the school and by the Society of Professional Journalists chapter at Emerson College in Boston. It was the final day of Emerson College's ``Terry Anderson Week,'' which featured a series of events to call attention to the plight of the hostages. Friday's speakers included Jeremy Levin, a former Cable News Network bureau chief in Beirut who himself was held hostage for almost a year. Friday was the fifth anniversary of Anderson's kidnapping in Beirut. He is the longest-held of eight American hostages in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Fires Three Pilots For Drinking Prior To Flight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with lawyer's comment, CORRECT St. Paul-Minneapolis to Minneapolis-St. Paul, add that federal limit on drinking is 8 hours. Picks up 8th graf, `The Air...'
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines on Friday fired three pilots accused of flying while legally intoxicated, saying the cockpit crew violated company rules by operating the jetliner within 12 hours of drinking. Each of the pilots on the 6:25 a.m. flight from Fargo, N.D., to the Twin Cities on March 8 had blood-alcohol levels exceeding .04 percent, a violation of federal regulations, the company said. ``Northwest pilots have established a reputation for airmanship and safety,'' company spokesman Alan Muncaster said. ``All of us at Northwest are now challenged to win back our reputation for flight excellence.'' The Federal Aviation Administration had already revoked the pilots' licenses after its own investigation showed that the cockpit crew boarded the flight within eight hours of drinking, the federal limit. Northwest imposes a stricter span of 12 hours. Northwest Flight 650, carrying 91 passengers, landed safely at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, where the cockpit crew was arrested by the FAA and airport police. Dismissed were Capt. Norman Prouse, 51, Conyers, Ga.; 1st Officer Robert Kirchner, 35, Highland Ranch, Colo.; and 2nd Officer Joseph Balzer, 34, Antioch, Tenn. None of the three has any previous alcohol or drug-related incidents on their flying records, the company said. Balzer's attorney, Bruce Hanley of Minneapolis, said he ``hasn't taken a formal position'' on the firing. Calls to Kirchner could not get through because the phone was busy and Prouse has an unlisted telephone number. The Air Line Pilots Association, the union representing Northwest's 5,400 pilots and about 36,600 other pilots, issued a statement out of Washington on Friday saying it has ``no tolerance whatsoever toward drugs or alcohol in the cockpit. ``Any airline pilot would be outraged and would take it as an affront to his profession, if it were proven that a cockpit crew flew impaired as alleged in this incident,'' the union statement said. But the statement emphasized that the three Northwest pilots are entitled to a fair hearing on the accusations. The National Transportation Safety Board has scheduled an appeals hearing before an administrative law judge April 3-6 in Minneapolis for the three crew members. All three were expected to appeal the license revocation, although Kirchner was the only pilot to file an appeal by Friday, said Drucilla Andersen, an NTSB spokeswoman. The pilots also face possible criminal prosecution by the city of Minneapolis and by the chief prosecutor in Cass County, North Dakota. The pilots were drinking at the Speak Easy, a Moorhead, Minn., restaurant and lounge late the night before they flew the Boeing 727, and a tipster informed the FAA, officials said. The plane took off while an inexperienced federal inspector in Fargo was telephoning his superiors to ask what to do, Associate FAA Administrator Anthony Broderick told a congressional committee Wednesday. Northwest said Friday that the inspector spoke to each of the pilots at the Fargo airport but did not stop the flight. Balzer issued a statement Thursday saying he offered to take a breath test, urine test or blood test for the FAA investigator before boarding the plane in Fargo. He said he was not required to do so. ``I offered to cooperate fully,'' Balzer said. ``It is absurd to suggest that the plane could take off from the Fargo airport without proper authorization from the control tower, which is operated by the FAA and manned by FAA controllers.'' Fred Farrar, an FAA spokesman in Washington, said Friday that the inspector instructed the cockpit crew that they could be in violation of FAA regulations by flying the plane. The crew decided to fly the plane despite the warning, Farrar said. The FAA inspector in Fargo telephoned Minneapolis after the flight departed from Fargo, setting up the arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Peace Activist Abie Nathan Meets with PLO leader
DOC.TEXT:
Peace activist Abie Nathan met with PLO chairman Yasser Arafat on Friday in defiance of an Israeli law that has already put him behind bars once, the PLO news agency WAFA reported. ``I came from Israel to meet with you after having spent 122 days in prison,'' WAFA quoted Nathan as saying to Arafat. ``I am working for peace and am against the law prohibiting contacts with the leaders of the PLO.'' An amendment to Israel's anti-terrrorism law makes meeting with officials in a terrorist organization a crime punishable by a maximum prison sentence of three years. Israel considers the Palestine Liberation Organization a terrorist group. ``Your courageous act is unforgettable for men who love peace and for the Palestinian and Israeli people,'' the agency quoted Arafat as saying. ``Future generations will appreciate your courageous and noble struggle for peace in the region.'' It was Nathan's eighth meeting with the PLO leader. Nathan's first meeting with Arafat was in 1982, when he went to Lebanon during the Israeli siege of Beirut in an unsuccessful attempt to gain freedom for a captured Israeli soldier. Nathan, 63, was sentenced to six months in prison after pleading guilty to meeting Arafat and other PLO officials in Tunis in 1988. He entered an Israeli prison near Tel Aviv on Oct. 10, 1989, and his penalty was reduced by two months for good behavior.
When he was freed Feb. 9, he passed through the prison gates and immediately vowed to meet Arafat again.

DOC.HEAD: Haiti State Council Pledges to Be `Watchdogs' for New President
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A civilian State Council that will help provisional President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot govern Haiti pledged Friday to be her ``watchdogs'' until elections are held. She introduced 11 of the 19 council members at a ceremony at the National Palace, saying, ``You are asked to help the government in its efforts to put in place the structures and conditions for holding democratic elections.'' ``Rest assured, Madame President, we will be your watchdogs to help you carry out the heavy load you have to bear,'' replied Louis Roy, main author of Haiti's 1987 constitution and the most prominent council member. The remaining members will come from eight provincial districts and will be sworn in later. The State Council will represent labor, human rights, church, business and peasant groups and will have veto power over presidential decisions. The Cabinet, subject to council approval, is expected to be appointed within days. Initially, the State Council was to contain an army representative but Roy said Thursday the army chose not to be in it. Roy said someone will be picked from The Women's Movement group to fill the vacancy. That means Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot's interim government will be all-civilian. The military had ruled Haiti, one of the poorest countries in the Western Hemisphere, since the fall of the Duvalier family dictatorship in 1986. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillota, a Supreme Court justice and Haiti's first woman president, became the country's leader Tuesday, one day after military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril fled Haiti. She will govern until elections, expected within three to six months. Businessman Antoine Izmery, a leader in the Unity Assembly party coalition that chose Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, said the U.S. Embassy is pushing for fast elections. The embassy denied it. ``The U.S. is more interested in a credible electoral process than in any particular candidate,'' U.S. Ambassador Alvin Adams told The Associated Press during Friday's ceremony. Adams was said to have played a big role in helping persuade Avril to quit. The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a highly popular priest and a strong critic of U.S. policy, cautioned the United States against backing a candidate who represents the interests of Haiti's tiny elite. He said that would provoke a popular reaction and could lead to ``the revolutionary road.''

Engineers managed to shift a wayward private communications satellite out of harm's way Friday, at least temporarily, and an aerospace company offered equipment for a possible salvage mission by a space shuttle. Engineers were able to send the Intelsat VI satellite to a new, higher orbit, where it won't be drawn back to Earth by the thickening atmosphere. The satellite failed to separate from its launch vehicle, a commercial Titan 3 rocket, after liftoff from Cape Canaveral on Wednesday and was trapped in a useless orbit that swung within 103 miles of Earth. On Friday, rocket builder Martin Marietta attributed the failure to a wiring problem in its Titan 3 launch vehicle that was ``undetected by the processes and test procedures used in pre-launch checkout.'' Kerry Masson, a Martin Marietta spokeswoman in Denver, said the signal failed to make it from an onboard computer to the mechanism that was to separate the rocket and the satellite. Without that separation, a motor attached to the satellite was unable to propel the spacecraft to its duty station 22,300 miles above Earth. When engineers finally separated the sent rockets, the booster rocket remained with the launch vehicle and both were expected to fall back to Earth soon. Intelsat, the international communications consortium which owns the $150 million uninsured satellite, fired small onboard thrusters and raised the satellite's orbit by nearly 60 miles. That put the 5-ton satellite out of immediate reach of the atmosphere. ``This is very good news,'' said Tony Trujillo, spokesman for the 118-nation consortium. ``We feel much better about the mission right now.'' ``Right now, we are concentrating discussing with NASA on the possibility of assistance,'' Trujillo said. Such assistance would have to come from the space shuttle. Orbital Sciences Corp., a small Virginia aerospace company, sent a letter to various parties, including Intelsat and NASA, offering a newly developed rocket assembly that can be attached to a stranded satellite in orbit. ``Specifically, the OSC plan is to carry a replacement perigee motor to orbit on the shuttle, mate the motor to the satellite, and complete the mission from orbit rather than returning the satellite to Earth for refurbishment and relaunch,'' said the letter to NASA administrator Richard Truly and others. The device, called a transfer orbit stage or TOS, is designed to boost spacecraft from low Earth orbit to the 22,300 mile-high altitude at which communications satellites operate. The device was qualified for space flight only in January. ``We haven't proposed anything,'' said Robert Lovell, a vice president of Orbital Sciences. But, he said, the company has talked with colleagues about using the transfer stage if the shuttle were made available. ``The TOS could be sent up in the shuttle, astronauts would attach it to the spacecraft and send it on its way,'' Lovell said. Only one transfer orbit stage has been built _ the engineering model used in qualification tests. Lovell said that's the one that would be offered for the rescue. While the satellite was in a 103 mile by 218 mile orbit, NASA said it would not consider a rescue. The low point of that orbit brushes the upper edge of the atmosphere and the satellite was given only a nine-day life. NASA has performed five spectacular space rescues, the latest this year when it brought back the bus-size Long Duration Exposure Facility. In 1984, astronauts brought back two satellites stranded in a useless orbit because their attached rockets didn't ignite. Johnson Space Center spokesman Kyle Herring said that mission, which involved spacewalks, required nine months of planning. Asked what a rescue mission for the Intelsat satellite would cost, Lovell said the biggest expense would be the shuttle mission. The transfer orbit stage would require about a third of the space in the cargo bay, he said. In its new orbit, 161 miles at the low point, the Intelsat satellite can stay in space for months. Moreover, because the satellite had enough steering fuel to last for 13 years, there is plenty left to keep it out of the grip of the atmosphere. The satellite was propelled into space at a cost of about $270 million in the fourth commercial launch of a payload by a U.S. company. The Intelsat VI spacecraft was intended to transmit three TV channels and up to 120,000 telephone calls simultaneously. It was to have eventually replaced two older satellites over the Atlantic.

DOC.HEAD: Anderson Begins Sixth Year in Captivity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final two grafs with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Carter remarks, later Say comment.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY18,TOK3,DAM1,NIC2,WX17,WX23
DOC.TEXT: Terry Anderson's daughter pleaded for the father she loves but has never met to come home Friday, the day Anderson began his sixth year as a hostage in Lebanon. The journalist's family, friends and colleagues marked the anniversary with commemorations and prayers in Washington, New York, and Cyprus. Yellow ribbons fluttered from trees, signs and poles in Anderson's hometown of Batavia, N.Y. Former hostages chained themselves to a tree in Paris to protest Anderson's captivity, and President Bush pledged to work for the hostages' release. But no message was as poignant the one on television Friday evening in Lebanon. In a videotape, Anderson's 4-year-old daughter Sulome appeared, wearing a green coat and riding a bicycle given to her at Christmas in Anderson's name. ``I got the bike for Christmas, Daddy. Thank you,'' said Sulome, who was born 83 days after Anderson was seized by a pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem faction in Beirut. ``I love you, Daddy, come home, please come home. I love you, Daddy. Come home. Send me to the circus,'' she beseeched. The videotape was made earlier in the week and shipped to the television stations in Beirut. Lebanese newspapers also published a letter Friday signed ``Sulome and Madeleine,'' from the girl and her mother, Madeleine Bassil, who wait in Cyprus for Anderson's release. ``The world without God is not the world, it's hell. A home without a husband or father is not a home, it's hell,'' the letter said. ``I am always wondering if you have ever been able to read the letters sent to you on different occasions, or even if they were read to you to let you know how much we love you and how different and difficult life is without you,'' Ms. Bassil wrote. ``We are in as much captivity, Terry. Only our living space is bigger here and it is shared by the millions. I know you will keep well, I know you will never give up. Until we meet again soon. God bless you. We love you.'' Papers published the English text of the letter hoping that Anderson, who did not know Arabic when he was kidnapped, would be allowed to read it. Anderson, 42, is the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He has been held longer than any of the 18 Western hostages in Lebanon. Most of the others, who include eight Americans, have been held at least three years and the prayers offered on Friday were for all the hostages. The factions holding captives are affiliated with the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, made up of Shiite Moslem zealots following the anti-Western teachings of the late Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. A Hezbollah prayer leader, speaking at a rally in Lebanon on Friday, said ``We in Hezbollah are regarded as terrorists and kidnappers of innocent people. ... America, Israel and France taught us to kill. They kidnapped us and kidnapped thousands of people. Our hostages are more than theirs.'' ``The abduction of one American is the end of the world, but no one cares about the abduction of a whole nation,'' Sheik Mohammed Khatoun said as about 2,000 sympathizers chanted Islam's cry of ``Allahu Akbar!'' The rally was called to mourn five Hezbollah fighters killed in a clash with Israeli troops in south Lebanon on March 8. Bush pledged to work for the hostages' freedom. ``I intend to keep open lines of communications with all parties, including Iran, who have influence over hostage takers,'' he said in a letter to Peggy Say, Anderson's sister. But Thursday, the president said there were no immediate prospects for the hostages' freedom and said he was perplexed by the recent ``wave of speculation'' about a possible hostage release. This included reports in Iranian newspapers recently saying the hostage issue should be resolved. However, on Thursday a group holding three American educators threatened to kill them unless their demands were met. It did not specify its demands. Earlier in the month, another faction denounced media reports of possible hostage releases and said it had no intention of freeing its captives. Anderson is held by Islamic Jihad. It has demanded the release of comrades jailed in Kuwait for bombing the U.S. and French embassies in December 1983. Mrs. Say met privately with Bush and his wife at the White House, then spoke at a ceremony across the street at Lafayette Park. Directing her remarks to her brothers' captors, she said: ``You complain that your story has not been told and yet the man who would tell it has been chained to a basement wall for five years. ... ``I don't want to punish them. I don't want to hunt them down. I just want my brother back. But I'm not going to pay them for doing so,'' she said. Louis D. Boccardi, president and general manager of The Associated Press, said at the ceremony, ``At this point the greatest gift we can give him is to press on, to not falter, to find an honorable way to get the job done. If you know Terry, that's what he's thinking, too.'' Those attending included the Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, a former hostage who spent time locked up with Anderson before his release in 1986. The other Americans still held hostage are: Thomas Sutherland, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut; Frank Herbert Reed, director of the private Lebanon International School in Beirut; Joseph James Cicippio, acting comptroller of the American University of Beirut; Edward Austin Tracy, author of children's books; Jesse Turner, visiting professor of mathematics and computer science at Beirut University College; Alann Steen, journalism professor at Beirut University College; and Robert Polhill, assistant professor of business and lecturer in accounting at Beirut University College. Anderson's friends and colleagues attended a Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. In Tokyo, the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan arranged a Friday night ceremony to honor Anderson, who worked out of the AP Tokyo bureau from 1977 to 1981. Anderson's sister-in-law, Penny Anderson, and a cousin, Carl Anderson, were among those who attended an interfaith church service Thursday evening in the Buffalo suburb of Orchard Park, N.Y., about 40 miles from Anderson's boyhood home of Batavia. In Damascus, former President Jimmy Carter said Friday chances seem better than ever for the hostages' release and that Syrian President Hafez Assad pledged anew to help win their freedom. Carter, who later arrived in Jordan, said of Anderson, ``My own conviction is that more opportunities exist now for his release than ever before.'' State-run Syrian television broadcast a 20-minute interview with Mrs. Say, who toured the region last month to explore prospects for a hostage release. She expressed hope the hostages could be released in a way that would improve relations among America, the Arabs and Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Shootings Make Passengers Nervous; Striker Arrested in Attack
DOC.TEXT: A spate of shooting attacks against Greyhound buses left some replacement drivers here nervous, striking drivers defensive and passengers eyeing the aisle seats Friday. ``I'll sit in the middle. Not in the front and not in the back _ in the middle,'' 19-year-old Jane Smith said as she waited for a bus that would take her to Huntsville, Ala. ``And I'll sit kind of low, too,'' she added. As union and company negotiators met separately with federal mediators, a striking driver was arrested in Connecticut in one of more than a dozen shootings apparently related to the two-week-old strike. Roger D. Cawthra, 44, of Stratford was accused by police of firing a single shot from a large-caliber semiautomatic gun into the luggage compartment of a Greyhound bus outside Farmington on Monday. None of the 19 passengers was injured. Cawthra, a Greyhound driver for three years, was arraigned on charges of first-degree criminal mischief, a felony, and three misdemeanor counts: first-degree reckless endangerment, unlawful discharge of a firearm and unlawful discharge of a firearm on a public highway. He didn't enter a plea, but has declared he is innocent. Police said Cawthra, who was ordered held on $100,000 bond, was identified by the bus driver from a videotape of strikers taken by company security forces. Also Friday, a bullet fired from a passing car hit the windshield of a bus outside Phoenix, said Greyhound spokeswoman Ann Wheat. No one was injured. Ms. Wheat said three shots were fired; police said there was one. In Chattanooga, police escorted Greyhound buses within city limits _ a precaution prompted by two shootings in two days. Neither resulted in injuries. The first shooting occurred Wednesday, when a bullet hit the door of a bus on a highway after it left the Chattanooga terminal. On Thursday, a shot struck a bus windshield. There were no arrests. A telephoned bomb threat to a Greyhound bus yard in Los Angeles on Friday prompted evacuation of replacement workers and pickets alike, said police Sgt. Tom Jones. The anonymous caller said there was a bomb in the lobby, and in the search that followed bomb squad members found a suitcase that emitted a ticking sound in the cargo hold of a bus. That turned out to be a lost suitcase with an alarm clock inside, he said. Negotiators for Greyhound Lines Inc. and the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions met separately Friday in Tucson, Ariz., in preparation for face-to-face talks Saturday. It would be the first meeting of the adversaries since 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 other members of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions struck March 2 over wages and grievance procedures. Neither side commented on Friday's meetings. The Dallas-based company carried 47,685 passengers on Thursday, 38.5 percent of the number it carried the same day last year, according to spokeswoman Lyn Graley. Greyhound Chairman Fred. G. Currey has accused the union of ``terrorism'' in the attacks, but union leaders note none have been proven to be the work of strikers. One man has been killed in the walkout, a striking driver crushed by a bus on a picket line in Redding, Calif., on March 3. Striking drivers in Chattanooga on Friday said they shouldn't be blamed for the shootings. ``There are less than 20 union employees here, and we work a six-hour shift (on the picket line),'' said J.W. Kirk, a Greyhound driver for 27 years. ``After working six hours, you don't feel up to going out there and trying to hide (to shoot at a bus) and all that sort of stuff. And we are all family men.'' Some replacement drivers hired by the company said the attacks made them nervous. ``It's a thought, but it's not something my thoughts dwell on,'' said driver Ron Edwards, 36, during a stop at the Chattanooga terminal on a run between Atlanta and Chicago. ``I'm here to do a job,'' Edwards said. ``I hate that I had to get it because of the strike, I hated to walk across the picket line. But I was hungry.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Minister Calls Zambia's President a Dictator
DOC.TEXT: A former ally of President Kenneth Kaunda denounced the prominent African leader Friday as a dictator and called for democracy during a ruling party convention. The convention had been called to decide whether to keep one-party rule or allow multiparty democracy, but Kaunda announced Wednesday that the current system, in place since 1973, would remain. The attack on Kaunda came from Sikota Wina, who was once a Cabinet minister and belonged to the central committee of the ruling United National Independence Party. Wina made his criticisms in an open letter circulated Friday among 1,000 delegates to the fifth national convention of the party, the only lawful political movement in Zambia, a landlocked nation in southern Africa. Kaunda led the British colony of northern Rhodesia to independence as Zambia in 1964. Wina, drummed out of the party over 10 years ago for criticizing authoritarian rule, slammed Kaunda's homegrown philosophy of humanism. In his letter, Wina said, ``The country at present is run as a dictatorship masked behind the cloak of a meaningless slogan called `humanism.''' He also said ``the top leadership and their offspring'' had committed ``economic sabotage.'' He said they feel they are ``above the law.'' Wina said the convention should restore the multiparty system inherited from Zambia's colonial ruler. He also called for a limit in the terms a president can serve. Wina has made few public statements since 1986 when he was detained, first in India and then at home, on accusations of drug trafficking. He was later freed because of lack of evidence, and he has generally concentrated on private business since then.

DOC.HEAD: Fort Bragg NCO Said Investigated For Panama Incident
DOC.TEXT: The Army is investigating allegations that a prisoner was shot to death during the U.S. invasion of Panama, a military journal said Friday. Fifty-nine other incidents also are being investigated, including suicides and an accidental killing, Army Times said. All were described as happening in ``a combat situation.'' Army Times is an independent weekly. The publication provided advance copies of an article on the Panama invasions to appear in Monday's edition. Col. William Mulvey, chief of public affairs for the Army, said, ``They've got it wrong.'' But he declined to detail what was wrong with the article. Eight of the incidents involved deaths, including one in which a senior non-commissioned officer allegedly shot a prisoner and beat another after a skirmish at a roadblock, the journal reported. The NCO, said to have been a member of the 82nd Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, N.C., was part of a roadblock that stopped a car following the U.S. invasion on Dec. 20. Someone inside the car threw a hand grenade at the soldiers, who then fired into the car, killing some occupants, according to Army Times' account. The remaining occupants surrendered, got out and were taken prisoner. The NCO allegedly shot one of the prisoners, killing him, and severely beat another, according to the weekly. Other incidents involved the accidental killing of one U.S. soldier by another and two suicides, the publication said. In all, 21 formal investigations by the Criminal Investigation Command have been opened, Army Times said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Calls for More Anti-Apartheid Pressure
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela urged an increase in international pressure on South Africa's white government Friday, the same day President F.W. de Klerk announced talks have been arranged with the African National Congress. Mandela, vice president of the ANC, made no direct reference to the announcement in his speech to a rally of about 13,000 at Stockholm's Globe arena. Instead, he repeated his anti-apartheid group's conditions for negotiations with the South African government and called for renewed pressure through international sanctions. ``When the water is about to boil, it is foolish to turn off the heat,'' he declared. The rally, held in Mandela's honor, capped his five-day visit to Sweden to meet with African National Congress president Oliver Tambo, who is recovering from a stroke. During the international tour, Mandela also visited Zambia, Zimbabwe, Tanzania and the Netherlands. Mandela made the trip after he was freed from a South African prison in February. He served 27 years in prison on charges of sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white government. He shortened his visit to Sweden, originally intended to last until Saturday, to leave late Friday by chartered plane direct for Johannesburg to attend a rally in his honor there. Though he is expected to lead his group's delegation at talks with the government announced by de Klerk for April 11, Mandela said nothing of those plans Friday. Met by a standing ovation, Mandela said, ``The fundamental aspects of apartheid are intact, but there are signs the apartheid system is about to crumble.'' Apartheid is the South African system of racial discrimination. In his 15-minute speech, he repeated conditions for talks demanded earlier by the ANC: total lifting of the state of emergency in South Africa, freeing of all political prisoners, and repeal of repressive legislation. Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson, who attended the rally, promised in a brief speech that the Swedish government would stiffen its sanctions. He gave no details.

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong Proposes First Bill of Rights for Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: The government Friday released a proposed bill of rights to reassure Hong Kong residents that China will respect their political and economic system for 50 years after the territory reverts to Chinese rule. However, lawmaker Martin Lee called the document ``unacceptable'' because he said it could be changed by future legislatures. Beijing has pledged to guard human rights in Hong Kong and retain this British colony's legal and capitalistic systems for a half-century after it assumes control of Hong Kong in 1997. The proposed bill of rights, Hong Kong's first, amends the colonial constitution to incorporate the provisions of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. ``The bill of rights, as the embodiment of the covenant, will be the benchmark by which all laws enacted in Hong Kong will be tested,'' said Secretary for Constitutional Affairs Michael Suen. Suen said it would be almost ``impossible and very complicated'' to repeal the bill. However, the bill was criticized by some members of the Hong Kong lawmaking Legislative Council. Legislator Jimmy McGregor told the government-funded Radio Hong Kong that the draft was not in the best interest of the people. He said it could be easily repealed by the government after 1997. The bill allows for anyone who feels his rights have been violated to seek redress in any court or tribunal in the territory. In an emergency, the bill gives the government the right to take actions that would infringe on the Civil Rights Convenant. But these measures could not restrict certain basic rights, such as the right of life or freedom of conscience and religion. The government hopes to enact the bill in July. It decided to consolidate all the human rights provisions from various ordinances into a bill of rights because of mounting concern in Hong Kong that China would renege its pledges after 1997. Confidence in those pledges has evaporated since Beijing's June 3-4 military crackdown on the student-led Chinese movement for democratic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Children Injured in Bus-Truck Crash
LaserPhoto CO1
DOC.TEXT: A school bus carrying 43 pupils collided with a truck at a downtown intersection Friday. At least 12 children were injured but only one was admitted to a hospital. Bus driver Robert Conway, 30, and a witness said the bus and a truck were both headed northbound when the truck, on the bus's right side, tried to make a left turn. Aboard the bus were 43 third- through fifth-graders from Clinton Elementary School, two teachers and the driver, said one of the teachers, Samella Potter. The truck driver ``must have decided he needed to make a lefthand turn, and that's just what he did, right in front of that school bus,'' said Marie Forker, a witness who was driving behind the truck. ``When it happened (the pupils') heads just surged to the front.'' Conway said the bus was returning to Clinton Elementary after taking the children to see a play downtown. The truck driver, Harry C. Myers, 19, of Pickerington, was cited for making an improper left turn. The owner of the truck, Diewald and Pope Inc., a mechanical contractor, declined to comment. Children's Hospital spokeswoman Pam Barber said the hospital examined 12 pupils. Ten were treated and released, one was admitted in fair condition with a possible neck injury, and one was held for further examination. She said the children mostly complained of head and neck injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Giant Cocaine Bust Yields Guilty Pleas _ to Possessing 1 Ounce
DOC.TEXT: Two men arrested in a nine-ton cocaine bust _ described as the nation's second-largest _ pleaded guilty Friday to a reduced charge of possessing less than one ounce of cocaine. Prosecutor Ed Cyganiewicz said he agreed to the plea bargain because he feared the state court jury might give a lenient sentence or even probation. Jurors might have been sympathetic because the defendants worked only as ``mules,'' or laborers, for drug kingpins who aren't in custody, he said. Defense attorneys welcomed the plea bargain, entered in the middle of a trial after the prosecution rested its case based on the seizure of 18,360 pounds of cocaine at a farm house last year. ``You've got to admit there's a big difference between 18,360 pounds and one ounce,'' said defense attorney Hector Villarreal said. Defendants Hermenegildo Sosa Rivas, 51, and Guadencio Garcia Garcia, 39, both Mexican citizens, face two to 20 years in prison and fined $10,000 on the second-degree felony charge. The original first-degree felony charge of possessing more than 400 grams could have brought them life in prison and a $100,000 fine. Under Texas law, possession of less than 28 grams _ one ounce _ of cocaine is a second-degree felony carrying a two- to 20-year sentence. Possession of more than an ounce is a first-degree felony, with harsher penalties that increase further if the amount exceeds 400 grams, or about nine-tenths of a pound. Texas Department of Public Safety narcotics agents arrested Sosa and Garcia on Oct. 4, 1989, during the siezure in Harlingen in southern Texas. The only larger U.S. cocaine seizure, the department said, was a 20-ton cache found in a Los Angeles-area warehouse the week before. The prosecutor said he would ask Judge Darrell Hester to impose the maximum penalty of 20 years at the sentencing, scheduled for May 4. Defense attorney Villarreal maintained that Sosa and Garcia took a job as day laborers Oct. 4, unaware the job was packing cocaine for shipment. He said drug smugglers locked them in the house after they arrived. The prosecutor countered that the house was unlocked, and the men could have escaped any time or telephoned for help during the four hours they worked at the house.

DOC.HEAD: President Backs Talks With Guatemalan Rebels
DOC.TEXT: President Vinicio Cerezo gave his backing Friday to talks with leftist guerrillas on ending 30 years of fighting, dropping a demand that the rebels first lay down their arms. A member of the National Reconciliation Commission announced Thursday that it would hold its second meeting with the rebels March 27 to March 29 in Oslo, Norway. The commission was set up as part of a regional peace plan. ``We are going to listen to the proposal of the subversives,'' Cerezo said at a news conference Friday. ``At this historic moment, things are changing in the region,'' he said. ``What happened in Nicaragua, the softening of the attitude of the (Salvadoran) Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front and the willingness to talk with the Guatemalan guerrilla groups open very important expectations.'' The leftist Sandinistas in Nicaragua, who had provided a haven for Salvadoran and Guatemalan rebels, lost Feb. 25 elections to the U.S.-backed opposition. In El Salvador, leftist rebels said Tuesday they've called off assassination attempts on civilian officials and attacks on public transport to show they're serious about resuming peace talks with the rightist government. Speaking about the situation in Guatemala, Defense Minister Gen. Hector Alejandro Gramajo said at Friday's news conference, ``If the subversives are not doing this for international publicity, we believe that the talks ... can move forward.'' The government leadership earlier had insisted the rebels lay down their arms before talks get under way. Both Cerezo and Gramajo said Friday they are willing to renew contact with the rebels if they showed willingness to negotiate. The reconciliation commission is trying to determine whether that is true. The Guatemalan National Revolutionary Union has battled to overthrow a succession of military-dominated governments. More than 80,000 people have been killed in the conflict, most of them Indian peasants.

DOC.HEAD: Pretelt Attorney Wants Secret Government Files
DOC.TEXT: The lone co-defendant of Manuel Noriega in a Tampa drug and money-laundering case once accompanied the ousted Panamanian strongman to Washington to meet with Oliver North and William Casey, an attorney said. But Enrique ``Kiki'' Pretelt, a Panamanian jeweler, went along on the 1983 trip purely to socialize, according to defense attorney George Tragos. Pretelt also went with Noriega to Havana in 1984 for talks with Cuban President Fidel Castro. Again, Pretelt claims it was merely in a social capacity. Tragos filed a motion Thursday in federal court in Tampa seeking access to classified government documents he says will show his client's frequent contacts with Noriega didn't involve drug smuggling or money laundering. Pretelt and Noriega were indicted in 1988 on charges of taking bribes from Tampa-based drug smugglers to help ferry $300 million worth of Colombian marijuana safely through Panama. ``The government's case involves guilt by association, but only the government has information which can disprove these allegations,'' Tragos said. Pretelt went underground soon after the U.S. invasion of Panama on Dec. 20. Noriega also fled, taking refuge for 10 days at a Vatican diplomatic building before surrendering to U.S. agents on Jan. 3. Pretelt, 47, surrendered to FBI agents in Panama on Jan. 17 and was brought to Tampa. He pleaded innocent in January and is being held at an undisclosed site. Federal investigators are thought to be trying to strike a deal, but Tragos says he's preparing for trial. Noriega is in prison near Miami awaiting trial there next January on drug-smuggling charges. A federal indictment in Miami says Noriega was paid off by the Medillin Cartel of Colombian drug smugglers to allow use of Panama for shipping drugs and drug money. That indictment says Noriega went to Cuba for a meeting that Castro mediated with cocaine traffickers who were upset with the Panama military after a cocaine laboratory was raided. According to Tragos' motions here, Noriega went to Washington in November 1983 to seek U.S. approval for the election of Nicolas Ardito Barletta as Panama's president. Noriega met separately with former Marine Lt. Col. Oliver North and other members of the National Security Council; with Casey, late head of the CIA and other agency officials; and with Langhorn E. Motley, then assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs, the motions state. Pretelt ``was not present at any of the official discussions and was again only present for social gatherings with General Noriega,'' Tragos wrote. He wants records from the Bank of Credit and Commerce International that he claims will prove Pretelt wasn't involved in any illegal activity. The bank pleaded guilty to money-laundering charges in January and agreed to forfeit a record $14 million plus interest.

DOC.HEAD: College Financial Aid Service Experiencing Delays
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of thousands of college financial aid applications nationwide are being delayed because of processing problems at the firm that analyzes them for schools, a company official said Friday. ``What would take two to three weeks to process at this time of the year is now running four to five weeks,'' said Kathleen Brouder, director of information services at the College Scholarship Service, part of the Educational Testing Service. The data processing center is the financial aid division of the College Board, and is the starting point for financial aid applications for about 3 million students every year. The service analyzes financial aid applications, which detail family assets and income, to make sure they comply with federal financial aid rules and determine how much aid students should receive, then sends the analysis to the colleges chosen by the students. Ms. Brouder said the delays were partly caused by new federal procedures and partly by an engineering problem several weeks ago in a scanner used to review applications automatically. The firm had to switch to a slower, manual process for several days while the scanner was repaired. She said this is the peak time of year for financial aid applications, when students must meet college deadlines to apply for aid for the coming school year. Colleges are being notified of the delays, Ms. Brouder said. So far this year, the center has received 1.1 million applications, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Premier Quits, Setting Off Indian Political Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal resigned Friday, creating turmoil in the governing National Front coalition and giving Prime Minister V.P. Singh his first political crisis after three months in office. Devi Lal, 75, quit because he felt some senior coalition leaders were out to malign him and his son, according to United Press of India news agency. It said he sent a letter of resignation to Singh, but no immediate word came that Singh accepted it. Newspapers and politicians blamed Devi Lal's son, Om Prakash Chauthala, for violence and vote-rigging in last month's elections to state assemblies. Chauthala was named chief minister of northern Haryana state last December after Devi Lal resigned the post to join the federal Cabinet. By law, Chauthala then had to be elected to the stte assembly to keep his job as chief minister. Voting on Feb. 27 was marked by violence that killed at least 13 people. New elections were ordered. Industries Minister Ajit Singh, known to be a strong rival of Devi Lal, demanded that Chauthala resign ``on moral grounds.'' The National Front is a centrist alliance dominated by Janata Dal, to which Devi Lal, V.P. Singh and Ajit Singh (no relation) belong. Whether Devi Lal's resignation would trigger a split in Janata Dal was not immediately clear, but he has a strong following in the party. Also on Friday, Atinder Pal Singh, a Sikh facing trial on charges of masterminding bomb attacks, was brought from jail by armed police and was sworn in as a member of the lower house of Parliament. The police did not enter Parliament, and Atinder Pal Singh was returned to jail after the ceremony. Atinder Pal Singh, no relation to the Cabinet ministers, won his seat in Nov. 22-26 general elections while remaining in prison. He also was implicated in the 1984 assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, but those charges were dropped after the election.

DOC.HEAD: Supporters Fast, Pray For Anderson's Release
With AM-Hostages-Anderson Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with fast broken at service. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Other ceremonies...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Yellow ribbons hung from trees, signs and telephone poles in Terry Anderson's hometown Friday as relatives, friends and strangers fasted and prayed for the release of the journalist held hostage in Lebanon. A 24-hour fast begun by about 180 people Thursday night in the Buffalo suburb of Orchard Park, 40 miles to the west, was broken Friday night ata service at the Genesee Country Mall in downtown Batavia. ``I hereby commit myself to one day of prayer and fasting for Terry's release and the release of all innocent human beings held hostage anywhere in the world,'' read pledges signed by the fasters on Friday, the fifth anniversary of Anderson's abduction in Beirut. They included Penny Anderson, Terry's sister-in-law, and Carl Anderson, a cousin, two of the few relatives still living in this town of 17,000 in New York's dairy country. Also fasting was Anne Zickl, who has never met Anderson but has become a leader of local efforts to win his release. ``Terry is dying a slow death in Lebanon,'' Stephen Hawley, a Genesee County legislator and high school classmate of Anderson's, said at the service here. ``The time has come for all governments who have any influence over the captors to heed our pleas and our prayers. Release Terry Anderson. Release all the hostages now,'' Hawley said. Other ceremonies were held Friday in Lorain, Ohio, Anderson's birthplace, and in Washington, D.C., where the humanitarian group No Greater Love held a service in Lafayette Park across from the White House. In Tokyo, the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan held a ceremony Friday night for the abducted newsman, who worked in The Associated Press' Tokyo bureau from 1977 to 1981. Anderson, 42, is the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He has been held longer than any of the 18 Western hostages in Lebanon. Most of the others have been held at least three years and the prayers offered on Friday also were for the other hostages. Anderson left Batavia in 1965 to join the Marine Corps. His subsequent career as a journalist kept him abroad for most of his working life; his sister, Peggy Say, said the last time Anderson visited Batavia may have been for their mother's funeral in 1977. ``When you're kind of an international journalist, you don't really have a home,'' Mrs. Zickl said. ``He would tell Peggy that wherever she was, that was home, because she was this mom figure after his mother died.'' Nevertheless, the hometown tie, admiration for Say and outrage over the hostage-taking prompted many residents who had never met Anderson to band together to support his cause. The idea of the 24-hour fast for the hostages was conceived by Buffalo Area Metropolitan Ministries, an ecumenical group, and was adopted enthusiastically by Say, who fasted while she attended ceremonies in Washington. The Rev. Francis ``Butch'' Mazur, a Roman Catholic priest who organized the Orchard Park service, told worshipers that fasting ``is a transformation of self, which leads to a transformation of society, which takes its shape from our lives.'' He urged all who support the hostages to make some sacrifice during the day. ``It may mean abstaining from one of the three meals that you would have in the next 24 hours,'' Mazur said Thursday night. ``For little kids, it may mean fasting from candy or soda pop. For others, it may mean fasting from television or coffee or caffeine.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Economy Grew in 1989 at Nearly Twice the Forecasted Rate
DOC.TEXT: An increase in manufacturing helped the Mexican economy grow last year at nearly twice the rate forecasted by government analysts, the Planning Department said Friday. The announcement was another indication that Mexico's economy is pulling out of a protracted slump that began when world oil prices skidded in 1982. ``This favorable result was accompanied by a reduction of inflation to nearly one-third that observed a year earlier,'' the government news release said. Inflation in 1989 was 19.7 percent, compared to 51.7 percent for 1988, the Bank of Mexico reported. The gross domestic product grew 2.9 percent in 1989, based on preliminary data from the National Statistics, Geography and Information Institute, the Planning Department said. Officials had forecast a 1.5 percent growth in the GDP for the year. However, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari estimated in November at his first state-of-the-nation speech that 1989 growth would be 2.5 to 3 percent. Manufacturers, including the country's many factories dotting the 1,950-mile U.S.-Mexico border, were responsible for the increased 1989 output, while farmers and ranchers, forestry and fishing businesses produced less than in 1988, the statement said. It blamed shrinkage in the other sectors on ``adverse climatic conditions.'' Growth in manufacturing was 6 percent, while agricultural output fell 3.1 percent, the department reported. The GDP grew 1.1 percent in 1988, and 1.5 percent in 1987, the government newspaper El Nacional said. In 1986, the GDP dropped by 3.7 percent, compared with a 2.5 percent increase in 1985, according to the Bank of Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Dogs Die Eating Contaminating Dog Food
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian dog food manufacturer said Friday at least eight dogs died in Ontario from eating its puppy food because it was contaminated with a poultry vaccine. Chuck Martin, a spokesman for Martin Feed Mills Ltd., said high levels of the poultry medication monensin were found in 90-kilogram (198-pound) bags of its Techni-Cal Growth puppy food. ``We have not ruled out sabotage as the levels of monensin found were far higher than allowable for poultry feeds and the substance is not allowed in pet foods,'' Martin was quoted as telling The Canadian Press from company operations at Elmira, Ontario. The company also makes poultry feed, but in a separate building. Martin Feed ordered a recall of 1,263 bags of the puppy food distributed in Canada east of Thunder Bay, Ontario. An additional 100 bags were sent to U.S. distributors. The contaminated product carries lot number 0110 and was made Jan. 9-10. The first dog reported to have died was a Labrador retriever from Limehouse, which died shortly after it was brought to an animal clinic Tuesday. Tests on Friday confirmed the presence of the vaccine in the animal, which had eaten two meals made from the contaminated food. Other deaths were reported in Toronto and neighboring Mississauga. Techni-Cal Growth is an expensive brand for puppies and lactating mothers often used by breeders and trainers. It is available only from pet food suppliers and veterinarians. Martin Feed Mills notified Canadian dealers, breeders and veterinarians. Bags sold in the United States were being traced. About 40 percent of the contaminated lot has been returned so far, said company sales manager Lynette Taylor.

DOC.HEAD: St. Pat's Day Revolution: First Female President for Irish Society
DOC.TEXT: The 253-year-old Charitable Irish Society is marking St. Patrick's Day by taking a bold step: inaugurating its first woman president. ``They're quite pleased. I think they feel it's about time,'' said William Connaughton, a former president of the Boston-based society, which calls itself the oldest Irish immigrant organization in the United States. Catherine B. Shannon, a Westfield State College professor, was scheduled to be installed Saturday as president. It was a major development for a society that didn't admit women to its ranks until the early 1980s. ``I think that what happened was there were a lot of men who were coming onto the board who were in their 40s and 50s who said, `This is ridiculous. Stag dinners are not that much fun,' '' Shannon said. Shannon said Irish history is her field of study and she also has researched the role of women in modern Ireland, giving her a unique perspective in her new job. ``What I think is most important is to have us focus on what our tradition has been; to be of service to those who are in distress or need,'' she said this week. ``I think women are perhaps uniquely prepared to recognize that very quickly and early on.'' The society dates back to 1737, when it was founded by mainly Protestant businessmen in Boston to help immigrant Irish of both faiths. Shannon, who joined the society in 1985, said she hoped to lead the organization in recruiting more young members and reaching out to recent immigrants.

DOC.HEAD: Roh Replaces Economic Minister in Cabinet Shakeup
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo on Saturday replaced his economic minister in a major Cabinet reshuffle expected to herald a push to speed the growth of South Korea's economy. The reshuffle, affecting 15 of 22 posts, has been expected since last month's merger of Roh's governing party with two centrist opposition groups. The alliance resulted in a powerful conservative party giving the president a comfortable parliamentary majority. Chief presidential spokesman Lee Soo-jung said Saturday's shakeup was aimed at invigorating national politics as Roh enters the second half of his five-year term ending in 1993. Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon and his entire 22-member Cabinet resigned Friday to give Roh a free hand to reorganize the government. Kang was renamed prime minister of the new Cabinet on Saturday. However, Roh replaced most of the Cabinet's economics officials, including Economic Planning Minister Cho Soon, who is a deputy premier. Lee Seung-yun, 58, a former finance minister who served under ex-President Chun Doo-hwan, succeeded Cho as the nation's top economic planner. His appointment is expected to bring a considerable change in South Korea's economic policy, which has put emphasis on distribution rather than growth. Lee, a respected economist, is known as an advocate of a growth-oriented policy. ``My first job will be to look into the problems of our economy many people say is in a crisis and prepare appropriate measures,'' Lee told reporters after the reshuffle. Cho and his economic team have been criticized for a series of policy failures that aggravated land speculation, increased inflation and slowed exports. Korean exports in the first two months of this year decreased 2.5 percent to $8.7 billion from a year ago. Cho's successor declined to provide details but said he was willing to announce new measures ``as soon as possible to rectify problems and adjust the course of the Korean economy.'' The state television KBS said the new economic planning minister would push a series of bold measures to encourage investment and stimulate exports. In Saturday's reorganization, the first since December 1988, Roh kept Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong, Defense Minister Lee Sang-hoon and several other non-political members. Ahn Ung-mo, a deputy director of the Agency for National Security Planning, the government's main intelligence body, was named the new home minister who controls the nation's 130,000-member national police. Park Pil-soo, a former government economic official and now president of Hankook University of Foreign Studies, became the minister of trade and industry. Chung Young-ui, chief of the Securities Supervisory Agency, was appointed as finance minister. The reorganization also affected the presidential staff and several less political cabinet-level posts handling environmental and legal government affairs. Several ex-opposition lawmakers who joined in the new governing Democratic Liberal Party were given non-political Cabinet posts in the reorganization. Roh, a former army general, was elected president in December 1987 following a split of two opposition parties. He replaced Chun, who called the vote following mass demonstrations to demand democratic reforms and an end to autocratic rule. On Friday, about 3,000 radical students, some shouting ``Down with the conservative party!'' rallied at four universities in Seoul to protest the reorganization.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Blocks Most Testing of Navy Civilians
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge struck down most of the Navy's program of random drug tests for 80,000 civilian employees, saying the Pentagon failed to limit the practice to jobs affecting safety or military secrets. U.S. District Judge D. Lowell Jensen, in a ruling made public Friday, also overturned the Navy's plan for drug testing any of its 325,000 civilian employees who cause an accident involving injury or property damage. He said the Navy failed to limit post-accident testing to serious accidents and gave local commanders too much authority to decide who would be tested. The ruling is one of a series of decisions from lower federal courts on drug testing programs ordered for all federal agencies under President Reagan in 1986. The Supreme Court upheld testing of some railway workers and Customs Service job applicants last year but didn't rule on random drug testing. ``This decision proves that they'll not allow the government to subject federal workers to agency drug testing programs without adequate justifications,'' said Diane Witiak of the American Federation of Government Employees, which represents 74,000 civilian Navy workers. ``The court is looking at individual job duties.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney George Stoll said the government wouldn't comment Friday. Jensen had blocked the entire Navy civilian drug testing program just before it was to take effect in January. His new ruling appeared to allow just a small fraction of the random testing program to go into effect, though neither side in the case could provide any figures Friday. Jensen described as overly broad the Navy's stated justifications for random tests for 80,000 workers in 45 job categories. Those criteria include the workers' relation to the operation or maintenance of equipment, national security, public health and safety, protection of life and property, or drug and alcohol rehabilitation. The judge, however, upheld random testing of some of the 80,000 in certain job classes, including law enforcement officers, firefighters, drivers, and staff with access to top-secret information. He also allowed testing of any Navy employee based on reasonable suspicion of current drug use. For example, he said, ``national security'' covers not only employees with access to top-secret information, but also those involved in a broad range of policy- and planning-related work; ``public health and safety'' includes lab technicians and dental hygienists, and ``protection of life and property'' includes record-keepers for rail lines. ``The Navy interests are so broadly defined as to describe virtually any duties of civilian Navy employees,'' Jensen said. Only 80,000 employees considered to have the most sensitive jobs out of the Navy's total of 325,000 employees were targeted by the proposed random testing program. In a separate ruling, Jensen prohibited post-accident drug testing of the 5,800 civil service employees of the federal Office of Personnel Management. He said OPM failed to limit the program to employees who actually cause accidents.

DOC.HEAD: College Star Died of Heart Disease; No Illegal Drugs Found
DOC.TEXT: Hank Gathers, the college basketball star who collapsed during a tournament game and died last week, was killed by heart disease, according to autopsy results released Thursday. The Loyola Marymount University center didn't have any trace of illegal drugs in his system, the Los Angeles County Coroner's office reported. Gathers, the second player ever to lead college basketball in both scoring and rebounding in the same season, collapsed on his home court March 4, moments after sinking a slam dunk in a game against the University of Portland. The 23-year-old Philadelphia native died of idiopathic cardiomyopathy, or inflammation and scarring of the heart muscle, said coroner's spokesman Bob Dambacher. ``Toxological tests revealed that no drugs nor medications were found,'' said a coroner's press release. Further tests were planned to determine if Gathers had been taking medication prescribed for an irregular heartbeat diagnosed after Gathers collapsed on the court Dec. 9. In the days before he died, Gathers was said to have asked doctors to reduce the dosage because it made him sluggish. He reportedly complained he was unable to perform at the level that made him college basketball's leading scorer and rebounder during the 1988-89 season. He was considered a certain first-round pick in the next National Basketball Association draft. Dambacher said medical examiners hadn't determined what caused Gathers' heart condition. But Stephen Berens, a cardiologist in Santa Monica, said it was likely the result of a viral infection, possibly brought on by the flu. Loyola's Lions, ranked 21st in the nation, were scheduled to play a first-round National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament game Friday against 24th-ranked New Mexico State.

DOC.HEAD: Hawaii-Bound Flight Returns to LAX After Smoke Reported in Cabin
DOC.TEXT: A Delta Airlines pilot who reported smoke aboard his Hawaii-bound airliner turned it around shortly after takeoff Thursday and made an emergency landing at Los Angeles International Airport, authorities said. No one was injured and passengers walked off the Lockheed L-1011 at an airport boarding gate without using emergency chutes, said Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman Elly Brekke. Delta Flight 1571, en route to Maui with 278 people aboard, was over the Pacific Ocean about 30 miles west of the airport when the pilot reported smoke, Brekke said. He requested permission to return to the airport immediately, she said. ``The pilot turned around, dumped fuel over the ocean and returned straight to the airport,'' Brekke said. Delta spokeswoman Glenda Hatchett-Johnson said one of the plane's flight crew checked the passenger section after a smoke alarm sounded and discovered ``what he called a thin haze in the air'' toward the back of the plane. ``Just to be safe the crew decided to return to the airport,'' she said. The cause of the smoke had not been determined by late afternoon, said Fred O'Donnell, an FAA spokesman in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Store Employee Faces Felony Charge for Selling 2 Live Crew Album
DOC.TEXT: A 19-year-old record store employee was arrested on a felony charge Thursday for selling a copy of the controversial rap album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' to an 11-year-old girl. Chauncey Reese, an employee at Sarasota's ``Tracks'' record store, may be one of the first people arrested in Florida for selling the recording by the Miami group 2 Live Crew, said Sarasota Police spokesman Russ Nugent. ``I'm just glad that someone has decided to do something, whatever it takes, to keep this trash out of the hands of minors. I'm just elated,'' said the girl's mother, Ann Skolnick. Reese, who is accused of selling the Miami rap group's tape to the girl in January, was taken into custody at 3 p.m. Thursday after police investigated a complaint by the girl's mother. He was later released on his own recognizance. ``She felt that the lyrics were obscene and had no business being listened to by her 11-year-old daughter,'' said Nugent. He did not know of any other such arrest in the state involving the rap group's recordings.
