DOC.HEAD: Mexico Seeks Buyers for State-Owned Companies
DOC.TEXT: If you're interested in buying a fish processing plant, sugar refinery, telephone company or even a former convent, Mexico is interested in you. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's government is trying to sell hundreds of inefficient businesses and industries, many nationalized more than 40 years ago, that have beome a crippling drain on the budget. Motivations for taking over the companies were many: to free the country from foreign exploitation, improve the lot of workers, save jobs, avoid social unrest and bail out owners who had labor or profit problems. After nationalization, the companies became sinkholes of corruption and havens for political hacks from the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party. Two generations later, privatization has become part of a strategy to reduce government subsidies, improve efficiency and obtain new foreign investment and credit as Mexico tries to emerge from seven years of economic crisis. ``What we have to do and what we are doing in Mexico is to create attractive conditions for doing business in Mexico,'' said Angel Gurria, assistant treasury secretary in charge of foreign debt negotiations. He mentioned the sale of state-owned companies as one of those conditions. A disadvantage is the loss of thousands of jobs through layoffs, either by the government before the sale or the new owners afterward. Heberto Castillo, a leader of the leftist opposition Democratic Revolutionary Party, estimated 200,000 jobs were lost to privatization and modernization in the past year. Mexico under Salinas has become, in the eyes of its creditors, a model for debtor nations. It has opened the economy to foreign investment and imports, brought down inflation and trimmed the bureaucracy and budget. ``A state that is too busy administering its enterprises is neither just nor revolutionary,'' Salinas said Nov. 1 in his first state of the nation address. In January, he told residents of a poor suburb that some of the money from sales of state companies would be used to bring them services and that new owners of the companies would have to invest in creating jobs. Not everything is being sold. Under the constitution, the government must own and control the oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, which includes the oil operations expropriated from foreign companies in 1938, basic petrochemical production, electric power, nuclear energy and radioactive minerals, satellite communications, railroads and mail service. It has skirted the law by shifting many petrochemicals from basic to secondary categories, thus permitting private and foreign investment. Even historic mines and steel companies, some started by the government, are included on the for-sale list. The Real del Monte y Pachuca silver and gold mines, which the Aztecs worked before the Spanish conquest, have been sold. Of the 1,155 companies the government owned seven years ago, 194 have been sold, 322 closed and 75 merged with others, according to the Treasury Department. Among items awaiting buyers are 11 fish processing plants, seven sugar refineries, two gas distributorships, the national telephone company, a coconut plant and the former convent. The 1990 federal budget includes $14 billion in payments to state-owned enterprises. That is up from $11.7 billion in 1989, but it includes social security payments and airport funds. Luis Pazos, an economist who runs a private research center on free enterprise, said figures on how many companies and government operations have been sold or closed are unrealistic because ``many only existed on paper.'' He also questioned the government's commitment. If it really wants to divest itself, the commercial banks, nationalized in 1982, should be returned to private hands, and peasants who work state-owned farms should be given title to the land, Pazos said. ``It's going very slowly, probably for political reasons,'' he said. ``There is still fear of the left.'' Some operations, including steel plants, are being held back while generous union contracts are renegotiated and the facilities are modernized. ``We have found that, without making certain changes, there isn't anyone to buy them,'' said Alfredo Genel, director of industries at the Commerce and Industrial Development Department. ``Over the years, not only union contracts, but relations with suppliers, then with clients, became distorted,'' he said. ``They aren't as rigorous in demanding the lowest price from suppliers. They gave low prices or special terms to the clients. They don't have a group of stockholders to answer to.'' European countries found the steel industry could not be sold unless it was modernized, he said. A privatization success story is the airline Aeromexico, which was famous for delays and cancellations until it was sold late in 1988 to a private consortium and the pilots' union. Now it is known for on-time performance and better service. Financial figures were not available. The government no longer is in the soft drink, textile, cement and dish manufacturing businesses, among others. As for the convent of Santa Catarina in Oaxaca, southern Mexico, it later was a jail and now is the Hotel Presidente. Several hotels are on the list of government offerings, but only the operation of the Hotel Presidente will be sold because the building is a national monument.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, March 25

DOC.TEXT: A surprise nationwide sweep of fast-food restaurants and other businesses found 7,000 teen-agers employed for too many hours or in dangerous jobs in violation of child-labor laws, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said. The three-day investigation, called ``Operation Child Watch,'' is expected to result in more than $1.8 million in civil fines against businesses, she said Thursday. Fines totaling $2.7 million were assessed during all of 1989. The majority of allegations involved firms in which 14- and 15-year-olds worked more hours or later at night during the school week than allowed under federal law.

The management of Saks Fifth Avenue, in partnership with a Japanese retailer, has offered to buy the upscale department store chain from its London-based parent BAT Industries PLC. Terms of the proposal were not disclosed. Saks management said Thursday that the joint bid with Tobu Department Store Co. was fully financed. Analysts have said the 46 Saks specialty department stores would fetch a price roughly equal to the chain's annual sales, which totaled about $1.3 billion in 1989.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has signed a full-power license for the Seabrook nuclear power plant, ending any chance opponents will be able to prevent it from operating before court appeals are completed. Thomas Murley, director of the NRC's Office of Nuclear Reactor Regulation, made the license official Thursday, two weeks after the NRC voted unanimously to allow the New Hampshire plant to operate commercially. The commission placed a two-week hold on its vote to allow time for filing court appeals.

President Bush voiced concern about the nation's slowing economy and called for industry and government to redouble efforts to boost U.S. competitiveness and reap a ``growth dividend.'' ``There is a great deal we have to do to keep this expansion going,'' the president told a group of newspaper executives Thursday. ``The economy at this moment isn't as robust as I'd like to see it.'' But Bush indicated the signs of weakness come against a backdrop of a generally sound economy.

Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said he does not believe the recent rise in the value of the dollar will adversely affect the nation's trade deficit this year. A stronger dollar could cause the nation's trade deficit to widen because it would make imported goods cheaper while increasing the price of U.S. products sold overseas. Brady made his comments Thursday.

Talks with the Japanese on a key trade dispute involving purchases of American satellites broke off this week after ``zero progress'' had been made, a U.S. trade official said. The official said Thursday that no further talks would be held unless the Japanese alter their position. Satellites are one of three U.S. product groups that have been targeted for the removal of trade barriers by the Japanese. If significant progress has not been made by June 15, the administration has the power to retaliate by imposing higher tariffs on Japanese products.

Scott Paper Co. allegedly was cheated out of up to $1 million by two businessmen and three companies that bribed a Scott engineer and put his wife on the payroll for arranging purchases of needless supplies at inflated prices. A federal prosecutor said Thursday that William M. Engelman and Gerald M. Chernow were named as defendants in a 21-count indictment alleging that Scott's S.D. Warren mill in Westbrook was bilked from March 1984 to June 1987. Engelman and Chernow face charges of conspiracy, mail fraud, and the use of interstate facilities in furtherance of private bribery.

AT&T and its unions are discussing plans to offer early retirement to non-management employees for the first time in the company's long-running campaign to slim down. American Telephone and Telegraph Co. had no details Thursday on who would be affected, how many workers would be eligible and what incentives would be offered because talks were in an early stage, a company spokesman said.

Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. told a bankruptcy judge they plan to pay $25 million to top managers and executives over the next two years to keep them from leaving the companies. David G. Heiman, an attorney for the Cincinnati-based retailers, said Thursday the program was designed to help Federated and Allied retain key managers who might leave to join competitors because of companies' uncertain status. Federated and Allied filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors two months ago.

The stock market eked out a small gain Thursday as Wall Street quietly awaited an approaching ``witching hour.'' The Dow Jones industrial average, up about 18 points at its peak, closed with a 7.88 gain at 2,695.72. The dollar declined against most major foreign currencies except the Japanese yen. Bond prices finished slightly lower. Soybean and sugar futures prices rose sharply; grain futures advanced; petroleum futures rose; copper surged while precious metals were mixed; cattle futures retreated; and pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Couple Settles Insider Trading Charges Involving Revco
DOC.TEXT: A former Cleveland investment bank employee and her estranged husband have settled insider trading charges involving the stock of Revco Drug Stores and two other companies. The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the settlement in Washington on Thursday. Shirley Shiffman, formerly an administrative assistant with the investment banking firm of Golenberg & Co., was accused last July of passing inside information to her husband, George, who allegedly made $52,839 in illegal trading profits. The Shiffmans, of Aurora, Ohio, agreed to settle and consented to a federal court order barring them from further alleged violations of federal securities law. In addition, George Shiffman, was ordered to pay $105,678 in fines and restitution, plus an additional $18,415 in interest. Ms. Shiffman was not required to pay any fines or penalties. ``There was no evidence that she personally profitted from the trades,'' said James Kidney, an SEC attorney in Washington. Shiffman, who separated from his wife before the settlement was reached, filed for bankruptcy court protection, the SEC said. Kidney said the SEC would pursue its claims against Shiffman in bankruptcy procceedings, adding, ``We'll take whatever we can get.'' Ms. Shiffman's attorney, Jonathan Eisenberg of Washington, who said she would fight the charges when they were filed last July, said she settled after authorities agreed not to seek any fines or monetary penalties. ``It's much better to settle for nothing than to litigate,'' said Eisenberg. The SEC complaint charged that Ms. Shiffman, while working at Golenberg & Co., obtained confidential corporate information about pending deals that included a management leveraged buyout of Revco in 1986. The other alleged illegal trades involved the stock of Magnetics International Inc. and Fisher Foods Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Airlines Adds First Flights in Two Years
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines has added 100 daily flights, including service to Panama, Costa Rica and several U.S. cities, in its first schedule expansion in two years. The Houston-based subsidiary of Texas Air Corp. said Thursday it will end its two-year ``no-growth mode'' by adding 23 planes to its fleet and expanding its services to 1,417 daily flights. ``We needed to get our arms around our operational difficulties,'' said Stan Hula, Continental vice president of schedule development. ``We think we've got those problems licked.'' Hula said Continental's financial condition has improved. The airline reported a $3.1 million profit for 1989 despite a $56.1 million fourth-quarter loss. In addition, he said Department of Transportation statistics reported customer complaints about Continental were down 96 percent since 1987, and the carrier's on-time arrival performance was the third-best among the nation's airlines in 1989. Beginning May 15, Continental will inaugurate Houston flights to Panama City, Panama and San Jose, Costa Rica, giving Continental the largest number of U.S. flights to Central America, he said. The airline already has flights to Belize, El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras. ``We look to expand in Central America even further as time passes,'' Hula said. ``The changing conditions in Panama obviously make this service possible. The improving political climate has a great deal to do with our interest in Central America.'' In the United States, Continental is starting a late-night operation out of Houston Intercontinental Airport with a dozen flights leaving at 10:30 p.m. Elsewhere, new service is being added from Cleveland to Louisville, Ky. and Norfolk, Va. From Newark, N.J., service is being added to Greensboro, N.C., Norfolk, Va., Columbia, S.C. and Antigua, West Indies. Those flights start May 1. Hula said the additional flights could prompt the airline to hire nearly 1,000 new workers, including about 200 pilots and 600 flight attendants.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T, Unions Discuss Early Retirement Plan
DOC.TEXT: AT&T has presented one of its main unions with a plan to sweeten pensions to encourage early retirements, the company's latest move in a continuing effort to trim its workforce. The Communications Workers of America had a mixed reaction to the proposal and offered a counter plan, said spokesman Steve Rosenthal, but no details available. Talks were to resume Monday. AT&T said it held talks Thursday with the CWA and its other main union, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, on plans that for the first time would offer early retirement for non-management employees. Last year, a special retirement plan for managers prompted 12,500 to depart out of 35,000 who were eligible, the company said. The arrangement added five years to each manager's age and tenure, and boosted pension payments by 15 percent for five years, or until a retired worker reached 65. The company had few details about the plan because talks were in an early stage, said company spokesman Burke Stinson at AT&T's Basking Ridge office. Though AT&T is headquartered in New York, the bulk of its operations are in New Jersey. The efforts are ``another step in a continuing goal to reduce overhead costs and consolidate operations,'' Stinson said. Though IBEW spokesman Tom Hickman said he could not comment on the talks, he said the idea of offering enhanced pensions to induce retirements ``is obviously something that we're not opposed to.'' Probably less than 10,000 people would be affected, said Stuart Crane, an analyst for Gruntal & Co., though he noted it is impossible to predict how many will accept the deal. ``I just think they're continuously putting the bait in front of the donkey to get him to drive away,'' Crane said. Crane said it is likely AT&T will continue to try to pare down its workforce through the 1990s. According to AT&T's Stinson, the company has steadily reduced its workforce since 1984, when Bell Telephone broke up into regional Baby Bell phone companies. As AT&T computerizes its operations with new digital and solid state technology, it has increasing numbers of workers with less to do, Stinson said. More switching and operator services are done by computer, and digital equipment has made equipment installation easier. Also, competition has forced AT&T to pare away extra layers of employees that it could afford when it was a monopoly. At the time of the break-up, the company had 373,000 employees. They now employ 281,400, 173,500 of whom are non-management. Last year a total of 25,000 jobs were cut, some through attrition, Stinson said.

DOC.HEAD: Automakers Offering Money if You Buy Competitor's Car
DOC.TEXT: If a slew of incentives wasn't enough to fog a car-buyer's mind, Nissan Motor Corp. is offering $100 to those who test its Stanza sedan before buying a Honda Accord or Toyota Camry. Chrysler Corp. recently ended a similar program urging potential car-buyers to drive a Chrysler product and stack it up against the competition. That program, which ran only last month, applied to more cars than Nissan's does, but carried a reward of just $50. Ever since the mid-1970s, when the Federal Trade Commission relaxed a ban on using a competitor's name in advertising, companies have shown their products in action against the competition. ``It's becoming more and more popular because of credibility. Consumers see it and say `Well, if their saying it, it must be true,''' Melvin Helitzer, a former advertising executive who is a journalism professor at Ohio University in Athens, said Thursday. The Nissan and Chrysler promotions, designed to boost sales and get people into showrooms, are the latest attempts by automakers to persuade consumers to compare products, something smart shoppers do naturally. ``Those really are (showroom) traffic builders,'' said Jim Wangers, president of Automotive Marketing Consultants Inc. of Vista, Calif. ``They say, `I've got enough confidence in my car and I will put it on the line with anybody's.' ``But what it really says is, `Bring me more bodies.''' Chrysler and Nissan dealers could use more bodies in their showrooms. During the first two months of the year, Chrysler's total vehicle sales of 305,985 were down 1.4 percent compared with the year-ago period, and Nissan's total vehicle sales were 89,974, off 16.3 percent. Nissan spokesman E.C. Mueller said the focus of the $100 test-drive offer is to get people into the Stanza, a newly redesigned car. The offer works like this: A potential buyer test drives a Stanza between Feb. 12 and April 30 and fills out an evaluation form. The dealer reviews it, keeps one copy, sends another to Nissan headquarters and gives one to the consumer. If the consumer takes delivery of an Accord or Camry within seven days of the Stanza test drive and attaches the purchase order to the copy of the Nissan evaluation, the consumer gets the $100 by mail from Nissan in four to six weeks. If the consumer buys the Stanza, Mueller said, there's no reward. The results of Chrysler's $50 test-drive program are private information, Chrysler spokesman Tom Jakobowski said.

DOC.HEAD: Dispute Erupts in Cabinet Over U.S.-Japan Trade Measure
DOC.TEXT: A government dispute erupted Friday over Washington's demand that Japan open its markets and prompted Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to quickly intervene, officials said. The dispute, at a regular Cabinet meeting, was between the ministers of trade and home affairs, over how to handle U.S. demands to abolish a law restricting the opening of large retail stores. Meanwhile, U.S. Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher was ending trade talks in Tokyo after meeting with five major users of semiconductors to encourage them to buy more from U.S. producers. Mosbacher came to Tokyo to follow up on the summit two weeks ago between President George Bush and Kaifu in Palm Springs, Calif., and address ways to reduce Japan's $49 billion dollar trade surplus with the United States. One move requested by U.S. negotiators is to abolish Japan's law protecting small businesses from being overwhelmed by supermarkets or department stores moving into their neighborhoods. During Friday's Cabinet meeting, Home Affairs Minister Kaiwa Okuda said Japan should eliminate the law entirely, said a Home Affairs ministry official. Okuda criticized the minister of trade and industry, Kabun Muto, because the trade ministry wants only to modify the law and make it quicker for large retailers to get permits to open stores, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The home affairs minister said the trade minister's measure would be insufficient to solve the dispute with Washington and urged the trade ministry to come up with stronger measures that would improve Japanese standards of living, the official said. Kaifu intervened before Muto was able to respond, the official said, and the three met afterward. It was not immediately clear whether the matter was resolved. The dispute at the usually mundane meeting was the top item on noontime television news. Increasing the spread of large-scale retailers is thought to raise the sales of imported goods, as small neighborhood stores are less likely to stock foreign-made products. Mosbacher was to return to Washington later Friday. During his four days in Tokyo, the commerce secretary met with Kaifu, Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, Trade Minister Muto and officials of the country's top business group, the Federation of Economic Organizations (Keidanren). On Thursday, Mosbacher urged Japan to move into a close partnership with the United States to eliminate trade barriers. ``If we do not act soon, we may throw away our last chance to save the world trading system from serious damage,'' Mosbacher told reporters at the Japan National Press Club.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower Ahead of U.S. Figures, Gold Slightly Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower in European trading this morning as the market waited for the release of a series of U.S. economic indicators. Gold prices were slightly higher in thin trading, mainly responding to the dollar's movements, dealers said. ``The dollar is pretty much at a standstill'' as investors awaited figures of U.S. producer prices, housing starts and industrial production, a Milan trader said. The American currency fell in New York trading Thursday after statements from President Bush, who said he wanted U.S. interest rates to fall. But market observers said investors may have been looking for a reason to take some profits on recent dollar gains. Analysts in Milan said the U.S. figures probably won't provide a definitive answer to the current debate over the direction of U.S. interest rates between the White House and the U.S. Federal Reserve, which favors keeping the rates steady. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.03 yen to a closing 152.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 152.23 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.6980 West German marks, down from 1.7025; 1.5157 Swiss francs, down from 1.5222; 5.7375 French francs, down from 5.7545; 1.9130 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9265; 1,253.63 Italian lire, down from 1,257.25; and 1.1830 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1778. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6233, compared with $1.6177 late Thursday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $399.50 a troy ounce, up from $398.50 bid late Thursday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $399.20. In Zurich, the bid price was $399.25, up from $398.40 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.73 to close at a bid $399.68. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.11 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $5.10.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Slightly, Stocks Slip
DOC.TEXT: The dollar remained steady against the Japanese yen today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell moderately. The dollar closed the week at 152.50 yen, up 0.03 yen from Thursday's finish of 152.47 yen. After opening at 152.25 yen, the U.S. currency ranged between 152.20 yen and 152.63 yen. An estimated $7.65 billion changed hands in spot trading, up from the previous day's volume of $7.13 billion. ``The dollar edged up in afternoon after mixed trading in the morning session, with the sense of disapointment'' among traders after Thursday's denial by Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno the bank's official discount rate would be raised, said Chiyuki Watanabe, a dealer with Sanwa Bank. Mieno, who returned from a nine-day European trip, during which he attended a monthly meeting of the Bank for International Settlements in Switzerland, told a news conference Thursday there was no change in the central bank's stance of monitoring the effects of its last rate hike. Market players have speculated for weeks the central bank would raise its discount rate today by as much as 1 percentage point from the current 4.25 percent, in effect since last December, to stem the yen's downswing. The discount rate, the interest rate charged on loans by the central bank to commercial banks, has a strong effect on other interest rates. Higher interest rates tend to support a currency but discourage stock traders. Kazuyuki Suzuki, an stock analyst with Daiwa Securities, said the stock market was disappointed by inaction of the central bank over its key lending rate. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 319.51 points Thursday, shed 55.20 points, or 0.17 percent, closing the week at 32,616.44. The index gained 62.28 points at the end of the morning session. ``The trading pattern remains almost unchanged this week, with shares being bought first and then sold in the afternoon,'' Suzuki said. An estimated 500 million shares on the first section changed hands, up from 470 million shares traded Thursday. The Nikkei index lost a total of 1,640.99 points Monday through Wednesday before Thursday's gain. The price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds closed at 86.79 points, up from Thursday's close at 86.33. Their yields fell to 7.180 percent from 7.275 percent the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Alleges Young Investor Schemed to Avoid Losses
DOC.TEXT: A recent Harvard University graduate who has traded securities since the seventh grade was accused by federal officials of misleading brokers so he would not lose money on deals. Andrew Worden, whose age was listed as 23 or 24, was described Thursday as a self-employed investor in a Securities and Exchange Commission civil lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan that charges him with securities law violations. Court papers said that despite his young age, Worden was an experienced securities trader, having traded securities for his own account as well as making investments for family members. Lawrence Iason, the SEC's regional administrator in New York, said in court papers that the alleged scheme was ``abhorrent because it tends to facilitate manipulation and excessive speculation.'' According to the lawsuit, Worden most recently worked out of his Manhattan apartment, ordering securities for 41 different brokerage accounts by creating corporate-sounding names to make his purchases. If the stocks went up in value, he would sell and make partial or delayed payments on the order, the SEC charged. If the value dropped, he would not pay at all and force the brokerage house to take the loss. Worden allegedly misled brokers by creating names for his accounts _ like Convergence Corp. and Worden Management _ and giving false information about his finances. The lawsuit said the alleged scheme took place between August 1987, before his graduation from Harvard in 1988, to the present. It said Worden avoided losses of $131,353 and profited by at least $2,330. Worden's lawyer, Marc Powers, said Thursday evening he had just received the lawsuit and would not comment. The SEC is seeking a court order freezing Worden's assets.

DOC.HEAD: Federated, Allied to Reveal Employee Retention Plan
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. are giving a U.S. Bankruptcy Court details of their two-year, $25 million retention program designed to keep top managers from joining competitors. David G. Heiman, a lawyer for the two Cincinnati-based retailers, told U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. at a hearing Thursday that the plan would be filed today with Aug's court, where Federated and Allied filed Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization petitions two months ago. The companies, which have 260 stores and 100,000 employees in 28 states, listed a total of $7.7 billion in debts accumulated when Toronto-based Campeau Corp. bought Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. In the Chapter 11 proceedings, Federated and Allied must get the bankruptcy court's approval for spending proposals. Heiman also said he hopes the companies can file their reorganization plans sometime this year, but said he could not be more specific. Lewis Rosenbloom, a lawyer representing thousands of Federated's unsecured creditors, said they have not been told when to expect the reorganization plans, but would like to see them as soon as possible to more effectively review proposed spending by Federated and Allied. ``You're dealing with some of these things in a vacuum and out of context,'' Rosenbloom said. Heiman said the manager retention plan will affect about 2,300 Federated and Allied employees nationwide, including senior executives down through divisional merchandise managers, focusing on a core of about 400 key executives. The plan will cost between $10 million and $11 million each of its two years, with an additional $5 million ``discretionary pool'' that management can use to reward performance, Heiman said. He described the plan as a basic program to provide job security assurances and performance bonuses. Aug will be asked to approve the program at a hearing April 12, Heiman said. Rosenbloom said creditors support the retention program and realize the need for it, but are concerned that it grants Federated and Allied substantial discretion in operating the plan. Heiman also told the judge that preliminary indications show Federated and Allied are enjoying better than expected sales this month after sustaining a poor fourth quarter. Heiman declined to give details of March sales. Aug on Thursday also gave Federated and Allied permission to pay lawyers, accountants and investment bankers on the basis of statements to be submitted monthly that will be shared with creditors. The payments will be subject to stringent quarterly reviews, Heiman said. He declined to say how much Federated and Allied have budgeted for those expenses. Aug told lawyers in the courtroom, ``I am going to be reviewing these fees in minute detail ... I'm looking for evidence of abuse.'' Federated and Allied will ask Aug March 27 to approve spending to continue five store remodeling or construction projects valued at about $91 million. These involve projects at Bon Marche stores in Seattle and Tukwila, Wash., and Eugene, Ore.; a Goldsmith's store in Memphis, Tenn.; and a Bloomingdale's store in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Merc Slates Vote On Dual Trading Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange says it will seek membership approval for dual-trading restrictions that would ban the controversial practice in most of the Merc's financial futures markets. The Merc said Thursday it had scheduled an April 17 referendum in which owners of the exchange's approximately 2,700 seats will vote on whether to ban dual trading in any contract month with average daily volume of 10,000 contracts, with certain exceptions. If adopted, the proposal would require approval of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the federal regulator of the futures markets, which is considering a complete ban on dual trading. Congress also is considering dual-trading restrictions that would be potentially more severe than those proposed by the Merc, although the congressional plans would allow dual trading in markets with a proven ability to detect fraud. Dual trading is the widespread, legitimate practice among floor brokers at futures exchanges of trading both for their own accounts and their customers. Critics of the practice contend it allows brokers to defraud their customers by positioning themselves to profit from large customer orders they know will move a market, an illegal activity known as front-running that prevents customers from getting the best possible deal. Brokers are supposed to execute any customer orders before trading for their own accounts. Front-running is one of many fraud schemes alleged by the government in indictments against 48 people from the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade. The exchanges have generally defended dual trading, claiming it improves the efficiency of their markets by effectively increasing the pool of buyers and sellers. The more players in the market, they say, the faster a customer order can be executed. The Merc proposal addresses this liquidity issue by restricting dual trading on a contract-month basis instead of banning the practice in an entire market. For example, in the Merc's Standard & Poor's 500 stock-index futures pit, contracts are currently traded for delivery in March, June, September and December. Each contract represents the basket of stocks tracked by the S&P 500 index. Of the four contract months listed, only two _ March and June _ have average daily trading volume in excess of 10,000. Dual trading would be banned in those markets but not in the September and December contracts. The Merc proposal would label the high-volume contract months as ``mature liquid'' contracts. Most of the Merc's stock-index and currency futures contracts would fall into that category but its agricultural futures would not, said spokesman Andrew Yemma. In contrast, a bill passed last year by the House of Representatives would ban dual trading in any futures market with an annual daily volume of at least 7,000 trades for all contract months combined. That restriction would apply to nearly all of the markets at the Merc and the Board of Trade.

DOC.HEAD: Retailer Hit With Another Complaint from Union
DOC.TEXT: The United Food and Commercial Workers Union has filed another unfair labor practice complaint against Nordstrom Inc., this one contending the company is withholding documents essential to the bargaining process. Joe Peterson, UFCW Local 1001 president, said Thursday that the company has refused to produce a number of important documents dealing with employee schedules. The union contends the company recently allowed employees to change their schedules so they, on company time, could organize and attend an anti-union rally in Seattle. The company also is refusing to provide paperwork on back-pay issues for which the union has already filed complaints, Peterson said. Company spokeswoman Kellie Tormey told KIRO-TV Thursday that the latest allegations are ``ludicrous'' and ``wishful thinking on the part of the union.'' The first contract talks since January between the union and the company began Thursday afternoon and ended after three hours, Peterson said Thursday night. ``We made no progress. Nordstrom seemed even more intransigent than ever,'' he said, adding ``Nordstrom's main goal is to eliminate the union.'' Nordstrom spokesmen could not be reached for further comment Thursday evening. The union has filed six complaints against Nordstrom with the National Labor Relations Board, Peterson said. The board two weeks ago issued a complaint to the company for allegedly bargaining directly with employees on the issue of back wages, a process Peterson said is supposed to go through the union. And the state Department of Labor and Industries said in mid-February that Nordstrom had violated state law by failing to pay some employees for putting in time without compensation while attending company meetings, writing customer thank-you notes and making deliveries. The back pay could cost Nordstrom many millions of dollars, especially if it's extended to include the company's 50,000 current and former employees in Washington, Oregon, California, Virginia, Utah and Alaska. The 2,000 sales, office and display workers in King and Pierce counties who are members of the union have been working without a contract since July 31, Peterson said. At issue are wages, benefits, grievance procedures, job security and scheduling. ``We are as far apart today as we were the first day we started talking last May,'' Peterson said.

DOC.HEAD: Market Weakens for Soft White Wheat
DOC.TEXT: A glut of grain in India and Pakistan, credit problems in Egypt and higher shipping costs are being blamed for a suddenly-weak market for soft white wheat grown in the Northwest. ``There's just not much grain moving here,'' Tom Winn, Oregon Wheat Commission administrator said of the Port of Portland. Bids for soft white wheat have fallen more than $1 during the past year, to $3.76 a bushel Thursday in Portland, Winn said. ``We're going nuts attempting to get a market turnaround,'' said Wes Grilley of Pendleton, executive vice president of the 9,000-member Oregon Wheat Growers League. Oregon's soft white wheat is used in Asia for noodles, cookies and baked products. In Egypt and other Middle Eastern nations, it is used in unleavened bread and pita bread. Grilley said India and Pakistan had a bumper crop last year and another is predicted this year. ``Egypt is desperate to get more wheat, but they need credit,'' he said. Grilley also blamed the cargo preference provisions of the Food for Peace program, which require the bulk of federal aid exports to be shipped on U.S.-flag vessels. ``Recently, on a sale to Egypt, the U.S. vessels were charging $27 more per ton from the West Coast than from the East Coast and the foreign flag vessels were charging $1 a ton more,'' Grilley said. The Northwest, he said, was hit harder than other regions of the country. Prices for Midwest dark northern spring wheat and hard red wheat have fallen only about 75 cents during the past year, he said. ``It's obviously going to create some hardships,'' Grilley said. ``I think we are in for some strong belt tightening.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Groups in Giant Fraud Case Divvying Up $753 Million
DOC.TEXT: Washington Public Power Supply System bondholders could receive as much as 32 cents on the dollar under an agreement between two groups sharing a $753 million settlement fund. For some bondholders, the payoff could be as little as 10 cents for each of the $1 bonds. The payment agreement, announced Thursday, requires federal court approval, said New York-based Chemical Bank, trustee of the WPPSS bond fund. Payments would be made June 1, 1991. Sharing in the settlement would be holders of the defaulted WPPSS bonds, which were sold to finance two since-abandoned nuclear power plants, and members of a class-action lawsuit that alleged fraud against the supply system, Northwest utilities and other parties. Original investors who have held the bonds through most of this decade will be able to collect as both bondholders and members of the class-action suit. The $753 million fund was collected from settlements made before, during and after the giant fraud case went to court before U.S. District Judge William Browning in September 1988. Defendants in the case included 88 Northwest utilities, the supply system, bond underwriters, engineering firms and WPPSS advisers. The case was settled out of court after three months of trial. The case consolidated dozens of lawsuits filed after WPPSS defaulted on $2.25 billion in bonds sold to finance construction of unfinished nuclear plants WPPSS Nos. 4 and 5. The default was the biggest in the history of the municipal bond market. Jeffrey Klafter, attorney for the class-action plaintiffs, said the recommended settlement would pay about 22 cents on the dollar to those with a claim who had retained their bonds. The award would be less for those who sold their bonds at reduced prices, he said. The bond fund, managed by Chemical Bank, will receive some of the $753 million and also has received money from the sale of scrap parts from the abandoned plants. The fund will total $210 million, said Chemical Bank Vice President William Berls, enough to pay bondholders only about 10 cents on the dollar. Thus some plaintiffs would receive the 22 cents plus 10 cents per dollar invested. Those who purchased bonds after WPPSS missed its payments in June 1983, leading to default the next month, would apparently receive the least from the settlement fund. Those bonds have been considered speculative, and many of the buyers paid original purchasers as little as eight or nine cents on the dollar. Berls said all parties should be pleased with the agreement ``given the litigation risks, given the time we have saved everyone ... and the uncertainties of appeals.'' The two sides also agreed to repay the bond fund $52 million for previous litigation expenses. In addition, $50 million and $43.5 million in interest will be transferred from the settlement fund to the bond fund on June 1, 1991. Also expected to come out of the settlement fund is nearly $100 million that has been requested by lawyers for the class-action plaintiffs. Browning has yet to decide on the eventual payoff for lawyers. Another lawsuit still before Browning could result in $400 million in payoffs for bondholders. That suit, against WPPSS and the Bonneville Power Administration, alleges expenses for two other supply system plants were unfairly billed to plants Nos. 4 and 5.

DOC.HEAD: Proxy Fights: Latest Takeover Trend
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after the 20th graf, beg. Coniston later, with Xtra board losing proxy fight.
DOC.TEXT: Suddenly it seems that proxy battles are in, with corporate predators making them the latest trend in takeovers. But while directors of several big companies have become targeted for removal by dissident investors, it remains to be seen how successful these ploys are. The boards of Lockheed Corp. and Avon Products Inc. face proxy fights by corporate suitors at their upcoming annual meetings. Meanwhile, USX Corp. has averted a threatened proxy battle with Carl Icahn by agreeing to put his proposal for selling the company's steel business to a shareholder vote. Proxy fights _ essentially a contested shareholder election for control of management _ have regained some of their luster as other takeover methods such as junk bond-financed hostile buyouts have lost theirs. High-risk junk bonds were raiders' tool of choice during the hostile takeover binge of the 1980s. But with the collapse of several junk-financed companies and the bonds' main purveyor, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., some would-be acquirers think it's easier to seize control through proxy battles. Investor Harold Simmons plans a proxy fight at Lockheed's March 29 annual meeting because he's unhappy with the current board's management of the defense and aerospace company. He thinks he can do a better job of deploying its assets and cutting costs _ thereby increasing the value of his Lockheed stock. Simmons, who is Lockheed's biggest shareholder with 19 percent of its stock, has nominated a slate of directors that includes such high-powered names as former Texas Sen. John Tower and retired Admiral Elmo Zumwalt Jr., a former member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. At a news conference this week, Simmons was undaunted when a reporter noted that proxy fights _ notably Icahn's unsuccessful 1988 attack on the board of Texaco Inc. _ generally have had little success. Simmons said of Icahn, who is chairman of Trans World Airlines, ``He's not basically a manager.'' Simmons and Icahn both are viewed as corporate raiders, but Simmons believes he has a better track record after running companies like NL Industries Inc., Amalgamated Sugar Co., and Keystone Steel and Wire Co. Simmons thinks that should carry some weight with Lockheed shareholders. He also believes his chances for success are better than Icahn's were at Texaco because Lockheed is in worse financial shape than the oil giant was two years ago and probably has more unhappy shareholders. Icahn, then Texaco's biggest shareholder, tried to unseat the Texaco board because he thought the company wasn't doing enough to increase its stock price. If he had won control, he planned to sell some of its assets and distribute the proceeds to Texaco shareholders. Texaco won the proxy battle when shareholders voted against Icahn's slate of nominees. But it also undertook a restructuring that included billions of dollars in asset sales and a special dividend to shareholders. Icahn was considering a proxy fight at USX, where he also is the largest stockholder. However, he sidestepped that tactic in exchange for a shareholder vote May 7 on splitting up the oil, steel and gas company, which he says would increase shareholder value. Other companies have thwarted proxy fights long before their annual meetings are held. A year ago, Polaroid Corp. stopped a proxy attack by Shamrock Holdings Inc. by putting enough of its shares in friendly hands to defeat a Shamrock slate of nominees. Shamrock gave up after the courts in Delaware, where Polaroid is incorporated, upheld the defensive move. Some other companies have averted proxy fights only by capitulating to dissidents' demands. Allegis Corp. abandoned plans to become a travel empire after Coniston Partners, which held a 13 percent stake in the company, and the pilots of Allegis' United Airlines unit began soliciting votes to unseat management in 1987. Coniston and the pilots wanted to replace the Allegis board with directors who would sell the company's non-United assets, including Westin Hotels and Hertz car rental. The board ended up doing that anyway, fired Chairman Richard Ferris and changed the company's name to UAL Corp. Coniston later dropped its proxy campaign. Sometimes proxy battles that go to a vote do succeed. On Thursday, the board of Xtra Corp., a Boston-based trailer leasing concern, said it had lost a proxy fight to a slate of dissidents who opposed management's plans to sell the company. Chartwell Associates L.P., which includes the owners of Mary Kay Cosmetics and a Getty family trust, plans a proxy battle for four seats on the 11-member board of Avon Products. The group, which owns nearly 10 percent of stock in the cosmetic company, said it wants to maximize shareholder value by selling Avon, which is best known for its core direct-sales business.

DOC.HEAD: Industrial Proeduction Up in February
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Industrial production, pulled down in January by a cutback in automobile output and utility use, bounced back 0.6 percent in February with the return of autoworkers, the government said today. The Federal Reserve said February's advance followed a revised 1.0 percent drop in January's output and a 0.1 percent gain in December. January's output originally was reported to have fallen 1.2 percent. In a second report, the Fed said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities _ which usually moves in tandem with industrial production _ rose 0.3 percentage point to 82.3 percent in February. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels. ``The output of motor vehicles and parts increased sharply in February following the substantial cut in January, although the level of motor vehicle production in February was still more than 5 percent below its December level,'' the Fed said in its industrial production report. ``Excluding motor vehicles and related industries, production was little changed,'' it added. Thousands of autoworkers returned to production lines in February after being laid off the previous month as the industry reduced bloated inventories. Industrial production at manufacturing plants making both durable and non-durable goods rose 0.7 percent in February after falling 0.7 percent a month earlier. Durable manufacturing was up 1.4 percent after a 1.5 decline in January. Non-durable manufacturing slipped 0.2 percent compared to a 0.4 percent gain the previous month. Output at mines dipped 0.5 percent from a 2.5 percent advance while utility output was off 0.8 percent after a 10.6 percent drop in January. The Fed said its industrial production index in February stood at 141.8 percent of its 1977 base, up from 141.0 percent in January. The Fed also said the increase in capacity utilization ``resulted almost exclusively from an increase in the operating rate for auto and truck assembly facilities after most had been shut down for part of January. ``Utilization rates in most other manufacturing industries, as well as mining and utilities, declined in February,'' it said. The manufacturing plant operating rate rose to 82.4 percent from 82.0 percent in January. The rate at factories producing durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ was up to 80.5 percent from 79.6 percent the previous month. The rate at factories producing non-durable goods was down from 85.5 percent in January to 85.0 percent last month. The operating rate at mines slipped to 84.4 percent from 84.8 percent in January, while it fell 0.7 percentage point to 77.3 percent at utilities.

The stock market staged a broad advance today in an upbeat ``triple witching hour'' on Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 12.61 to 2,708.33 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 658 up, 305 down and 434 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 59.61 million shares as of 10 a.m. EST. Blue chip stocks attracted buy orders at the witching hour, marking the last trading in a set of options and futures on stock indexes used by professionals in computerized index arbitrage. The market's response was less clear, however, to word that the producer price of finished goods was unchanged in February after climbing 1.8 percent the month before. The apparent dropoff in inflationary pressures, which had been widely forecast, was attributed primarily to a decline in energy prices. Brokers said the data, excluding often-volatile food and energy prices, still suggested a worrisome degree of underlying inflation. Gainers among the blue chips included Exxon, up { at 47]; Philip Morris, up { at 38{; American Telephone & Telegraph, up | at 41}, and International Business Machines, up } at 107}. DOC.HEAD: Mandatory Jail Terms, Fines Urged for Violating Child Labor Laws
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 10 grafs new with quotes; editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Two House members called today for mandatory jail terms and fines of up to $100,000 for employers who repeatedly violate child labor laws. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., said child labor laws need to be overhauled to make effective the Labor Department's efforts to crack down on businesses that violate them. Schumer, speaking before a House Government Operations subcommittee on employment and housikng, called for increasing the civil penalties for child labor violations from $1,000 to $10,000. Schumer said that between 1987 and 1989 there were 128,000 minors who were injured and an estimated 59 killed in the workplace. Yet 37 employers who were cited for violations relating to those cases were fined a total of only $27,000, he said. ``The average penalty was a paltry $740 _ $740 for a child's life in the United States,'' Schumer said. The hearing came a day after Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole announced that a three-day sting operation had uncovered 7,000 minors employed in dangerous jobs or working long hours in violation of child labor laws. The companies are expected to face civil fines totaling $1.8 million, she said. Rep. Don Pease, D-Ohio, said, ``A three-day undercover sting followed by a highly publicized media blitz is no substitute for practical laws and sustained enforcement over time,'' Pease said. Schumer and Pease plan to introduce legislation next month to expand the definition of child labor violations. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., the committee chairman, said the panel would explore why child labor violations have increased and whether it is due to labor shortages or increased economic pressures on families. ``The sad fact is that it may continue to make economic sense to employers to violate the law'' if penalties remain at present levels, Schumer said. Lantos said more enforcement personnel are needed, ``not for three days, but every single day of the year so the most valuable resource of this nation _ children _ will not be frittered away in terms of their time, energy and physical well-being.'' At a news conference Thursday, Mrs. Dole said proposed revisions to the nation's child labor laws were under review. She said the government should first make the most of current resources. ``Then if additional funds are needed, you can bet I'll ask for those funds,'' she said. Most of the violations uncovered this week involved firms in which 14- and 15-year-olds worked more hours or later at night during the school week than allowed under federal law, said William Brooks, an assistant labor secretary. But there also were more than 900 youngsters, mostly 16- and 17-year-olds, who were performing dangerous tasks or using hazardous equipment such as power-driven meat-slicing machinery, dough mixers and paper-balers. Federal law forbids 14- and 15-year-olds from working more than three hours on a school day or 18 hours during a week when school is in session. Eight hours is permitted on weekend days and 40-hour weeks are permitted in summer and during vacations. Those youngsters may not work outside the hours of 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., or to 9 p.m. from June 1 to Labor Day. Brooks also said nearly 200 youngsters under 14 _ barred from most jobs, with a few exceptions such as certain farm work and newspaper delivery _ were found illegally employed. Mrs. Dole declined to name businesses involved, saying investigations are continuing. Officials said, however, that most of the alleged violations occurred at service businesses such as restaurants, grocery stores, pizza and doughnut shops and dry-cleaning establishments.
