DOC.HEAD: NBC Sues Sony, Columbia Over Home Video Venture
DOC.TEXT: NBC Inc. has filed a $250 million lawsuit against Sony Corp. and Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., alleging they secretly diverted home video distribution business to Sony. The lawsuit filed Thursday in Superior Court concerns RCA-Columbia Home Video, jointly owned by NBC and Sony-Columbia. It is among the nation's leading home video distributors. The suit charges Sony, Columbia and various subsidiaries practiced ``self-dealing designed to appropriate the assets, business opportunities and profits of RCA-Columbia Home Video for their own companies.'' A Sony spokesman declined to comment, saying the company had not received a copy of the lawsuit. But the company issued a statement saying, ``the lawsuit is surprising because Columbia and NBC have enjoyed a good relationship.'' In a recent deal, Sony-Columbia acquired theatrical distribution and home video distribution rights for a major package of future films by Orion Pictures. NBC's complaint alleges that Orion first offered distribution rights to RCA-Columbia, but that Sony-Columbia refused to let the joint venture proceed. It also says Sony-Columbia never told RCA-Columbia it was secretly negotiating its own deal. Harry Rubin, NBC vice president for home video, said Sony and Columbia ``have intentionally diverted business to themselves that should have should have gone to the joint venture. ``This goes beyond a normal business dispute and is not the type of behavior we are accustomed to from business partners,'' he said in a statement. The complaint also alleges Sony and Columbia have used confidential information on the joint venture's distribution goals to Sony's benefit. ``It is our contention that Sony's executive in charge of strategic planning in Japan directly contacted the various Sony-Columbia representatives and required that type of information be shared with them,'' NBC spokesman Joe Rutledge said in a telephone interview from New York. Rutledge said RCA-Columbia, in which NBC has a half-interest, had been averaging annual profits of more than $70 million and was itself valued at more than $1 billion before Sony acquired Columbia in October 1989.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 440.94 up 2.88 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Mostly Lower On Lack Soviet Sales
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures opened mixed, then turned mostly lower today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid disappointment over the lack of anticipated sales of corn and soybean meal to the Soviet Union. Wheat futures showed some strength, though, after the Agriculture Department announced it had accepted bids from exporters to sell 300,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat to China at subsidized prices. Many analysts had expected a higher opening in the soybean market following Thursday's gains of as much as 13{ cents a bushel on rumors that the Soviets were in the market for corn and, by logical extension, soybean meal as livestock feed. But, ``there was no evidence this morning that the Russians bought more corn,'' said Walter Spilka, a grain market analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. The soybean market showed little reaction to news that Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello had ordered a halt to agricultural subsidies. Brazil is the world's second-largest soybean producer. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.85\ a bushel; corn was { cent to } cent lower with March at $2.46{ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1\ cents higher with March at $1.45 a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 3{ cents lower with March at $5.82 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .08 cent to .22 cent higher with April at 77.52 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .28 cent higher with March at 82.77 cents a pound; live hogs were .02 cent lower to .50 cent higher with April at 53.20 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .12 cent lower to .45 cent higher with March at 50 cents a pound. Cattle futures retreated on Thursday while pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesale Prices Steady in February
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 22nd graf, bgng: In other, to make it children's clothing, sted men's and boys'
DOC.TEXT: The effect of milder-than-usual weather on energy supplies held wholesale prices steady in February, the government said today. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index showed no change following a huge 1.8 percent jump in January. A holiday cold snap had caused record increases in energy prices and large food price rises, propelling the overall index in January to the largest increase in 15 years. The February report, despite another substantial rise in food costs, was the best in six months. Figures for the two months, taken together, represent an annualized wholesale inflation rate of 11.4 percent. However, economists do not expect anything approaching that for the entire year. Most anticipate prices will rise between 4 percent and 4.5 percent in 1990, slightly lower than the 1989 rate of 4.8 percent. The February price report was in line with economists' predictions and traders said it had little effect on stock and bond prices. However, a Federal Reserve report showing less-than-expected strength in manufacturing helped send financial markets higher in early trading. Economic weakness is seen as giving the Fed room to lower interest rates, a boon to stock and bond prices. Industrial production rose 0.6 percent in February after falling 1 percent in January, the central bank said. The bounce-back was weaker than anticipated. Meanwhile, the Commerce Department said the seasonally adjusted rate of new construction of homes and apartments fell 7 percent last month after a huge 24.7 percent rise in January. Stock markets were also heavily influenced by computerized trading, driven by the ``triple witching hour'' expiration of a set of options and futures contracts on stock indexes. In the first half hour of trading, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks rose 12.61 to 2,708.33. Energy prices in February plunged 5 percent after soaring 13.6 percent in January. The effect of the weather showed up most strongly in fuel oil prices, which rocketed 25.3 percent in January and plummeted 30.2 percent in February. They were the biggest increase and decrease since the department began tracking that price in 1973. Gasoline prices fell 2.3 percent last month after rising 16.7 percent in January. Natural gas prices edged up 0.1 percent after jumping 3.2 percent in the previous month. Food prices in February rose 0.9 percent, compared with January when they rose 2.1 percent, the biggest jump in six years. Vegetable prices last month shot up 23.3 percent, on top of the 58 percent rise in January. The holiday freeze killed vegetable crops from Texas to Florida. However, analysts expect vegetable costs to subside this spring as new crops are harvested. In other good news for grocery buyers, the wholesale price of eggs plunged 24 percent while dairy costs fell 2.7 percent. Both of those categories had been increasing for most of the previous year. However, chicken prices shot up 8.5 percent and fruit rose 8 percent. Prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors rose a moderate 0.4 percent in February after a slight 0.1 percent rise in January. Economists often use this so-called core rate as a better indication of underlying inflationary pressures in the economy. ``Inflation has been capped but it hasn't been broken,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Co. Weakness in manufacturing is preventing inflation from accelerating, he said, but the sluggishness hasn't spread to other sectors enough to substantially reduce inflation. In other categories, prices rose 1.1 percent for children's clothing, held steady for passenger cars, jumped 2.9 percent for tobacco products and plunged 5 percent for home electronic equipment. The various changes put the index for finished goods at 117.4 in February. This meant that a hypothetical selection of goods which cost $100 in 1982, cost $117.40 last month, up from $111.70 a year earlier. Price pressures in earlier stages of the production process also eased in February. Intermediate goods fell 0.7 percent, following a 1.2 percent rise in January, while crude goods increased a moderate 0.4 percent following a 2.4 percent jump a month earlier. An example of the three stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude.

DOC.HEAD: President Announces Emergency Economic Measures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to CORRECT that freeze only affects prices. Pickup 9th, `In March...'
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello today announced sweeping economic reforms including a 30-day price freeze and a new currency to slash 2,700 percent annual inflation and a $31 billion budget deficit. The austerity measures were announced one day after Collor de Mello was inaugurated as Brazil's first popularly elected president in 29 years. ``The measures are profound, courageous and indispensable. Society needs less state and more economy,'' he said. Brazil has the Western world's eighth-largest economy and third-biggest trade surplus, and is a producer and exporter of sophisticated goods such as computers, cars, aircraft and rockets. But it also has Third World's largest foreign debt, put at $114 billion; soaring inflation, 7 million street children, high adult illiteracy, sprawling shantytowns, epidemics of dengue, malaria and yellow fever. Collor de Mello said his free-market economic reforms would move toward correcting Brazil's social and economic imbalances. The measures introduced today included a crackdown on official corruption and white-collar crime. The reform package takes effect immediately but must be approved by Congress within 30 days. If Congress fails to vote, Collor de Mello can reissue the measures for another 30 days. Collor de Mello said once the price freeze ends in mid-April, a government index will determine monthly wage and price increases. Globo, Brazil's largest commercial television network, said salaries and prices would jump 40 percent in April and 20 percent in May. In March, salaries will increase by February's inflation rate, or 73 percent. Inflation this month was expected to reach 85 percent. Collor de Mello also said the cruzado novo currency would be replaced by the ``cruzeiro.'' The nation's fourth currency in as many years will be devalued by about 100 percent versus the cruzado novo, economists said. The ``cruzeiro,'' was the name of a currency suspended in 1986. Collor de Mello decreed a new law to punish crimes against the economy, including speculation and illegal price increases. The law imposes a five-year prison term for violators. White-collar crime by public employees would also result in firings and jail time, Collor de Mello said. ``Who tries to cheat and fool the people will be jailed,'' Collor de Mello said. The new measures included: _Steep new income taxes for citizens and corporations. _The suspension of an estimated $2.2 billion spent annually in government subsidies to private enterprise. Export companies were the principal beneficiaries. _Privatization of some of Brazil's 188 state-owned companies, many of which operate at a loss. They have total debts of around $62 billion. _Stiff increases in public utility rates. _An administrative reform that includes mass dismissal of public employees. The federal government has about 700,000 workers, and aides to Collor de Mello have talked of firing about 80,000. _The disbanding of some government enterprises, including the Institute of Sugar and Alcohol, the Brazilian Coffee Institute, the steel holding company Siderbras, the port authority Portobras, and Interbras, the foreign trade subsidiary of the oil monpoly Petrobras. Collor de Mello said he was serious about slashing federal spending. ``This year's federal deficit will be zero. ... There's no way to knock down inflation if the government spends more than it takes in,'' he said. Collor de Mello also said he would slash import barriers and encourage foreign capital. ``We will modernize our economy and stimulate competition ... Free initiative is the only way to sustained and progressive growth'' he said. Collor de Mello issued decrees Thursday cutting the number of government ministries from 25 to 12, putting up for sale government-owned mansions and cars, and preventing public employees from holding more than one public job. Initial reaction from conservative politicians and the business community to Collor de Mello's economic measures was positive. ``We've worked all our lives for reforms like a balanced budget. Halelujah!,'' said conservative Sen. Jarbas Pasarinho of the Social Democracy Party. Albano Franco, president of the National Confederation of Industry, said: ``The package will allow Brazil to escape this terrible economic crisis.'' But labor unions have made clear their displeasure. ``Once again, the workers will be sacrificed,'' said Jair Meneguelli, president of the leftist Central Workers Union, a labor umbrella group representing 12 million workers. Collor de Mello ended the five-year term of President Jose Sarney, who took office after an Electoral College vote set up by the military regime that ruled Brazil between 1964 and 1985.

The stock market pushed ahead today in an upbeat ``triple witching hour'' on Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 21.40 to 2,717.12 by noontime EST. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 803 up, 461 down and 510 unchanged. Blue chip stocks attracted buy orders at the witching hour, marking the last trading in a set of options and futures on stock indexes used by professionals in computerized index arbitrage. The market's response was less clear, however, to word that the producer price of finished goods was unchanged in February after climbing 1.8 percent the month before. The apparent dropoff in inflationary pressures, which had been widely forecast, was attributed primarily to a decline in energy prices. Brokers said the data, excluding often-volatile food and energy prices, still suggested a worrisome degree of underlying inflation. Norton Co., subject of a $75-a-share bid by BTR PLC, led the active list and shot up 15} to 74. Gainers among the blue chips included Exxon, up { at 47]; Philip Morris, up } at 38}; American Telephone & Telegraph, up { at 41|, and International Business Machines, up ~ at 107~. Apple Computer jumped 3 to 39} as one of the volume leaders in the over-the-counter market. Late Thursday the company said its sales and earnings for the quarter that ends March 30 will be stronger than expected. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.13 to 187.33. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.65 at 363.92. Volume on the Big Board came to 118.69 million shares at noontime, against 66.11 million at the same point Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Indictment Returned Against General Development
DOC.TEXT: General Development Corp. has agreed to plead guilty to federal charges in connection with an alleged scheme to inflate the cost of homes at the firm's nine Florida developments, federal officials said today. The plea was announced along with the unsealing of a 16-count indictment against General Development and two former executives. The indictment was issued Tuesday but not made public while officials discussed possible plea agreements with the defendants. The Miami-based real estate development firm agreed to plead guilty to one count of ``conspiring through certain of its officers to violate the federal mail fraud statute.'' General Development agreed to pay a fine of not more than $500,000 and agreed in principle to enter into a civil consent decree establishing a restitution fund for eligible homebuyers who purchased homes between Jan. 1, 1982 and Dec. 31, 1989. Charles J. Simons, chairman, president and chief executive officer, said he was ``gratified that General Development has been able to put this episode in its history behind it.'' ``This company will be run in full compliance with all laws and regulations and with the highest standards of business ethics,'' said Simons. ``It is clear that our house prices had gotten out of line with our competition and that some of our customers were disadvantaged.'' The indictment alleged that General Development sold more than 10,000 homes between 1983 and 1989 at prices exceeding fair market value. In at least one case, the home was valued at less than half its sale price. Also named in the indictment was GDV Financial Corp., a General Development subsidiary that provided mortgages and other financial assistance to home buyers. Former General Development Chairman David Brown and former President Robert Ehrling were accused of fraud in the indicatment and were also considering plea agreements, U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said. There was no immediate comment from either man, and General Development said it did not have telephone numbers where they could be reached. Brown and Ehrling were ousted from General Development a week ago. Lehtinen said a plea agreement for the two executives could include jail time. Lehtinen said details of the planned restitution by General Development were still under discussion and would not be official until he files a civil consent order. Under the agreement, which still must be approved by financial institutions holding mortgages on General Development homes, up to $100 million could be set aside for reimbursement. Lehtinen said federal officials hoped General Development would remain in business, but the plea agreement could require dismissal of other top executives. General Development is fighting to survive a cash shortage that the company says results from its legal problems. Lenders and investors have deserted General Development since it disclosed that it might be indicted by a federal grand jury investigating how General Development markets its homes.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 4,000 Take U S West Early Retirement
DOC.TEXT: Slightly more than 4,000 U S West Inc. managers and administrators have accepted the company's latest voluntary retirement program, a U S West spokesman said. Dick MacKnight said Thursday 4,022 people chose from a variety of retirement plans and left the payroll last month. Last year, the Denver-based company, parent of U S West Communications in Omaha, offered 6,300 managers incentives to take early retirement. U S West said the proposals were aimed at reducing costs and focusing attention on customer services. Of the total, 2,881 took pension benefits in a lump sum, MacKnight said. The remainder chose monthly pensions. Despite the employee cutbacks, which have occurred at U S West since 1982, the company's work force stood at 70,587 at the end of last year, only 178 fewer than employed by the company in 1984. MacKnight said U S West had added employees through creation of new companies and acquiring others. ``What's happened is that the telephone companies have continued to downsize and others outside the telephone companies have continued to grow,'' he said. In a report to stockholders, Jack A. MacAllister, chairman and chief executive officer, said that U S West planned to increase its annual investment in the telephone business to $2 billion a year, or by 15 percent, beginning in 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Crazy Eddie Founder Disappears; Court Appearance Friday
LaserPhoto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf with 2 grafs with Antar not appearing today.
DOC.TEXT: Eddie Antar, the eccentric founder of the Crazy Eddie Inc. stereo chain, once suddenly changed his mind about going to dinner with a group of associates and jumped into a long black limousine in front of the restaurant. After dinner, the associates saw the limo still there and asked the driver what had happened to Mr. Antar, as the story is told by a businessman who had dealings with Antar. The driver was confused, and then understood. ``He said, `That crazy guy? He walked in one door and out the other,''' said the businessman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Antar has become even more elusive. In fact, he is a fugitive from a federal judge's contempt citation in a Securities and Exchange Commission insider trading case against him. Antar failed to appear today to give sworn testimony in the case, paving the way for him to be found in default and have a judgment entered against him. And in court papers filed late Thursday, his attorneys said they wanted to withdraw from the case ``based on Antar's unavailability.'' The Brooklyn, N.Y.-born high school dropout built an empire of 43 stores in four states from a lone outlet. Much of his success was to two decades of TV-rattling commercials advertising ``INSANNNNNE'' prices. ``His commercials used to annoy me, and now he's annoying me,'' said U.S. Marshal Arthur Borinsky, the man in charge of tracking Antar down. ``I have no expectations at all about seeing him,'' said a source close to Antar. Antar disappeared after U.S. District Judge Nicholas H. Politan found him in contempt for failing to appear in court to Feb. 28. Earlier, Politan required Antar to repatriate $52 million in allegedly illegal profits, believed to be in Israeli banks, from selling Crazy Eddie stock. Politan has also frozen Antar's assets and appointed a trustee to trace them. The fugitive entrepreneur was last seen by authorities at a Feb. 13 appearance. In addition to a criminal contempt finding by Politan, the U.S. attorney has also filed criminal contempt charges against him. The SEC charges Antar and other former Crazy Eddie officials reaped millions of dollars in illegal trading profits after inflating the company's income. They allegedly exaggerated inventory and falsely reduced bills to suppliers. There have been numerous sightings of Antar, but none panned out, said Ray Mack, a U.S. postal inspector investigating the case. Antar's wife, former wife, in-laws and friends all say they have no idea where he is. The SEC even asked actor Jerry Carroll, the company's manic broadcast pitchman from 1972 to 1989. No luck. ``Eddie was always a reclusive guy,'' Carroll said in an interview. ``If Eddie didn't want to talk to you, he didn't talk to you.'' Carroll said he was paid handsomely for making more than 6,000 commercials, and was given options for 81,000 shares of stock in unsolicited bonuses. The options are now worthless. New management failed to turn around the teetering chain and went to bankruptcy court. Crazy Eddie was liquidated last year. Its stock had traded as high as $21, and the company had revenues in 1987 of more than $350 million. Stores were in New Jersey, New York, Connecticut and Pennsylvania. Antar's name was rarely mentioned in print without the word ``reclusive'' attached to it. The 42-year-old onetime Wall Street darling infrequently appeared in public. Pictures are few, though the latest shows him, hair slicked back and beard closely trimmed, holding a U.S. marshal's processing number. It came after his Feb. 13 court appearance. Known by the nickname Kelso, after the famous racehorse, the eccentric Antar often wore jogging suits, even when surrounded by people in black tie and gowns at formal company parties. He kept a large German shepherd with him, had exercise equipment in his office and reportedly wore a lucky black sweater for two years. Antar grew up in a compact community of Syrian Jews in Brooklyn's Flatbush section, most of whom trace roots to the ancient trading city of Aleppo. Many in the remarkably successful community spend their summers in the Jersey shore town of Deal. Antar is ``very bright, very private and right now, very put upon,'' said his New Jersey lawyer, Jack Arseneault, who denied the SEC charges and blamed them on the bitter statements of three disaffected company officials. Disgruntled shareholders sued him in 1987 and the U.S. attorney is seeking a criminal indictment. He also has been embroiled in a reopened divorce case with his previous wife.

DOC.HEAD: MCI's Wright Retiring from Office of Chief Executive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead, 2nd and 5th grafs to add Wright's age and to clarify that Wright shared the office of chief executive with McGowan.
DOC.TEXT: V. Orville Wright is retiring from the office of chief executive of MCI Communications Corp., the company said Friday. Wright, 68, will continue as vice chairman and a member of the board of directors and will be a consultant, MCI said. William G. McGowan will resume sole responsibilities as chairman and chief executive officer of MCI, which is the nation's second-largest long-distance company. Wright, who joined MCI in 1975 as president and chief operating officer, first retired in 1985 and was succeeded by Bert C. Roberts Jr., who continues in that position. Wright came back to the company as acting chief executive officer in 1987 when McGowan suffered a heart attack. Wright later was appointed to the office of chief executive, a position shared with McGowan. Wright previously was an executive at International Business Machines Corp., Xerox Corp. and RCA.

DOC.HEAD: Engineers Lift Stranded Spacecraft into `Parking' Orbit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 16th graf pvs, ``There are, to restore Kristofferson's first name.
DOC.TEXT: With commands from the ground, engineers have succeeded in raising the orbit of an errant $150 million communications satellite so that it won't crash through the atmosphere in the next nine days. The higher orbit buys time for the owner, Intelsat, to explore rescue options. Tony Trujillo, spokesman for the Washington-based company, said today that a letter was going to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration discussing its help, possibly a rescue by a space shuttle. The satellite was left in an orbit that went within 103.5 miles of Earth after it failed to separate properly from its Titan 3 rocket after launch on Wednesday. If the satellite had remained at that altitude, atmospheric drag would pull the spacecraft into the atmosphere, where it would burn up. Using small steering thrusters and hydrazine fuel stored aboard for small course corrections, engineers boosted the satellite to an egg-shaped orbit of 161 miles by 276 miles, a satisfactory position for ``parking.'' ``This is very good news,'' Trujillo said of the successful effort to boost the 5-ton satellite. The maneuver does nothing, however, to restore the satellite to usefulness: it must be in a geosynchronous orbit, 22,300 miles high, to carry out its functions. NASA said once it is asked by Intelsat for help, ``questions of planning for such a complex mission, crew training and modifications to the shuttle would have to be evaluated in the light of the orbit achieved by the Intelsat spacecraft.'' There were reports, too, that Intelsat was asking the Soviets for help, but Trujillo said only that ``right now we are concentrating discussing with NASA the possibility of assistance.'' The satellite was propelled into space at a cost of about $270 million in the fourth commercial launch of a payload by a U.S. company. It wound up in the wrong orbit after failing to separate properly from the second stage of its booster rocket. The satellite was separated about seven hours later by computer commands sent from Intelsat's headquarters in Washington. But the rocket motor that was to have boosted the satellite into higher orbit remained attached to the second stage booster. The Titan's second stage, traveling at about the same speed as the satellite in the same elliptical orbit 90 to 190 miles above Earth, has until about Wednesday before falling back to Earth, said Maj. Thomas Niemann of the U.S. Space Command. The rocket has more mass than the satellite and more surface area, causing greater atmospheric drag. The U.S. Space Command probably will not know where the spacecraft will come down until about 12 hours beforehand, Niemann said. John Pike, associate director for space policy for the Federation of American Scientists, said the satellite is ``worthless'' no matter where it is unless NASA agrees to help. ``The best they can do is to hope they get it in some orbit that would enable a shuttle, probably the American shuttle, to bring it back down,'' Pike said. Before the 1986 Challenger disaster, shuttles brought back two satellites for refurbishing and crew members repaired two others in space. Following the explosion, President Reagan and Congress directed NASA to move away from launching commercial satellites and devote its efforts to research and development. ``There are so many unknowns in this thing,'' NASA spokesman Karl Kristofferson said. ``First, whether it's doable. Second, whether it would fit.'' Martin Marietta Corp., which launched the rocket and satellite, has not yet determined what went wrong, company spokesman Art Koski said. Of 142 Titan 3 launches, 136 have been successful. The Intelsat VI spacecraft was intended to transmit three TV channels and up to 120,000 telephone calls simultaneously 22,300 miles above Earth for more than 13 years. It was to have eventually replaced two older satellites over the Atlantic. Intelsat, a not-for-profit international consortium that operates a global communications satellite system, had not acquired insurance for Wednesday's launch. Instead, it self-insured the satellite and launch vehicle through a reserve fund established to cover failures. Martin Marietta's stock dropped $1.375 a share Wednesday as investors became nervous about the company's possible financial liability for the $150 million satellite and $115 million rocket. The stock rebounded Thursday, closing at $41.375, up 12{ cents. The company said its financial responsibility ended when the Titan 3 rocket ignited. Under its contract with the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization, or Intelsat, Martin Marietta's financial responsibility ended before the rocket cleared the launch tower, a company spokesman said. But Intelsat officials declined to comment on Martin's assessment of its liability for the satellite. ``It would be dangerous for us to talk about when their liability ended and ours began at this time,'' said Intelsat spokesman Tony Trujillo. ``It could come up in litigation.'' Wednesday's launch was Intelsat's 44th; 35 were successful.

DOC.HEAD: BTR Launches 1.64-billion Dollar Offer For Norton
DOC.TEXT: British industrial giant BTR PLC announced today an unsolicited $1.64 billion tender offer for Norton Co., a U.S. abrasives manufacturer. BTR said it was offering $75 a share for Norton through a U.S. subsidiary, ER Holdings Inc. Norton responded that its board of directors was reviewing the offer, and would tell shareholders by March 29 of its position on the bid. BTR's finance director, Chris Bull, said the company would finance the bid with corporate reserves and bank borrowing. He said he did not know how much debt would be incurred, but added that BTR could cope with any repayments despite Britain's 15 percent interest rates. Norton had earnings of $85.8 million on sales of $1.53 billion in 1989. BTR, formerly known as British Tire and Rubber, has diverse activities, including electronics, sports products and transportation. It had after-tax profit 783 million pounds, or $1.3 billion, on sales of 7.03 billion pounds, or $11.3 billion, last year. Norton stock soared on the news of the bid, rising $15.62{ to $73.87{ by midday on the New York Stock Exchange. London's stock market also reacted enthusiastically to the move. BTR's shares jumped 20 pence, or 32 cents, to close at 437 pence, or $7.04, on London's Stock Exchange. Analysts generally said BTR would benefit from owning Norton despite recent problems at the U.S. company. ``I think it's a very good deal,'' said analyst Jack Jones of the London investment firm UBS-Phillips and Drew. David Ireland, an analyst with Hoare Govett Ltd. said Norton has ``excellent products and good market position.'' But Scott Fulton, an analyst with Charterhouse Tilney took a negative view. ``Everybody's been waiting for BTR to make an acquisition and I don't think people should get excited about this acquisition,'' he said. Norton's main lines of business are in decline globally and the company suffers from high manufacturing costs, Fulton said. BTR Chairman John Cahill said the company would continue its acquisitive trend in 1990. ``We have a number of companies we're looking at,'' Cahill said, adding that he was targeting the United States as a prime buying market. ``The United States is in vogue,'' he said.
Here are the major business events and economic events scheduled for the coming week (some dates are tentative; times are EST):

WILLIAMSBURG, Va. _ Experts from 25 countries meet through Friday for global warming conference sponsored by NASA-Langley. EAST BERLIN _ ``Two-plus-Four'' talks on German unification expected to resume.

WASHINGTON _ Labor Department reports consumer prices for February, 8:30 a.m. WASHINGTON _ Commerce Department reports merchandise trade for January, 8:30 a.m. WASHINGTON _ Senate returns from week-long recess to continue debate on clean air bill. ANCHORAGE, Alaska _ Closing arguments in Joseph Hazelwood trial stemming from Exxon Valdez oil spill. BRIDGEPORT, Conn. _ Second trial scheduled to begin in suit by deli owner claiming he is owed stock in Paul Newman's food company for services rendered when the company was launched eight years ago. GREELEY, Colo. _ Special county election on whether expensive waste treatment facility should be required at huge hog farm. Issue pits the Bass brothers, Texas millionaires and hog farm owners, against millionaires Philip Anschutz and Peter Coors. LONDON _ Government presents annual budget to Parliament.

WASHINGTON _ William Seidman, chairman of FDIC and Resolution Trust Corp., is luncheon speaker at National Press Club. PHOENIX _ Court-appointed examiner of American Continental-Keating operations reports findings to federal judge. LOUIS _ Sentencing for Paul Koerner, investment adviser convicted of masterminding platinum investing scam in 1986 in several states.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Bus Strike Talks Haunted by Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5 bgng `A striking...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with arraignment in Connecticut, details of shooting in Phoenix.
DOC.TEXT: Neither side in the 15-day Greyhound bus strike is confident that renewed talks will produce a settlement, as gunshots again were fired at a bus today and a striking driver was arrested in an earlier shooting. Federal mediators scheduled separate meetings today in Tucson, Ariz., with company officials and union negotiators. The two sides were to meet face-to-face Saturday for the first time since 6,300 drivers and an estimated 3,000 other Greyhound workers walked out. Greyhound Lines Inc. Chairman Fred G. Currey on Thursday accused the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions of terrorism in connection with shooting attacks on buses and other violence. A striking driver was charged today in the shooting Monday of a Greyhound bus in Farmington, Conn. Roger D. Cawtra, 44, of Stratford was arrested at his home by state police and charged with reckless endangerment and weapons offenses, police said. A judge ordered him held on $100,000 bond. A shot fired from a passing car hit the windshield of a bus in Phoenix early today, police said. Greyhound spokeswoman Ann Wheat said the glass was not penetrated and no one was injured. She said the 43 passengers on the bus bound from New York to Los Angeles were put on another bus. Currey said the violence has undermined his optimism at reaching a settlement. ``I guess the best way to characterize my feeling is that I have high hopes but very low expectations,'' Currey said. ``I believe these union leaders ... think they can win this strike through violence, terrorism and intimidation and if they think that, then I have very low expectations,'' he said. Union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson defended union leaders, though he acknowledged union members may be responsible for some of the violence. ``Union leaders do not believe violence will solve this problem,'' he said. ``We have repeatedly gone to union officials at the local level, imploring them to let their own members know that this is not a way to solve a strike.'' Nelon suggested the company is positioning itself to walk out of the negotiations. ``It takes two parties to negotiate,'' Nelson said. ``If one party is not prepared to negotiate then there can't be negotiations.'' Currey said the company was returning to the bargaining table only because federal mediators indicated it might help end the strike. He would not say if the company has a new offer, repeating past statements that Greyhound can afford no more than the $63 million, three-year contract it first offered. The strike began March 2 after talks broke down over wages and job security. Nelson said the two sides are ``not that far apart'' on financial aspects, but differ on grievance procedures. Since the walkout began, there have been at least 14 shooting attacks on Greyhound buses, 46 bomb threats and numerous other incidents of vandalism or threats, Currey said Thursday. In Chattanooga, Tenn., police escorted buses out of town late Thursday after a second sniper attack in as many days. A bullet shattered a bus windshield Thursday afternoon shortly after it left the Chattanooga terminal en route to Detroit, and two shots struck a bus Wednesday night on Interstate 24. No one was injured in either incident. Also Thursday, strikers and employees were forced to evacuate a Greyhound maintenance yard in Los Angeles after a caller phoned in the threat. Bomb squad members found a ticking suitcase in the cargo area of a bus in the yard but later discovered an alarm clock and clothing inside, said police Sgt. Tom Jones. Greyhound has won court orders barring violence in more than a dozen cities and reached agreement with the union Thursday to ban picketing and demonstrations at three Greyhound operations in Jacksonville, Fla. Greyhound, the nation's only intercity bus company, has been operating at reduced levels since the strike began, using permanent replacements and union members willing to cross the picket line. The company says 394 union drivers are at work, joining 1,002 permanent replacements. The union says only 94 of its drivers have crossed the line.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down in Europe, Gold Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version for AMs is planned by 5:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar declined against major currencies except the Canadian dollar in dull European trading on Friday, weakened by worries over low U.S. economic growth. Gold prices regained the $400 level. Foreign exchange dealers said hopes of a more robust U.S. economy were not fulfilled in new statistics on producer prices, housing starts and industrial production. The dollar also was hurt by continuing speculation that the West German mark will strengthen next week if Sunday's parliamentary elections in East Germany signal a quickening of German unity. In London, one British pound cost $1.6235 late Friday, more expensive for buyers than Thursday's late $1.6177. Other late dollar rates compared with late Thursday's quotes included: 1.6945 West German marks, down from 1.7025; 1.5080 Swiss francs, down from 1.5222; 5.7245 French francs, down from 5.7545; 1.9077 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9265; 1,251.00 Italian lire, down from 1,257.25; and 1.1802 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1778. Earlier in Tokyo the dollar closed at 152.50 Japanese yen, up from 152.47. In London late Friday the dollar closed higher at 152.30 yen. Gold bullion prices rose as the dollar declined, going back above $400 for the first time in four days. But dealers said they do not expect gold to go much higher because of the lack of interest. Gold closed in London, the major market, at a bid of $400.50 a troy ounce, up from $398.50. The closing bid in Zurich was $401 an ounce, up from $398.40. Earlier in Hong Kong gold closed at $399.75 bid, up from $397.52 Thursday. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid of $5.13 a troy ounce, up from $5.120.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Advance in London
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Prices advanced strongly in moderately active trading on London's Stock Exchange Friday, as some panic buying in blue chip stocks and a strong start to Wall Street boosted the overall market. Institutional investors were spotted in the market for the first time in a long while, dealers said. This week's earnings reports from several major British companies improved market sentiment and encouraged hopes that British profits will be strong in 1990. ``Things are beginning to improve,'' said one market maker. ``All you need is a little bit of buying to set things alight.'' The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was up 29 points, or 1.3 percent, at 2,263.9, well above the session low of 2,238.8 and just below its peak of 2,264.2. Volume came to 485.5 million shares, compared with 350.4 million Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders Approve Recap Plan, Sale of Some Assets
DOC.TEXT: Sea Containers Ltd. announced Friday its stockholders approved the company's proposed recapitalization, which involves selling certain container and ferry assets to Tiphook PLC and Stena AB. Part of the proceeds from the asset sales will be used by Sea Containers to buy back 7 million shares of its common stock at $70 apiece. The vote, which occurred Thursday at the annual general meeting in Hamilton, Bermuda, was 9.9 million shares in favor of the moves and 1.6 million against. The Sea Containers board of directors was re-elected at the meeting. President James B. Sherwood said final sale agreements have been executed with Stena and Tiphook. The transactions should be completed by the end of March and the share program would be carried out by early April. Sweden's Stena and Britain's Tiphook had jointly pursued Sea Containers through a ferry consortium they own together, called Temple Holdings Ltd. Sea Containers rejected three Temple takeover proposals, including the latest one worth $1.04 billion. Temple in mid-January offered to drop its bid if Sea Containers agreed to sell portions of its ferry and container businesses to Tiphook and Stena. Sherwood said in a news release that after the recapitalization, Sea Containers' main areas of operation would be specialized marine container leasing and related activities, especially refrigerated container transport. Sea Containers also will continue to have interests in ferries and ports, particularly high speed car and passenger transportation; and property development, mostly in the United Kingdom. Sea Containers said it earned $100.3 million, or $7.15 a share, in 1989, up 17.7 percent from $85.2 million, or 5.87 a share, in 1988. Revenue rose about 14 percent to $1 billion from $875.3 million a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Agrees to Sell Majority Interest in Cleveland TV Station
DOC.TEXT: The National Broadcasting Co. said Friday it had agreed to sell a majority interest in its Cleveland television station WKYC-TV to Multimedia Inc., which would be making its first major purchase since undertaking a $1.1 billion recapitalization in 1985. Terms of the sale and the size of the stake being sold were not disclosed. Multimedia, which owns four television stations and has interests in newspapers, radio, television programming and cable TV, would assume complete responsibility for managing and operating the station. WKYC-TV serves the nation's 11th largest TV market and would be Multimedia's biggest TV property. The deal could free NBC to buy another TV station in a larger market, trimming its holdings to six stations reaching 20 percent to 21 percent of the country. Its seven stations including Cleveland reached about 22 percent of the country. Federal regulations prohibit a company from owning stations with a combined reach of more than 25 percent of the country. NBC would retain a minority interest in the Cleveland station, but would have no day-to-day role. The station went on the air in 1948. The deal is subject to completion of a definitive agreement and approval by the Federal Communications Commission and the boards of Multimedia and NBC's parent, General Electric Co. NBC said Multimedia approached it with the proposal several months ago. Robert C. Wright, president and chief executive at NBC, said the proposal offered ``a terrific opportunity to expand our relationship with an accomplished group of broadcasters.'' Three of the four Multimedia stations are NBC affiliates _ WLWT in Cincinnati, WBIR in Knoxville and KSDK in St. Louis. The fourth, WMAZ in Macon, Ga., is affiliated with CBS. ``This was the smallest owned and operated station that NBC has,'' Walter Bartlett, chairman and chief executive of the Greenville, S.C.-based company, said in a telephone interview. ``We knew they were in pursuing a larger market station.'' Joe Rutledge, an NBC spokesman, said NBC has no immediate plans to buy another station. But he said the network always has been interested in ``attractive stations at reasonable prices.'' He said the Cleveland station has been profitable, but he declined to reveal its cash flow. Industry analysts said a well-run station can command a sale price of 12 times its cash flow. Multimedia borrowed $1.13 billion in 1985 as part of a recapitalization but has since reduced its debt to about $700 million, Bartlett said. He said the company is about $100 million ahead of where it expected to be in repaying the $650 million bank debt incurred in the recapitalization. In addition, Bartlett said the company has raised about $30 million to $40 million after taxes from sales of a small newspaper, several radio stations and an independent television station in Nashville, Tenn., over the past few years. As a result, he said, the company was able to jump at the opportunity to buy a majority interest in what would be its biggest TV market to date. Bartlett declined to comment on the company's future plans for expansion. In addition to its TV stations, Multimedia publishes 14 daily newspapers and 50 non-daily newspapers, owns seven radio statuons, operates 100 cable TV franchises in four states and produces and syndicates TV shows including ``The Phil Donahue Show'' and ``Sally Jessy Raphael.'' NBC owns TV stations in New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Washington, D.C., Miami and Denver. It also operates the NBC Television Network with more than 200 affiliates nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Sends Wholesale Inflation on Roller-Coaster Ride
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs to ADD time element
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Topsy-turvy weather is sending wholesale inflation on a roller-coaster ride so far this year, with prices unchanged in February after a steep increase a month earlier. A sharp drop in energy prices offset increases for other items and held the Labor Department's Producer Price Index steady overall last month, the government said Friday. It was the best report in six months and welcome relief after the huge 1.8 percent rise in January. That increase, the largest in 15 years, was driven by a record gain in energy costs and a large jump in food prices. Food costs rose substantially again in February, particularly vegetables. Taken together, the two months represent an annual wholesale inflation rate of 11.4 percent. But, many analysts believe prices are falling this month and predict the manufacturing slowdown will keep the rate for all of 1990 below the 4.8 percent price gain last year. ``Inflation has been capped but it hasn't been broken,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. Unusual weather _ a deep freeze around Christmas followed by unseasonal warmth _ also contributed to sharp swings in other economic indicators. The Federal Reserve Board said industrial production, after slumping 1 percent in January, bounced back 0.6 percent in February. Output at utilities fell and rose with the temperature. A cutback at auto plants followed by a production rebound also contributed to the overall swing. The operating rate at factories, mines and utilities, increased 0.3 percentage point to 82.3 percent of capacity in February. Housing starts fell 7 percent in February, returning to a more normal seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.48 million units after a record leap of 24.7 percent a month earlier, the Commerce Department said. Both months were warmer than usual, but rain held back builders in February. Analysts trying to sort through the figures found little to help them divine the direction of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy. The central bank sought to avoid a recession by cutting interest rates over the last half of 1989. It has left short-term rates unchanged since late December and now appears more interested in keeping rates high enough to dampen growth and, consequently, inflationary pressures. ``Federal Reserve policy will be on hold until the direction of the economy becomes clearer,'' said economist Samuel D. Kahan of Fuji Securities Inc. Kahan said prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, the so-called core rate of inflation, advanced at about the same rate as previous months. They rose a moderate 0.4 percent in February after a slight 0.1 percent rise in January. Energy prices plunged 5 percent in February after soaring 13.6 percent. Fuel oil plummeted 30.2 percent after shooting up 25.3 percent, the biggest increase and decrease since the department began tracking that price in 1973. Gasoline prices fell 2.3 percent, recovering only partly from a 16.7 percent rise in January. Natural gas edged up 0.1 percent after jumping 3.2 percent. ``The fuel oil people are cutting prices like crazy to get rid of what they've got. But the gasoline people are anticipating the driving season and aren't unhappy to see inventories rising,'' said economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University. Food prices rose 0.9 percent, compared with a 2.1 percent jump in January, the biggest in six years. Vegetable prices last month shot up 23.3 percent, on top of the 58 percent rise in January. The wholesale price of eggs plunged 24 percent and dairy costs fell 2.7 percent. Both items had been increasing for most of the previous year. However, chicken prices shot up 8.5 percent and fruit rose 8 percent. ``The revitalized Florida crops are coming back in and we should see those vegetable prices tumbling in March and April,'' Ratajczak said. Clothing prices rose 1.1 percent for children, 0.7 percent for women and 0.6 percent for men. The strong dollar, which reduced the price of imports, should keep clothing prices for continuing higher. In other categories, prices held steady for passenger cars, jumped 2.9 percent for tobacco products and plunged 5 percent for home electronic equipment. The various changes put the index for finished goods at 117.4 in February. This meant that a hypothetical selection of goods sold for $100 in 1982, cost $117.40 last month, up from $111.70 a year earlier. Price pressures in earlier stages of the production process also eased in February. Intermediate goods fell 0.7 percent, following a 1.2 percent rise in January, while crude goods increased a moderate 0.4 percent after a 2.4 percent jump a month earlier. An example of the three stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude.

DOC.HEAD: Sober Binge: Brewer Plans Another Responsible Drinking Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Anheuser-Busch Inc. spends millions of dollars trying to convince people not to drink the brewer's best-selling beers, and says it doesn't mind getting only goodwill in return. ``We are a big part of society's desire to reduce abuse,'' said Steve Burrows, vice president for consumer awareness and education at the world's largest brewery, which commands 42 percent of the domestic beer market. ``It's an area we feel we have a responsibility to be in.'' The brewer is introducing another national advertising campaign about responsible drinking Tuesday. This one's called ``Family Talk About Drinking'' and it joins 11 other campaigns the company is running. Busch has pioneered an industry effort to promote sobriety and distance itself from the beer-guzzling image. Moreover, it's just good business to remind consumers not to over-indulge, said Burrows, who has worked solely on alcohol awareness programs for nearly a year. He has a staff of seven and estimates Anheuser-Busch already has spent $1 million on the new ``Family Talk'' program. Last year Anheuser-Busch spent as much on the Know When to Say When program, which encompasses all its alcohol-awareness endeavors, as it did on the Michelob Dry rollout, Burrows said. Although anti-drinking activists have accused some brewers of using the sobriety message as a public relations ploy, industry analysts see no ulterior motives in the push by Busch and other brewers to combat alcohol abuse. George Thompson, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York, said it's a logical path to travel for Busch, which has introduced low-alcohol beer (L.A.) and no-alcohol brew (O'Doul's) in the last few years. Thompson said Busch will never make money on those brands and likely won't profit from its alcohol awareness programs either. ``But it's not something they'll let up on,'' Thompson said. ``They're not trying to impress people, they're trying to solve the problem.'' Bob Weinberg, head of of R.S. Weinberg & Associates, St. Louis research firm that tracks the brewery business, said a good test was whether people recalled the brand name sponsoring responsible drinking ads. He passed. ``I'm not sure I can distinguish between the brewers,'' said Weinberg, who is also a professor at Washington University. ``The message, I remember.'' The company doesn't expect to strengthen its already dominant position in the beer industry with ``Family Talk.'' It may even lose sales. ``That's business that we will gladly lose,'' Burrows said. Busch is targeting its ``Family Talk'' campaign at a specific audience, going for the fathers in Sports Illustrated, the mothers in Good Housekeeping, and both in Newsweek and Parent. Its message is mostly common sense. The ads invite readers to telephone a toll-free number to obtain guidelines that tell parents how to be a role model, provide the facts about drinking and driving, enforce rules and encourage positive friendships. A six-person staff of expert advisers which helped develop the guides also advises starting discussions on the subject early, at about age 9. The guides include sample dialogue to encourage bringing up the subject informally. It may sound simple, but Roger Vogler, a clinical psychologist from Pomona Collge in Claremont, Calif., and a member of the advisory board, says it's not. ``My experience is that people are surprisingly uninformed about things that may seem pretty obvious,'' Vogler said. ``A lot of parents in my experience believe that they are there to enforce the rules rather than facilitate their kids meeting their own needs. ``We don't have a good format for teaching people how to parent in our society and I think parents need some help.'' Even before the ad campaign's debut, Burrows spread the toll-free number by word of mouth through the brewery's wholesalers. He said there already have been hundreds of calls on the number (1-800-359-TALK) set up for people to order free copies of the guide packet. Response has been so brisk, Burrows said, that Anheuser-Busch also is planning to translate the package into Spanish. Unlike its other programs, which feature celebrities and sports figures warning of the evils of alcohol abuse, ``Family Talk'' is more subtle. The first ad features a small photo of an old-fashioned bicycle below the message, ``Talk To Your Kid About Drinking Before He Gets His First Set Of Wheels.'' It's a different, more low-key approach by a company that spends most of its advertising dollar on network sports programming. As for the ever-burgeoning responsible drinking division at Busch, Burrows says it's not time to say when yet. ``As we fine-tune this effort, if we see an opportunity, we'll certainly seize it,'' Burrows said. ``We'll continue to address the issue and we're always looking for new ideas.''

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Drop On Brazilian Reforms; Grains Rise
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed moderately lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade in reaction to a Brazilian economic reform plan while grain futures finished mostly higher. Newly inaugurated Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello on Friday announced a broad package of economic measures designed to halt Brazil's runaway inflation rate, including the introduction of a new currency with free-floating exchange rates. Traders speculated that a free-floating currency would encourage export sales of soybeans from Brazil, the world's second-largest producer after the United States. But analysts said it was impossible to predict the ultimate effect of the broad economic reforms on the soybean market. ``The world wants and needs the Brazilian crop but the question is, given all the economic reforms, how is that crop going to move to the world,'' said Mickey Luth, oilseeds analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``No one knows.'' Grain futures were led higher by the March wheat contract, which rose sharply on indications of tight availability of near-term supplies. At the close, wheat was 1\ cents lower to 5{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.90 a bushel; corn futures were } cent to 1{ cents higher with March at $2.48 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2 cents higher with March at $1.46 a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 4{ cents lower with March at $5.81{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Qintex Shows Big Quarterly Loss, Describes Interest by Potential Buyers
DOC.TEXT: A quarterly loss of $3.8 million on sales of $8.2 million was reported Friday by Qintex Entertainment Inc., a producer and distributor of TV programs that is stalled in bankruptcy proceedings and looking for a buyer or investor. Qintex Entertainment, best known for co-producing the miniseries ``Lonesome Dove,'' is a U.S. affiliate of Qintex Australia Ltd. Qintex Australia's $1.5 billion agreement to buy MGM-UA Communications Co. collapsed for lack of financing last year. Qintex Entertainment officials said they were forced into a Chapter 11 filing last October when Qintex Australia failed to provide them a promised $5.9 million owed to MCA Inc. in connection with the distribution of ``The New Leave It to Beaver Show.'' The amount of its programming has since fallen off. Qintex Entertainment said more than 30 potential buyers or investors had expressed interest through its investment banker, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. The company has publicly identified only one of those, SCS Communications Inc., a media and entertainment company owned by Stephen Swid. The earnings reported Friday, the equivalent of a loss of 18 cents per share, were for Qintex Entertainment's second quarter, which ended Jan. 31. During the same period last year, Qintex Entertainment earned $1.8 million, or 8 cents per share, on revenue of $32.5 million. For the first six months of its fiscal year 1990, Qintex Entertainment lost $9.8 million, or 46 cents per share, on revenue of $14.5 million. During the same period in 1989, the company turned a profit of $3.4 million, or 16 cents per share, on sales of $59.4 million.

DOC.HEAD: Fixed-Rate Mortgages Average 10.34 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.34 percent, up from 10.29 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.55 percent this week, up from 8.5 percent the week before.
Stock prices capped off their third straight week of gains with a strong advance today. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 37.61 at 2,733.33.

DOC.HEAD: Beauty Salons to Get Another Magazine
DOC.TEXT: A new magazine, American Style, is making an appointment for September at 140,000 beauty salons across the country in the latest media venture aimed at giving advertisers access to a large audience of women. American Style will be an oversized, bimonthly magazine from Whittle Communications, a Knoxville, Tenn.-based media concern that had conducted a two-year test of a similar magazine, Southern Style, in Southern beauty parlors. Peter Finn, the Whittle division president reponsible for American Style, said the magazine will be in beauty parlors which handle 90 percent of the nation's beauty salon customers. He said the magazine, which will feature affordable fashions, beauty tips and profiles of women who other women admire, should reach an unduplicated audience of 29 million adult women readers every quarter. ``The location enables us to reach women when they can really focus on the magazine and obviously, on the advertising,'' Finn said. The announcement of the new magazine comes as another media company, Communications Venture Group of Rye, N.Y., begins to distribute Confetti, a series of six separate bimonthly magazines designed for women in beauty shops. Each Confetti magazine will focus on a different topic _ people, writing, style, home, connections and leisure _ and will be distributed in about 4,000 salons in department stores and malls. About 8 million women are expected to read the magazines at least once every two months. Unlike American Style, the publishers of Confetti require that they be allowed to handle all of the magazines that will be available in a given beauty salon and to limit that to no more than four other magazine titles. Controlled-circulation magazines such as American Style will be prohibited from beauty salons signing up to receive Confetti, according to Dave Smith, a managing director at Communications Venture Group. ``There is a lot of magazine clutter out there,'' he said. Smith said his company is focusing on beauty shops located in stores or near stores because it puts the magazine in the hands of women who would be in position to act immediately on any advertising-generated impulses to shop. ``A women in a beauty shop on the fifth floor of a department store will be bumping into the counters of our advertisers as she leaves,'' he said. Murdoch Magazines, a unit of News Corp. Ltd. headed by Rupert Murdoch, announced last month that it planned to create commercially-sponsored video programs designed for beauty shop clients. Murdoch's Salon Network would consist of tapes of 30 minute to 40 minute programs including 10 minutes of ads that would be delivered for replay in at least 3,000 beauty parlors starting June or July. The creators say 2 million to 2.5 million women are expected to see the programs while at the beauty shop. The shows would contain video versions of stories that have appeared in Murdoch magazines such as Mirabella, New Woman, New York and Premiere. Advertising rates are just under $1 million for a page in each of six bimonthly issues of American Style; $300,000 for one page in each of six bimonthly issues of Confetti; and $20,000 for a 30-second commercial on a Salon Network program. Joseph Ostrow, worldwide media director at the advertising firm Foote Cone Belding Communications in New York, said the new magazine and video vehicles have potential because they address a very specific target audience in a setting where the right message could motivate people to buy a product. ``The question is whether the women will indeed read them or view them. It is one thing to get them into distribution and quite another to get them read,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 37 Percent Rise in Quarterly Income
DOC.TEXT: Dayton Hudson Corp., a major retailing company, said Thursday its fourth-quarter profit grew 37 percent from a year earlier while its 1989 income climbed 43 percent to a record level. The company said it earned $250 million, or $3.50 a share, for the three months ended Feb. 3, up from $182 million, or $2.31 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 9.4 percent for the 14-week fourth quarter to $4.49 billion from $4.1 billion in 1988's 13-week fourth quarter. For the year, the owner of Target discount stores, Mervyn's stores and Dayton Hudson Department Store Co. said it earned $410 million, or $5.37 a share, up from $287 million, or $3.45 a share, in fiscal 1988. ``We are very pleased with this earnings report, especially because it follows 1988's record results,'' said Kenneth A. Macke, Dayton Hudson chairman. Revenue for the 53 weeks of fiscal 1989 were $13.64 billion, up 11.8 percent from $12.2 billion in the 52 weeks of fiscal 1988. Target posted its 15th consecutive year of record operating profit, with a 32 percent increase over 1988, Dayton Hudson reported. Mervyn's operating profit increased 40 percent, while Dayton Hudson Department Store Co.'s operating profit increased 12 percent. ``All three of our companies are strong and have great momentum to capture additional market share,'' Macke said. At the end of fiscal 1989, Dayton Hudson Corporation operated 657 stores in 33 states.

DOC.HEAD: Saab Recalls All '86-'90 9000 Model Cars With Automatic Transmissions
DOC.TEXT: Saab-Scania of America Inc. on Friday recalled all 25,000 1986 through 1990 model Saab 9000 cars with automatic transmissions sold in the United States to correct a potential overheating problem in a lamp switch. Saab also said that among those cars were about 14,000 1988 through mid-1989 models recalled to install a bracket to prevent chafing between a throttle cable and one of three brake fluid lines. Saab sent letters to owners of those cars on March 5. On Friday, Saab mailed notifications to owners in the larger recall, saying an electric circuit would be modified to eliminate the possibility of overheating. The company, the U.S. importing and marketing arm of Saab-Scania AB of Sweden, said in a news release received Friday in Detroit it knew of no accidents or injuries associated with either problem. Repairs would be performed for free.

DOC.HEAD: West Point-Pepperell Sells Some Divisions to Bidermann Group
DOC.TEXT: Bidermann Industries Corp. said Friday it has agreed to buy three divisions of Cluett, Peabody and Co. at a price an analyst said was well below what cash-strapped industrialist William Farley had hoped to get. The purchase price was about $350 million in cash and a $60 million note due March 2000, according to a joint statement by Farley's West Point-Pepperell Inc. and Bidermann. The note provides for no principal payments until maturity. Interest will accrue and be added to principal until January 1998, after which interest will be payable in cash, the statement said. ``Farley started to sell those at $600 million,'' analyst Edward F. Johnson of Johnson Redbook Service in New York said of the sale. ``The price is down and not all of it is in cash.'' ``They are still in a tight position financially,'' Johnson said. The sale follows renegotiation with bankers Wells Fargo & Co. and Bankers Trust Co. of a $1.2 billion loan, which buys Farley more time to complete his takeover of Georgia-based Pepperell. Cluett, Peabody is a leading manufacturer of menswear. The transaction involves divisions that make and sell Arrow shirts, Schoeneman suits and Gold Toe socks. Farley, the Chicago-based industrialist who acquired Pepperell in a hostile takeover last year for $1.56 billion, is selling the Cluett, Peabody divisions to get through a cash squeeze. The agreement with Bankers Trust and Wells Fargo, announced earlier this week, extends through 1994 a loan that was set to mature on March 31. The loan package consists of a term loan of $550 million and a revolving credit line of up to $650 million. Lenders previously had agreed to extend the loan only if Farley could sell some of Pepperell's assets. There was concern that Farley would default on the $1.04 billion bridge loan he got to buy West Point. The sale completes negotiations that were begun last fall, when Bidermann and West Point announced that an agreement had been reached to acquire Cluett, Peabody. Bidermann Industries is the principal American subsidiary of Bidermann Industries Corp., based in France. The Bidermann group of companies manufactures and markets a wide range of men's and women's designer apparel internationally, including labels by Daniel Cremieux, Daniel Hechter, Kenzo, Ralph Lauren, Bill Robinson and Yves Saint Laurent.

DOC.HEAD: High-Speed Network Links Scientists Across Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and European scientists will be able to compare notes across the Atlantic with a new, high-speed data link unveiled Thursday by the National Science Foundation. The foundation said it was extending the nation's largest computer network used in science and education, NSFNET, to Europe, thanks to support from International Business Machines Corp. and MCI Communications Corp. Stephen S. Wolff, a division director of the foundation, said the new trans-Atlantic link will speed the exchange of information in areas such as global weather changes, mapping the human gene, analyzing reactions in particle physics and predicting weather. European and U.S. researchers will be able to exchange information at the network speed of 1.5 million bits per second, or almost 200,000 characters per second. That is the equivalent of about 50 single spaced pages of text a second. But even that blinding speed _ news agencies tranbsmit text at 150 characters per second, and facsimile machines can reach 1,200 characters per second _ is not enough for today's computer networks to handle sophisticated graphics from several locations at once. Later this year, NSFNET should go to 45 million bits per second, about 5.6 million characters per second, in the United States, according to the announcement of the new network at the National Net '90 networking conference. The trans-Atlantic fiber optic cable will remain limited to 1.5 million bits per second. Network officials demonstrated prototype equipment that transmitted information between Washington and Ann Arbor, Mich. at 45 million bits per second. ``It is clear that this kind of collaboration has the potential to speed up the research process and lead us to new scientific breakthroughs that today we cannot even imagine,'' said Wolff. The connection between NSFNET and the European Academic Supercomputer Initiative Network will be made at the Cornell National Supercomputer Facility at Ithaca, N.Y., and at CERN, the European Laboratory for Particle Physics, near Geneva, Switzerland. NSFNET is a partnership of the foundation, IBM, MCI, the state of Michigan and the Merit Computer Network, a consortium of eight Michigan universities. NSFNET links more than 1,000 U.S. universities, business and government research networks and provides access to supercomputers financied by the foundation.
