Figures for the two months, taken together, represent an annualized wholesale inflation rate of 11.4 percent. However, economists do not expect anything approaching that for the entire year. Most anticipate prices will rise between 4 percent and 4.5 percent in 1990, slightly lower than the 1989 rate of 4.8 percent. In two other economic reports released today, the government said housing starts returned to a more normal, slower pace in February and industrial production bounced back from a January decline. The Commerce Department said new homes and apartments were built at a seasonably adjusted annual rate of 1.48 million units in February, down 7 percent, after leaping a revised 24.7 percent in January. The Federal Reserve said industrial production rose 0.6 percent in February following a 1.0 percent drop in January's output. In a separate report, the Fed said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose 0.3 percentage point to 82.3 percent in February. Energy prices in February plunged 5 percent after soaring 13.6 percent in January. The effect of the weather showed up most strongly in fuel oil prices, which rocketed 25.3 percent in January and plummeted 30.2 percent in February. They were the biggest increase and decrease since the department began tracking that price in 1973. Gasoline prices fell 2.3 percent last month after rising 16.7 percent in January. Natural gas prices edged up 0.1 percent after jumping 3.2 percent in the previous month. Food prices in February rose 0.9 percent, compared with January when they rose 2.1 percent, the biggest jump in six years. Vegetable prices last month shot up 23.3 percent, on top of the 58 percent rise in January. The holiday freeze killed vegetable crops from Texas to Florida. However, analysts expect vegetable costs to subside this spring as new crops are harvested. In other good news for grocery buyers, the wholesale price of eggs plunged 24 percent while dairy costs fell 2.7 percent. Both of those categories had been increasing for most of the previous year. However, chicken prices shot up 8.5 percent and fruit rose 8 percent. Prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors rose a moderate 0.4 percent in February after a slight 0.1 percent rise in January. Economists often use this so-called core rate as a better indication of underlying inflationary pressures in the economy. In other categories, prices rose 1.1 percent for men's and boy's clothing, held steady for passenger cars, jumped 2.9 percent for tobacco products and plunged 5 percent for home electronic equipment. The various changes put the index for finished goods at 117.4 in February. This meant that a hypothetical selection of goods which cost $100 in 1982, cost $117.40 last month, up from $111.70 a year earlier. Price pressures in earlier stages of the production process also eased in February. Intermediate goods fell 0.7 percent, following a 1.2 percent rise in January, while crude goods increased a moderate 0.4 percent following a 2.4 percent jump a month earlier. An example of the three stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower, Gold Higher
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined Friday against most major foreign currencies with buyers focusing on the Swiss franc and West German mark. Gold prices gained in domestic and overseas dealings. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid for a troy ounce of gold at $400 as of 4 p.m. EST, up $1.80 from Thursday's late bid. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for March delivery settled at $399.60 a troy ounce, $1.50 higher than Thursday. Currency dealers said a bearish attitude toward the dollar prevailed in foreign exchange markets. Interest in trading dollars slackened in the New York afternoon, which is typical before a weekend. Traders usually are reluctant to establish significant new positions on Fridays for fear developments over the weekend could have an impact on currency values. This was especially true this Friday because of Sunday's parliamentary elections in East Germany. There has been speculation that the West German mark will strengthen next week if the East German elections signal a quickening of German unity. As trading ended in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.6980 West German marks, down from 1.6990 marks late Thursday. Meanwhile, a batch of statistics about the economy's performance in February furnished fresh evidence of weakness. Judging by the reports, analysts said they don't foresee any imminent change in Federal Reserve credit policy, which could influence the dollar's value against its foreign counterparts. Marc Chandler, a currency market analyst at MMS International in Chicago, said stronger demand for Swiss francs also caused dollar selling. Chandler said the Japanese yen remained the weakest of the major currencies because interest rates in that country have stayed put rather than gone up as many currency traders expected. One dollar bought 152.65 Japanese yen late in New York compared to 152.285 yen on Thursday. Earlier in Tokyo the dollar closed at 152.50 Japanese yen, up from 152.47. In London late Friday the dollar closed higher at 152.30 yen. Also in London, one British pound cost $1.6235 late Friday, more expensive for buyers than Thursday's late $1.6177. Later, in New York, a pound fetched $1.6190, down from $1.6215 on Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Thursday, included: 1.5095 Swiss francs, down from 1.5180; 5.736 French francs, down from 5.7415; 1,253.00 Italian lire, down from 1,255.00; and 1.18285 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18085. Selected late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared with Thursday's late levels, were: 1.6945 West German marks, down from 1.7025; 1.5080 Swiss francs, down from 1.5222; 5.7245 French francs, down from 5.7545; 1.9077 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9265; 1,251.00 Italian lire, down from 1,257.25; and 1.1802 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1778. Gold and silver prices rose as the dollar declined. A troy ounce of gold bullion was bid at $400.50 late in London, the major European precious metals market, up from $398.50. The closing bid in Zurich was $401 an ounce, up from $398.40. Earlier in Hong Kong gold closed at $399.75 bid, up from $397.52 Thursday. In New York, silver bullion for March delivery closed at $5.093 a troy ounce, up from $5.079 on Thursday. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid of $5.13 a troy ounce, up from $5.120.

DOC.HEAD: Norton Targeted by British Company in Takeover Bid
DOC.TEXT: British industrial conglomerate BTR PLC offered $1.64 billion Friday to acquire Norton Co., the Worchester-based abrasives manufacturer, in an unsolicited tender offer that sent Norton shares skyrocketing. London-based BTR, which has international operations ranging from building materials to sporting goods, offered $75 a share for Norton through a U.S. subsidiary, ER Holdings Inc. BTR also threatened a proxy fight to win control of Norton's board if the company tried to block its tender offer. Norton stock soared on news of the bid, rising $16.62{ to $74.87{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Norton spokesman Francis J. Doherty Jr. said Norton's board of directors was reviewing the offer and would inform shareholders of its position on the bid by March 29. Norton, the world's largest manufacturer of abrasives, also produces ceramics, plastics and chemical process products. The company earned $85.8 million on sales of $1.53 billion in 1989. It employs 16,600 people and operates 120 plants in the United States and 27 in other countries. Operations of BTR, formerly known as British Tire and Rubber, include electronics, sports products and transportation under such companies as Stewart Warner in the United States, Borg Warner in Australia, Dunlop Slazenger and Rockwell Valve. The company had an after-tax profit of $1.3 billion on sales of $11.3 billion last year. BTR's finance director, Chris Bull, said the company would finance the bid with corporate reserves and bank borrowing. He said he did not know how much debt would be incurred, but added that BTR could cope with any repayments. BTR chairman John C. Cahill wrote in a letter to Norton chief executive John H. Nelson that he hoped the transaction would be ``enthusiastically supported'' by Norton's nearly 6,000 stockholders. But he said BTR would consider proposing an alternative slate of nominees for directors at Norton's annual meeting April 26 ``to ensure that Norton's board does not, either through action or inaction, deny Norton stockholders the opportunity to accept our all-cash offer.'' Cahill's letter also included a pledge not to close any of Norton's manufacturing facilities and to keep Norton's corporate headquarters in Worcester. British analysts generally said BTR would benefit from owning Norton despite recent problems at the U.S. company. ``I think it's a very good deal,'' said analyst Jack Jones of the London investment firm UBS-Phillips and Drew. David Ireland, an analyst with Hoare Govett Ltd. in London, said Norton has ``excellent products and good market position.'' But Scott Fulton, an analyst with Charterhouse Tilney in London, took a negative view. ``Everybody's been waiting for BTR to make an acquisition and I don't think people should get excited about this acquisition,'' he said. Norton's main lines of business are in decline globally and the company suffers from high manufacturing costs, Fulton said. Cahill said BTR would continue its acquisitive trend in 1990. ``We have a number of companies we're looking at,'' Cahill said, adding that he was targeting the United States as a prime buying market. ``The United States is in vogue,'' he said. A number of BTR's businesses were acquired, including Chicago-based Stewart Warner, a maker of electronic and fabricated metal products and hardware that BTR bought acquired in late 1987. BTR mounted a $1.8 billion hostile takeover attempt for Britain's Pilkington Brothers PLC, the giant glassmaker, in late 1986 but later dropped the bid amid a domestic political uproar over the move.

DOC.HEAD: Reilly Resigns, Shaffer Appointed President of Macmillan
DOC.TEXT: Maxwell Communication Corp. PLC said Friday that William F. Reilly has resigned as president and chief operating officer of its Macmillan Inc. subsidiary and will be replaced by David Shaffer, who headed the group's electonic publishing operations worldwide. Reilly resigned to devote full time to management of K-III Holdings, a partnership created more than a year ago by several top Macmillan executives with financial support from the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. Before taking responsibility for Maxwell's electronic publishing operations, Shaffer was president of Official Airline Guides, which Maxwell acquired from Dun & Bradstreet Corp. for $750 million in 1988. Shaffer has been on the board of London-based Maxwell Communications since last November. Macmillan, based in New York, is one of the world's largest publishing and information services concerns. K-III Holdings was formed in February 1989 to acquire and manage properties in the publishing, information and related fields. It already has purchased two properties once owned by Macmillan, Macmillan Books Clubs Inc. and Intertec Publishing Corp., which publishes trade magazines and technical books. On Thursday, Maxwell said it had rejected an offer of undisclosed size from K-III Holdings for Maxwell's 56 percent stake in Berlitz International Inc., the language services company. While president of Macmillan, Reilly also was president and chief executive of K-III Holdings. ``I fully understand Bill's desire to be an entrepreneur, but we're sorry to see him go,'' Maxwell Communication Chairman Robert Maxwell said in a statement. Reilly, 51, has been president of Macmillan since May 1981 and remained in that position after Maxwell Communication acquired Macmillan for $2.6 billion in November 1988. He said in a telephone interview that his goal is to build K-III Holdings' annual revenue to $500 million within three years from the present $200 million. Reilly said he is interested in acquiring publishing and information companies, direct marketing or mail order operations, directories and other specialized information operations. ``We are going to stay away from these big trade publishing companies,'' he said. Charles McCurdy, an executive vice president of K-III and former chief financial officer of Macmillan, said K-III hopes to ``build a large diversified company without resorting to the over-leveraged financing that has been the downfall of many companies in recent years.''

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Finds Valdez Oil Hard To Wash Off Corporate Image
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A year after the Alaska oil spill, some experts still point to Exxon Corp.'s reaction as a virtual primer on how not to handle a disaster. ``To be nice, I'd say they did not distinguish themselves,'' said Gerald Meyers, former chairman and chief executive officer of American Motors and author of a book on corporate crisis control, ``When It Hits The Fan.'' ``To be more blunt, they screwed up,'' he said. ``For whatever reason, the company appeared to be indifferent or uncaring or unconcerned while hundreds of sea otters and all kinds of wildlife were washing up on shore.'' Marilou Hedlund, managing director of the Hill & Knowlton public relations firm in Chicago, said several new clients came to her saying, in essence, ``We don't want to have what happened to Exxon happen to us.'' Reporters had trouble getting comment from Exxon about the March 24 spill, and company Chairman Lawrence G. Rawls stayed away from the area and didn't appear before reporters until April 18. Within hours of the spill, a local group volunteered to mobilize fishing boats to help move in equipment to keep the oil from spreading. But, in another example of what critics label Exxon's clumsiness, the company never returned their call, the group's members said. By the time Exxon responded with its own equipment, a storm had moved through the area and spread the oil over a wider region. The Associated Press called Exxon asking to discuss its handling of spills, but officials at the corporation's New York headquarters, its subsidiary's headquarters in Houston and its Bayway refinery in Linden, N.J., all declined comment. Ms. Hedlund and other crisis managers, a burgeoning sub-field of public relations, live by a simple maxim: There's no substitute for practice. ``We do crisis training with our clients, actually create an incredible crisis and simulated news and radio reports and see how they handle them,'' she said. Ms. Hedlund said she also refers clients to several ``textbook examples'' of good crisis management, including United Airlines' handling of the crash of Flight 232 in Iowa last summer and Johnson & Johnson's of the nightmarish Tylenol poisonings of the early 1980s. ``The key to the success of both cases was the company's immediate release of everything they knew and their handling of victims' families,'' she said. Meyers said British Petroleum's recent oil spill off Huntington Beach, Calif., provides another good example. ``They learned from Exxon, no doubt,'' he said. ``BP's chairman, Jim Ross, flew there almost immediately and showed a take-charge attitude. That was a very bad scene _ an oil spill right in the cradle of the environmental movement. But they weathered the storm.'' Exxon recently halted oil loading and unloading operations at its only East Coast refinery after three spills in two months in New York City-area waters, even though only one of the spills was directly tied to Exxon property. The shutdown illustrates Exxon's tension over its public image in the year since its tanker split open in Alaska's Prince William Sound, said Simon Trimble, international oils analyst for the investment firm Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York. These days, Trimble said, ``it doesn't take 10 million barrels of oil spilled into American waters for there to be a negative impact on Exxon.''

DOC.HEAD: One Year Later, Nation's Worst Oil Spill Is Hidden But Not Gone
An AP Extra
LaserPhotos
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: From a helicopter, the wave-washed beach looks as if the worst oil spill in U.S. history had never touched it. Silvery sticks of driftwood poke through a deep blanket of snow, and smooth gray pebbles roll in the surf under the gaze of a bald eagle perched in a shoreside spruce. But the view doesn't impress Joe Bridgman of the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation. Dashing out as the chopper lands, he digs into the cobble beach and quickly finds what he knew he would. ``Oil,'' he says. ``Smell it?'' The pungent odor of petroleum wafts through the air as the hole turns black with crude oil, an oozing remnant of the 10.8 million gallons spilled into Prince William Sound last March 24 by the tanker Exxon Valdez. Bridgman scoops up a shovelful of gravel, lugs it to the water's edge and dumps it in. A rainbow sheen of oil spreads across the water. ``Hundreds of gallons of oil are locked up under this beach,'' he says. ``And this isn't isolated. There are hundreds of beaches all over the sound that are still oiled, and the oil is slowly bleeding out. ``The beaches can look beautiful at the surface, but you can dig down, in this case just a few inches below the surface, and find lots of oil. Now, is that a threat or isn't it?'' A year after the wreck of the Exxon Valdez, the question clings like the oil under this Perry Island beach. Certainly, the worst is over; thousands of dead birds no longer wash up on shorelines as they did last summer. But assessing the continuing damage wrought by the nation's most extensive _ and expensive _ oil spill has just begun. As a growing slick of lawyers haggles over who is to blame, Exxon Corp. and government agencies debate how to clean up what's left and scientists track wildlife populations' first steps on the long road to recovery. Any hope of a quick solution faded last summer as oil from the Exxon Valdez spread across 1,100 miles of Alaska's wild southern coast. A cleanup army of 12,000 workers polished rocks by hand, blasted beaches with hot water and sprayed fertilizer to promote the growth of oil-eating microbes. But when Exxon suspended its $2 billion cleanup in mid-September, it had recovered only 5 percent to 9 percent of the oil spilled, state officials estimate. About 20 percent to 40 percent is believed to have evaporated. That leaves 50 percent to 75 percent of the oil in the water, on the ocean bottom or on beaches. Some was soaked up by unwilling sponges: the seabirds, eagles and sea otters whose carcasses now lie frozen in five vans in an Anchorage storage yard, awaiting their day as physical evidence in court. Workers found more than 1,000 dead otters, a sizable chunk of the spill area's total population of 15,000 to 22,000. Many of Prince William Sound's 3,000 bald eagles also suffered; at least 151 died, most poisoned by scavenging the oily remains of some of the 34,400 dead seabirds recovered. Those numbers alone make the Valdez spill the most lethal ever, but scientists say the actual death count is much higher, estimating that up to 90 percent of the seabirds caught in oil sank from sight or drifted out to sea. Exxon notes the spill did not wipe out any species and says surviving animals and birds will rebuild populations. But that may take up to 70 years for some hard-hit seabird colonies, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service researchers say. ``We never claimed that the spill put any animal on the endangered species list, but that's missing the point,'' said Fish and Wildlife spokesman Bruce Batten. ``It's still the greatest human-caused wildlife disaster that this agency knows about.'' Oily carcasses were an obvious measure of the spill's impact, but victims also included less visible members of the ecosystem, such as young salmon and tiny intertidal creatures. Assessment studies for these populations are not finished, and even preliminary findings are hard to come by _ researchers have been told by lawyers to save their findings for court, where it seems nearly everyone involved in the spill is headed. Capt. Joseph Hazelwood, skipper of the Exxon Valdez, is on trial this month in Anchorage on charges including criminal mischief and drunken driving of his vessel, and a federal grand jury recently issued criminal indictments against Exxon, starting a case that could take years to finish. Exxon already faces more than 150 civil lawsuits. Fishermen sued because of lost seasons. Tour-boat operators sued because fewer people wanted to cruise an oiled sound. The state sued, claiming the company was negligent in responding to the spill, only to be countersued by Exxon, which claimed state officials hindered the use of chemical dispersants that could have broken up large quantities of oil early on. Information about the spill is filtered through this litigious atmosphere, making much of it suspect. Exxon distributes before-and-after pictures of cleaned beaches; Bridgman and other state officials, accusing Exxon of ``myth-making,'' eagerly make room for journalists on flights to oiled beaches. State officials cite an October survey that showed 117 miles of shoreline remained moderately or heavily oiled, with oil more than two feet deep in some spots. They say observers flying over the sound still report 15 to 20 oil sheens bleeding off beaches daily. Exxon officials, meanwhile, say their winter monitoring of 64 sites shows wind and waves have scoured away, on average, more than half the surface oil left in September, and up to 80 percent of the buried oil. ``From a layman's point of view, what's left out there is really insignificant,'' said Exxon scientist Andy Teal.

DOC.HEAD: PERRY ISLAND: Andy Teal.
DOC.TEXT: Both the state and Exxon figures may be accurate, but even the best studies of the spill's effects are mere snapshots of a rugged, sparsely populated region the size of New Jersey, Maryland and Delaware combined. The Coast Guard has declared some sort of cleanup must resume May 1, but nobody has committed to how much or what kind. Decisions will be made after another survey of beach conditions next month. In general, exposed beaches eroded by winter storms appear to have fared the best, but surface oil remains thick in many sheltered coves and estuaries. Areas with oil hidden beneath the surface, such as the Perry Island beach Bridgman visited, may prove the most troublesome. State officials believe many of those beaches would benefit from intensive work, such as digging up gravel, tumbling it in rock-washing machines and replacing it. While that would kill nearly all living organisms, it would provide a clean slate for populations to rebuild, said Steve Provant, the Department of Environmental Conservation's spill coordinator. But Exxon officials say such intrusive techniques could do more harm than good. Some federal authorities are inclined to agree, recalling last summer's heavy-handed invasion of the Alaska wilderness. Frightened animals had to flee repeatedly from buzzing helicopters, and cleanup crews left behind tons of plastic boom material, absorbent pompons and other litter on previously pristine beaches. Even scientists made their mark, painting rocks with flourescent paint and tying orange plastic flagging to trees. ``You can see these things a mile away, and they're in areas where people otherwise would be having a quality wilderness experience,'' said Nancy Lethcoe, a sailboat-tour operator in Valdez. Lethcoe remembers a Prince William Sound where you could stand on a lonely beach and feel you were the first human ever there. It was a place where the world still felt big. Now the world seems suddenly smaller, civilization's reach extended by the greasy fingers of an oil spill. Lethcoe said she'll leave the blaming to the lawyers. When she goes out on the sound these days, she focuses on nature's recuperative powers. It works until she discovers that oil has found another of her favorite hideaways. ``When I know an area is oiled, I can brace myself,'' she said. ``But when I find an area that wasn't supposed to be oiled, it brings back the whole trauma of the spill. It brings back the pain.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: David Foster is the AP Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Citicorp Reorganizing Real Estate Division
DOC.TEXT: Citicorp said Friday it was reorganizing its commercial real estate division, a move analysts linked to a rise in bad loans because of a downturn in the market nationwide. Under the shift, Citicorp is expected to de-emphasize lending to large building projects and concentrate on real estate activities that generate fees for the bank, such as finding investors for projects. Citicorp, the nation's largest lender among commercial banks in the field, had $12.6 billion in domestic real estate loans at the end of 1989. Nonperforming loans totaled $1.16 billion, up from $548 million a year earlier. ``We've seen deterioration in real estate portfolios across the board for most large banks,'' said Richard Mueller, a banking analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. ``Citi may be looking at not building up the loans outstanding,'' he said. ``It doesn't make sense to (expand) a real estate loan portfolio if it's going to continue to demand capital and the returns may not be sufficient.'' The real estate industry in several regions of the country has weakened recently because of excess capacity following expansion in the early- and mid-1980s. Overbuilding was fueled by easy credit from banks and savings and loans and an assumption that the market would continue expanding. Analysts said that has led to a reduction of new construction to allow demand to catch up with expansion. Among the hardest hit banks has been the Bank of New England, an aggressive lender during the mid-1980s construction boom, which lost $1.1 billion in 1989, largely due to bad loans. Along with continuing problems in the Southwest tied to a recession there, the Northeast has the weakest commercial real estate market now, analysts said. Florida, Arizona and the mid-Atlantic region also have been softening. Citicorp said it ``remains committed to this business and we intend to grow and expand our franchise to deliver financial solutions to our clients.'' The bank suggested that increasing competition from abroad also played a role in the reorganization. Foreign banks involved in a rising level of cross-border real estate investments have pushed down profit margins on international and high-grade projects. Citicorp suffered a sharp rise in nonperforming loans, which are loans on which borrowers are not paying interest but have not yet defaulted, in the first six months of 1989. The bank has said it expects an increase in the nonperforming loans in 1990. According to published reports, the restructuring will create two new divisions, traditional real estate lending and fee-generating activities such as arranging sales, debt and equity for projects.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Plans Gentler Clean-up This Spring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details and quotes from Exxon news conference. No pickup. Also moving on general wires.
DOC.TEXT: When Exxon Corp. returns to the oiled beaches of Prince William Sound this summer, its cleanup will be smaller than last year's and use mostly low-impact techniques, company officials said Thursday. Lee Raymond, Exxon Corp. president, said at a news conference that winter storms had cleaned some of the gummy residue of the nation's worst oil spill, caused when the Exxon Valdez ran aground March 24 on a charted reef. But he said a tour of the beaches a week and a half ago showed him that much work remains to be done beyond the $2 billion the company reports it has already spent on the effort. Raymond declined to say how many people would join the clean-up effort. ``Significantly less than were involved last year,'' he said. ``We would hope we could get the job done this year. But that's based on information that won't be available until the end of April.'' David Kennedy, oil spill coordinator for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, said earlier this week that he expected the Exxon workforce to number in the hundreds, rather than approach the 10,000 hired last year. NOAA has suggested Exxon crews pick up tarballs and oiled debris by hand, break up asphalt and tar mats with shovels, and spray fertilizer over the contaminated sand and gravel to promote natural bacteria which eat oil. Only in extreme cases should heavy machinery be brought in, Kennedy said. Heavy machinery such as plows can be used to turn over gravel to expose it to oxygen and sunlight, helping the natural break-down of oil. NOAA and the state have recommended the extreme measure of digging up the sand, washing it and putting it back on beaches where people gather shellfish for food. The agencies say that the short-term damage would be overshadowed by the longterm gains. Otto Harrison, Exxon Alaska operations manager, said the company will use clean-up techniques this summer generally ``less intrusive on the environment'' than the hot water and steam-hose baths employed last year. They range from ``bioremediation'' _ using the oil-eating bacteria _ to simply removing the oiled sediment. ``To dig it up is the most intrusive thing you can do,'' Harrison said. ``We don't know if the benefits are worth it.'' A multi-agency group is to conduct a shoreline survey in April and turn in a work plan by May 1, Harrison said. Work will begin the first of May or as soon as weather permits, Harrison said. Exxon's plan must be approved by Coast Guard Adm. David Ciancaglini, the federal on-scene coordinator. Harrison said some sections of the shoreline most exposed to wind and wave action are 50 percent cleaner than they were when Exxon clean-up workers left the coast in September. ``The storms did a little better than we'd hoped,'' Harrison said. ``And we're not through the winter yet.'' The Exxon Valdez leaked nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into the clear waters of Prince William Sound, staining beaches, shutting down fishing seasons and killing countless birds and mammals. Exxon said more than 25 studies have been done over the winter, most of which show significant shoreline improvement, excellent water quality, no missing species and no stressed animals. ``Fin fish are safe for consumption. Generally, the same is true for shellfish except for those in the Windy Bay area,'' Harrison said. Responding to a reporter's question, the officials said they didn't plan to hire any ``rock polishers,'' as the company did last year. ``Wiping rocks with rags was never a primary technique,'' Harrison said. ``The material on the rocks this year is pretty heavy. Bioremediation and removal will be the primary tools.''

DOC.HEAD: Seagram Posts 22.9 Percent Quarterly Profit Increase
DOC.TEXT: The Seagram Co. Ltd., the distilled spirits, wine and soft drink giant, said Thursday its profit rose 22.9 percent in the fourth quarter and 20.5 percent for the year. Edgar Bronfman Jr., president and chief operating officer, said the results reflected marked increases in all beverage operations, full-year contributions from the Martell and Tropicana lines acquired in April 1988 and a strong performance from Seagram's 24 percent stake in DuPont Co. For the three months ended Jan. 31, the Montreal-based Seagram said it earned $146.2 million, or $1.53 a share, up from $119 million, or $1.21 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the fourth quarter rose 7.8 percent to $1.69 billion from $1.57 billion a year earlier. For the year, Seagram said it earned $710.6 million, or $7.37 a share, up from $589.5 million, or $6.12 a share, in the previous fiscal year. Annual revenue rose 10.4 percent to $5.58 billion from $5.06 billion a year earlier. Among Seagram's products are Chivas Regal and Glenlivet Scotch Whiskies, Crown Royal and Seagram's V.O. Canadian Whiskies, Seagram's Extra Dry Gin, Martell Cognac, Sterling Vineyards Wines, Seagram's Coolers, Tropicana Pure Premium Orange Juice and Soho Natural Sodas.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Government Wasted Money While Printing Money
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government spent more than $1 million too much on no-bid contracts to put the green and the black in the nation's greenbacks, according to a congressional report released Thursday. The General Accounting Office also said the head of the company that got a contract to supply ink for the nation's currency was a friend of the then-director of the head the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, the government's money-printer. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, described the contract as ``a highly questionable procurement.'' He said the government was offered a price for ink in 1988, when contracts became competitive, that was $1.3 million cheaper than the same supplier sold to the government on a non-competitive bases in 1986. The savings would have been higher still if the government had let potential ink suppliers compete for the contract from the start, he added. Beginning in 1982, the Bureau of Engraving and Printing stopped making its own black and green dollar-printing ink and began buying it from the U.S. subsidiary of a Swiss company, SICPA, S.A. In 1986 the contract was opened to competition and SICPA offered the highest of four bids, the report said. Complaints about ink fumes led the government to cancel two tests of the offered inks and throw out all the bids. SICPA continued as the government's single supplier and the contract process dragged on for another two years. Bids were solicited again in 1988 and SICPA reduced its price by 10 percent to submit the lowest bid. Other bidders increased their prices over the 1986 proposals, the report said. But even before the 1986 proposals, said the GAO _ the investigative arm of Congress _ SICPA President Maurice Amon and then-Bureau of Engraving and Printing Director Robert Leuver were apparently becoming friends. They took a 1985 trip to Brazil and traveled in 1986 to the Far East with U.S. Treasurer Katherine Ortega. The Brazil trip was billed as an inspection of an underground inkmoving system at a SICPA plant. But the plant had no underground inkmoving system, the report said. In 1987, according to the GAO, Leuver suggested another sole-source contract for SICPA and, triggering an internal confrontation with Ortega, Ortega's deputy and Peter Daly, then Leuver's deputy and now the bureau's director. ``Leuver was not involved in ink procurement matters'' after that and retired a year later, the report said. Although the government spends only about $11.2 million annually on ink for American money, said Glenn, the report highlights the need to ensure there are no personal relationships between agency chiefs and contractors. ``Procurement integrity is not some theoretical abstract,'' said Glenn, who heads the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, which is looking into government contracting. Daly did not immediately return a call seeking comment.

DOC.HEAD: Michigander Picked for S&L Post
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday he would appoint a Michigan real estate executive to the board overseeing his savings and loan bailout. Robert C. Larson, chief executive officer of the Taubman Company in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was named to one of two vacant seats on the five-member Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who heads the board, said he expects the White House to announce the fifth member next week. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and Housing Secretary Jack Kemp are also members. The board sets policy and controls the purse strings of the bailout agency created last August. Congressional Democrats have complained that Bush waited until after most of the bailout policies were in place before naming the public members of the board, who were supposed to balance the influence of the government officials. Brady said the appointments were slow because the administration sought people experienced in real estate disposal. That complicated clearance checks for possible conflicts of interest, he said. ``We've done the right thing and gotten people who really know what they're doing, instead of just a name,'' he said. On another matter, the oversight board voted unanimously to clear the way for state housing agencies to provide low-cost mortgages to low-income and moderate-income people who purchase homes from the corporation. The agency plans to offer about 10,000 properties to low-income people, of which 5,174 are in Texas, 968 in Oklahoma and 881 in Louisiana. The Texas Housing Agency has offered to reserve up to $140 million in low-cost mortgages to speed the purchase of homes there.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee Futures Plummet On Brazilian Economic Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Coffee futures prices fell sharply Friday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange after Brazil's new president announced sweeping economic reforms that were seen as likely to spur sales of Brazilian coffee. The Brazilian economic package also was linked to a decline in soybean futures prices and to a sharp rise in sugar futures, although analysts conceded the measures were difficult to interpret. On other commodity markets, grain futures rose; oil futures were mostly lower; precious metals advanced and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher. Coffee futures settled 5 cents to 6 cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at 89.50 cents a pound. The economic reforms outlined Friday by President Fernando Collor de Mello included abolishment of the Brazilian Coffee Institute, introduction of a new currency with free-floating foreign exchange rates and limits on bank withdrawals, all of which were seen as encouraging Brazilian producers and exporters to pour more coffee onto the world market. Brazil, the largest coffee producer, has been withholding coffee from the market, which recently helped to boost coffee futures prices to their highest levels in eight months. Analysts said the Brazilian Coffee Institute, which administers the government's export and internal marketing policies, is known to be holding a large quantity of low-quality coffee, possibly as many as 17 million 132-pound bags. By dissolving the institute as a cost-cutting measure, the government could force the agency to sell that coffee sooner that it would have otherwise, although the beans would probably go for internal consumption rather than export, said analyst Celeste Georkakis of Cargill Investor Services Inc. A free-floating Brazilian currency could encourage Brazilian exporters to offer more coffee on the world market, analysts said. They said limits on bank withdrawals might prompt producers and exporters to sell coffee at lower prices as a way of raising cash. Analyst Arthur Stevenson of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said that increased coffee sales was only one possible interpretation of the Brazilian reform package. He said the selloff in coffee futures also reflected disappointment about what Collor de Mello did not say. ``The market was perhaps looking for a very constructive statement from the new Brazilian government and that statement was not forthcoming,'' Stevenson said. Concerns about the new Brazilian currency also prompted selling of soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade. Brazil is the second-largest producer of soybeans after the United States. Soybeans settled 4{ cents lower to 1 cent higher with March at $5.81} a bushel; wheat futures were 1{ cents lower to 5 cents higher with March at $3.89{ a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1{ cents higher with March at $2.47} a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2 cents higher with March at $1.46 a bushel. Sugar futures surged in New York on the Brazilian news amid expectations that the government would curtail sugar exports and divert more of Brazil's sugar cane to the country's extensive fuel alcohol program. Sugar futures settled .19 cent to .39 cent higher with May at 16.13 cents a pound. Petroleum futures finished mostly lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid profit-taking. Many traders refrained from buying or selling while the monitoring committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries met in Brussels, Belgium. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 31 cents lower to 1 cent higher with April at $20.07 a barrel; heating oil was .52 cent to .84 cent lower with April at 54.46 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .40 cent to 1.37 cents lower with April at 56.96 cents a gallon. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures ended $1.20 to $1.40 higher with April at $400.90 a troy ounce; silver was 1.2 cents to 1.4 cents higher with March at $5.093 a troy ounce. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of the Agriculture Department's monthly cattle-on-feed report. The report, which was released after the close, showed 5 percent more cattle on feedlots as of March 1 than on the same date a year ago. The figure was close to market expectations and was expected to have little impact on futures prices. Live cattle futures settled unchanged to .23 cent higher with April at 77.47 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .18 cent lower to .13 cent higher with March at 82.72 cents a pound; hog futures were unchanged to .72 cent higher with April at 53.42 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .20 cent lower to .70 cent higher with March at 50.55 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices End Mostly Lower
DOC.TEXT: Petroleum futures prices finished mostly lower in moderate trading Friday, reflecting seasonal demand weakness. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the April contract for West Texas Intermediate, which rose 33 cents in Thursday's session, fell 31 cents a barrel to $20.07. WTI is the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil. All other crude oil contracts for 1990 delivery also ended lower, while 1991 futures finished slightly higher. Among refined products, the April contract for unleaded gasoline dropped 0.98 cent to 56.96 cents a gallon. May gasoline fell 1.37 cents to 61.57 cents and June lost 0.88 cent to 61.77 cents a gallon. No. 2 heating oil for April delivery fell 0.52 cent to 54.46 cents a gallon, May lost 0.54 cent to 52.89 cents and June dropped to 52.32 cents, down 0.63 cent. Analysts said demand for crude oil has weakened in recent weeks due mainly to seasonal factors including warmer weather nationwide and spring maintenance when refineries use less crude oil to make gasoline and other products. ``As of last week, the 13-week average demand was down 1 percent from the same period last year,'' said Peter Beutel, energy analyst with Elders Futures Inc. Slower demand has resulted in a sharp buildup in crude oil inventories in the nation's storage tanks. Supplies are running approximately 5.6 percent higher than last year, according to statistics released this week. ``We will see demand pick up later this year but for now there's plenty of oil out there,'' Beutel said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
Eds: Restores dropped `481 unchanged' in 4th graf
DOC.TEXT: The stock market climbed sharply to a two-month high Friday, turning the quarterly ``triple witching hour'' to its favor in a busy session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 45.50 to 2,741.22, its highest close since it stood at 2,760.67 on Jan. 11. The average's gain for the week amounted to 57.89 points, on top of a 119-point rise over the two previous weeks. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 3 to 2 in the daily tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 884 up, 591 down and 481 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 222.52 million shares, up from 144.41 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 256.66 million shares. Blue chip stocks attracted buy orders at the witching hour, marking the last trading in a set of options and futures on stock indexes used by professionals in computerized index arbitrage. Reports from the trading floor of the NYSE showed imbalances toward the buy side on numerous big-name stocks at the opening of trading and again in the last half hour. The market's response was less clear, however, to word that the producer price of finished goods was unchanged in February after climbing 1.8 percent the month before. The apparent dropoff in inflationary pressures, which had been widely forecast, was attributed primarily to a decline in energy prices. Brokers said the data, excluding often-volatile food and energy prices, still suggested a worrisome degree of underlying inflation. Norton Co., subject of a $75-a-share bid by BTR PLC, shot up 16| to 74~ in heavy trading. Gainers among the blue chips included Exxon, up | at 47{; Philip Morris, up | at 38|; American Telephone & Telegraph, up } at 41~; DuPont, up { at 39], and International Business Machines, up 1| at 108|. An exception was Federal National Mortgage, down \ at 35~. Company data showed a flat showing in February for one basic measure of its profitability. Apple Computer jumped 3{ to 40\ as one of the volume leaders in the over-the-counter market. Late Thursday the company said its sales and earnings for the quarter that ends March 30 will be stronger than expected. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $29.19 billion, or 0.89 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.72 to 187.92. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 5.16 to 396.40, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 3.84 at 341.91. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 4.10 to 442.16. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 364.18, up 1.91.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Rise Strongly
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices shot up Friday as traders detected weakness in the nation's manufacturing sector and signs that the economy remains sluggish and inflation in check. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond climbed 13-16 point, or $8.13 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, fell to about 8.54 percent from 8.61 percent late Thursday. The government released three reports on February economic statistics. But analysts said figures showing of no change in wholesale prices and a 7 percent decline in housing starts during the month had little effect because of the influence of unseasonable weather. Instead, bond prices climbed after the Federal Reserve said industrial production rose 0.6 percent, less than economists had anticipated and largely due to a return of automobile workers after January slowdowns. ``The factory sector of the economy remains weak,'' said Steven A. Wood, economist with BankAmerica Capital Markets in San Francisco. Analysts had expected an increase in industrial production of 0.8 percent to 0.9 percent, Wood said, so the lower figure was interpreted as a further sign of weakness. Factoring in resurgent auto production, the signs were even weaker, he said. ``What you had in the markets was expectations for worse news on the price front and the economic front,'' which strengthened the credit market, said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, president of Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc. The industrial production report was good for the bond market because a slowdown in such economic indicators dampens the likelihood the Fed will think it necessary to raise interest rates in order to curb inflation. Higher interest rates lower the value of existing bonds. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index showed no change following a huge 1.8 percent jump in January attributed to a holiday cold snap. Mild weather in February kept energy prices down. Economists said inflation, which erodes the value of bonds, still was on a 4 percent to 4.5 percent annual course. Also, housing starts returned to a more normal pace in February, declining 7.0 percent following a steep jump during January's record warm weather. Analysts said both reports virtually were ignored by bond traders as they were in line with expectations. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments gained [ point to \ point, intermediate maturities were up 11-32 point to { point and long-term issues shot up 23-32 point to 13-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, climbed 4.25 to 1,151.81. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 8.15 percent as the discount was down 2 basis points to 7.90 percent. Yields on six-month bills dropped to 8.26 percent as the discount was 2 basis points lower at 7.85 percent. Yields on one-year bills were off sharply at 8.34 percent as the discount lost 5 basis points to 7.75 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, down from 8\ percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 91 15-32, up 3-32 point. The average yield to maturity was 7.49 percent, compared with 7.48 percent late Thursday. The Bond Buyer changed the mix of bonds in the index on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Ministers Open Talks on Oil Market
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES with 3 new grafs after 2nd graf pvs, `OPEC Secretary-General ...'; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `In advance ...
DOC.TEXT: OPEC oil ministers met Friday evening to review the group's pricing and production strategy and decide whether to change it in the coming months. The meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' special monitoring panel got under way amid widespread speculation that the cartel was unlikely to rein in current production anytime soon despite slackening demand and softer world oil prices. OPEC Secretary-General Subroto said demand for the group's oil is expected to fall to 20.8 million barrels a day in coming months, far below the 23.7 million barrels the cartel is estimated to be pumping. The ministers met for about 90 minutes in formal session then adjourned. The committee was expected to hold informal discussions in their hotel rooms on Saturday. No date was set for a final session but many doubt the discussions will continue beyond the weekend. In advance of the session, some ministers expressed concern that quota-cheating by various OPEC members, which has swelled the cartel's production well above its target, could dampen prices further. Prices have been slipping since early January, and are expected to weaken further in the traditionally weak second quarter when seasonal factors and annual refinery maintenance reduces demand for crude oil. ``Those countries that overproduce, I think, they have some explanations. Surely they have some reasons behind it,'' said Ginandjar Kartasasmita, oil minister of Indonesia. ``We would like to hear it,'' he said. Kuwaiti Oil Minister Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, reflecting the unease about the upcoming quarter, said, ``It has three months _ April, May and June. I wish it had two.'' The opening of the committee meeting was delayed several hours to give the ministers time to huddle privately in their suites at a luxury hotel not far from OPEC headquarters. Several ministers said no changes would be made in the cartel's production and pricing guidelines for the first half of the year. ``We are not suppose to take any decisions,'' said Ginandjar. Nigerian Oil Minister Jibril Aminu said the purpose of the meeting is to monitor production and quotas. ``What decision is taken depends on the data available to us,'' he said. Some were clearly worried by the cheating of such countries as Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. Mana Saeed Otaiba, the Emirates' oil minister, told reporters he would like to see both higher production and higher prices but acknowledged, ``That is impossible.'' When pressed to make a choice, he said, ``We'd rather increase production until everybody is satisfied.'' Industry analysts put OPEC's output at well over 23 million barrels a day. Its supply ceiling for the January-June period is a bit more than 22 million barrels a day, compared with 20.5 million barrels in the last quarter of 1989. Until recently, demand in the United States and other consuming nations has dried up the excess supply, keeping prices above the cartel's benchmark of $18 a barrel. But some worry that continued high production will lead to weaker prices in the April-June quarter when demand tends to shrink with warming weather. ``(Overproduction) is a concern to us,'' said Ginandjar. Algerian Oil Minister Sadek Boussena, upon arrival late Thursday, said, ``We knew from the beginning the second quarter will be difficult.'' Iraq's minister, Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi, said demand ``will go down'' in the April-June quarter _ ``that's for sure.'' He predicted it would run between 21 million to 22 million barrels a day. In order to keep prices up, he said, ``we will ask everybody to adhere to the quota, and I think this will be met.'' ``Prices are ... not as firm as they used to be a few weeks ago. ... So maybe they (the overproducers) will think twice (about raising output),'' he said. The average price of a basket of seven crudes monitored by OPEC was $18.36 a barrel in the first week of March. It hit $20.56 a barrel in the first week of January. West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark American crude, has been trading in the range of $20 to $21 a barrel. In advance of the committee meeting, Chalabi reportedly pressed _ although unsuccessfully _ for a 10 percent increase in the $18 reference price. His suggestion _ like that of Kuwait's Ali Khalifa al-Sabah to scrap the quota system _ will likely get an airing at the committee meeting. The talks are designed to lay the groundwork for a decision-making conference in May. Sabah has said the quota system should be shelved because it is unrealistic and often ignored. The cartel sets an overall output ceiling and then gives each country a quota for its production. Without a quota, each member could produce freely. But some of the countries now are producing at their limits and could not go any higher. OPEC members are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: To Plead Guilty in Florida Home-Buying Scam
DOC.TEXT: General Development Corp. has agreed to plead guilty to a felony charge and pay up to $500,000 in fines to settle charges it schemed to inflate home prices at its nine Florida developments, prosecutors said Friday. A 16-count indictment said thousands of home buyers lured by slick sales pitches and Florida sunshine fell prey to an elaborate scheme in which General Development allegedly made $850 million on more than 11,000 overpriced homes. The indictment said the homes were sold mostly to Midwest and Northeast residents, many of them recent emigrants brought to Florida on sales junkets and blocked from learning the facts about the state housing market. Many of the homes sold by General Development in nine communities between 1982 and 1989 were at least 20 percent overvalued compared to similar Florida homes, and at least one was listed for more than twice its estimated worth, officials said. ``People's lives were devastated. ... They were stuck with mortgage payments and homes valued far under what they paid,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Norman Moscowitz, who led the two-year investigation. Federal prosecutors said General Development agreed to plead guilty to one count of mail fraud and pay the fine as part of a consent decree that must receive court approval. Also, the homebuilder agreed to reorganize top management and set up a court-monitored restitution fund that could exceed $100 million during the next 25 years. Two former General Development executives named in the fraud indictment are considering a plea agreement that would call for some jail time, but the details have not been finalized, U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said. Former chairman David Brown and former president Robert Ehrling were making $600,000 a year each before being forced out by General Development directors March 9. They could not be reached for comment Friday. Meanwhile, the New York investment firm United Capital Corp., which owns 12.7 percent of General Development, announced it plans to nominate six candidates to the company's board at elections in May. General Development, which also faces several class-action suits, has restructured its home-sale policies and plans to remain in business, said Charles Simons, president and chief executive officer. ``It is clear that our house prices had gotten out of line with our competition and that some customers were disadvantaged,'' he said. General Development, whose nationwide real estate holdings equal nearly half the size of Rhode Island, this month has laid off about 5,500 workers, about 10 percent of its work force, and shut down sales offices in Hollywood, Fla., and Boston. In addition to 350,000 lots in the nine Florida developments, General Development operates a time-share resort near Disney World, a recreational community in Tennessee and 10 time-share resorts in the West. Through dozens of northern sales offices and seminars, General Development pitched vacant lots or built homes. Only other General Development homes were used in appraisals to back up company statements on the value of the properties, the indictment alleged. Many customers took advantage of three-day ``Southward Ho!'' subsidized trips to Florida. But General Development kept potential buyers from learning about prices in other developments by assigning a sales representative to track customers constantly and screen telephone calls their hotel rooms, the indictment alleged. Those agreeing to buy a house were told to seek a mortgage at GDV Financial Corp., a General Development subsidiary also named in the indictment. General Development sales officials told buyers that only cash and GDV mortgages were accepted as part of the company's ``one-stop shopping.'' Chase Federal Savings and Loan and California Federal Savings and Loan, two major purchasers of GDV mortgages, stopped investing after learning of the overvalued homes. Since 1988, GDV sold $70 million in mortgages to the public through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and PaineWebber Inc. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. also stopped buying GDV mortgages in 1985 because of the company's appraisal policies.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel To Provide More Information on Bonuses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 11th graf pvs, `Also Friday... to UPDATE with judge resolving asset sale dispute; PICKS UP penultimate graf, `Drexel, once... ^By STEFAN FATSIS
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Friday ordered Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. to give creditors more information about $260 million in bonuses paid before the firm filed for bankruptcy protection. Lawyers for Drexel agreed to provide detailed information about the firm's 1989 compensation and bonus payments over the weekend to attorneys and accountants for the official committee of unsecured creditors. Drexel also said it would turn over transcripts of depositions of Drexel executives taken by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is investigating the bonus payments. Creditors have questioned the timing of the bonus payments of $196 million in cash and $64 million in securities to Drexel exceutives in the months prior to the firm's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing on Feb. 13. SEC Chairman Richard Breeden told Congress on March 2 the commission was investigating whether there was any was wrongdoing in the bonus payments, which Drexel said were made in December and January. Under federal law, creditors can seek to recover payments made to company insiders up to one year before a bankruptcy filing. Creditors routinely seek a wide range of information about a company's financial condition leading up to a filing. After Drexel creditors attorney Marc Kirscher said the company was trying to impede a study of the firm's financial condition before the Chapter 11 filing, Drexel agreed to turn over copies of financial statements and auditors' reports for 1988. A Drexel spokesman said 1989 reports were not yet completed. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard C. Buschman III said if the creditors committee was not satisfied with information provided by Drexel it could raise complaints at a hearing Monday. Drexel had asked that the information about the payments remain confidential, but Buschman said it would become public in court or through the SEC. The bonus payments were made by Drexel's securities subsidiary, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which is not part of the bankruptcy case. But creditors can seek information about the payments because they relate to the financial status of the parent firm. Also Friday, Drexel also disclosed in court that it hoped to sell its $65 million investment in Paramount Petroleum Corp. for $9.5 million. Drexel owns 53 percent of the company, which is in bankruptcy proceedings. Buschman also resolved the first challenge by creditors to a planned asset sale when he allowed Drexel to accept an offer for nearly $10 million for $14.1 million in high-yield notes issued by Petco, a California pet supply company. Drexel underwrote the 15.5 percent notes due in March 1991 in a private placement. Creditors had wanted to Drexel to consider other bids to try to get a higher price. Drexel, once one of the most powerful firms on Wall Street, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after defaulting on short-term debt and failing to raise new bank credit. Under an agreement between the company and creditors, three Drexel board members are supervising the firm's liquidation with input from creditors.

British industrial conglomerate BTR PLC offered $1.64 billion to acquire Norton Co., the Worchester-based abrasives manufacturer, in an unsolicited tender offer that sent Norton shares skyrocketing. London-based BTR, which has international operations ranging from building materials to sporting goods, offered $75 a share on Friday through a U.S. subsidiary, ER Holdings Inc. Norton stock soared $16.62{ to $74.87{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange. The company said its board was reviewing the offer and would inform shareholders of its position on the bid by March 29.

U.S. industrial output rose 0.6 percent in February, the government reported, but the rise reflected a resumption of automobile production and practically no strengthening elsewhere. Thousands of autoworkers, who were laid off in January as manufacturers trimmed bloated inventories, returned to production lines in February and contributed nearly all of the increase in industrial output, the Federal Reserve reported Friday.

Topsy-turvy weather is sending wholesale inflation on a roller-coaster ride so far this year, with prices unchanged in February after a steep increase a month earlier. A sharp drop in energy prices offset increases for other items and held the Labor Department's Producer Price Index steady overall last month, the government said Friday. In another report, housing starts fell 7 percent in February but remained well above the level of the last 11 months of 1989. Analysts said the building pace could not be maintained.

Citicorp said it was reorganizing its commercial real estate division, a move analysts linked to a rise in bad loans because of a downturn in the market nationwide. Under the shift announced Friday, Citicorp is expected to de-emphasize lending to large building projects and concentrate on real estate activities that generate fees for the bank, such as finding investors for projects.

A federal judge ordered Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. to give creditors more information about $260 million in bonuses paid before the firm filed for bankruptcy protection. Lawyers for Drexel agreed Friday to provide details about the firm's 1989 compensation and bonus payments over the weekend to attorneys and accountants for the official committee of unsecured creditors. Creditors have questioned the timing of the payment of $196 million in cash and $64 million in securities to Drexel exceutives in the months prior to the firm's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing Feb. 13.

President Fernando Collor de Mello implemented a sweeping emergency package of economic reforms that include a price freeze, a new national currency, and jail terms for ``economic crimes.'' Collor de Mello announced his plans Friday, one day after taking office as Brazil's first popularly elected leader in 29 years. Brazil has the developing world's largest foreign debt, $114 billion. Inflation is 2,700 percent, and the budget deficit is $31 billion. Millions of people live on the street or in shantytowns.

The National Broadcasting Co. said it had agreed to sell a majority interest in its Cleveland television station WKYC-TV to Multimedia Inc., which would be making its first major purchase since undertaking a $1.1 billion recapitalization in 1985. Terms of the sale and the size of the stake being sold were not disclosed in Friday's announcement. The deal could free NBC to buy another TV station in a larger market and still comply with federal regulations on station ownership.

General Development Corp. has agreed to plead guilty to a felony charge and pay up to $500,000 in fines to settle charges it schemed to inflate home prices at its nine Florida developments. A 16-count federal indictment released Friday said thousands of home buyers lured by slick sales pitches and Florida sunshine fell prey to an elaborate scheme in which General Development allegedly made $850 million on more than 11,000 overpriced homes.

The Federal Trade Commission announced an investigation into the environmental claims of products ranging from trash bags to hairspray, saying it will vigorously pursue deceptive advertising and packaging. Commission Chairwoman Janet Steiger said Friday the FTC staff would join various state officials and a number of companies ``to substantiate ... environmental claims'' in advertising and packaging. No specific companies were targeted.

The stock market climbed sharply to a two-month high Friday, turning the quarterly ``triple witching hour'' to its favor in a busy session. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 45.50 to 2,741.22, its highest close since Jan. 11. The dollar declined against most major foreign currencies. Bond prices rose sharply. Coffee futures prices tumbled; grain futures rose; oil futures were mostly lower; precious metals advanced and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Zenith: Groupe Bull Owes an Additional $49.5 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, `Zenith is... to UPDATE with Groupe Bull response; PICKS UP 5th graf pvs, `On Friday,...
DOC.TEXT: Zenith Electronics Corp. said Friday it had determined that Groupe Bull owes the company an additional $49.5 million for Zenith's computer products business. The announcement is the latest development in a disagreement that began last month over the French company's acquisition of Zenith Data Systems. No one was immediately available for comment at Groupe Bull's U.S. offices in Billerica, Mass., a woman in the company's public relations office said. Zenith is disputing Bull's request for a $49 million refund on its Dec. 28 payment of $496.4 million for Zenith Data Systems. A Groupe Bull spokesman at the company's U.S. office in Billerica, Mass., took issue with Zenith's claim. ``The price was based on net book value, and that's something that's subject to business judgment,'' said the spokesman, who asked not to be named. ``Right now Zenith Electronics and Bull are proceding through the stipulated process ...,'' the spokesman said. ``It's a negotiating process.'' On Friday, Zenith said it expected a further payment of $49.5 million as the final adjustment to the purchase price. ``Based on extensive reviews to date by its staff and outside auditors, Zenith Electronics Corp. concluded today that Groupe Bull owes an additional $49.5 million for Zenith's computer products business,'' Zenith said in a statement. Zenith said that if in 30 days it is still in disagreement with Groupe Bull over the sale price, the matter would be referred to an arbitrating accounting firm. On another matter, Zenith said Thursday its development of high-definition television will lower its profits for the next few years. The project, undertaken in partnership with American Telephone & Telegraph Co., will cost Zenith $10 million this year, president and chairman Jerry K. Pearlman said.
